<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="index">Index<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#index" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>341</p>
<p>vii</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="introduction">Introduction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#introduction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The second edition of the <em>Fundamentals of Nursing: Clinical Skills Workbook</em> has been published with the aim of building on the already-established and trusted relationship between nursing students and Potter and Perryâ€™s <em>Fundamentals of Nursing</em>. Written to align with the fourth edition of <em>Fundamentals of Nursing</em>, nursing students and lecturers familiar with the Nursing Skills format in the textbook will benefit from this separate, lightweight workbook, which enables students to easily transport the skills content to lectures, labs and clinical practice. Additionally, the workbook provides students with a clear and accessible personal record of achievement and allows an opportunity for reflection to encourage meaningful learning.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="new-features">New features<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#new-features" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The checklists in this edition of the workbook have been revised to align with the updated skills in the fourth edition of Potter and Perryâ€™s <em>Fundamentals of Nursing</em>. Twelve new skills and checklists have been included covering the following areas: health assessment and physical examination; vital signs; skin integrity and wound care; fluid, electrolyte and acidâ€“base balance; and pain management.</p>
<p>Also new to the second edition is the inclusion of the New Zealand competencies for Registered Nurses, to sit alongside the Australian competencies. The complete lists of New Zealand and Australian competencies are included at the end of this book, and the criteria all students will be working to are referred to under â€˜Domainsâ€™ and â€˜Performance Criteriaâ€™ within each checklist.</p>
<p>The simple structure of the workbook allows students to work through and master the skills necessary to become a competent, qualified nurse.</p>
<p>A concise overview precedes each skill set, providing a valuable introduction and an understanding of the clinical context. Each skill from Potter and Perryâ€™s <em>Fundamentals of Nursing</em> features the favoured step-by-step approach and rationales to help students understand how and why a skill is performed.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="skills">Skills<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#skills" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The skills encompass the following:</p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Delegation considerations</strong> guide students in delegating tasks to Assistants in Nursing and Enrolled Nurses</li>
<li><strong>Equipment</strong> lists the essential tools required to carry out a skill</li>
<li><strong>Critical decision points</strong> alert students to the critical steps within a skill to ensure safe and effective client care</li>
<li><strong>Steps</strong> in concise, easy-to-understand language outline each action that needs to be undertaken to complete the skill</li>
<li><strong>Rationale</strong> provides the student with the logic behind each step</li>
<li><strong>Recording and reporting</strong> provides guidelines for what to document and report</li>
<li><strong>Home care considerations</strong> explain how to adapt skills for the home setting.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="checklists">Checklists<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#checklists" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The clinical skill checklists that follow the skills allow students to track their skill development progress, as well as providing assessors with a clear competency assessment tool.</p>
<p>Each checklist includes the following:</p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Performance criteria</strong> list the Australian and New Zealand national competency standards for Registered Nurses aligned to the skill</li>
<li><strong>Competency criteria</strong> indicate the imperative steps that students must include while carrying out the skill</li>
<li><strong>Performance criteria/Evidence</strong> lists the specific steps required to successfully complete that particular skill</li>
<li><strong>The five-point Bondy Rating Scale</strong> provides the backbone of the checklist to clearly indicate the level of competence achieved; the five variants upon which students are graded are: Independent, Supervised, Assisted, Marginal and Dependent</li>
<li><strong>Reflection</strong> provides room for students to detail their experience, whether they master the skill on the first attempt or wish to record notes to assist in a future attempt</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="videos">Videos<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#videos" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A suite of Clinical Nursing Skills Videos is available online for use with the workbook. Produced in association with Edith Cowan University, the videos are ideal for viewing in class or as a valuable tool for revision prior to assessment.</p>
<p>viii</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-five-point-bondy-rating-scale">The five-point Bondy Rating Scale<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-five-point-bondy-rating-scale" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The five-point Bondy Rating Scale is a useful tool used to assess professional competency and, subsequently, the amount of supervision needed to successfully master the nursing skills included in this workbook. The scale is also a useful indicator of students' ability to carry out these skills with accuracy, safety and satisfactory effect.</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="acknowledgements">Acknowledgements<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#acknowledgements" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>In this edition of the <em>Fundamentals of Nursing: Clinical Skills Workbook</em>, as nurse academics, we have been indulged by our inclusion in establishing a well-developed base for the building of nursing knowledge and skills for nurses. We have been very lucky to have worked with a group of extremely talented people to do this. We would like to acknowledge and thank the peer reviewers for their thoughtful and helpful critique in the development of this skills workbook. And a huge thank you to Libby Houston, our publisher, and Elizabeth Coady, our developmental editor, for their invaluable support and encouragement.</p>
<p>Finally, we acknowledge you, the reader, and dedicate this edition to those of you studying to become a Registered Nurse. We wish you all the very best with your studies and transition towards becoming a practising Registered Nurse.</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="reviewers">Reviewers<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reviewers" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="safety-overview">Safety Overview<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#safety-overview" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Safety, often defined as freedom from psychological and physical injury, is a basic human need that must be met. Healthcare provided in a safe manner and a safe environment is essential for a patient's survival and wellbeing. The nurse incorporates critical thinking skills when using the nursing process, and is responsible for assessing the patient and the environment for hazards that threaten safety, as well as planning and intervening appropriately to maintain a safe environment. By doing this, the nurse is not only a provider of safe acute, restorative and continuing care, but also an active participant in health promotion. These principles are particularly important when performing the skills presented in this chapterâ€”applying restraints and seizure precautionsâ€”given the inherent risk of injury to both patients and healthcare workers in carrying out these skills.</p>
<p>The nurse integrates knowledge from nursing and other scientific disciplines, previous experience in caring for patients who had an injury or were at risk, critical thinking attitudes such as perseverance and any standards of practice that are applicable. For example, the Australian Nursing and Midwifery Accreditation Council National Competency Standards for the Registered Nurse (2006) discuss the nurse's responsibility in maintaining patient safety. The Australian Council on Healthcare Standards also provides standards for safety (e.g. in the administration of medications, use of restraints and use of medical devices). All this information and experience is referred to by nurses as they conduct a detailed assessment of a specific patient.</p>
<p>A physical restraint is a device used to immobilise a patient or an extremity and to restrict the freedom of movement of, or normal access to, a person's body. Restraints were commonly used in the past to limit the activities of patients who were confused, combative or at high risk of falling when unattended. Restraints include both physical and chemical means of controlling a person's behaviour and come with inherent risksâ€”hence correct use is paramount for patient and staff safety.</p>
<p>Special precautions are necessary to prevent injury in patients susceptible to seizures, encompassing all nursing interventions to protect the patient from traumatic injury, positioning for adequate ventilation and drainage of oral secretions, and providing privacy and support following the seizure.</p>
<p>This chapter explores the psychomotor skills that focus on creating a safe clinical environment for the client. The skills addressed include applying restraints (15-1) and seizure precautions (15-2).</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260125-e6e70a1d.jpeg" alt="img-2.jpeg"></p>
<p>2 FUNDAMENTALS OF NURSING: CLINICAL SKILLS WORKBOOK</p>
<p>SKILL 15-1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="applying-restraints">Applying restraints<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#applying-restraints" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="delegation-considerations">DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delegation-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Use of restraints is an intervention with elements that can be delegated and elements that cannot be delegated.</p>
<p>Elements that cannot be delegated because they require the problem-solving and knowledge-application abilities of professional nurses include the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>assessment of safety needs</li>
<li>selection of appropriate interventions</li>
<li>evaluation of effectiveness of restraint</li>
<li>ongoing assessment to prevent complications of restraint use.</li>
</ul>
<p>Elements that can be delegated to nurse assistants include the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>Instruct care provider to inform the nurse if any skin excoriation is present under or around restraint location.</li>
<li>Instruct care provider in proper way to remove and reapply restraint to provide skin care and allow supervised movement.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Proper restraint</li>
<li>Padding</li>
</ul>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>1. Assess whether patient needs a restraint.</td><td>Restraints are used when other measures have failed to prevent interruption of therapy such as traction, IV infusions or nasogastric tube feedings; to prevent a confused or combative patient from self-injury by falling out of bed or a wheelchair; to prevent a patient from removing a Foley catheter, surgical drain or life support equipment; and to reduce risk of injury to others by the patient.</td></tr><tr><td>2. Review agency policies regarding restraints. Check doctor's order for purpose of restraint and type and duration of restraint.</td><td>A doctor's order is necessary to apply restraints and should be renewed every 24 hours. The least restrictive type of restraint should be ordered. Because restraints limit the patient's ability to move freely, the nurse must make clinical judgments appropriate to the patient's condition and agency policy. If the nurse restrains a patient in an emergency situation, a doctor's order should be obtained as soon as possible.</td></tr><tr><td>Critical decision point: Jacket or vest restraints are not covered in this textâ€”many healthcare agencies prohibit their use because of their association with fatal injuries.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>3. Review manufacturer's instructions before entering patient's room.</td><td>The nurse should be familiar with all devices used for patient care and protection. Incorrect application of a restraining device may result in patient injury or death.</td></tr><tr><td>4. Inspect area where restraint is to be placed. Assess condition of skin underlying area on which restraint is to be applied.</td><td>Restraints may compress and interfere with functioning of devices or tubes. Provides baseline assessment data regarding skin integrity. Provides nursing personnel with an objective measure for subsequent skin assessment.</td></tr><tr><td>5. Explain to patient and family the need for the restraint, and try to obtain consent.</td><td>Helps minimise patient anxiety during application of the device and helps minimise family concern during maintenance of restraint.</td></tr><tr><td>6. Place patient in proper body alignment.</td><td>Proper body alignment should be maintained to prevent contractures and neurovascular injury.</td></tr><tr><td>7. Pad skin and bony prominences before applying restraints.</td><td>Padding reduces friction and pressure to skin and underlying tissue.</td></tr><tr><td>8. Apply appropriate restraint, making sure it is not over an IV line or other device (e.g. dialysis shunt).</td><td>IV lines and other therapeutic devices may become occluded.</td></tr><tr><td>A. Belt restraint: Device that secures patient to bed or stretcher. Avoid placing belt too tightly across patient's chest or abdomen (see illustration).</td><td>Restraints centre of gravity and prevents patient from rolling off stretcher or sitting up while on stretcher or from falling out of bed. Tight application may interfere with ventilation.</td></tr><tr><td>B. Extremity (ankle or wrist) restraint: Restraint designed to immobilise one or all extremities. Commercially available limb restraints are composed of sheepskin with foam padding (see illustration).</td><td>Maintains immobilisation of extremity to protect patient from injury from fall or accidental removal of therapeutic device (e.g. IV tube or Foley catheter).</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>SAFETY 3</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>C. Mitten restraint: Thumbless mitten device to restrain patient's hands (see illustration).</td><td>Prevents patients from dislodging invasive equipment, removing dressings or scratching, yet allows greater movement than a wrist restraint.</td></tr><tr><td>D. Elbow restraint: Piece of fabric with slots in which tongue blades are placed so that elbow joint remains rigid (see illustration).</td><td>Used with infants and children to prevent elbow flexion (e.g. when an IV line is in place).</td></tr><tr><td>E. Mummy restraint: Blanket or sheet that is opened on bed or cot with one corner folded towards centre. Child is placed on blanket with shoulders at fold and with feet towards opposite corner (see illustration, 1). With child's right arm straight down or secured against body, right side of blanket is pulled firmly across right shoulder and chest and secured beneath left side of body (see illustration, 2). Left arm is placed straight against body or secured, and left side of blanket is brought across shoulder and chest and locked beneath child's body on right side (see illustration, 3). Lower corner is folded and brought over body and tucked or fastened securely with safety pins (see illustration, 4).</td><td>Maintains short-term restraint of small child or infant for examination or treatment involving head and neck. Effectively controls movement of torso and extremities.</td></tr><tr><td>9. Secure restraints with a quick-release tie (see illustration).</td><td>Allows for quick release in an emergency.</td></tr><tr><td>10. Attach restraints to bed frame, which moves when the head of bed is raised or lowered (see illustration).</td><td>Patient may be injured if restraint is secured to side rail and it is lowered.</td></tr><tr><td>Critical decision point: Do not attach to side rails.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>11. Insert two fingers under the secured restraint (see illustration for Step 8B).</td><td>A tight restraint may cause constriction and impede circulation. Checking for constriction prevents neurovascular injury.</td></tr><tr><td>12. Every 30 minutes, proper placement of restraint and skin integrity, pulses, temperature, colour and sensation of restrained body part should be assessed.</td><td>Frequent assessment prevents complications, such as suffocation, skin breakdown and impaired circulation.</td></tr><tr><td>13. Restraints should be removed for 30 minutes every 2 hours. If patient is violent and non-compliant, remove one restraint at a time and/or have staff assistance while removing restraints. Patient should not be left unattended at this time.</td><td>Provides opportunity to change patient's position and perform full range of motion (ROM).</td></tr><tr><td>14. Secure call bell or intercom system within reach.</td><td>Allows patient, family or caregiver to obtain assistance quickly.</td></tr><tr><td>15. Leave bed or chair with wheels locked. Bed should be in lowest position.</td><td>Locked wheels prevent bed or chair from moving if patient attempts to get out. If patient falls when bed is in lowest position, the chances of injury are reduced.</td></tr><tr><td>16. Inspect patient for any injury, including all hazards of immobility, while restraints are in use.</td><td>Patient should be free of injury and not exhibit any signs of immobility complications. Use of restraints should be seen as a temporary measure and discontinued as soon as possible (Stolley, 1995).</td></tr><tr><td>17. Observe IV catheters and urinary catheters to ensure that they are positioned correctly and that therapy remains uninterrupted.</td><td>Use of restraints can further increase disorientation.</td></tr><tr><td>18. Provide appropriate sensory stimulation and reorient patient as needed.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>RECORDING AND REPORTING</td><td>HOME CARE CONSIDERATIONS</td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Record patient behaviours that place patient at risk of injury, type of restraint applied, time restraints were applied and patient's behaviour after restraints were applied.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Document specific assessments related to ventilation, skin integrity, musculoskeletal system and peripheral vascular integrity.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Describe patient's response when restraints were removed.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Describe alternatives to restraints that were used and patient's response.</td><td>â€¢ Plan care with family.</td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Instruct family (or other caregiver) in use of alternatives to restraints (see Box 15-6).</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ If physical restraints are necessary, instruct family (or other caregiver) in proper application and observation of possible complications related to restraint use. Also inform caregiver whom to contact if any abnormal findings occur.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ A patient who needs to be restrained in bed should have a hospital bed and will require constant supervision in the home.</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="applying-restraints">APPLYING RESTRAINTS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#applying-restraints" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<p>6 FUNDAMENTALS OF NURSING: CLINICAL SKILLS WORKBOOK</p>
<p>SKILL 15-2</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="seizure-precautions">Seizure precautions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#seizure-precautions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="delegation-considerations">DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delegation-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Interventions for a patient who is experiencing a seizure cannot be delegated. The nurse must constantly assess the patient's airway patency, adequacy of breathing and circulatory status. Clinical judgments must be made quickly, using the elements of critical thinking. Nurse assistants can remain with the nurse during a seizure, to obtain needed supplies and notify other personnel at the nurse's request.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Proper restraint</li>
<li>Padding</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Oral airway</li>
<li>Padding for side rails and headboard</li>
<li>Suction machine, oral suction equipment</li>
<li>Clean disposable gloves</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Proper restraint</li>
<li>Padding</li>
</ul>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>1. Assess seizure history, noting frequency of seizures, presence of aura and sequence of events, if known. Assess for medical and surgical conditions that may lead to seizures or exacerbate existing seizure condition. Assess medication history.</td><td>This enables the nurse to anticipate onset of seizure activity. Seizure medications must be taken as prescribed and not stopped suddenly, as this may precipitate seizure activity.</td></tr><tr><td>2. Inspect patient's environment (in a healthcare agency or in the home) for potential safety hazards if a seizure occurs.</td><td>Patient's bed should be in its lowest position, with side rails padded and patient positioned in side-lying position when possible (see illustration).</td></tr><tr><td>3. For patients with a history of seizures, an airway (see illustration), suction apparatus, clean gloves and pillows should be visible in the hospital setting for immediate use.</td><td>This ensures prompt, organised intervention.</td></tr><tr><td>4. When a seizure begins, position patient safely. If patient is standing or sitting at time of seizure, guide patient to floor and protect head by cradling in nurse's lap or placing a pillow under head. Clear surrounding area of furniture. If patient is in bed, raise side rails, add padding and put bed in low position.</td><td>Protects patient from traumatic injury, especially head injury.</td></tr><tr><td>5. Provide privacy.</td><td>Embarrassment is common after a seizure, especially if the seizure was witnessed by others.</td></tr><tr><td>6. If possible, turn patient on side, with head flexed slightly forwards.</td><td>Prevents tongue and dentures from blocking the airway and promotes drainage of secretions, thus reducing risk of aspiration.</td></tr><tr><td>7. Do not restrain patient. Loosen clothing.</td><td>Prevents musculoskeletal injury.</td></tr><tr><td>8. Do not place any objects in patient's mouth.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Critical decision point: Injury may result from forcible insertion of a hard object. Soft objects may break or come apart and be aspirated. Placing objects in the patient's mouth could result in tooth loss, lacerations, stimulation of the gag reflex with vomiting and aspiration and respiratory distress (Roth and others, 2011).</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>9. Stay with patient, observing the sequence and timing of seizure activity.</td><td>Continued observation is necessary to ensure adequate ventilation during and following seizure activity. Accurate, specific observations will assist in documentation, diagnosis and treatment of the seizure disorder.</td></tr><tr><td>10. After the seizure is over, explain what happened and answer patient's questions.</td><td>Informing patients of the type of seizure activity experienced will help them participate knowledgeably in their care.</td></tr><tr><td>Status epilepticus</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>11. For a patient experiencing status epilepticus, put on clean gloves and insert a Guedel airway (see illustration for Step 3) when the jaw is relaxed between seizure activity. Do not place fingers near or in patient's mouth.</td><td>Prevents transmission of infection. Patient is in continual seizure state and requires oral airway to ensure airway patency.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>SAFETY 7</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>12. Access oxygen and suction equipment. Prepare for IV insertion.</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<ol start="13">
<li>Use pillows/pads to protect patient from injuring self. | In this emergency patient requires adequate airway and IV access.
Traumatic injury will be avoided.  |
|  RECORDING AND REPORTING | HOME CARE CONSIDERATIONS  |
|  â€¢ Record the timing of seizure activity and sequence of events. Record presence of aura (if any), level of consciousness, posture, colour, movements of extremities, incontinence and patterns of sleep following the seizure.
â€¢ Document patientâ€™s response and expected or unexpected outcomes. | â€¢ Communicate with patient and family to identify precipitating factors.
â€¢ Teach family to care for the patient during a seizure.
â€¢ Provide family with guidelines to detect status epilepticus.
â€¢ Until a seizure condition is well controlled (usually for at least 1 year), the patient should not have a bath in a bathtub or engage in activities such as swimming unless a knowledgeable family member is present. Driving may also be restricted during this time.
â€¢ Patient should wear a medical alert bracelet or tag and have an ID card noting the presence of a seizure disorder and listing the medications taken.
â€¢ Referral to a support group may be indicated (see The EpiCentre website <a href="http://137.172.248.46/epilepsy.htm" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://137.172.248.46/epilepsy.htm</a>).  |</li>
</ol>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="seizure-precautions">SEIZURE PRECAUTIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#seizure-precautions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="health-assessment-and-physical-examination">Health assessment and physical examination<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#health-assessment-and-physical-examination" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="overview">Overview<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#overview" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Health assessment is essential and fundamental knowledge for registered nurses. Health assessment involves the systematic collection of subjective and objective data from the patient and analysis of these data to make clinical judgements about the patient's health status.</p>
<p>The process of collecting data for health assessment is often described as invisible and continual. Nurses are continually observing their patients to collect data in order to make the necessary clinical judgements regardless of where they areâ€”hospital, clinic, community, home or residential long-term care. Assessment is the first step of the nursing process, and learning to effectively collect information systematically and comprehensively from patients about their health for assessment and clinical judgements is crucial to making accurate clinical decisions about patient treatment and care.</p>
<p>As the only healthcare professionals with patients 24 hours a day, seven days a week, nurses are usually the first to detect and respond to changes in a patient's condition at the bedside. Nurses are reliant on their health assessment knowledge and skills in order to identify life-threatening complications for the patient, as well as to detect subtle and overt changes that represent deterioration in the patient's condition. Registered nurses save lives and improve the health outcomes of their patients through early recognition and nursing actions as a result of continuing assessment on a daily basis. Hence it is important that students learn to develop, practise and consolidate skills to conduct systematic and comprehensive health assessments, through the collection of a health history and physical examination of the patient. It is vital that nurses listen to their patients and inspect and examine them in a systematic and comprehensive way.</p>
<p>This chapter provides students with the opportunity to develop the knowledge, skills and techniques for conducting health assessments using a systems framework approach. The skills addressed include assessment of the abdomen and gastrointestinal tract (27-1), assessment of the musculoskeletal system (27-2), assessment of the cardiovascular and peripheral vascular systems (27-3), assessment of the respiratory system (27-4), mental state assessment (27-5) and assessment of central nervous system and level of consciousness (27-6).</p>
<p>FUNDAMENTALS OF NURSING: CLINICAL SKILLS WORKBOOK</p>
<p>SKILL 27-1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="assessment-of-the-abdomen-and-gastrointestinal-tract">Assessment of the abdomen and gastrointestinal tract<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#assessment-of-the-abdomen-and-gastrointestinal-tract" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="delegation-considerations">DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delegation-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Assessment of the abdomen and gastrointestinal (GI) tract may be undertaken by enrolled nurses under the guidance of the registered nurse.</p>
<ul>
<li>Ensure review of the anatomy and physiology of the GI system.</li>
<li>Ensure that hand hygiene is performed and personal protective equipment is worn when appropriate.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Stethoscope</li>
<li>Small pillow for under the knees</li>
<li>Tape measure or ruler</li>
<li>Marking pen</li>
<li>Pen</li>
<li>Documentation</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="steps">STEPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Determine need to assess GI status of patient.</li>
<li>Focused health history</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Determine chief complaintâ€”ask about the key characteristics of pain and each sign/symptom using the PQRST approach (see Chapter 6).
b. Ask the patient to describe their elimination pattern, and specifically the presence of:</p>
<ul>
<li>abdominal pain</li>
<li>nausea and/or vomiting</li>
<li>anorexia</li>
<li>dysphagia</li>
<li>diarrhoea</li>
<li>constipation</li>
<li>abdominal distension</li>
<li>increased eructation</li>
<li>increased flatulence</li>
<li>dysuria and/or nocturia.
c. Ascertain past history of abdominal-specific pathology, including surgery and communicable diseases.
d. Ask about alcohol and/or drug use.
e. Ask about travel history.</li>
</ul>
<ol start="3">
<li>Explain procedure to patient and clarify any concerns.</li>
<li>Ensure patient comfort and privacy.</li>
<li>Ensure appropriate position for examinationâ€”supine with small pillow beneath knees. Examiner stands to the right of the patient.</li>
<li>Abdominal landmarks</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Identify abdominal landmarks
(1) Xiphoid process.
(2) Costal margins.
(3) Abdominal midline.
(4) Umbilicus.
(5) Rectus abdominis muscles.
(6) Anterior superior iliac spine.
(7) Inguinal ligament.
(8) Symphysis pubis.
b. Anatomical mapping</p>
<p>(1) Four quadrants:</p>
<ol>
<li>Right upper quadrant (RUQ)</li>
<li>Right lower quadrant (RLQ)</li>
<li>Left upper quadrant (LUQ)</li>
<li>Left lower quadrant (LLQ)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="rationale">RATIONALE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rationale" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Abdominal pain is one of the most common symptoms reported when seeking healthcare.</p>
<p>The focused abdominal health history provides insight into the link between a patient's lifestyle and abdominal information and pathology.</p>
<p>Promotes patient's cooperation and comfort during the assessment.</p>
<p>The abdomen is the largest cavity of the body. It is located between the diaphragm and symphysis pubis. It is ovoid in shape and contains several vital organs.</p>
<p>Anatomical maps provide a framework for examination of the abdomen.</p>
<p>The abdominal cavity can be divided into four quadrants (see Figure 27-13A):</p>
<ul>
<li>Imaginary vertical line from xiphoid process to symphysis pubis</li>
<li>Imaginary horizontal line level with umbilicus.</li>
</ul>
<p>HEALTH ASSESSMENT AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION 11</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>(2) Nine regions:</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<ol>
<li>Epigastric region</li>
<li>Umbilical region</li>
<li>Hypogastric region</li>
<li>Right hypochondriac region</li>
<li>Left hypochondriac region</li>
<li>Right lumbar region</li>
<li>Left lumbar region</li>
<li>Right iliac region</li>
<li>Left iliac region | The abdominal cavity can be subdivided into a further nine anatomical regions:
â€¢ Imaginary vertical lines linking left and right mid-clavicles to left and right inguinal ligaments
â€¢ Horizontal line level with lower border of costal margins
â€¢ Horizontal line level with anterior superior iliac spines.  |
|  7. Examination of the abdomen
A. Inspect the abdomen in each of the 4 quadrants for:
(1) Contour, symmetry, pigmentation and colour, viewed from the costal margin to the symphysis pubis.
(2) Separation of the rectus abdominis musclesâ€”instruct the patient to raise the head and shoulders.
(3) Scars and striae.
(4) Obvious signs of trauma.
(5) Respiratory movement.
(6) Masses or nodules.
(7) Visible peristalsisâ€”peristaltic movement slowly traverses the abdomen in a slanting downward direction.
(8) Umbilicus in relation to the abdominal surface. | Normally the abdominal contour is flat.
The abdomen should be symmetrical bilaterally.
The abdomen should be uniform in colour and pigmentation.
Normally the symmetry of the abdomen remains uniform, and no ridge is observed parallel to the umbilicus or between the rectus abdominis muscles.</li>
</ol>
<p>Normally respiratory movement should rise with inspiration and fall with expiration. There should be no respiratory retractions.
Ripple of peristalsis may be observed in thin patients.  |
|  B. Auscultate the abdomen in each of the 4 quadrants for bowel sounds, noting frequency, pitch, quality. Place the diaphragm of the stethoscope lightly on the abdominal wall, beginning in the RLQ. Listen to the frequency of bowel sounds.
C. Percuss the abdomen in each of the 4 quadrants:
(1) Abdominal surface (distribution of percussion sounds).
(2) Intensity, pitch, duration, quality.
(3) Beginning in the RLQ, moving upward and crossing over to the LUQ and down to the LLQ.
(4) Bladderâ€”percuss upward from the symphysis pubis to the umbilicus. | The umbilicus is normally depressed and beneath the abdominal surface.
Bowel sounds are heard as intermittent gurgling sounds throughout the abdominal quadrants. They are usually high-pitched and occur between 5 and 30 times a minute. Bowel sounds result from the movement of air and fluid through the GI tract. Normally no audible bruits are auscultated.
Tympany is normally the predominant sound heard because of the presence of air in the stomach and intestine. It is a high-pitched sound of lengthy duration.
Dullness is normally heard over the liver or a distended bladder. Dull sounds are high-pitched and of moderate duration.
Normally the liver span is between 6 and 12 cm in the right midclavicular line. There is a direct correlation between body size and liver size.
Dullness is also heard over solid organs or masses. Note where the sound changes from dullness to tympany.
A urine-filled bladder is dull to percussion. A recently emptied bladder should not be percussable above the symphysis pubis.
Normally the abdomen should feel soft, non-tender and without masses. Light palpation reveals changes in skin temperature, tenderness or guarding or large masses.
Normally no organ enlargement should be palpable. Nor should there be any abnormal masses, bulges or swelling.
Normally only the aorta and the edge of the liver are palpable in thin patients. When the large colon or bladder are full, palpation is possible but atypical.  |
|  D. Palpate the abdomen in each of the 4 quadrants:
(1) Warm your hands.
(2) First identify location of abdominal tenderness.
(3) Watch personâ€™s face during palpation.
(4) Light palpation (2â€“3 cm depth)â€”use the pads of fingers to depress the abdominal wall.
(5) Deep palpation (4â€“5 cm depth)â€”use the palmar surface of the extended fingers to depress the abdominal wall. |   |
|  RECORDING AND REPORTING | HOME CARE CONSIDERATIONS  |
|  â€¢ Findings from inspection, auscultation, percussion and palpation assessment of the abdomen are documented.
â€¢ Report any abnormal findings. | â€¢ Explanation of factors that promote bowel and bladder elimination.
â€¢ Caution against the excessive use of laxatives.
â€¢ Recommendations and evaluation of management of acute or chronic pain.  |</p>
<p>Reference: Estes MEZ 2010 Health assessment and physical examination, ed 4. New York, Cengage Learning.</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="assessment-of-the-abdomen-and-gastrointestinal-tract">ASSESSMENT OF THE ABDOMEN AND GASTROINTESTINAL TRACT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#assessment-of-the-abdomen-and-gastrointestinal-tract" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<p>HEALTH ASSESSMENT AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION 13</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="skill-27-2">SKILL 27-2<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#skill-27-2" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="assessment-of-the-musculoskeletal-system">Assessment of the musculoskeletal system<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#assessment-of-the-musculoskeletal-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="delegation-considerations">DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delegation-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Assessment of the musculoskeletal system may be undertaken by enrolled nurses under the guidance of the registered nurse.</p>
<ul>
<li>Ensure review of the anatomy and physiology of the musculoskeletal system for risk factors, specifically the major muscle groups and joints.</li>
<li>Ensure hand hygiene is performed and personal protective equipment worn when appropriate.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Tape measure</li>
<li>Marking pen</li>
<li>Pen</li>
<li>Documentation</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="steps">STEPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Determine need to assess musculoskeletal status of patient.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Focused health history.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Determine chief complaintâ€”characteristics of pain and each sign/symptom.</p>
<p>b. Determine presence of:</p>
<ul>
<li>Painâ€”location and quantity, associated manifestations, aggravating and alleviating factors, timing</li>
<li>Weaknessâ€”location and quantity</li>
<li>Limited movementâ€”location and quantity, inflammation, stiffness, muscle atrophy, deformity, crepitus, joint effusion</li>
<li>Aggravating factorsâ€”overexertion, immobility, excessive weight gain, non-compliance with medication, physiotherapy (PT) and occupational therapy (OT) regimens</li>
<li>Alleviating factorsâ€”PT and OT, anti-inflammatory medications, analgesics, ice, heat, rest</li>
</ul>
<p>c. Ask about past history of musculoskeletal specific conditions and surgery, and non-musculoskeletal-specific conditions.</p>
<p>d. Ask about social historyâ€”alcohol use, work environment, recreation and leisure.</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>
<p>Explain procedure to patient and clarify any concerns.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Ensure patient comfort and privacy.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Ensure appropriate position for examination. The examiner stands in front of the patient for anterior assessment and behind the patient for posterior assessment.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Physical examination</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>A. Overall appearance</p>
<p>(1) Height and weight.</p>
<p>(2) Ability to tolerate weightbearing on lower limbs.</p>
<p>(3) Observe for structural abnormalities.</p>
<p>(4) Note indications of discomfort.</p>
<p>B. Posture</p>
<p>(1) Instruct the patient to stand with feet together. Observe the structural and spatial relationship of the head, torso, pelvis and limbs.</p>
<p>(2) Assess for symmetry of the shoulders, scapulae and iliac crest.</p>
<p>(3) Instruct the patient to sit; observe posture.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="rationale">RATIONALE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rationale" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Alterations in the musculoskeletal system will affect the person's ability to complete activities of daily living, occupation and recreation. The assessment focuses on determining range of joint motion, muscle strength and tone and joint and muscle condition.</p>
<p>The focused musculoskeletal health history provides insight into the link between a patient's lifestyle and musculoskeletal information and pathology.</p>
<p>Promotes patient's cooperation and comfort during the assessment.</p>
<p>Body height and weight should be appropriate for age and gender. The patient should be able to enter the assessment area by ambulating independently.</p>
<p>Normally, in the standing position the head and torso are upright. The shoulders and hips are level, with symmetry of the scapulae and iliac crests. The arms hang freely from the shoulders. The feet are aligned and toes point forward. The extremities are proportional to the overall body size and shape; the limbs are symmetrical with each other.</p>
<p>In the sitting position, both feet should be placed firmly on the surface of the floor, with toes pointing forward.</p>
<p>FUNDAMENTALS OF NURSING: CLINICAL SKILLS WORKBOOK</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>C. Gait and mobility</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(1) Instruct the patient to walk normally across the room.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(2) Observe the patient during transfer between standing and sitting positions.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(3) Observe patient's balance during above movements.</td><td>Normally, walking is initiated in a smooth and rhythmic motion. The foot is lifted and propelled forwards in a straight line; as the heel strikes the floor, bodyweight is shifted to the ball of the foot. The patient remains erect and balanced during all stages of gait. Step height and length are symmetrical for each foot. Arms swing freely at the side of the torso and in the opposite direction to the movement of the legs. The head and neck face the intended direction. The patient should be able to transfer with ease between varying positions.</td></tr><tr><td>D. Inspection</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(1) Muscle size and shapeâ€”overall appearance of muscle mass; observe for muscle contraction.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(2) Joint contourâ€”observe the shape of the joint in its neutral anatomical position. Observe the skin and subcutaneous tissue surrounding the joint for colour, inflammation, bruising, deformities, masses, nodules and skin integrity.</td><td>Normally muscle contraction will be affected by the exercise and activity patterns of the individual. During contraction, tautness in the muscle should be observed. Muscle shape may be accentuated in certain body areas but should be symmetrical.</td></tr><tr><td>Normally joint contour is flat in extension and smooth and rounded in flexion.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>There should be no observable abnormalities to the skin and subcutaneous tissue surrounding the joint.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Bilateral joints should be symmetrical and similar in appearance.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>E. Palpation</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(1) Muscle toneâ€”palpate each muscle group by applying light pressure with the pads of the fingers of the dominant hand. Note the change in muscle shape between the 'belly' of the muscle (wide central area) and where it tapers off into the tendon.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(2) Jointsâ€”palpate each of the major skeletal joints, with the joint in the neutral anatomical position. Apply light pressure with the pads of the fingers of the dominant hand. Palpate from the periphery inwards to the centre of the joint. Note any pain, swelling, crepitus, warmth or nodules.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(3) Range of motion (ROM): examine each of the major skeletal joints: temporomandibular joint, cervical spine, shoulders, elbows, wrists and hands, hips, knees, ankles and feet, spine (see Table 27-14).</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>a. Instruct the patient to move each of the major skeletal joints through each of its various ranges of movement. Notice the angle, pain, tenderness or crepitus.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>b. If the patient is unable to move a joint through active ROM, passive joint movement is required; gently support and move the joints of the extremities through their ROM (see Figure 27-16). Always stop at complaints of pain.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(4) Muscle strengthâ€”each muscle group is assessed for strength using the same movements as those performed through ROM (see Table 27-16 and Figure 27-17). Note strength and equality. Compare the right and left of paired muscle groups. Note involuntary movements.</td><td>Normally, on palpation the muscle should feel smooth and firm.</td></tr><tr><td>Normally when the skeletal joints are palpated in their neutral anatomical position, the external joint contour feels smooth, strong and firm. The area surrounding the joint should be free from abnormalities.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Normally as the joint is moved through its ROM, it should be able to articulate in proper alignment without any visible or palpable deformity.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Normal muscle strength will allow for complete voluntary ROM of joints against both gravity and moderate to full resistance.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>RECORDING AND REPORTING</td><td>HOME CARE CONSIDERATIONS</td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Findings from inspection and palpation in the assessment of the muscles, joints and ROM are documented.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Report any abnormal findings.</td><td>â€¢ Education for the identification of risk factors affecting mobility and the interruption of the activities of daily living cycle.</td></tr><tr><td>Reference</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Estes MEZ 2010 Health assessment and physical examination, ed 4. New York, Cengage Learning.</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>

<p>SKILL 27-3</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="assessment-of-the-cardiovascular-and-peripheral-vascular-systems">Assessment of the cardiovascular and peripheral vascular systems<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#assessment-of-the-cardiovascular-and-peripheral-vascular-systems" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="delegation-considerations">DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delegation-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Assessment of the cardiovascular system (CVS) and peripheral vascular system (PVS) may be undertaken by enrolled nurses under the guidance of the registered nurse.</p>
<ul>
<li>Ensure review of the anatomy and physiology of the CVS and PVS for risk factors.</li>
<li>Ensure hand hygiene is performed and personal protective equipment is worn when appropriate.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Stethoscope</li>
<li>Sphygmomanometer</li>
<li>Watch with second hand</li>
<li>Tape measure</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="steps">STEPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Determine need to assess CVS and PVS status of patient.</li>
<li>Focused health history</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Determine chief complaintâ€”characteristics of chest pain and each sign/symptom.
b. Determine presence of chest painâ€”description of onset, location/radiation, duration, character/quality, aggravating factors, relieving factors, timing and severity (0â€“10 scale).
c. Ask about associated signs and symptoms:</p>
<ul>
<li>syncope</li>
<li>palpitations</li>
<li>nausea and vomiting</li>
<li>peripheral oedema</li>
<li>extremity pain
d. Ask about past history:</li>
<li>cardiac-specific, e.g. angina, heart failure, coronary artery disease (CAD), hypertension, rheumatic fever, valvular disease</li>
<li>non-cardiac-specific, e.g. bleeding or blood disorders, diabetes, stroke</li>
<li>cardiac or vascular surgery
e. Ask about smoking and alcohol and/or drug use.
f. Ask about travel history.
g. Determine family historyâ€”heart and vascular diseases that are familial include aneurysm, stroke, CAD, hypertension, myocardial infarction, stroke.</li>
</ul>
<ol start="3">
<li>Explain procedure to patient and clarify any concerns.</li>
<li>Ensure patient comfort and privacy.</li>
<li>Ensure appropriate position (supine/semi-Fowlerâ€™s) for examinationâ€”performed through the anterior thorax with the examiner on the right side of the patient.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="rationale">RATIONALE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rationale" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A patient with the signs and symptoms of heart (cardiac) problems (e.g. chest pain or irregular pulse) may be suffering a life-threatening condition requiring immediate attention.</p>
<p>The focused cardiac and peripheral vascular health history provides insight into the link between a patientâ€™s lifestyle and cardiac and peripheral vasculature information and pathology.</p>
<p>Promotes patientâ€™s cooperation and comfort during the assessment</p>
<p>Patients with heart or respiratory disease often suffer shortness of breath when lying flat.</p>
<p>HEALTH ASSESSMENT AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION 17</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>6. Assessment of cardiovascular system</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>A. Identify praecordial (cardiac) landmarks:</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>A. Aortic area: 2nd intercostal space at right sternal border</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>P. Pulmonic area: 2nd intercostal space at left sternal border</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>T. Tricuspid area: 4th intercostal space at left sternal border</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>M. Mitral/apical area/impulse/point of maximal impulse (PMI): 4th to 5th intercostal space left of midclavicular line</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>B. Assessment of the praecordium: inspection and palpation are performed simultaneously and methodically, looking for visible pulsations, source of vibrations or thrills and the apical impulse.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(1) Inspect and palpate the angle of Louis (between the sternal body and manubrium) with the index finger.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(2) Inspect and palpate the aortic area.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(3) Inspect and palpate the pulmonic area.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(4) Inspect and palpate the tricuspid area.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(5) Inspect and palpate the mitral area.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>C. Auscultation of heart sounds is commenced at the aortic cardiac landmark and a systematic approach is followed across each of the cardiac landmarks.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(1) Place the diaphragm of the stethoscope on the chest wall over the aortic landmark and listen for Sâ‚‚.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(2) Place the diaphragm of the stethoscope on the chest wall over the pulmonic landmark and listen for Sâ‚‚.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(3) Place the diaphragm of the stethoscope on the chest wall over the tricuspid landmark and listen for Sâ‚.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(4) Place the diaphragm of the stethoscope on the chest wall over the mitral landmark and listen for Sâ‚.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(5) Auscultate for rate and rhythm when both sounds are heard clearly.</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<ol start="8">
<li>Assessment of peripheral vascular system
A. Upper limbs
(1) Inspection: lift both hands and inspect both sides, noting colour of skin, nail bed, temperature, texture and turgor and the presence of lesions, oedema or clubbing.
(2) Palpation:
a. Capillary return: depress the nail bed and release; note the time for colour return (usually 1â€“2 seconds).
b. Radial pulse: palpate both radial pulses, located laterally to the radius and apply pressure. Note the rate, rhythm, elasticity of the vessel wall and relative strength of the pulses (should be equal). | Inspection, palpation and auscultation should be performed using a systematic approach, over the identified praecordial landmarks. The use of percussion is limited because X-rays and other diagnostic tests provide the same information more accurately.</li>
</ol>
<p>No pulsations or vibrations or thrills should be visible or felt in the aortic, pulmonic or tricuspid areas. If pulsations or vibrations are palpated, their occurrence is timed in relation to systole or diastole by auscultating heart sounds simultaneously.
Auscultation of the heart detects normal heart sounds, extra heart sounds and murmurs. Normal sounds are created by the closing of the valves.
Sâ‚‚ is produced by the closure of the semilunar valves, and is louder than Sâ‚ at the aortic and pulmonic landmarks.
Sâ‚ is produced by the closure of the tricuspid and mitral valves. Sâ‚ at the tricuspid area is softer than at the mitral area.
Sâ‚ is heard loudest in the mitral area.</p>
<p>Flattening of angle and clubbing occur with congenital cyanotic heart disease and cor pulmonale.</p>
<p>Never use your thumb to take a pulse. The thumb contains a â€˜falseâ€™ pulse that beats at a different rate to the heart. Never palpate both carotid arteries simultaneouslyâ€”this occludes the blood supply to the brain and surrounding structures.  |</p>
<p>FUNDAMENTALS OF NURSING: CLINICAL SKILLS WORKBOOK</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>c. Brachial pulse: palpate the brachial pulse bilaterally; located medially in the cubital fossa. Note the rate, rhythm, elasticity of the vessel wall and relative strength of the pulses (should be equal).</td><td>It is not usually required to palpate the ulnar pulse; however, this is performed during the Allen test to identify collateral circulation and is commonly performed prior to arterial blood gas sampling.</td></tr><tr><td><strong>B. Lower limbs</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(1) Inspection: inspect both legs together, noting skin colour, hair distribution, venous patterns, size and any skin lesions, scars or ulcers. Both legs should be symmetrical without swelling or atrophy. Measure the limbs' circumference at an equal distance from each patella. Record your findings in centimetres.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(2) Palpation:</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>a. Palpate for temperature along both legs down to the feet. The skin should be warm and equal bilaterally.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>b. Palpate the peripheral arteries in both legs. Note the rate, rhythm, elasticity of the vessel wall and relative strength of the pulses (should be equal).</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>c. Femoral pulse: located inferior to the inguinal ligament halfway between the pubis and anterior superior iliac spines.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>d. Popliteal pulse: more diffuse and difficult to locate. Often it is lateral to the medial tendon.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>e. Posterior tibial pulse: curve your fingers around the medial malleolus. You will feel tapping behind the groove between the malleolus and the Achilles tendon. If you cannot, try dorsiflexing the foot.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>f. Dorsalis pedis: requires a very light touch. Normally it is just lateral to and parallel with the extensor tendon of the big toe.</td><td>Abnormal:</td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Acute, unilateral painful calf swelling and asymmetry of calves of 1 cm or more is abnormal and could signify evidence of a deep-vein thrombosis</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Asymmetry bilaterally 1â€“3 cm could indicate mild lymphoedema; 3â€“5 cm moderate lymphoedema; and &gt;5 cm severe lymphoedema.</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Never use your thumb to take a pulse. The thumb contains a 'false' pulse that beats at a different rate to the heart.  |
|  RECORDING AND REPORTING | HOME CARE CONSIDERATIONS  |
|  â€¢ The cardiovascular system plays a role in the function of many health systems, and therefore it is important to document any abnormal findings.
â€¢ Documentation includes
â€” Rate (beats per minute): normally 60â€“100 (adult), 70â€“130 (child, depending on age)
â€” Rhythm: normally strong and regular
â€” Character: unequal pulses; congenital abnormality in radial pulseâ€”aortic arch aneurysm; lower limb pulsesâ€”atherosclerosis, arterial embolism
â€¢ Compare all pulses bilaterally, taking note of the rate, rhythm and character of each pulse and document on the vascular observation chart. | â€¢ All chest pain should be considered to be cardiac in nature until proven otherwiseâ€”urgent medical assistance is required.
â€¢ Any abnormal finding could indicate impairment in the function of the cardiovascular system and should be considered a potential emergency and medical attention is required.  |
|  Reference: Estes MEZ 2010 Health assessment and physical examination, ed 4. New York, Cengage Learning.  |   |</p>
<p>HEALTH ASSESSMENT AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION 19</p>
