<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="assessment-of-the-respiratory-system">Assessment of the respiratory system<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#assessment-of-the-respiratory-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="delegation-considerations">DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delegation-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Assessment of the respiratory system may be undertaken by enrolled nurses under the guidance of the registered nurse.</p>
<ul>
<li>Ensure review of the anatomy and physiology of the respiratory system for risk factors.</li>
<li>Ensure review of the anatomical landmarks of the chest wall.</li>
<li>Ensure hand hygiene is performed and personal protective equipment worn when appropriate.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Stethoscope</li>
<li>Pen</li>
<li>Documentation</li>
<li>Watch (with a second hand)</li>
<li>Portable pulse oximeter</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="steps">STEPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Determine need to assess the respiratory function of the patient.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Focused health history</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Determine chief complaintâ€”characteristics of pain and each sign/symptom.</p>
<p>b. Ascertain main respiratory symptoms:</p>
<ul>
<li>dyspnoea</li>
<li>cough and sputum</li>
<li>haemoptysis</li>
<li>chest pain</li>
<li>wheeze (note: severe asthma may not have a wheeze)</li>
</ul>
<p>c. Ascertain past medical historyâ€”any history of similar symptom(s) with any treatment and outcome:</p>
<ul>
<li>childhood asthma, wheezing or 'bronchitis'</li>
<li>malignant disease</li>
<li>infections including pneumonia, tuberculosis and whooping cough</li>
<li>chest trauma and operations</li>
<li>thromboembolic disease, specifically deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolus</li>
</ul>
<p>d. Ask about drug history:</p>
<ul>
<li>use of inhalers</li>
<li>use of steroids</li>
<li>other relevant drugs that may affect respiratory function, e.g. morphine (respiratory depression), angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors (cough).</li>
</ul>
<p>e. Ask about allergies:</p>
<ul>
<li>food</li>
<li>inhaled allergens</li>
<li>drugs</li>
</ul>
<p>f. Ask about occupational and social history:</p>
<ul>
<li>occupational history may be very important in respiratory disease</li>
<li>hobbies and pets may also be responsible for respiratory disease</li>
</ul>
<p>g. Ask about lifestyle, including alcohol and illicit drug use.</p>
<p>h. Smoking history should detail, for example, the type and number of cigarettes smoked currently and in the past.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="rationale">RATIONALE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rationale" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The primary role of the respiratory system is to transfer oxygen into the body via the lungs and to remove carbon dioxide to the external environment. Respiration is a basic human need for survival. Nurses need to be able to recognise and understand the signs of impaired respiration or respiratory distress and provide urgent interventions.</p>
<p>The focused respiratory health history provides insight into the link between a patient's lifestyle and respiratory information and pathology.</p>
<p>HEALTH ASSESSMENT AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION 21</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>3. Physical examination</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>A. Inspection</p>
<p>(1) Thorax:
â€¢ Size
â€¢ Shape
â€¢ Symmetry
â€¢ Contour</p>
<p>(2) Respiration:
â€¢ Rate
â€¢ Pattern
â€¢ Inspiration/expiration ratio
â€¢ Audible adventitious sounds
â€¢ Use of accessory muscles</p>
<p>(3) Skin:
â€¢ Condition
â€¢ Colour
â€¢ Superficial venous patterns</p>
<p>(4) Peripheries:
â€¢ Lips
â€¢ Fingers
â€¢ Toes</p>
<p>B. Palpation</p>
<p>(1) Divide the thorax up into four sections: posterior chest, anterior chest, right and left lateral chest, and apices.</p>
<p>(2) General palpation.
a. Palpate the skin by gently placing the end of your fingers on the body; note temperature, skin condition.
b. Palpate thoracic muscles for abnormalities.
c. Palpate thoracic skeleton for abnormalities. If the patient identifies an area of abnormality or pain, inform them that you will palpate this last.</p>
<p>(3) Assess thoracic expansion.
a. Anterior hand position: hands are placed on the anterolateral chest with thumbs extended along the costal margin aimed at the xiphoid process.
b. Posterior hand position: thumbs are placed along the 10th rib with the hand placed gently on the posterolateral chest. Note: thumbs should be 3â€“5 cm apart.</p>
<p>(4) Assess tactile fremitus. While systematically palpating the thorax, have the patient repeat the words â€˜one, two, threeâ€™ or, more commonly, â€˜ninety-nineâ€™. | An accurate measurement of the respiratory system requires inspection, palpation and percussion of the chest wall. It will also include listening to the lung sounds heard during inspiration and expiration.</p>
<p>The depth of inspiration is assessed by the movement of the chest wall. Deep inspiration involves the complete expansion of the lungs with complete expiration.</p>
<p>The tissue contains fine pockets of air that can be felt on palpation. During palpation a â€˜cracklingâ€™ can be feltâ€”crepitation, e.g. subcutaneous emphysema.</p>
<p>Thoracic expansion refers to the degree of expansion of the thorax that can be palpated during inspiration. Nurses need to note the rise and fall of the chest, symmetry and that the thorax expands.</p>
<p>Fremitus refers to a vibration that can be felt during palpation. Tactile fremitus is palpable against the thoracic wall when the patient is speaking (phonation). The strength of the vibration decreases as distance between the palpating hand and the sound transmission increases. Observed in e.g. pneumothorax or pleural effusion.</p>
<p>In the context of a respiratory assessment percussion is used to identify the relative amount of air, liquid or solid matter in the lung and to identify the position and boundaries of organs.</p>
<p>Auscultation is a useful tool that can identify how the respiratory system is functioning. It allows you to be able to identify obstruction in the airway.  |
|  C. Percussion
Percussion is the â€˜tappingâ€™ of the body surface to identify underlying structures.</p>
<p>D. Auscultation
a. The diaphragm of the stethoscope is commonly used to auscultate the chest (see Figure 27-43).</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>Monitor patient for signs of light-headedness or signs of hyperventilation. |   |</li>
</ol>
<p>FUNDAMENTALS OF NURSING: CLINICAL SKILLS WORKBOOK</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>RECORDING AND REPORTING</th><th>HOME CARE CONSIDERATIONS</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>â€¢ The respiratory system plays a role in the function of many health systems, and therefore it is important to document any abnormal findings.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Documentation includes:</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€” rate (breaths per minute): normally 12â€“20 (adult), 20â€“30 (child)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€” rhythm: normally regular and deep</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€” sound: normal breath sounds are called vesicular</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Abnormal sounds could be evidence of an obstruction requiring urgent intervention and thus need to be reported immediately, including:</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€” wheeze: narrowing of the airways</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€” crackles: can represent the opening of alveoli and is evident in pulmonary congestion</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€” bronchial breathing: harsh sounds and poor quality (gaps can be heard during the inspiratory and expiratory phases)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€” pleural rub: stiffening of the pleural membrane, commonly heard in pleurisy</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€” stridor: harsh inspiratory sound evident of a partial obstruction of the airway. In children, stridor is often accompanied by a â€˜seal-likeâ€™ barking cough in the case of croup.</td><td>â€¢ Any abnormal finding could indicate an impairment in the function of the respiratory system and should be considered a potential emergency and medical attention is required.</td></tr><tr><td>References:</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Epstein O, Perkin G, Cookson J and others 2008 Clinical examination, ed 4. Edinburgh, Mosby.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Jarvis C 2008 Physical examination and assessment, ed 5. St Louis, Saunders.</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>

hand positioning</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Percusses the thorax</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Auscultates lung and tracheal sounds</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Identifies respiratory rate and rhythm</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Cleans and disposes of equipment appropriately</td><td>Disposes of used equipment in appropriate receptacle</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Performs hand hygiene</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Completes documentation</td><td>Documents procedure and associated assessment findings/complications</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="scale">SCALE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#scale" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="date">DATE:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#date" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>FUNDAMENTALS OF NURSING: CLINICAL SKILLS WORKBOOK</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="sxill-27-5">SXILL 27-5<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sxill-27-5" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="mental-state-assessment">Mental state assessment<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mental-state-assessment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Mental state assessment is a key nursing skill and provides a structured set of observations about the patient's cognitive and emotional state at a specific point in time.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="delegation-considerations">DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delegation-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The mental state assessment can be conducted without supervision. Most aspects of the mental state assessment can be carried out as part of routine nursing care, i.e. they can be integrated into other nursing procedures.</p>
<p>Before proceeding:</p>
<ul>
<li>review the categories of mental state assessment, and communication skills</li>
<li>revise the structured format for mental state assessment (BATOMI) (see Box 44-4)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Mental health assessment uses communication skills and therapeutic use of self</li>
<li>Consider privacy and appropriateness of setting</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="steps">STEPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Determine need to assess mental state of patient.</li>
<li>Focused mental health history</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Consider the patient's usual mental state, and how mental state might be affected by illness.
b. Consider the presence of factors that may affect mental state:</p>
<ul>
<li>pain/discomfort</li>
<li>sedative or other effects of medication</li>
<li>tiredness</li>
<li>anxiety about health/hospitalisation</li>
<li>sensory loss or impairment</li>
<li>nausea or other symptoms</li>
<li>any history of mental illness</li>
<li>alcohol or drug use</li>
</ul>
<p>c. Procedure:</p>
<p>(1) Initiate communication by introductions, clarification of the patient's immediate needs and problems.
(2) Consider positioning of nurse and patient to assist communication, i.e. by enabling eye contact.
(3) Ideally sit at the same level as the patient.
(4) Continue with assessment using guideline below to assess mental state.</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>Assess mental state</li>
</ol>
<p>A. Assessment of appearanceâ€”includes both expected and unusual aspects of appearance. Observe for:</p>
<p>(1) Gross appearance (stature, state of dress, appropriateness of dress for current situation).
(2) Patient's apparent age compared with recorded age.
(3) Position during assessment (sitting, lying).
(4) Grooming and evidence of self-care or neglect.
(5) Jewellery, makeup.
(6) Distinguishing features (complexion, marks on skin, any observable disabilities).
(7) Facial expressions.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="rationale">RATIONALE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rationale" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Mental state is changeable, and is influenced by a range of biological, psychological and emotional factors.</p>
<p>The focused mental health history provides insight into the links between a patient's general health and their cognitive and emotional state.</p>
<p>Promotes rapport and psychological comfort during assessment.</p>
<p>Appearance provides an initial set of clues to the patient's mental state.</p>
<p>Expected and unusual aspects of appearance are equally important.</p>
<p>HEALTH ASSESSMENT AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION 25</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>B. Assessment of behaviourâ€”includes all observable behaviour. Observe for:</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(1) Physical signs of anxiety or distress (handwringing, nervous mannerisms, plucking at clothes/hair, clutching objects such as purse or personal items).</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(2) Changes in behaviour in response to assessment.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(3) Any tremor or involuntary movements.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(4) Gestures with hands, eyes, head.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(5) Crying, laughing or other behavioural indications of mood.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(6) Eye contact with interviewer (observe for constant, intermittent, intense or absent eye contact).</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(7) Motor activity (settled/relaxed, changes of position, restlessness).</td><td>Many changes in mental state are apparent from observations of behaviour.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Changes in behaviour can provide an indication of concerns and anxieties.  |
|  C. Assessment of affect and moodâ€”includes direct and indirect observations of emotional state.
(1) Emotional responsiveness (warm, engaging, distant, aloof).
(2) Responses to topics of discussion.
(3) Crying, smiling, laughing and other behavioural indicators of emotional state.
(4) Conversational triggers to emotional responses.
(5) Congruence between emotional response and content of conversation.
(6) Irritability/anger.
(7) Indications of anxiety.
(8) Patientâ€™s self-rating of mood (1 = lowest ever; 10 = best ever). | Assessment of mood includes both the nurseâ€™s assessment and the patientâ€™s statements about their mood.</p>
<p>Affect may change throughout an interview or procedure; changes can be as important as overall mood.  |
|  D. Assessment of thought and speechâ€”includes directly observed speech and underlying thought processes. Make allowances for age, culture, language. Observe for:
(1) Rate of speech (slowed, normal, accelerated, pressured).
(2) Themes of thought and speech (preoccupations, guilt, depressive themes, dominant concerns).
(3) Reduced/absent speech.
(4) Organisation of speech (coherent, logical, complete sentences, goal oriented).
(5) Evidence of high ideas that are out of context (i.e. paranoid ideas, delusions).
(6) Evidence of unexplained perceptions (voices, visual hallucinations). | Patterns of thought are assessed by attending to speech.</p>
<p>Patients can also be asked to describe their thoughts.  |
|  E. Assessment of orientation
(1) Aspects of orientation are:
â€¢ Time
â€¢ Place
â€¢ Person.
(2) Orientation is assessed by asking specific questions or interpreting conversational cues to orientation (e.g. names, time, place of assessment). | Orientation provides important clues to organic or functional confusional states as well as additional information about problems of mood, thinking and perception.  |
|  F. Assessment of memoryâ€”includes all retention of information, whether short or long term.
(1) Observe for:
â€¢ Attention/concentration/registration
â€¢ Short-term memory
â€¢ Long-term memory.
(2) Ask specific questions if you need to test different aspects of memory, i.e. can the patient remember your name:
â€¢ immediately on being introduced (registration)
â€¢ five minutes after introduction (short-term memory)
â€¢ the day after an introduction (long-term memory) | Memory can be disrupted in many illnesses and when emotional and cognitive functioning is impaired.</p>
<p>General assessment conversation can provide important information about memory.  |</p>
<p>FUNDAMENTALS OF NURSING: CLINICAL SKILLS WORKBOOK</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>G. Assessment of insight and judgmentâ€”assesses and records the patient's understanding of their current health problems. Observe for:</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(1) Realistic perception of current health problems.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(2) Realistic perception of any need for treatment.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(3) Awareness of consequences of own choices.</td><td>Insight is important in order to engage patient in a plan of care.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Impaired cognitive and emotional functioning can lead to reduced insight. Assessment of judgment can be an important indicator of safety.  |
|  RECORDING AND REPORTING | HOME CARE CONSIDERATIONS  |
|  â€¢ Mental state assessment is recorded in a narrative style using a structured format with headings for each component of assessment (see Box 45-5). Issues of concern such as low mood or anxiety should be discussed with a senior colleague or supervisor.
â€¢ Each mental state assessment should be compared with the patient's baseline assessment. | â€¢ Mental state assessment can be undertaken in the home as part of routine nursing care.
â€¢ The assessment may need to be abridged if there is not sufficient privacy.  |</p>
<p>HEALTH ASSESSMENT AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION 27</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="mental-state-assessment">MENTAL STATE ASSESSMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mental-state-assessment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="skill-27-6">SKILL 27-6<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#skill-27-6" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="assessment-of-central-nervous-system-and-level-of-consciousness">Assessment of central nervous system and level of consciousness<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#assessment-of-central-nervous-system-and-level-of-consciousness" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="delegation-considerations">DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delegation-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Assessment of the central nervous system (CNS) may be undertaken by enrolled nurses under the guidance of the registered nurse.</p>
<ul>
<li>Ensure review of the anatomy and physiology of the CNS for risk factors</li>
<li>Ensure review of the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)</li>
<li>Ensure hand hygiene is performed and personal protective equipment is worn when appropriate.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Penlight torch</li>
<li>Neurological observation chart</li>
<li>Pen</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="steps">STEPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Determine need to assess neurological status of patient.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Focused health history</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Determine chief complaintâ€”characteristics of pain and each sign/symptom using the PQRST approach (see Chapter 6).</p>
<p>b. Ascertain presence of:</p>
<ul>
<li>headache</li>
<li>seizureâ€”location (i.e. body parts involved), quantity in time, quality (general or localised)</li>
<li>associated manifestationsâ€”incontinence, injury, memory loss and cyanosis</li>
<li>aggravating factorsâ€”bright/flashing lights, TV, sleep deprivation, stress, fever in children, alcohol.</li>
</ul>
<p>c. Ask about settingâ€”warning aura, sequence of events, e.g. headache</p>
<p>d. Ask about timingâ€”first onset.</p>
<p>e. Assess syncopeâ€”quality, i.e. total vs partial loss of consciousness; and quantity in time.</p>
<p>f. Assess painâ€”location and quality</p>
<p>g. Assess paraesthesia and associated manifestations, e.g. pain, stiffness, gait changes, poor peripheral pulses, injury</p>
<p>h. Assess disturbances in gait: qualityâ€”ataxic, spastic, hemiplegic</p>
<p>i. Assess visual changes: qualityâ€”blindness, in particular fields of vision, blurred vision, bright/flashing lights</p>
<p>j. Ask about vertigo.</p>
<p>k. Assess for memory disorders: qualityâ€”recent or remote memory loss</p>
<p>l. Assess for dysphasia or dysphagia.</p>
<p>m. Determine past history of neurological-specific conditions and surgery, and non-neurological-specific conditions.</p>
<p>n. Ask about social historyâ€”alcohol use, work environment, recreation and leisure, sexual practice, stress.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="rationale">RATIONALE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rationale" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Certain conditions place patients at risk of neurological alterations (stroke, seizure, paralysis). Physical signs and symptoms such as confusion, drowsiness and limb weakness may indicate alterations in neurological function.</p>
<p>As cognitive function deteriorates, the patient becomes disorientated to time, place and person and is unable to process and demonstrate higher order functioning.</p>
<p>The focused neurological health history provides insight into the link between a patientâ€™s lifestyle and neurological information and pathology.</p>
<p>FUNDAMENTALS OF NURSING: CLINICAL SKILLS WORKBOOK</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>3. Explain procedure to patient and clarify any concerns.</td><td>Promotes patient's cooperation and comfort during the assessment.</td></tr><tr><td>4. Ensure patient comfort and privacy.</td><td>The GCS assesses the patient's level of consciousness. It is able to evaluate the brain function as a whole, rather than assessing particular lobes of the brain.</td></tr><tr><td>5. Neurological assessment commences with a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score to measure level of consciousness (see Table 27-25).</td><td>The level of consciousness exists along a continuum from full waking, alertness and cooperation through to any form of external stimuli. A fully conscious patient responds to questions spontaneously. As consciousness lowers, a patient may show irritability, a shortened attention span or an unwillingness to cooperate.</td></tr><tr><td>A. Eye opening</td><td>The patient's eyes typically should be open (depending on time of day or presentation). Patient assessed in this level of consciousness should be recorded as 'spontaneous' (score 4).</td></tr><tr><td>(1) Observe the patient's eyes when entering the room.</td><td>Positive patient response should be recorded as eye opening 'to speech' (score 3).</td></tr><tr><td>(2) If the patient is not awake, give the patient a command such as: 'Open your eyes.'</td><td>Positive patient response should be recorded as eye opening 'to pain' (score 2).</td></tr><tr><td>(3) If the patient does not respond to verbal stimuli, assess their response to a painful stimulus (see motor response below); progress from light to deep stimulus.</td><td>Patient assessed in this level of consciousness should be recorded as 'no response' (score 1).</td></tr><tr><td>(4) There may be no response to speech or painful stimuli.</td><td>If answered correctly, patient response should be recorded as 'orientated' (score 5).</td></tr><tr><td>B. Best verbal response</td><td>If answered incorrectly, patient response should be recorded as 'onintated' (score 4).</td></tr><tr><td>(1) Assess orientation by seeking the best verbal response from the patient to simple questions: 'What is your name?' 'Where are you at the moment?' 'What day is it today?' 'Do you know what month it is?' 'Do you know what year it is?'</td><td>Patient response should be recorded as 'inappropriate words' (score 3).</td></tr><tr><td>(2) Patients should be able to hold a conversation and answer the above questions correctly.</td><td>Patient response should be recorded as 'incomprehensible sounds' (score 2).</td></tr><tr><td>(3) Patient may respond with single words and answer does not match the question asked.</td><td>Patient response should be recorded as 'no response' (score 1).</td></tr><tr><td>(4) Patient may respond with incomprehensible sounds only (such as moans and groans).</td><td>Positive patient response should be recorded as 'obeys commands' (score 6).</td></tr><tr><td>(5) There may be no response to any stimuli.</td><td>As neurological function deteriorates motor responses are reduced. A patient with serious neurological impairment exhibits abnormal posturing in response to pain.</td></tr><tr><td>C. Best motor response</td><td>Patient response should be recorded as 'localises to pain' (score 5).</td></tr><tr><td>(1) Assess the patient's ability to follow two simple commands such as: 'Stick out your tongue.' 'Lift up your arms.' 'Squeeze and let go of my hands.'</td><td>Patient response should be recorded as 'flexion withdrawal' (score 4).</td></tr><tr><td>(2) If patient is unable to perform the above activities, apply a central painful stimulus (e.g. trapezium squeeze) to determine the best arm response.</td><td>Patient response should be recorded as 'abnormal flexion' (score 3).</td></tr><tr><td>a. The patient may demonstrate purposeful movement to remove the painful stimulus, bringing the hand up to at least chin level.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>b. The patient may bend the arm at the elbows but fails to locate the pain.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>c. The patient may demonstrate abnormal flexion (decorticate posturing): flexion of the elbow, wrist and fingers, with adduction of the limb. Lower limbs may also be in extension, internal rotation and plantar flexion.</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>HEALTH ASSESSMENT AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION 31</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>d. The patient may demonstrate abnormal extension (decerebrate posturing): elbow extension, adduction and internal rotation with palm pronated. Lower limbs may also be in extension and plantar flexion.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>e. There may be no response after the application of a central painful stimulus.</td><td>Patient response should be recorded as â€˜abnormal extensionâ€™ (score 2).</td></tr><tr><td>6. Total GCS scores out of 15 and document on neurological observation chart.</td><td>Patient response should be recorded as â€˜no responseâ€™ (score 1).</td></tr><tr><td>7. Assess pupil reaction and gauge.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>a. Check pupillary response for shape, size (mm) and reaction to light.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>b. Use a pen torch to elicit a response from the pupilsâ€”shine the light from the peripheries of the eye, to the centre.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>c. Note pupillary response for both eyes, which should be brisk constriction to light.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>d. Measure pupil size, which should be equal.</td><td>Overall score or change in score determines need to report to medical officer.</td></tr><tr><td>8. Assess limb power.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>A. Bilateral upper limb muscle strength</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>

<p>B. Bilateral lower limb muscle strength
(1) Ask the patient to push down with their foot onto your hands against resistance.
(2) Ask the patient to lift up their foot against your hand with resistance.
(3) Apply gently pressure to the shins and ask the patient to extend and flex their legs against resistance. | Response is recorded on a continuum from normal through mild weakness, severe weakness, flexion, extension to no response.  |
|  9. Continue to perform neurological assessment as required by presentation and hospital protocol. | The GCS allows the evaluation of a patientâ€™s status over time. The higher the score, the more improved or normal the level of functioning.  |
|  RECORDING AND REPORTING | HOME CARE CONSIDERATIONS  |
|  â€¢ Record GCS scores with date and time of assessment. Report decrease in GCS by two or more points to medical officer immediately.
â€¢ Pupilsâ€™ response: document size of pupil (mm) and response to light.
â€¢ Limb movementsâ€™ response: document power of movements of arms and legs. | â€¢ Act FAST:
Face: check their faceâ€”has their mouth drooped?
Arms: can they lift both arms?
Speech: is their speech slurred? Do they understand you?
Time: is critical. If you see any of these signs, call for emergency medical assistance (National Stroke Foundation, 2012).  |

<p>HEALTH ASSESSMENT AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION 33</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>COMPETENCY CRITERIA</th><th>PERFORMANCE CRITERIA/EVIDENCE</th><th>I</th><th>S</th><th>A</th><th>M</th><th>D</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Performs clinical procedure</td><td>Neurological assessment</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Commences with a Glasgow Coma Scale score to measure level of consciousness</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>A. Eyes open
Score 1â€“4
(1) Observes patientâ€™s eyes when entering the room
(2) If the patient is not awake, gives patient a command such as â€˜Open your eyesâ€™
(3) If the patient does not respond to verbal stimuli, assesses their response to a painful stimulus (progresses from light to deep stimulus)
(4) No response to speech or painful stimuli</p>
<p>B. Orientation
Score 1â€“5
(1) Assesses orientation by seeking the best verbal response from patient to simple questions, e.g. â€˜What is your name?â€™, â€˜Where are you at the moment?â€™
(2) Patient should be able to hold a conversation and answer these questions correctly
(3) Patient responds with single words and answer does not match the question asked
(4) Patient responds with incomprehensible sounds only (such as moans and groans)
(5) There is no response to any stimuli</p>
<p>C. Best motor response
Score 1â€“6
(1) Assesses patientâ€™s ability to follow two simple commands such as â€˜Stick out your tongueâ€™, â€˜Lift up your armsâ€™, â€˜Squeeze and let go of my handsâ€™
(2) If patient is unable to perform the above activities, applies a central painful stimulus (e.g. trapezium squeeze) to determine the best arm response
a. Patient demonstrates purposeful movement to remove the painful stimulus, bringing the hand up to at least chin level
b. Patient bends the arm at the elbows but fails to locate the pain
c. Patient demonstrates abnormal flexion (decorticate posturing): flexion of the elbow, wrist and fingers, with adduction of the limb. Lower limbs may also be in extension, internal rotation and plantar flexion.
d. Patient demonstrates abnormal extension (decerebrate posturing): elbow extension, adduction and internal rotation with palm pronated. Lower limbs may also be in extension and plantar flexion.
e. There is no response after the application of a central painful stimulus.</p>
<p>GCS score: totals patientâ€™s score out of 15 and documents on neurological observation chart</p>
<p>Pupil reaction and gauge
a. Checks pupillary response for shape, size (mm) and reaction to light
b. Uses a pen torch to elicit a response from the pupils; shines light from the peripheries of the eye to the centre
c. Notes pupillary response for both eyes
d. Measures pupil size</p>
<p>Limb power
A. Bilateral upper limb muscle strength
(1) Asks patient to take examinerâ€™s hand and squeezes
(2) Asks patient to pull examinerâ€™s hands towards them against resistance
(3) Asks patient to push examinerâ€™s hands away against resistance |  |  |  |  |   |</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="vital-signs">Vital signs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vital-signs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="overview">Overview<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#overview" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Vital signs are the most frequent measurements obtained by nurses; they include temperature, pulse, respiratory rate and blood pressure. Vital sign assessment and interpretation are integral in determining a patient's health status. Careful measurement techniques and knowledge of the normal range in vital signs will ensure more accurate findings and interpretation of those findings. The primary indication for assessing a patient's vital signs is to establish a baseline for comparison of alterations in health. An important aim of measuring vital signs is to identify early patient deterioration.</p>
<p>Accurate monitoring and consistency in the method used to collect vital signs is essential. Variations in the methods used to collect a patient's vital signs may result in false identification of alterations in health patterns. Careful measurement techniques, knowledge of normal ranges and specifications of reportable altered vital signs parameters, and clear and effective communication channels for reporting abnormal patient vital signs and deterioration ensure more accurate interpretation in a timely manner.</p>
<p>Vital signs are routinely collected:</p>
<ul>
<li>on patient admission to a healthcare facility</li>
<li>before and after a surgical or an invasive procedure</li>
<li>before, during and after the administration of medications that affect cardiovascular, respiratory and temperature-control functions</li>
<li>as indicated by any significant change in the patient's health status</li>
<li>before and after nursing interventions that affect vital signs</li>
<li>if a patient reports nonspecific symptoms of physical distress</li>
<li>on a schedule according to agency policy or the medical practitioner's prescription.</li>
</ul>
<p>General observation charts exist for recording vital signs. The nurse needs to identify the institution's procedure for documenting information. In addition to the actual vital sign values, the nurse records in the patient's case notes any accompanying or precipitating symptoms, such as chest pain and dizziness with abnormal blood pressure, shortness of breath with abnormal respirations, cyanosis with hypoxaemia, or flushing and diaphoresis with elevated temperature. The nurse also documents any interventions initiated as a result of vital sign measurement, such as administration of oxygen therapy or antihypertensive medication.</p>
<p>This chapter explores the psychomotor skills that focus on specific nursing care of the patient requiring measurement and recording of vital signs. The skills addressed include measuring body temperature (28-1), assessing the radial and apical pulses (28-2), assessing respirations (28-3), measuring oxygen saturation (pulse oximetry, <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{SpO}_2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.9275em; vertical-align: -0.2441em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">SpO</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.207em;"><span style="top: -2.4559em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">â€‹</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.2441em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>) (28-4), measuring blood pressure (28-5) and performing a brief body systems assessment of the hospitalised patient (28-6).</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260125-cd80c601.jpeg" alt="img-3.jpeg"></p>
<p>FUNDAMENTALS OF NURSING: CLINICAL SKILLS WORKBOOK</p>
<p>SKILL 28-1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="measuring-body-temperature">Measuring body temperature<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#measuring-body-temperature" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="delegation-considerations">DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delegation-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Temperature measurement can be delegated to enrolled nurses (ENs).</p>
<ul>
<li>Inform EN of the frequency of temperature measurement.</li>
<li>Determine that EN is aware of the reportable levels for patient.</li>
<li>Inform EN of the need to report any abnormalities that should be reconfirmed by the nurse.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Appropriate thermometer</li>
<li>Pen, observation chart</li>
<li>Plastic thermometer sleeve or disposable probe cover</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="steps">STEPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Assess for signs and symptoms of temperature alterations and for factors that influence body temperature.</li>
<li>Determine any previous activity that would interfere with accuracy of temperature measurement. When taking oral temperature, wait 15â€“20 min before measuring temperature orally if patient has smoked or ingested hot or cold liquids or foods.</li>
<li>Determine appropriate temperature site and device for patient.</li>
<li>Explain how temperature will be taken and importance of maintaining proper position until reading is completed.</li>
<li>Perform hand hygiene.</li>
<li>Help patient assume comfortable position that provides easy access to temperature site.</li>
<li>Obtain temperature reading.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="a-oral-temperature-measurement-with-electronic-thermometer">A. Oral temperature measurement with electronic thermometer<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-oral-temperature-measurement-with-electronic-thermometer" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>(1) Put on oral probe cover
(2) Remove thermometer pack from charging unit. Attach oral probe (blue tip) to thermometer unit. Grasp top of probe stem, being careful not to put pressure on the ejection button.
(3) Slide disposable plastic probe cover over thermometer probe until cover locks in place (see illustration).
(4) Ask patient to open mouth; then gently place thermometer probe under tongue in posterior sublingual pocket lateral to centre of lower jaw.
(5) Ask patient to hold thermometer probe with lips closed.
(6) Leave thermometer probe in place until audible signal occurs and patient's temperature appears on digital display; remove thermometer probe from under patient's tongue.
(7) Push ejection button on thermometer stem to discard plastic probe cover into appropriate receptacle.
(8) Return probe to storage position of thermometer unit.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="rationale">RATIONALE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rationale" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Physical signs and symptoms may indicate abnormal temperature. Nurse can accurately assess nature of variations.</p>
<p>Smoking or oral intake of food or fluids can cause false temperature readings in oral cavity.</p>
<p>Chosen based on patient requirements, advantages and disadvantages of each site (see Box 28-6).</p>
<p>Reduces transmission of microorganisms.</p>
<p>Ensures comfort and accuracy of temperature reading.</p>
<p>Use of oral probe cover, which can be removed without physical contact, minimises need to wear gloves.</p>
<p>Charging provides battery power. Ejection button releases plastic probe cover from tip.</p>
<p>Soft plastic cover will not break in patient's mouth and prevents transmission of microorganisms between patients.</p>
<p>Heat from superficial blood vessels in sublingual pocket produces temperature reading. With electronic thermometer, temperatures in right and left posterior sublingual pocket are significantly higher than in area under front of tongue.</p>
<p>Maintains proper position of thermometer during recording.</p>
<p>Probe must stay in place until signal occurs to ensure accurate reading.</p>
<p>Reduces transmission of microorganisms.</p>
<p>Protects probe from damage. Returning probe automatically causes digital reading to disappear.</p>

</ol>

SKILL 28-2</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="assessing-the-radial-and-apical-pulses">Assessing the radial and apical pulses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#assessing-the-radial-and-apical-pulses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="delegation-considerations">DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delegation-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Pulse measurement can be delegated to enrolled nurses who are informed of:</p>
<ul>
<li>appropriate patient position when obtaining apical pulse measurement</li>
<li>appropriate duration of radial and apical pulse count</li>
<li>patient history or risk of irregular pulse</li>
<li>frequency of pulse measurement</li>
<li>the usual reportable levels for the patient</li>
<li>the need to report any abnormalities.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Stethoscope (apical pulse only)</li>
<li>Wristwatch with second-hand or a digital display</li>
<li>Pen, observation chart</li>
<li>Alcohol swab</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="steps">STEPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Determine need to assess radial or apical pulse:
a. Note risk factors for alterations in apical pulse.
b. Assess for signs and symptoms of altered stroke volume and cardiac output such as dyspnoea, fatigue, chest pain, orthopnoea, syncope, palpitations (person's unpleasant awareness of heartbeat), jugular venous distension, oedema of dependent body parts, cyanosis or pallor of skin.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Assess for factors that normally influence apical pulse rate and rhythm:
a. Age
b. Exercise
c. Position changes
d. Medications
e. Temperature
f. Emotional stress, anxiety, fear</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Determine previous baseline apical rate (if available) from patient's record.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Explain that pulse or heart rate is to be assessed. Encourage patient to relax and not speak.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Perform hand hygiene.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>If necessary, draw curtains around bed and/or close door.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Obtain pulse measurement.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="a-radial-pulse">A. Radial pulse<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-radial-pulse" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>(1) Help patient assume a supine or sitting position.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="rationale">RATIONALE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rationale" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Certain conditions place patients at risk of pulse alterations. Heart rhythm can be affected by heart disease, cardiac arrhythmias, onset of sudden chest pain or acute pain from any site, invasive cardiovascular diagnostic tests, surgery, sudden infusion of large volume of intravenous fluid, internal or external haemorrhage and administration of medications that alter heart function.</p>
<p>Physical signs and symptoms may indicate alteration in cardiac function.</p>
<p>Allows for accurate assessment of presence and significance of pulse alterations.</p>
<p>Acceptable range of pulse rate changes with age (see Table 28-2).</p>
<p>Physical activity requires an increase in cardiac output that is met by an increased heart rate and stroke volume.</p>
<p>Heart rate increases temporarily when changing from lying to sitting or standing position.</p>
<p>Antiarrhythmics, sympathomimetics and cardiotonics affect rate and rhythm of pulse; opioid analgesics and general anaesthetics slow heart rate; central nervous system stimulants such as caffeine increase heart rate.</p>
<p>Fever or exposure to warm environments increases heart rate; heart rate declines with hypothermia.</p>
<p>Results in stimulation of the sympathetic nervous system, which increases heart rate.</p>
<p>Allows nurse to assess for change in condition. Provides comparison with future apical pulse measurements.</p>
<p>Activity and anxiety can elevate heart rate. Patient's voice interferes with nurse's ability to hear sound when apical pulse is measured.</p>
<p>Reduces transmission of microorganisms.</p>
<p>Maintains privacy.</p>
<p>Provides easy access to pulse sites.</p>
<p>FUNDAMENTALS OF NURSING: CLINICAL SKILLS WORKBOOK</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>(2) If supine, place patient's forearm straight alongside or across lower chest or upper abdomen with wrist extended straight (see illustration). If sitting, bend patient's elbow 90 degrees and support lower arm on chair or on nurse's arm. Slightly flex the wrist with palm down.</td><td>Relaxed position of lower arm and extension of wrist permits full exposure of artery to palpation.</td></tr><tr><td>(3) Place tips of first two fingers of hand over groove along radial or thumb side of patient's inner wrist (see illustration).</td><td>Fingertips are the most sensitive parts of hand to palpate arterial pulsation.</td></tr><tr><td>(4) Lightly compress against radius, obliterate pulse initially and then relax pressure so pulse becomes easily palpable.</td><td>Pulse is more accurately assessed with moderate pressure. Too much pressure occludes pulse and impairs blood flow.</td></tr><tr><td>(5) Determine strength of pulse. Note whether thrust of vessel against fingertips is bounding, strong, weak or thready.</td><td>Strength reflects volume of blood ejected against arterial wall with each heart contraction.</td></tr><tr><td>(6) After pulse can be felt, look at watch's second-hand and begin to count rate; when second-hand hits number on dial, start counting with 0, then 1, 2 and so on.</td><td>Rate is determined accurately only after nurse is assured pulse can be palpated. Timing begins with 0. Count of 1 is first beat palpated after timing begins.</td></tr><tr><td>(7) If pulse is regular, count rate for 30 s and multiply total by 2.</td><td>A 30 s count is accurate for rapid, slow or regular pulse rates.</td></tr><tr><td>(8) If pulse is irregular, count rate for 60 s. Assess frequency and pattern of irregularity.</td><td>Inefficient contraction of heart fails to transmit pulse wave, interfering with cardiac output, resulting in irregular pulse. Longer time ensures accurate count.</td></tr><tr><td>Critical decision point: If pulse is irregular or rapid, assess for pulse deficit that may indicate alteration in cardiac output. Count apical pulse while colleague counts radial pulse. Begin apical pulse count out loud to simultaneously assess pulses. If pulse count differs by more than 2, a pulse deficit exists.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>B. Apical pulse</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(1) Help patient into supine or sitting position. Move aside bedclothes and gown to expose sternum and left side of chest.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(2) Locate anatomical landmarks to identify the point of maximal impulse (PMI), also called the apical impulse. Heart is located behind and to left of sternum with base at top and apex at bottom. Find angle of Louis just below suprasternal notch between sternal body and manubrium; can be felt as a bony prominence. Slip fingers down each side of angle to find second intercostal space (ICS). Carefully move fingers down left side of sternum to fifth ICS and laterally to the left midclavicular line (MCL). A light tap felt within an area 1â€“2 cm of the PMI is reflected from the apex of the heart.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(3) Place diaphragm of stethoscope in palm of hand for 5â€“10 s.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(4) Place diaphragm of stethoscope over PMI at the fifth ICS, at left MCL, and auscultate for normal S_{1} and S_{2} heart sounds (heard as 'lub-dub') (see illustration).</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(5) When S_{1} and S_{2} are heard with regularity, use watch's second hand and begin to count rate: when second hand hits number on dial, start counting with 0, then 1, 2 and so on.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(6) If apical rate is regular, count for 30 s and multiply by 2.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(7) If heart rate is irregular or patient is receiving cardiovascular medication, count for 1 min (60 s).</td><td>Exposes portion of chest wall for selection of auscultatory site.</td></tr><tr><td>Use of anatomical landmarks allows correct placement of stethoscope over apex of heart, enhancing ability to hear heart sounds clearly. If unable to palpate the PMI, reposition patient on left side. In the presence of serious heart disease, the PMI may be located to the left of the MCL or at the sixth ICS.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Warming of metal or plastic diaphragm prevents patient from being startled and promotes comfort.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Allow stethoscope tubing to extend straight without kinks that would distort sound transmission. Normal sounds S_{1} and S_{2} are high-pitched and best heard with the diaphragm.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Apical rate is determined accurately only after nurse is able to auscultate sounds clearly. Timing begins with 0. Count of 1 is first sound auscultated after timing begins.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Regular apical rate can be assessed within 30 s.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Irregular rate is more accurately assessed when measured over longer interval.</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>VITAL SIGNS 43</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>(8) Note regularity of any dysrhythmia (S_{2} and S_{3}) occurring early or later after previous sequence of sounds; for example, every third or every fourth beat is skipped).</td><td>Regular occurrence of dysrhythmia within 1 minute may indicate inefficient contraction of heart and alteration in cardiac output.</td></tr><tr><td>(9) Replace patientâ€™s gown and bedclothes; help patient return to comfortable position.</td><td>Restores comfort and promotes sense of wellbeing.</td></tr><tr><td>(10) Clean earpieces and diaphragm of stethoscope with alcohol swab as needed (optional).</td><td>Controls transmission of microorganisms when nurses share stethoscope.</td></tr><tr><td>8. Discuss findings with patient as needed.</td><td>Promotes participation in care and understanding of health status.</td></tr><tr><td>9. Perform hand hygiene.</td><td>Reduces transmission of microorganisms.</td></tr><tr><td>10. Compare readings with previous baseline and/or acceptable range of heart rate for patientâ€™s age (see Table 28-2).</td><td>Checks for change in condition and alterations.</td></tr><tr><td>11. Compare peripheral pulse rate with apical rate and note discrepancy.</td><td>Differences between measurements indicate pulse deficit and may warn of cardiovascular compromise. Abnormalities may require therapy.</td></tr><tr><td>12. Compare radial pulse equality and note discrepancy.</td><td>Differences between radial arteries indicate compromised peripheral vascular system.</td></tr><tr><td>13. Correlate pulse rate with data obtained from blood pressure and related signs and symptoms (palpitations, dizziness).</td><td>Pulse rate and blood pressure are interrelated.</td></tr><tr><td>RECORDING AND REPORTING</td><td>HOME CARE CONSIDERATIONS</td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Record pulse, noting the site used, in observation chart. Measurement of pulse rate after administration of specific therapies should be documented in narrative form in progress notes.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Report abnormal findings to nurse in charge or medical practitioner.</td><td>â€¢ Assess home environment to determine room that will afford quiet environment for auscultating apical rate.</td></tr></tbody></table>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="assessing-the-radial-and-apical-pulses">ASSESSING THE RADIAL AND APICAL PULSES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#assessing-the-radial-and-apical-pulses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<p>DEMONSTRATES: The ability to effectively and safely assess the radial and apical pulses</p>
