<p>SKILL 28-3</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="assessing-respirations">Assessing respirations<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#assessing-respirations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="delegation-considerations">DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delegation-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Respiration measurement can be delegated to enrolled nurses who are informed of:</p>
<ul>
<li>appropriate patient position when obtaining respirations</li>
<li>appropriate duration of respiratory rate count</li>
<li>patient history or risk of increased or decreased respiratory rate or irregular respirations</li>
<li>frequency of respirations measurement</li>
<li>the reportable levels for the patient</li>
<li>the need to report any abnormalities.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Wristwatch with second-hand or a digital display</li>
<li>Pen, observation chart</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="steps">STEPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Determine need to assess patient's respirations:</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Note risk factors for respiratory alterations.</p>
<p>b. Assess for signs and symptoms of respiratory alterations such as bluish or cyanotic appearance of nail beds, lips, mucous membranes and skin; restlessness, irritability, confusion, reduced level of consciousness; pain during inspiration; laboured or difficult breathing; adventitious breath sounds (see Chapter 27), inability to breathe spontaneously; thick, frothy, blood-tinged or copious sputum produced on coughing.</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Assess pertinent laboratory values:</li>
</ol>
<p>A. Arterial blood gases (ABGs). Normal ABGs (values may vary slightly within institutions):</p>
<p>pH 7.35â€“7.45</p>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{PaCO}_2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">PaCO</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">â€‹</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> 35â€“45 mmHg</p>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{PaO}_2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">PaO</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">â€‹</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> 80â€“100 mmHg</p>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{SaO}_2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">SaO</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">â€‹</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> 94â€“98%</p>
<p>B. Pulse oximetry <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(\mathrm{SpO}_2)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">SpO</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.207em;"><span style="top: -2.4559em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">â€‹</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.2441em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span>. Acceptable <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex-error" title="ParseError: KaTeX parse error: Expected 'EOF', got '&amp;' at position 16: \mathrm{SpO}_2 &amp;Ì²gt; 95\%" style="color: rgb(204, 0, 0);">\mathrm{SpO}_2 &amp;gt; 95\%</span></span> on room air. <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>88</mn><mo>âˆ’</mo><mn>92</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">88 - 92\%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">88</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">âˆ’</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">92%</span></span></span></span></span> may be acceptable for patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.</p>
<p>C. Full blood count (FBC). Normal FBC for adults (values may vary within institutions):</p>
<p>(1) Haemoglobin: males 130â€“180 g/L; females 115â€“165 g/L.
(2) Haematocrit: males 0.42â€“0.52%; females 0.35â€“0.47%.
(3) Red cells: males 4.50â€“6.50 Ã— 10Â¹Â²/L; females 3.90â€“5.60 Ã— 10Â¹Â²/L.</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>Determine previous baseline respiratory rate (if available) from patient's record.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="rationale">RATIONALE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rationale" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Certain conditions place patient at risk of alterations in ventilation detected by changes in respiratory rate, depth and rhythm. Fever, pain, anxiety, diseases of chest wall or muscles, constrictive chest or abdominal dressings, gastric distension, chronic pulmonary disease (emphysema, bronchitis, asthma), traumatic injury to chest wall with or without collapse of underlying lung tissue, presence of a chest tube, respiratory infection (pneumonia, acute bronchitis), pulmonary oedema and emboli, head injury with damage to brain stem and anaemia can result in respiratory alteration.</p>
<p>Physical signs and symptoms may indicate alterations in respiratory status related to ventilation.</p>
<p>Arterial blood gases measure arterial blood pH, partial pressure of oxygen <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(\mathrm{PaO}_2)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">PaO</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">â€‹</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span> and carbon dioxide <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(\mathrm{PaCO}_2)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">PaCO</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">â€‹</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span> and arterial oxygen saturation <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(\mathrm{SaO}_2)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">SaO</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">â€‹</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span>, which reflects patient's oxygenation status.</p>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{SpO}_2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.9275em; vertical-align: -0.2441em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">SpO</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.207em;"><span style="top: -2.4559em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">â€‹</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.2441em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> less than <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>85</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">85\%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">85%</span></span></span></span></span> is often accompanied by changes in respiratory rate, depth and rhythm.</p>
<p>Complete blood count measures red blood cell count, volume of red blood cells and concentration of haemoglobin, which reflects patient's capacity to carry oxygen and therefore influences interpretation of the results.</p>
<p>Allows nurse to assess for change in condition. Provides comparison with future respiratory measurements.</p>
<p>VITAL SIGNS 47</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>4. Be sure patient is in comfortable position, preferably sitting or lying with the head of the bed elevated 45â€“60 degrees.</td><td>Sitting erect promotes full ventilatory movement.</td></tr><tr><td>Critical decision point: Patients with difficulty breathing (dyspnoea), such as those with heart failure or abdominal ascites or in late stages of pregnancy, should be assessed in the position of greatest comfort. Repositioning may increase the work of breathing, which will increase respiratory rate.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>5. Draw curtain around bed and/or close door. Perform hand hygiene.</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<ol start="6">
<li>Be sure patientâ€™s chest is visible. If necessary, move bedclothes or gown.</li>
<li>Place patientâ€™s arm in relaxed position across the abdomen or lower chest, or place nurseâ€™s hand directly over patientâ€™s upper abdomen (see illustration).</li>
<li>Observe complete respiratory cycle (one inspiration and one expiration).</li>
<li>After cycle is observed, look at watchâ€™s second-hand and begin to count rate: when second-hand hits number on dial, begin timeframe, counting 1 with first full respiratory cycle.</li>
<li>If rhythm is regular, count number of respirations in 30 s and multiply by 2. If rhythm is irregular, &lt; 12 or &gt; 20, count for 1 full minute. | Maintains privacy. Prevents transmission of microorganisms.
Ensures clear view of chest wall and abdominal movements.
A similar position used during pulse assessment allows respiratory rate assessment to be inconspicuous. Patientâ€™s or nurseâ€™s hand rises and falls during respiratory cycle.
Rate is accurately determined only after nurse has viewed respiratory cycle.
Timing begins with count of 1. Respirations occur more slowly than pulse; thus timing does not begin with 0.
Respiratory rate is equivalent to number of respirations per minute. Suspected irregularities require assessment for at least 1 minute.  |
|  Critical decision point: Respiratory rate &lt; 12 or &gt; 20 requires further assessment (see Chapter 27) and may require immediate intervention.  |   |
|  11. Note depth of respirations, subjectively assessed by observing degree of chest wall movement while counting rate. Nurse can also objectively assess depth by palpating chest wall excursion or auscultating the posterior thorax after rate has been counted. Depth is described as shallow, normal or deep.</li>
<li>Note rhythm of ventilatory cycle. Normal breathing is regular and uninterrupted. Sighing should not be confused with abnormal rhythm. | Character of ventilatory movement may reveal specific disease state restricting volume of air from moving into and out of the lungs.
Character of ventilations can reveal specific types of alterations.  |
|  Critical decision point: Occasional periods of apnoea, the cessation of respiration for several seconds, are a symptom of underlying disease in the adult and must be reported to the medical practitioner or nurse in charge. An irregular respiratory rate and short apnoeic spells are usual in a newborn.  |   |
|  13. Replace bedclothes and patientâ€™s gown.</li>
<li>Perform hand hygiene.</li>
<li>Discuss findings with patient as needed.</li>
<li>If respirations are assessed for the first time, establish rate, rhythm and depth as baseline if within normal range.</li>
<li>Compare respirations with patientâ€™s previous baseline and normal rate, rhythm and depth. | Restores comfort and promotes sense of wellbeing.
Reduces transmission of microorganisms.
Promotes participation in care and understanding of health status.
Used to compare future respiratory assessment.
Allows assessment for changes in patientâ€™s condition and for presence of respiratory alterations.  |
|  RECORDING AND REPORTING | HOME CARE CONSIDERATIONS  |
|  â€¢ Record respiratory rate and character in nursesâ€™ notes and observation chart. Indicate type and amount of oxygen therapy if used by patient during assessment. Measurement of respiratory rate after administration of specific therapies should be documented in narrative form in nursesâ€™ notes.
â€¢ Report abnormal findings to nurse in charge or medical practitioner. | â€¢ Assess for environmental factors in the home that may influence patientâ€™s respiratory rate such as secondhand smoke, poor ventilation or gas fumes.  |</li>
</ol>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="assessing-respirations">ASSESSING RESPIRATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#assessing-respirations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>CLINICAL SKILL 28-3: Assessing respirations</p>
<p>DEMONSTRATES: The ability to effectively and safely assess respirations</p>
<p>DOMAIN/S (AUS): Professional Practice and Provision and Coordination of Care</p>
<p>DOMAIN/S (NZ): Professional responsibility; management of nursing care; interpersonal relationships; interprofessional healthcare and quality improvement</p>
<p>PERFORMANCE CRITERIA: (numbers indicate National Competency Standards for the Registered Nurse)</p>
<p>AUS 1.1, 1.2, 1.3, 2.1, 2.2, 2.3, 2.5, 2.6, 3.2, 4.1, 4.2, 5.1, 5.2, 7.1, 7.2, 7.3, 9.1, 9.2, 9.5, 10.1, 10.2</p>
<p>NZ 1.1, 1.2, 1.3, 1.4, 1.5, 2.1, 2.2, 2.4, 2.6, 2.8, 2.9, 3.1, 3.2, 3.3, 4.1, 4.3</p>

Australia</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Wears appropriate PPE</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Gathers equipment</td><td>Observation chart and pen</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Watch with second hand</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Clean non-sterile gloves if appropriate</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Prepares equipment</td><td>Draws curtains for privacy</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Therapeutic communication</td><td>Initiates communication by introductions and clarification relax and not to speak during procedure</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Assists patient to comfortable position (e.g. head of bed elevated to 45â€“60 degrees if not contraindicated)</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Performs clinical procedure</td><td>Maintains privacy</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Ensures patient's chest is visible, removes gown and excess bed linen if required</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Places patient's arm across abdomen or lower chest or places own hand over abdomen</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Observes and counts respiratory cycle (inspiration and expiration)</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>If respiration is regular, counts for 30 seconds and multiplies by 2; if rhythm is regular &lt; 12 or &gt; 20 breaths per minute, counts for 60 seconds</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>If respiration is irregular, counts for 60 seconds and assesses frequency and pattern of irregularity</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Observes depth, regularity and quality of respirations and chest wall expansion</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Replaces bed clothes/linen that may have been removed for procedure</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Assists patient to a comfortable position</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Compares respirations with baseline rate, rhythm and depth</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>

<p>SKILL 28-4</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="a023a037">Measuring oxygen saturation (pulse oximetry, <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="sans-serif">S</mi><mi mathvariant="sans-serif">p</mi><mi mathvariant="sans-serif">O</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathsf{SpO}_2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.9386em; vertical-align: -0.2441em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathsf">SpO</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.207em;"><span style="top: -2.4559em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">â€‹</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.2441em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a023a037" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="delegation-considerations">DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delegation-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Oxygen saturation measurement can be delegated to enrolled nurses who are informed of:</p>
<ul>
<li>need to notify nurse immediately of any reading lower than <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{SpO}_2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.9275em; vertical-align: -0.2441em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">SpO</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.207em;"><span style="top: -2.4559em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">â€‹</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.2441em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>90</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">90\%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">90%</span></span></span></span></span></li>
<li>appropriate sensor site, probe and patient position for measurement of oxygen saturation</li>
<li>frequency of oxygen saturation measurements</li>
<li>factors that can falsely lower <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{SpO}_2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.9275em; vertical-align: -0.2441em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">SpO</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.207em;"><span style="top: -2.4559em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">â€‹</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.2441em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> (Box 28-12).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Oximeter</li>
<li>Oximeter probe appropriate for patient and recommended by manufacturer</li>
<li>Pen, observation chart</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="steps">STEPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Determine need to measure patient's oxygen saturation:
a. Note risk factors for alteration of oxygen saturation.
b. Assess for signs and symptoms of alterations in oxygen saturation such as altered respiratory rate, depth or rhythm; adventitious breath sounds (see Chapter 27); cyanotic appearance of nail beds, lips, mucous membranes and skin; restlessness, irritability, confusion; reduced level of consciousness; laboured or difficulty breathing.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Assess for factors that normally influence measurement of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{SpO}_2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.9275em; vertical-align: -0.2441em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">SpO</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.207em;"><span style="top: -2.4559em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">â€‹</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.2441em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>, such as oxygen therapy, haemoglobin level and temperature.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Review patient's medical record for medical practitioner's order or consult agency policy or procedure manual for standard of care.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Determine previous baseline <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{SpO}_2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.9275em; vertical-align: -0.2441em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">SpO</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.207em;"><span style="top: -2.4559em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">â€‹</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.2441em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> (if available) from patient's record.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Explain purpose of procedure to patient and how oxygen saturation will be measured. Instruct patient to breathe normally.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Assess site most appropriate for sensor probe placement (e.g. digit, earlobe) (see Box 28-11). Site must have adequate local circulation and be free of moisture.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Perform hand hygiene.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Position patient comfortably. If finger is chosen as monitoring site, support lower arm.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Instruct patient to breathe normally.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>If finger is to be used, remove any fingernail polish with acetone from digit to be assessed. If earlobe is to be used, remove any earrings. Wash site, swab with alcohol and air-dry.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Attach sensor probe to monitoring site. Instruct patient that clip-on probe feels like a clothes peg on the finger but should not hurt.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="rationale">RATIONALE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rationale" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Certain conditions place patients at risk of decreased oxygen saturation: acute or chronic compromised respiratory function, recovery from general anaesthesia or conscious sedation or traumatic injury to chest wall with or without collapse of underlying lung tissue, ventilator dependence, changes in supplemental oxygen therapy.</p>
<p>Physical signs and symptoms may indicate abnormal oxygen saturation.</p>
<p>Allows for accurate assessment of oxygen saturation variations. Peripheral vasoconstriction related to hypothermia can interfere with <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{SpO}_2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.9275em; vertical-align: -0.2441em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">SpO</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.207em;"><span style="top: -2.4559em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">â€‹</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.2441em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> determination.</p>
<p>Medical order may be required to assess oxygen saturation.</p>
<p>Baseline information provides basis for comparison and helps in assessment of current status and evaluation of interventions.</p>
<p>Promotes patient cooperation and increases compliance. Prevents large fluctuations in minute ventilation and possible error in <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{SpO}_2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.9275em; vertical-align: -0.2441em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">SpO</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.207em;"><span style="top: -2.4559em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">â€‹</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.2441em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> readings.</p>
<p>Peripheral vasoconstriction can interfere with <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{SpO}_2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.9275em; vertical-align: -0.2441em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">SpO</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.207em;"><span style="top: -2.4559em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">â€‹</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.2441em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> determination. Dark nail polish and acrylic nails impede sensor detection of emitted light and produce falsely elevated <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{SpO}_2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.9275em; vertical-align: -0.2441em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">SpO</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.207em;"><span style="top: -2.4559em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">â€‹</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.2441em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>.</p>
<p>Reduces transmission of microorganisms.</p>
<p>Ensures probe positioning and decreases movement that interferes with <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{SpO}_2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.9275em; vertical-align: -0.2441em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">SpO</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.207em;"><span style="top: -2.4559em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">â€‹</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.2441em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> determination.</p>
<p>Prevents large fluctuations in respiratory rate and depth and possible changes in <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{SpO}_2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.9275em; vertical-align: -0.2441em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">SpO</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.207em;"><span style="top: -2.4559em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">â€‹</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.2441em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>.</p>
<p>Ensures accurate readings. Opaque coatings decrease light transmission; nail polish containing blue pigment can absorb light emissions and falsely alter saturation.</p>
<p>Pressure of sensor probe's spring tension on a peripheral digit or earlobe may be unexpected.</p>
<p>VITAL SIGNS 51</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Critical decision point: Do not attach probe to finger, ear or bridge of nose if area is oedematous or skin integrity is compromised. Do not attach probe to fingers that are hypothermic. Select ear or bridge of nose if adult patient has history of peripheral vascular disease. Earlobe and bridge of nose sensors are not used for infants and toddlers because of skin fragility. Disposable adhesive probes contain latex and should not be used if patient has latex allergy.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>12. Turn on oximeter by activating power. Observe pulse waveform/intensity display and audible beep. Correlate oximeter pulse rate with patient's radial pulse. Differences require re-evaluation of oximeter probe placement and may require reassessment of pulse rates.</td><td>Pulse waveform/intensity display enables detection of valid pulse or presence of interfering signal. Pitch of audible beep is proportional to SpO_{2} value. Double-checking pulse rate ensures oximeter accuracy. Oximeter pulse rate, patient's radial pulse and apical pulse rate should be the same.</td></tr><tr><td>13. Leave probe in place until oximeter readout reaches constant value and pulse display reaches full strength during each cardiac cycle. Read SpO_{2} on digital display. Inform patient that oximeter will sound alarm if the probe falls off or if patient moves the probe.</td><td>Reading may take 10â€“30 s, depending on site selected.</td></tr><tr><td>14. If continuous SpO_{2} monitoring is planned, verify SpO_{2} alarm limits and alarm volume, which are preset by the manufacturer at a low of 85% and a high of 100%. Limits for SpO_{2} and pulse rate should be determined as indicated by patient's condition. Verify that alarms are on. Assess skin integrity under sensor probe and relocate sensor probe at least every 4 hours (every 2 hours for a spring-tension probe).</td><td>Alarms must be set at appropriate limits and volumes to avoid frightening patients and visitors. Spring tension of sensor probe or sensitivity to disposable sensor probe adhesive can cause skin irritation and lead to disruption of skin integrity.</td></tr><tr><td>15. Discuss findings with patient as needed.</td><td>Promotes participation in care and understanding of health status.</td></tr><tr><td>16. If intermittent or spot-checking SpO_{2} measurements are planned, remove probe and turn oximeter power off. Clean probe following manufacturer's instructions and store in appropriate location.</td><td>Batteries can be depleted if oximeter is left on. Sensor probes are expensive and vulnerable to damage.</td></tr><tr><td>17. Help patient return to comfortable position.</td><td>Restores comfort and promotes sense of wellbeing.</td></tr><tr><td>18. Perform hand hygiene.</td><td>Reduces transmission of microorganisms.</td></tr><tr><td>19. Compare SpO_{2} readings with patient baseline and acceptable values.</td><td>Comparison reveals presence of abnormality.</td></tr><tr><td>20. Correlate SpO_{2} with SaO_{2} obtained from arterial blood gas measurements (see Chapter 39) if available.</td><td>Documents reliability of non-invasive assessment.</td></tr><tr><td>21. Correlate SpO_{2} reading with data obtained from respiratory rate, depth and rhythm assessment.</td><td>Measurements assessing ventilation, perfusion and diffusion are interrelated.</td></tr><tr><td>RECORDING AND REPORTING</td><td>HOME CARE CONSIDERATIONS</td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Record SpO_{2} value on patient progress notes and observation chart, indicating type and amount of oxygen therapy used by patient during assessment. Also record any signs and symptoms of oxygen desaturation in narrative form in progress notes. Measurement of SpO_{2} after administration of specific therapies should be documented in narrative form in progress notes.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Report abnormal findings to nurse in charge or medical practitioner. Assessment of oxygen saturation after administration of specific therapies should be documented in narrative form in progress notes.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Record in progress notes patient's use of continuous or intermittent pulse oximetry.</td><td>â€¢ Pulse oximetry is used in home care to non-invasively monitor oxygen therapy or changes in oxygen therapy.</td></tr></tbody></table>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="c29ba4e4">MEASURING OXYGEN SATURATION (PULSE OXIMETRY, SpOâ‚‚)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c29ba4e4" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>CLINICAL SKILL 28-4: Measuring oxygen saturation (pulse oximetry, SpOâ‚‚)</p>
<p>DEMONSTRATES: The ability to effectively and safely measure oxygen saturations</p>
<p>DOMAIN/S (AUS): Professional Practice and Provision and Coordination of Care</p>
<p>DOMAIN/S (NZ): Professional responsibility; management of nursing care; interpersonal relationships; interprofessional healthcare and quality improvement</p>

<p>SKILL 28-5</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="measuring-blood-pressure-bp">Measuring blood pressure (BP)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#measuring-blood-pressure-bp" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="delegation-considerations">DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delegation-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Blood pressure measurement can be delegated to enrolled nurses who are informed of:</p>
<ul>
<li>appropriate patient position when obtaining blood pressure measurement</li>
<li>alterations affecting the appropriate limb for blood pressure measurement</li>
<li>appropriate-size blood pressure cuff for designated extremity</li>
<li>patient's risk of orthostatic hypotension</li>
<li>frequency of blood pressure measurement</li>
<li>reportable levels for the patient</li>
<li>the need to report any abnormalities.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Aneroid or mercury sphygmomanometer</li>
<li>Cloth or disposable vinyl pressure cuff of appropriate size for patient's extremity</li>
<li>Stethoscope</li>
<li>Alcohol swab</li>
<li>Pen, observation chart</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="steps">STEPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Determine need to assess patient's BP:</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Note risk factors for alteration in BP.</p>
<p>b. Observe for signs and symptoms of BP alterations:</p>
<p>(1) High BP (hypertension) is often asymptomatic until pressure is very high. Assess for headache (usually occipital), flushing of face, nosebleed, and fatigue in older adults.</p>
<p>(2) Low BP (hypotension) is associated with: dizziness, mental confusion; restlessness; pale, dusky or cyanotic skin and mucous membranes; cool, mottled skin over extremities.</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>
<p>Determine best site for BP assessment. Avoid applying cuff to extremity when: intravenous fluids are infusing; an arteriovenous shunt or fistula is present; breast or axillary surgery has been performed on that side; extremity has been traumatised, is diseased or requires a cast or bulky bandage. The lower extremities may be used when the brachial arteries are inaccessible.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Select appropriate cuff size.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Determine previous baseline BP (if available) from patient's record.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Encourage patient to avoid exercise and smoking for 30 min before assessment of BP.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Have patient assume sitting or lying position. Be sure room is warm, quiet and relaxing.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Explain to patient that BP is to be assessed and have patient rest at least 5 min before measurement. Ask patient not to speak when BP is being measured.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="rationale">RATIONALE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rationale" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Certain conditions place patients at risk of BP alteration: history of cardiovascular disease, renal disease, diabetes, circulatory shock (hypovolaemic, septic, cardiogenic or neurogenic), acute or chronic pain, rapid intravenous infusion of fluids or blood products, increased intracranial pressure, postoperative conditions, toxaemia of pregnancy.</p>
<p>Physical signs and symptoms may indicate alterations in BP. (See Table 28-6 for average optimal blood pressure for age.)</p>
<p>Inappropriate site selection may result in poor amplification of sounds, causing inaccurate readings. Application of pressure from inflated bladder temporarily impairs blood flow and can further compromise circulation in extremity that already has impaired blood flow.</p>
<p>Improper cuff size results in inaccurate readings (see Table 28-9). If cuff is too small, it tends to come loose while being inflated or results in false high readings. If the cuff is too large, false low readings may be recorded.</p>
<p>Allows assessment for change in condition. Provides comparison with future BP measurements.</p>
<p>Exercise and smoking can cause false elevations in BP.</p>
<p>Maintains patient's comfort during measurement. The patient's perception that the physical or interpersonal environment is stressful affect the BP measurement.</p>
<p>Reduces anxiety that can falsely elevate readings. Blood pressure readings taken at different times can be objectively compared when assessed with patient at rest. Talking to a patient when the BP is being assessed increases readings by 10â€“40%.</p>
<p>VITAL SIGNS 55</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>8. Perform hand hygiene. With patient sitting or lying, position patient's forearm or thigh, supported if needed. For arm, turn palm up; for thigh, position with knee slightly flexed.</td><td>Reduces transmission of microorganisms. If extremity is unsupported, patient may perform isometric exercise that can increase diastolic blood pressure.</td></tr><tr><td>9. Expose extremity (arm or leg) fully by removing constricting clothing.</td><td>Ensures proper cuff application.</td></tr><tr><td>10. Palpate brachial artery (arm); see illustration or popliteal artery (leg). Position cuff 2.5 cm above site of pulsation (antecubital or popliteal).</td><td>Inflating bladder directly over artery ensures proper pressure is applied during inflation.</td></tr><tr><td>11. Apply bladder of cuff above artery by centring arrows marked on cuff over artery. If there are not centre arrows on cuff, estimate the centre of the bladder and place this centre over artery. With cuff fully deflated, wrap cuff evenly and snugly around extremity.</td><td>Loose-fitting cuff causes false high readings.</td></tr><tr><td>12. Position manometer vertically at eye level. Observer should be no further than 1 m away.</td><td>Accurate readings are obtained by looking at the meniscus of the mercury at eye level. The meniscus is the point where the crescent-shaped top of the mercury column aligns with the manometer scale. Looking up or down at the mercury results in distorted readings.</td></tr><tr><td>13. If you do not know the patient's baseline BP, estimate systolic pressure by palpating the artery distal to the cuff, i.e. radial artery, with fingertips of one hand while inflating cuff rapidly to pressure 30 mmHg above point at which pulse disappears. Slowly deflate cuff and note point when pulse reappears. Deflate cuff fully and wait 30 s.</td><td>Estimating prevents false low readings, which may result in the presence of an auscultatory gap. Maximal inflation point for accurate reading can be determined by palpation. If unable to palpate artery because of weakened pulse, an ultrasonic stethoscope can be used. Deflating cuff prevents venous congestion and false high readings.</td></tr><tr><td>14. Place stethoscope earpieces in ears and be sure sounds are clear, not muffled.</td><td>Each earpiece should follow angle of ear canal to facilitate hearing.</td></tr><tr><td>15. Relocate brachial or popliteal artery and place bell or diaphragm chestpiece of stethoscope over it. Do not allow chestpiece to touch cuff or clothing.</td><td>Proper stethoscope placement ensures optimal sound reception. Stethoscope improperly positioned causes muffled sounds that often result in false low systolic and false high diastolic readings.</td></tr><tr><td>16. Close valve of pressure bulb clockwise until tight. Rapidly inflate cuff to 30 mmHg above palpated systolic pressure.</td><td>Tightening of valve prevents air leak during inflation. Inflation ensures accurate measurement of systolic pressure.</td></tr><tr><td>17. Slowly release pressure bulb valve and allow mercury or needle of aneroid manometer gauge to fall at rate of 2â€“3 mmHg/s.</td><td>Too rapid or slow a decline in mercury level or aneroid pressure can cause inaccurate readings.</td></tr><tr><td>18. Note point on manometer when first clear sound is heard. The sound will slowly increase in intensity.</td><td>First Korotkoff sound indicates systolic pressure.</td></tr><tr><td>19. Continue to deflate cuff, noting point at which muffled or dampened sound appears.</td><td>Fourth Korotkoff sound involves distinct muffling of sounds and is recommended as indication of diastolic pressure in children.</td></tr><tr><td>20. Continue to deflate cuff gradually, noting point at which sound disappears in adults. Listen for 10â€“20 mmHg after the last sound, and then allow remaining air to escape quickly.</td><td>Beginning of the fifth Korotkoff sound is recommended as indication of diastolic pressure in adults.</td></tr><tr><td>21. Remove cuff from extremity unless measurement must be repeated. If this is the first assessment of patient, repeat procedure on other extremity.</td><td>Continuous cuff inflation causes arterial occlusion, resulting in numbness and tingling of patient's arm. Comparison of BP in both extremities detects circulation problems. (Normal difference of 5â€“10 mmHg exists between extremities.)</td></tr><tr><td>22. Help patient return to comfortable position and cover upper arm if previously clothed.</td><td>Restores comfort and promotes sense of wellbeing.</td></tr><tr><td>23. Discuss findings with patient as needed.</td><td>Promotes participation in care and understanding of health status.</td></tr><tr><td>24. Perform hand hygiene.</td><td>Reduces transmission of microorganisms.</td></tr><tr><td>25. Compare reading with previous baseline and/or acceptable value of blood pressure for patient's age.</td><td>Checks for change in condition and alterations.</td></tr><tr><td>26. Compare blood pressure in both arms or both legs.</td><td>If using upper extremities, the arm with the higher pressure should be used for subsequent assessments unless contraindicated.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>FUNDAMENTALS OF NURSING: CLINICAL SKILLS WORKBOOK</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>27. Correlate blood pressure with data obtained from pulse assessment and related cardiovascular signs and symptoms.</td><td>Blood pressure and heart rate are interrelated.</td></tr><tr><td>RECORDING AND REPORTING</td><td>HOME CARE CONSIDERATIONS</td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Inform patient of value and need for periodic reassessment.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Record blood pressure on observation chart and in progress notes if necessary. Measurement of blood pressure after administration of specific therapies should be documented in narrative form in progress notes.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Report abnormal findings to nurse in charge or medical practitioner.</td><td>â€¢ Assess home noise level to determine room that will provide quietest environment for assessing BP.</td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Consider electronic blood pressure cuff for home if patient has hearing difficulties and if patient has sufficient financial resources.</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>VITAL SIGNS 57</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="measuring-blood-pressure-bp">MEASURING BLOOD PRESSURE (BP)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#measuring-blood-pressure-bp" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>CLINICAL SKILL 28-5: Measuring blood pressure (BP)</p>
<p>DEMONSTRATES: The ability to effectively and safely measure blood pressure</p>
<p>DOMAIN/S (AUS): Professional Practice and Provision and Coordination of Care</p>
<p>DOMAIN/S (NZ): Professional responsibility; management of nursing care; interpersonal relationships; interprofessional healthcare and quality improvement</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="brief-body-systems-assessment-of-the-hospitalised-patient">Brief body systems assessment of the hospitalised patient<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#brief-body-systems-assessment-of-the-hospitalised-patient" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="delegation-considerations">DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delegation-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Initial baseline patient assessment is the basis for the development of the nursing care plan and therefore should not be delegated by the registered nurse.</p>
<ul>
<li>Ongoing patient assessment may be delegated to an enrolled nurse who should report any abnormal findings.</li>
<li>All staff should perform hand hygiene and wear personal protective equipment when appropriate before and during patient assessment.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Pen</li>
<li>Penlight torch</li>
<li>Pulse oximeter</li>
<li>Stethoscope</li>
<li>Sphygmomanometer</li>
<li>Thermometer</li>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="steps">STEPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Before you begin the active part of the physical examination, perform a rapid visual assessment of the patient and their environment for important cues.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Primary survey</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>A. Airwayâ€”is the airway clear?
(1) Look for rise and fall of the chest.
(2) Listen for noisy or obstructed breathing.
(3) Feel for airflow over the mouth.
(4) If indicated, assess whether artificial airway is patent and secure (e.g. Guedel, nasopharyngeal, tracheostomy, endotracheal tube, non-invasive mask).</p>
<p>B. Breathingâ€”is the patient breathing spontaneously?
(1) Observe respirations and skin colour.
(2) Listen for air entry.</p>
<p>C. Circulationâ€”does the patient have adequate circulation?
(1) Observe skin colour.
(2) Feel pulse and warmth.</p>
<p>D. Disabilityâ€”what is the patient's level of consciousness?
(1) Determine if the patient is alert, responsive to voice, responsive to pain or unresponsive.</p>
<p>E. Exposureâ€”perform a quick head-to-toe scan of the patient and their environment:
(1) Does the patient look well, sick or critical?
(2) What treatments are in progress and how might these affect your assessment findings (e.g. medications, infusions, oxygen)?
(3) What monitoring devices or equipment are attached to the patient or in their environment, and what do they reveal?</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>Neurological</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Assess level of consciousness and mental status.
b. If indicated, perform a focused neurological assessment (see Skill 27-6), including Glasgow Coma Scale, pupil size and reaction, limb assessment and vital signs
c. If indicated, perform a mental state examination (see Skill 27-5).
d. Assess for pain or discomfort.
e. If indicated, perform a focused pain assessment (see Skill 41-1) using a pain assessment tool.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="rationale">RATIONALE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rationale" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Based on your nursing knowledge and information from handover, some of your observations will be expected. Allows you to determine if there is equipment in use that you need education about before you take over care.</p>
<p>The primary survey is concerned with identifying life-threatening circumstances that require immediate attention. The mnemonic ABCDE is utilised.</p>
<p>To apply knowledge of normal adult neurological parameters to this patient's assessment data.</p>
<p>FUNDAMENTALS OF NURSING: CLINICAL SKILLS WORKBOOK</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="brief-body-systems-assessment-of-the-hospitalised-patient">BRIEF BODY SYSTEMS ASSESSMENT OF THE HOSPITALISED PATIENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#brief-body-systems-assessment-of-the-hospitalised-patient" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>CLINICAL SKILL 28-6: Brief body systems assessment of the hospitalised patient</p>
<p>DEMONSTRATES: The ability to effectively and safely perform a brief body systems assessment of the hospitalised patient</p>
<p>DOMAIN/S (AUS): Professional Practice and Provision and Coordination of Care</p>
<p>DOMAIN/S (NZ): Professional responsibility; management of nursing care; interpersonal relationships; interprofessional healthcare and quality improvement</p>
