<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="infection-control">Infection control<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#infection-control" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="overview">Overview<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#overview" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Good health depends in part on a safe environment. Patients in all healthcare settings are at risk of acquiring infections because of their lowered resistance to infectious microorganisms and increased exposure to disease-causing microorganisms and invasive procedures. In acute care or day care facilities, or even in the home, patients can be exposed to pathogens, some of which may be resistant to most antibiotics. Practising effective infection prevention and control techniques can minimise transmission of infection and protect patients and healthcare workers from disease.</p>
<p>Patient education, including information concerning infections, modes of transmission and methods of prevention, is essential if patients and their families are to recognise sources of infections and implement protective measures. The modes of transmission relevant to specific infections should be thoroughly understood. Infection can be transmitted through direct contact (touch), droplet contact (body fluids), airborne spread (air currents), contaminated articles, food, water and vectors (insects or rodents). Healthcare workers can protect themselves from contact with infectious material or exposure to communicable diseases by understanding the infection process and implementing appropriate infection-control practices such as standard and transmission-based precautions.</p>
<p>One of the most common complications associated with hospitalised patients is infection. The nurse plays a pivotal role in preventing cross-contamination and the spread of infection. Universal practices used by nurses to minimise the spread of infection include a sound knowledge of the chain of infection and infection-control practices, implementation of aseptic techniques and practices, frequent handwashing, preparation and maintenance of the sterile field, opening sterile objects, pouring sterile solutions from a bottle, applying sterile gowns and gloves and patient education.</p>
<p>This chapter explores the psychomotor skills that focus on specific nursing care associated with infection-control practices in the healthcare setting. The skills addressed include handwashing (29-1), preparing an aseptic field (29-2), surgical handwashing (scrubbing): preparing for gowning and gloving (29-3), open gloving (29-4) and donning a sterile gown and performing closed gloving (29-5).</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260125-b14b5883.jpeg" alt="img-4.jpeg"></p>
<p>66 FUNDAMENTALS OF NURSING: CLINICAL SKILLS WORKBOOK</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="handwashing">Handwashing<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#handwashing" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="delegation-considerations">DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delegation-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>All staff caring for patients must wash their hands using correct handwashing techniques. All staff and carers should:</p>
<ul>
<li>Gain instruction and demonstrate competency in correct handwashing techniques.</li>
<li>Report any skin irritation from soaps or antimicrobial solutions immediately.</li>
<li>Gain instruction regarding the importance of caring for and maintaining the integrity of their skin.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Accessible sink with warm running water</li>
<li>Antimicrobial or regular soap solution</li>
<li>Paper towels or air dryer</li>
<li>Disposable plastic nail pick (optional)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="steps">STEPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Inspect surface of hands for breaks or cuts in skin or cuticles. Report and cover lesions before providing patient care.</li>
<li>Inspect hands for heavy soiling.</li>
<li>Ensure nails are short and free of nail polish and/or artificial nails. Do not tear or cut skin under or around nail.</li>
<li>Assess patientâ€™s risk of or extent of infection, e.g. white blood cell count, extent of open wounds, known medical diagnosis.</li>
<li>Remove all jewellery including wristwatch, rings and bracelets.</li>
<li>Stand in front of sink, keeping hands and uniform away from sink surface. (If hands touch sink during handwashing, repeat.)</li>
<li>Turn on water and regulate flow and temperature so that temperature is warm.</li>
<li>Avoid splashing water against uniform.</li>
<li>Regulate temperature and intensity of flow.</li>
<li>Wet hands and wrists thoroughly under running water. Keep hands and forearms higher than elbows during washing.</li>
<li>Apply a small amount of soap or antimicrobial solution, lather thoroughly.</li>
<li>Wash hands using plenty of lather and friction for at least 15 seconds. Interlace fingers and rub palms, sides and back of hands with circular motion at least 5 times each (see illustration).</li>
<li>Areas underlying fingernails are often soiled. Clean with fingernails with a plastic, disposable nail pick.</li>
<li>Rinse hands and wrists thoroughly (see illustration).</li>
<li>Gently pat hands dry from fingers to wrists and forearms with paper towel.</li>
<li>Discard paper or towel into the proper receptacle.</li>
<li>Turn off water with foot or knee pedals. To turn off hand tap, use clean, dry paper towel; avoid touching handles with hands (see illustration).</li>
<li>If hands are dry or chapped, a small amount of lotion or barrier cream can be applied.</li>
<li>Inspect hands for obvious signs of debris and contamination.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="rationale">RATIONALE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rationale" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Open cuts or wounds can harbour high concentrations of microorganisms. Agency policy may prevent nurses from caring for high-risk patients.</p>
<p>Requires more-lengthy handwash.</p>
<p>Most microbes on hands come from beneath the fingernails.</p>
<p>Transmission-based precautions such as the wearing of a mask and clean gown may be required for immunocompromised patients.</p>
<p>Jewellery can harbour microbes and rub against skin causing shedding of skin cells.</p>
<p>The inside of the sink is considered a contaminated area. Reaching over sink increases risk of touching edge, which is contaminated.</p>
<p>Warm water is more comfortable and it removes less of the skinâ€™s protective oils than hot water.</p>
<p>Microorganisms multiply in moisture.</p>
<p>Warm water is most comfortable.</p>
<p>Keeping hands elevated allows water to flow form least to most contaminated areas.</p>
<p>The amount applied should be as per the manufacturerâ€™s instructions.</p>
<p>Soap cleans by emulsifying fat and oils. Friction and rubbing mechanically will loosen and remove debris and transient bacteria. Interlacing the fingers and thumbs helps to ensure all surfaces are cleaned.</p>
<p>Most microbes on hands come from beneath the fingernails.</p>
<p>Rinsing mechanically washes away debris and microorganisms.</p>
<p>Drying from cleanest (fingertips) to least clean (forearms) area avoids contamination.</p>
<p>Gently patting hands dry helps prevents chapping and roughened skin.</p>
<p>Prevents transfer of microorganisms.</p>
<p>Minimises contamination of hands.</p>
<p>If dermatitis occurs, additional interventions may be needed.</p>
<p>If found, indicates poor technique. Handwashing should be repeated.</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="handwashing">HANDWASHING<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#handwashing" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>CLINICAL SKILL 29-1: Handwashing</p>
<p>DEMONSTRATES: The ability to effectively demonstrate handwashing techniques</p>
<p>DOMAIN/S (AUS): Professional Practice and Provision and Coordination of Care</p>
<p>DOMAIN/S (NZ): Professional responsibility; management of nursing care; interprofessional communication and documentation</p>
<p>PERFORMANCE CRITERIA: (numbers indicate National Competency Standards for the Registered Nurse)</p>
<p>AUS 1.1, 1.2, 1.3, 2.2, 2.5, 3.2, 4.1, 4.2, 7.1, 7.3, 9.5</p>
<p>NZ 1.1, 1.2, 1.3, 1.4, 2.5, 2.8, 4.3</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>COMPETENCY CRITERIA</th><th>PERFORMANCE CRITERIA/EVIDENCE</th><th>I</th><th>S</th><th>A</th><th>M</th><th>D</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Identifies indication/rationale</td><td>Identifies patient-related procedures and care that require minimising risks for infection</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Assesses patient/self</td><td>Inspects skin integrity for breaks/cuts; reports and covers lesions before providing patient care</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Inspects hands for heavy soiling</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Removes jewellery from hands</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Reviews patient's medical chart and pathology reports</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Gathers equipment</td><td>Sink with running warm water</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Antimicrobial or regular soap solution</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Paper towels</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Disposable plastic nail pick (optional)</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Prepares equipment</td><td>Turns on tap, minimising splashing</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Regulates water temperature to tepid</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Therapeutic communication</td><td>Clarifies purpose of handwashing procedure</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Reviews procedure against agency policy</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Performs clinical procedure</td><td>Wets hands/wrists thoroughly</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Applies small amount of soap</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Rubs into a lather</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Washes hands using plenty of lather and friction for 15â€“30 seconds; interlaces fingers, palms of hands, sides and backs of hands using a circular motion at least 5 times</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Cleans areas under fingernails with a nail pick</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Rinses hands and wrists thoroughly keeping hands above elbows</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Turns water off using foot pedal or uses elbows to turn off hand-operated taps</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Gently pats hands dry from finger tips to wrists then elbows using paper towel</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Inspects hands for any debris or contamination</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Inspects hands for dermatitis or cracked skin</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Cleans and disposes of equipment appropriately</td><td>Disposes of used equipment in appropriate receptacle</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Cleans and restocks equipment as required (e.g. soap, paper towels)</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Completes documentation</td><td>It is not necessary to record or report this procedure</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Reports any dermatitis to employee health and/or infection control as per agency policy</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>

SKILL 29-2</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="preparing-an-aseptic-field">Preparing an aseptic field<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#preparing-an-aseptic-field" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="delegation-considerations">DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delegation-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Preparing an aseptic field requires specialised knowledge regarding surgical asepsis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Sterile drapes</li>
<li>Assorted sterile supplies</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="steps">STEPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Prepare aseptic field just before planned procedure. Supplies are to be used immediately.</li>
<li>Work surfaces should be above waist level. Clean the work surface with an antiseptic solution and dry thoroughly.</li>
<li>Check all necessary equipment is present and inspect the integrity of packaging.</li>
<li>Check chemical indicators on supplies that indicate sterility of equipment. Scan barcodes of items or attach labels to patient documentation to enable effective tracking of sterilised items.</li>
<li>Apply personal protective attire.</li>
<li>Wash and dry hands thoroughly.</li>
<li>Place pack containing sterile drape on work surface and open as shown in Figure 29-10.</li>
<li>With fingertips of one hand, pick up folded top edge of sterile drape.</li>
<li>Gently lift drape up from its outer cover and let it unfold by itself without touching any object. Discard outer cover with your other hand.</li>
<li>With other hand, grasp adjacent corner of drape and hold it straight up and away from your body (see illustration).</li>
<li>Holding drape, first position and lay bottom half over intended work surface (see illustration).</li>
<li>Allow top half of drape to be placed over work surface last (see illustration).</li>
<li>Grasp 2.5 cm border around edge to position as needed.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="adding-sterile-items">ADDING STERILE ITEMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#adding-sterile-items" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol start="14">
<li>Open sterile item (following package directions) while holding outside wrapper in non-dominant hand.</li>
<li>Carefully peel wrapper onto non-dominant hand.</li>
<li>Being sure wrapper does not fall down on aseptic field, place item onto field at angle. Do not hold arm over aseptic field (see illustration).</li>
<li>Dispose of outer wrapper.</li>
<li>Pouring sterile solutions:
a. Verify contents and expiration date of solution.
b. Ensure receiving container for solution is on or near edge of aseptic field. Some aseptic field kits have cups or moulded plastic sections into which fluids can be poured.
c. Remove sterile seal and cap from bottle in an upward motion. Holding bottle away from aseptic field with label facing up and the bottle lip 3â€“4 cm over inside of receiving container, slowly pour contents into container (see Figure 29-11).</li>
<li>Perform procedure using aseptic non-touch technique.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="recording-and-reporting">RECORDING AND REPORTING<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#recording-and-reporting" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>It is not necessary to record or report this procedure.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="rationale">RATIONALE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rationale" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Prevents exposure of aseptic field and supplies to air and contamination.
Sterile object held below waist is considered contaminated.
Preparation of equipment in advance prevents break in technique.
Prevents transmission of infection.
Ensures sterility of packaged drape.
2.5 cm border around drape is unsterile and may be touched.
If sterile object touches any other non-sterile object, it becomes contaminated.
Drape can now be properly placed while using two hands. Drape must be held away from unsterile surfaces.
Prevents nurse from reaching over aseptic field.
Creates aseptic work surface.
Frees dominant hand for unwrapping outer wrapper.
Item remains sterile. Inner surface of wrapper covers hand, making it sterile.
Prevents reaching over field and contaminating its surface.
Prevents accidental contamination of aseptic field.
Ensures correct solution and sterility of contents.
Prevents reaching over aseptic field.
Prevents contamination of bottle lip and keeps inside of cap sterile. Edge and outside of bottle are considered contaminated. Slow pouring prevents splashing of liquids which causes fluid permeation of aseptic field and results in contamination.
Prevents transmission of infection to patient.</p>
<p>FUNDAMENTALS OF NURSING: CLINICAL SKILLS WORKBOOK</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="preparing-an-aseptic-field">PREPARING AN ASEPTIC FIELD<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#preparing-an-aseptic-field" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>CLINICAL SKILL 29-2: Preparing an aseptic field</p>
<p>DEMONSTRATES: The ability to effectively and safely demonstrate preparing an aseptic field</p>
<p>DOMAIN/S (AUS): Professional Practice and Provision and Coordination of Care</p>
<p>DOMAIN/S (NZ): Professional responsibility; management of nursing care; interprofessional healthcare and quality improvement</p>
<p>PERFORMANCE CRITERIA: (numbers indicate National Competency Standards for the Registered Nurse)</p>
<p>AUS 1.1, 1.2, 1.3, 2.1, 2.2, 2.3, 2.5, 2.6, 3.2, 4.1, 4.2, 5.1, 5.2, 5.3, 7.1, 7.3, 9.1, 9.2, 9.5, 10.1</p>
<p>NZ 1.1, 1.2, 1.3, 1.4, 2.1, 2.5, 2.8, 4.3</p>

<p>Adding sterile items
Opens sterile items while holding outside wrapper, carefully peels wrapper back, places item on sterile field at an angle; does not allow outer wrapper to make direct contact with sterile field
Ensures only sterile items make contact with sterile field</p>
<p>Pouring solutions
Ensures receiving container for solution is near edge of sterile field
Removes sterile seal and cap from bottle using an upward motion
Holds label of bottle upwards in palm of hand
Holds bottle approximately 3â€“4 cm over lips of receiving container and slowly pours contents into receiving container
Performs procedure using aseptic non-touch technique |  |  |  |  |   |</p>

<p>SKILL 29-3</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="surgical-handwashing-scrubbing-preparing-for-gowning-and-gloving">Surgical handwashing ('scrubbing'): preparing for gowning and gloving<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#surgical-handwashing-scrubbing-preparing-for-gowning-and-gloving" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="delegation-considerations">DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delegation-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The role of the circulating and instrument nurse can be delegated to a surgical technologist or licensed practical nurse in some countries. In Australia, registered nurses perform these roles. Individual healthcare organisations will determine the level of competency required for the role of the circulating and instrument nurse.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Deep scrub sink with automatic, foot or knee controls for dispensing water and soap (taps should be high enough for hands and forearms to fit comfortably).</li>
<li>Non-irritating, broad-spectrum, fast-acting antimicrobial scrub solutions, with an accumulative, residual effect, should be used. Note: the same antimicrobial solution used for the initial scrub of the day should be used for subsequent scrubs during the day, to maximise the residual cumulative antimicrobial effects. Staff using antimicrobial solutions should have direct access to the manufacturer's material safety data sheet (MSDS) which outlines directions for use and first aid.</li>
<li>Surgical scrub sponge with nail pick. Note: a scrub brush should only be used if hands are grossly contaminated, e.g. following gardening, painting, etc. Routine use damages the outer dermal layer of skin causing abrasions which breach the skin barrier enabling penetration of microbes into deeper tissue, increasing the risk of skin reactions.</li>
<li>Other: personnel are required to remove jewellery and don protective attire: freshly laundered scrub attire, appropriate footwear, shoe covers as required, hair covering, appropriate surgical face mask and protective eyewear prior to scrubbing.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="steps">STEPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Scrub each side of each finger, between the fingers, and the back and front of the hand for 2 minutes. The first hand and arm wash (scrub) for the day should take 5 minutes; subsequent scrubs should take 3 minutes. (Department of Health and Ageing, 2004).</li>
<li>Ensure fingernails are short, clean, healthy and free of artificial nails, nail polish and nail fillers.</li>
<li>Inspect hands for presence of abrasions, cuts or open lesions. Consult infection-control professional as necessary.</li>
<li>Don surgical face mask and protective eyewear.</li>
<li>Turn on water using knee or foot controls and adjust to comfortable temperature.</li>
<li>Start timing. Wet hands and arms under running lukewarm water and lather with an antimicrobial solution to 5 cm below the elbows. Keep hands higher than elbows at all times.</li>
<li>Rinse hands and arms thoroughly under running warm water. Remember to keep hands above the elbows.</li>
<li>Under running water, clean under nails of both hands with either a nail pick or the bristled side of a scrub brush (see illustration). Discard after use.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="rationale">RATIONALE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rationale" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Allows sufficient time to ensure the effectiveness of the surgical scrub.</p>
<p>Long nails and chipped or old polish increase number of bacteria residing on the fingernails. Long fingernails can puncture gloves, causing contamination.</p>
<p>Damaged tissue may have a greater number of microbes residing on skin surfaces.</p>
<p>Protects from splashes of chemicals and patient blood and body fluids.</p>
<p>Taps should be high enough to allow hands and forearms to fit comfortably underneath.</p>
<p>Water runs by gravity from fingertips to elbows. Hands become cleanest part of upper extremity. Keeping hands elevated allows water to flow from least to most contaminated areas.</p>
<p>Rinsing removes transient microorganisms from fingers, hands and forearms.</p>
<p>This removes debris that may harbour large numbers of microorganisms.</p>
<p>Note: World Health Organization (WHO) guidelines recommend that a surgical handscrub with a medicated soap, such as chlorhexidine or povidone-iodine for 2 or 3 minutes, reduces bacterial counts to acceptable levels and the time required for surgical alcohol-based handrubbing depends on the compound used (WHO, 2009). WHO guidelines also state that for preoperative hand preparation, alcohol-based formulations have better antimicrobial effectiveness than all other currently available methods (WHO, 2009).</p>
<p>INFECTION CONTROL 73</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>9. Wash arms using a circular motion, from hands to elbows, without returning to hands (see illustration). Discard brush. This 'pre-wash' should take 2 minutes initially, then 1 minute for subsequent scrubs.</td><td>This step allows the antimicrobial solution time to work.</td></tr><tr><td>10. Re-apply the antimicrobial solution and wash all surfaces of hands including between fingers (see illustration) and around wrists. Wash arms using a circular motion from hands to elbows, without returning to hands. This process should take 3 minutes initially, then 2 minutes for subsequent scrubs.</td><td>Scrubbing in a circular motion loosens resident bacteria that adhere to skin and helps ensure full coverage of surfaces.</td></tr><tr><td>11. Ensure hands are elevated above the elbows. Carefully rinse hands and arms thoroughly under running water, without touching taps (see illustration).</td><td>Correct rinsing to remove antimicrobial solution helps prevent skin irritation.</td></tr><tr><td>12. Turn off taps without touching them with the scrubbed parts of the hands and arms. Shake off excess water, clasp hands together and hold away from the body.</td><td>Keeping hands and arms elevated and away from clothing avoids contamination.</td></tr><tr><td>13. Walk carefully into the operating or set-up room to dry hands and arms in preparation for donning a sterile gown and gloves.</td><td>Floors around scrub sink can be slippery.</td></tr><tr><td>14. Obtain a sterile hand towel and stand back from the aseptic field. Lean forward, outstretch hands and allow the towel to unfold. Use one half of the towel to thoroughly pat dry, from the hand to the elbow using a circular motion, on one side of the towel, then use the other half of the towel to repeat the process for the other hand and arm (Australian College of Operating Room Nurses, 2010).</td><td>Leaning forward prevents accidental contact of arms with clothing. Drying hands thoroughly makes donning gloves easier.</td></tr><tr><td>15. Finally, drop the towel into the appropriate receptacle (Australian College of Operating Room Nurses, 2010) and proceed with gowning.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>RECORDING AND REPORTING</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Scan barcodes of sterile items or apply tracking stickers to documentation.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Report any dermatitis to employee health services or infection control as per agency policy.</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>

<p>SKILL 29-4</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="open-gloving">Open gloving<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#open-gloving" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="delegation-considerations">DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delegation-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Requires knowledge of aseptic technique.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Sterile gloves of the correct size</li>
<li>A clean surface on which to open the glove packet. Wipe over the surface with an antiseptic and allow it to dry thoroughly before use</li>
</ul>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>OPEN GLOVING</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<ol>
<li>Perform hand hygiene.</li>
<li>Open the glove packet by carefully separating and peeling apart the sides, on a recently cleaned surface.</li>
<li>Grasp the inner package, keeping the gloves on the sterile inside of the wrapper surface (see illustration).</li>
<li>Identify right and left glove. Each glove has cuff approximately 5 cm wide. Glove the dominant hand first.</li>
<li>With thumb and first two fingers of the non-dominant hand, grasp edge of the cuff of the glove for dominant hand. Touch only gloveâ€™s inside surface.</li>
<li>Carefully pull glove over dominant hand, leaving cuff and being sure cuff does not roll up wrist. Be sure thumb and fingers are in proper spaces (see illustration).</li>
<li>With gloved dominant hand, slip the fingers underneath second glove cuff (see illustration).</li>
<li>Carefully pull second glove over non-dominant hand. Do not allow the fingers and thumb of the gloved, dominant hand to touch any part of exposed non-dominant hand. Keep the thumb of the dominant hand abducted back (see illustration).</li>
<li>Once the second glove is applied, ensure a smooth fit over fingers and interlock the gloved hands, taking care not to touch the uniform (unless the nurse is wearing a sterile gown). The cuffs usually fall down after application. Be sure to touch only sterile sides (see illustration).</li>
</ol>
<p>GLOVE DISPOSAL
10. Grasp the outside of one cuff with the other gloved hand; avoid touching wrist.
11. Pull the glove off, turning it inside out. Place the removed glove in the remaining gloved hand.
12. Use the fingers of the bare hand to pull the remaining glove from the cuff over the hand. This will remove the glove and tuck the other glove inside.
13. Discard in an appropriate infectious waste receptacle.
14. Ensure hands are washed hands thoroughly, or liberally apply an antimicrobial alcohol hand-rub immediately after the removal of gloves. | Removes bacteria from skin surfaces and reduces transmission of infection.
Maintains the integrity of the sterile gloves.
Inner surface of glove package must remain sterile.
Proper identification of gloves enables efficient, correct gloving. Gloving the dominant hand first improves dexterity.
Inner edge of cuff will lie next to skin and is therefore not sterile.
If the outer surface of the glove touches the skin it is considered contaminated and must be replaced with a sterile glove.
Cuff protects gloved fingers. Ensures sterile items only touch sterile surfaces, thus avoiding contamination.
Contact of gloved hand with exposed skin of ungloved hand causes contamination. Unsterile glove must then be removed and replaced with a sterile glove.
Ensures a smooth fit over fingers.
Minimises contamination of underlying skin.
Outside of glove does not touch skin surface.
Contaminated gloves are contained.
Used gloves are contaminated with the microbes of the wearer and handled contaminants.
Microorganisms multiply in dark, moist, warm conditions such as on hands when gloves are worn. Gloves may contain microscopic perforations permitting the entry of microbes, which can proliferate on the wearerâ€™s hands.  |</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="recording-and-reporting">RECORDING AND REPORTING<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#recording-and-reporting" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>It is not necessary to record or report this procedure.</p>
<p>INFECTION CONTROL 77</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="open-gloving">OPEN GLOVING<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#open-gloving" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>CLINICAL SKILL 29-4: Open glowing</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="scale">SCALE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#scale" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

D Dependent</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>COMPETENCY CRITERIA</th><th>PERFORMANCE CRITERIA/EVIDENCE</th><th>I</th><th>S</th><th>A</th><th>M</th><th>D</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Identifies <p>INFECTION CONTROL 79</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="skill-29-5">SKILL 29-5<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#skill-29-5" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="donning-a-sterile-gown-and-performing-closed-gloving">Donning a sterile gown and performing closed gloving<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#donning-a-sterile-gown-and-performing-closed-gloving" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="delegation-considerations">DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delegation-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The role of the circulating and instrument nurse can be delegated to a surgical technologist or licensed practical nurse in some countries. In Australia, registered nurses usually perform these roles. Individual healthcare organisations will determine the level of competency required for the role of the circulating and instrument nurse.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Freshly laundered scrub attire</li>
<li>Appropriate, non-slip, clean shoes or shoes worn with shoe covers</li>
<li>Hair covering: hat or balaclava (to contain facial hair)</li>
<li>Two pairs of sterile gloves, the inner pair one size larger, the outer pair being the nurse's correct size</li>
<li>Surgical mask</li>
<li>Appropriate eye protection: for infection control. Protective eyewear specific to various types of lasers may also be required</li>
<li>Sterile gown that complies with national requirements.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="steps">STEPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="donning-a-sterile-gown">DONNING A STERILE GOWN<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#donning-a-sterile-gown" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Personnel are required to don protective attire: freshly laundered scrub attire, appropriate footwear, shoe covers as required, hair covering, appropriate surgical face mask and protective eyewear, prior to gowning and gloving.</li>
<li>Perform thorough surgical handwash (see Skill 29-3).</li>
<li>The circulating nurse aseptically opens a sterile gown pack containing a sterile gown, which is folded inside out.</li>
<li>The circulating nurse peels open glove package without contaminating the sterile inner contents. Inner glove package is then placed on sterile outer created by sterile outer wrapper.</li>
<li>Reach down to sterile gown package; lift folded gown directly up and step back away from table.</li>
<li>Hold the folded gown away from the scrub suit, locate neckband and allow the remainder of the gown to unfold without being touched.</li>
<li>Use both hands to find the arm holes of the gown and push the hands and arms through simultaneously (see illustration), without allowing the hands to protrude out from the wrist cuffs. Once the gown is pulled on, the sleeves should cover hands.</li>
<li>Circulating nurse may reach inside gown to arm seams to bring gown over shoulders. Ask the circulating nurse to securely tie up the back of the gown (see illustration).</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="closed-gloving">CLOSED GLOVING<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#closed-gloving" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>With hands still covered by the gown sleeves, open the inner package of the larger sized gloves (see illustration). The right glove will be located on the right side of the package, and the left glove will be located on the left side of the package.</li>
<li>With the dominant hand inside gown cuff, pick up the glove for the non-dominant hand by grasping the folded cuff.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="rationale">RATIONALE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rationale" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Prevents hair and air droplet nuclei from contaminating the aseptic field. Eyewear protects staff from inadvertent splashes of chemicals, blood and body fluids.</p>
<p>Removes transient and resident bacteria from fingers, hands and forearms.</p>
<p>Outer surface of gown remains sterile.</p>
<p>Inner packaging and gloves remain sterile, allowing instrument nurse to handle aseptically.</p>
<p>Provides sufficient space to don gown without contamination.</p>
<p>Outside of gown remains sterile.</p>
<p>Clean hands may touch the inside of the gown without contaminating the outer surface. Gown covers hands to prepare for closed gloving.</p>
<p>Gown must completely enclose underlying garments. The front tie or tab of the gown is handed to another sterile person to 'turn' the gown. This allows a sterile flap to cover the back.</p>
<p>Outside of gown remains sterile. Double gloving is recommended to minimise cross-infection from sharp items.</p>
<p>Sterile gown touches sterile glove.</p>
<p>FUNDAMENTALS OF NURSING: CLINICAL SKILLS WORKBOOK</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>3. Extend non-dominant hand and forearm, with the palm facing upwards and place the palm of the glove against the palm of non-dominant hand. Glove fingers will point towards the elbow.</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<ol start="4">
<li>Grasp back of glove cuff with covered dominant hand. Turn glove cuff over end of non-dominant hand and gown cuff (see illustration).</li>
<li>Grasp the cuff of the glove and the underlying gown sleeve, with the gown cuff still covering dominant hand. Carefully extend fingers into the sterile glove.</li>
<li>Glove the dominant hand in same manner, reversing hands (see illustration). Use gloved non-dominant hand to pull the other glove at the cuff of the gown and extend fingers into the glove. Keep the hand inside sleeve cuff at all times to ensure â€˜closed glovingâ€™. Ensure fingers are fully extended into both gloves.</li>
<li>The second outer pair of gloves can be applied by the instrument nurse; the sterile gloved hands touch the second sterile pair of gloves.</li>
<li>Undo the fastener or ties in front of the gown and hand to a gowned and gloved â€˜sterileâ€™ member of the surgical team. They will stand still while the instrument nurse turns around to cover their back, with extended gown flap. The instrument nurse retrieves their gown tie from sterile surgical team member and securely ties the gown (see illustration).</li>
<li>The scrub team must ensure they either pass each other face to face or back to back, to avoid the unsterile back of the gown contaminating the aseptic field or personnel. | Positions glove for application over cuffed hand, maintaining glove sterility.
Seal created by glove cuff over gown prevents exit of microorganisms over operative aseptic field.
When both hands are covered by sterile gloves, fingers can more easily be manipulated into the gloves.
A seal is created by the glove cuff over the gown to prevent exit of microorganisms onto the operative aseptic field.
Contact with an unsterile team member can risk contamination of sterile gown or gloves. Gown must completely enclose underlying garments.
Scrubbed personnel are considered sterile from mid-chest to waist and elbows to glove tips only. The back of the gown, the area under the arms, the collar, the area below the waist and the sleeves above the elbows are considered unsterile, as the nurse cannot keep these areas in constant view to ensure their sterility.  |
|  RECORDING AND REPORTING  |   |
|  â€¢ It is not necessary to record or report this procedure.  |   |</li>
</ol>
<p>INFECTION CONTROL 81</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="donning-a-sterile-gown-and-performing-closed-gloving">DONNING A STERILE GOWN AND PERFORMING CLOSED GLOVING<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#donning-a-sterile-gown-and-performing-closed-gloving" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>CLINICAL SKILL 29-5: Donning a sterile gown and performing closed gloving</p>
<p>DEMONSTRATES: The ability to effectively and safely don a sterile gown and perform closed gloving</p>
<p>DOMAIN/S (AUS): Professional Practice and Provision and Coordination of Care</p>
<p>DOMAIN/S (NZ): Professional responsibility; management of nursing care; interprofessional healthcare and quality improvement</p>
<p>PERFORMANCE CRITERIA: (numbers indicate National Competency Standards for the Registered Nurse)</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="skin-integrity-and-wound-care">Skin integrity and wound care<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#skin-integrity-and-wound-care" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="overview">Overview<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#overview" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The integumentary system, or skin, is the largest organ in the human body. The importance of the skin is largely forgotten until the body is injured and the integrity of the skin is breached. The primary function of the skin is to act as a barrier against disease-causing organisms and prevent communication to the external environment. The skin also acts as a sensory organ for pain, temperature and touch; provides shape; allows mobility; and can synthesise vitamin D from UV sunlight.</p>
<p>The skin is divided into various layers. The two main layers, the epidermis and the dermis, play an active role in wound healing. The function of the epidermis is to resurface the wound, completing a layer of skin that restores the skin's ability to protect the body from the external environment and potential invasion by disease-causing pathogens. The dermis provides structural support using newly developed collagen to restore the structural integrity and physical properties of the skin. It is important that both these layers close a wound. If only the epidermal layer closes a wound, the underlying space can place the patient at risk of infection, circulatory impairment and tissue breakdown.</p>
<p>A major role in nursing care is the maintenance of skin integrity. Nurses need to assess a patient's skin for breaks or impairment to the integrity of the skin. Risk assessment tools allow nurses to conduct systematic reviews of the integrity of the patient's skin in conjunction with their clinical judgement and skill. Skin impairment (pressure ulcer formation) occurs from prolonged pressure, shearing forces, irritation and immobility. Pressure ulcers increase the risk of infection and can result in a complex healing process. The impact of pressure ulcers can range from simple inconvenience to major pain and discomfort. In extreme cases, complications from pressure ulcers can lead to death.</p>
<p>Wound healing is a complex physiological process, which varies depending on the location, severity and extent of the injury. The duration of wound healing can range from months to years, depending on the severity of the wound and the patient's comorbidities. Wound classification provides information about the risks associated with a wound and implications for care. It is important that nurses understand the difference between an acute wound (normal healing process, which occurs in a timely manner) and a chronic wound (healing and repair are delayed or fail to occur, and return to normal function is delayed).</p>
<p>This chapter explores the psychomotor skills required to perform a risk assessment of the integumentary system and wound intervention. Nurses can use several risk assessment tools to identify patients at risk of pressure ulcer formation, such as the Norton, Waterlow and Braden tools. This chapter explores wound intervention and various treatments for pressure ulcers depending on the size, stage, location and presence or absence of healing. The skills addressed include performing a bacterial wound swab (30-1); performing a wound dressing (30-2); assessment, management and prevention of skin tears (30-3); and assessment for risk of pressure injury (30-4).</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260125-1f8fc015.jpeg" alt="img-5.jpeg"></p>
<p>FUNDAMENTALS OF NURSING: CLINICAL SKILLS WORKBOOK</p>
<p>SKILL 30-1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="performing-a-bacterial-wound-swab">Performing a bacterial wound swab<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#performing-a-bacterial-wound-swab" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="delegation-considerations">DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delegation-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A bacterial wound swab can be undertaken by all healthcare professionals if infection is suspected. Check organisational policies regarding which wound care interventions can be delegated to health workers. The assessment of wound infection requires the problem-solving and knowledge-application skills of a registered nurse.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="steps">STEPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Assess wound for suspected clinical signs and symptoms of wound infection, including quantity and type of exudate, presence of malodour, wound deterioration, increasing wound size and deterioration of periwound skin.</li>
<li>Assess patient's level of comfort and offer analgesia if appropriate.</li>
<li>Explain procedure to patient.</li>
<li>Close room or cubicle curtains and windows.</li>
<li>Position patient comfortably and drape with a sheet or towel to expose only wound site.</li>
<li>Place disposable contaminated-waste bag within reach of work area. Fold top of bag to make cuff.</li>
<li>Put on face mask and protective eyewear and wash hands thoroughly. Put on clean, disposable gloves.</li>
<li>Carefully remove dressings. If dressing is adhered, moisten to facilitate removal. Observe dressing for exudate, odour and colour. Remove gloves over contaminated dressings (see Skill 30-2) and discard into prepared bag. Perform hand hygiene.</li>
<li>Cleanse wound with normal saline or potable tap water.</li>
<li>Avoid touching the wound surface, sterile swab surface or swab container opening.</li>
<li>Move swab across the surface of the wound in a zig-zag motion at the same time as rotating the swab between the fingers. A representative area of the wound should be sampled, i.e. at least <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1\mathrm{cm}^2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">cm</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> from the wound bed. Gentle downward pressure may be applied.</li>
<li>Immediately following collection, return the swab carefully to the specimen container and accurately label as per laboratory guidelines.</li>
<li>Put on clean disposable gloves. Cover wound with appropriate dressing (see Skill 30-2).</li>
<li>Remove gloves by pulling them inside out. Dispose of in prepared bag.</li>
<li>Assist patient to a comfortable position.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="rationale">RATIONALE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rationale" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Helps to determine need for wound swab. Clinical signs of infection may be overt or subtle, and may be indicated by wound deterioration, increasing wound size or wound that fails to make satisfactory progress.</p>
<p>Removal of dressing and the presence of a wound infection may be associated with pain requiring analgesia.</p>
<p>Decreases anxiety.</p>
<p>Provides privacy and reduces airborne microorganisms.</p>
<p>Provides access to wound while minimising unnecessary exposure.</p>
<p>Ensures easy disposal of soiled dressings.</p>
<p>Protects nurse from splashes and reduces risk of transfer of microorganisms.</p>
<p>Reduces transmission of microorganisms.</p>
<p>Moistening dressing upon removal decreases pain and trauma to tissue. Glove removal prevents contact of nurse's hands with material on gloves.</p>
<p>Removes exudate, slough, necrotic tissue or dressing product from the wound bed to ensure a more accurate result.</p>
<p>Reduces transmission of microorganisms.</p>
<p>The Z-stroke technique involves rotating the swab in a 10-point zigzag fashion (side to side across the wound without touching the wound edges or periwound skin). Downward pressure helps to release fluid from the wound surface.</p>
<p>The specimen must be labelled to provide laboratory staff with information required to process results. It is important to transport the specimen to the laboratory as soon as possible for processing.</p>
<p>Provides a moist wound environment to facilitate wound healing, absorbs exudate, reduces risk of bacterial colonisation and pain.</p>
<p>Reduces transmission of microorganisms.</p>
<p>Promotes patient comfort.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="recording-and-reporting">RECORDING AND REPORTING<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#recording-and-reporting" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Document all relevant information in patient's chart, including the location the specimen was taken from and the date and time. In most organisations a bacterial wound swab will require prescription from a medical professional.</li>
</ul>
<p>SKIN INTEGRITY AND WOUND CARE 85</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="performing-a-bacterial-wound-swab">PERFORMING A BACTERIAL WOUND SWAB<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#performing-a-bacterial-wound-swab" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>CLINICAL SKILL 30-1: Performing a bacterial wound swab</p>
<p>DEMONSTRATES: The ability to effective swab a wound for bacterial culture</p>
<p>DOMAIN/S (AUS): Professional Practice and Provision and Coordination of Care</p>
<p>DOMAIN/S (NZ): Professional responsibility; management of nursing care; interpersonal relationships; interprofessional healthcare and quality improvement</p>
