<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="skill-30-2">SKILL 30-2<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#skill-30-2" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="performing-a-wound-dressing">Performing a wound dressing<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#performing-a-wound-dressing" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="delegation-considerations">DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delegation-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A wound dressing can be undertaken by all healthcare professionals. Check organisational policies regarding which wound care interventions can be delegated to health workers. The assessment of a wound requires the problem-solving and knowledge-application skills of a registered nurse.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Examination gloves</li>
<li>Apron</li>
<li>Facemask and protective eyewear</li>
<li>Sheet or towel for draping</li>
<li>Normal saline</li>
<li>Contaminated-waste bag</li>
<li>Acetate grid for wound tracing</li>
<li>Black fine-tip permanent marker</li>
<li>Sterile wound probe</li>
<li>Adhesive remover (optional)</li>
<li>Wound dressing (choice is dependent on wound characteristics including level of exudate, condition of wound bed, location of wound, mobility, etc)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="steps">STEPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Assess size and location of wound.</li>
<li>Assess patient's level of comfort.</li>
<li>Explain procedure to patient.</li>
<li>Close room or cubicle curtains and windows.</li>
<li>Position patient comfortably and drape with sheet or towel to expose only wound site.</li>
<li>Place disposable contaminated-waste bag within reach of work area. Fold top of bag to make cuff.</li>
<li>Put on face mask and protective eyewear, if required, and wash hands thoroughly. Put on clean, disposable gloves.</li>
<li>Carefully remove dressing. If dressing is adhered, moisten to facilitate removal. Note the amount of exudate present on the dressing removed, any odour and condition of periwound skin. Remove gloves over contaminated dressing (see illustration) and discard gloves and dressing into prepared bag.</li>
<li>Cleanse wound with normal saline or potable tap water. The decision to cleanse the wound should be based on the following:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>The shape, size and location of the wound</li>
<li>Condition of the wound bed and stage of healing</li>
<li>Availability and effectiveness of different methods of cleansing</li>
<li>The patient's perceptions and needs.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="rationale">RATIONALE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rationale" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Helps to plan for type and amount of supplies required.</p>
<p>Removal of dressing may cause pain and discomfort requiring pain medication.</p>
<p>Decreases anxiety.</p>
<p>Provides privacy and reduces airborne microorganisms.</p>
<p>Provides access to wound while minimising unnecessary exposure.</p>
<p>Ensures easy disposal of soiled dressings.</p>
<p>Protects nurse from splashes and reduces risk of transfer of infection between patients.</p>
<p>Moistening dressing upon removal decreases pain and trauma to tissue. Observing the dressing as it is being removed helps to determine the capacity of the current dressing to contain exudate, odour and its impact on the periwound skin. Removal of gloves over dressing reduces transmission of pathogens.</p>
<p>The aim of wound cleansing is to remove both organic and inorganic debris from the wound and periwound skin to facilitate wound healing, and to make wound assessment easier so that the size and extent of the wound can be visualised.</p>
<p>FUNDAMENTALS OF NURSING: CLINICAL SKILLS WORKBOOK</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>10. Perform wound assessment.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Wound aetiology</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Wound location</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Wound dimensions and extent of tissue loss. Apply acetate grid to wound and trace the wound margin with the felt pen. If the wound is a cavity or there is undermining of the wound margins, gently insert a sterile wound probe to measure the depth of the wound.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Evaluate the clinical appearance of the wound bed by estimating the percentages of tissue type in the wound bed (yellow/sloughy, red/granulating, black/necrotic, pink/epithelialising, green/infected tissue).</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Wound edge (sloping, punched-out, undermining, calloused, raised or rolled)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Exudate (type, amount, colour, consistency and odour)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Condition of surrounding skin (maceration, erythema, oedema, warmth, capillary refill time)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Pain (amount, character, quality, relieving or exacerbating factors).</td><td>Provides a combination of subjective and objective data to assess effectiveness of wound management plan and to plan appropriate interventions.</td></tr><tr><td>11. Put on clean gloves. Cover wound with appropriate dressing to provide a moist wound-healing environment. Dressing selection is based on the following factors:</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Aetiology of the wound</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Characteristics of the wound:</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€” Location</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€” Extent of tissue damage</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€” Wound size</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€” Phase of healing (epithelialising, granulating, sloughy, necrotic)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€” Level of exudate</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€” Pain</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€” Odour</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€” Presence of infection</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Factors affecting wound healing</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Cost-effectiveness</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Ease of application and removal</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Dressing should cause minimum distress or disturbance to the patient</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Awareness of the limitations/contraindications of dressings.</td><td>Provides a moist wound environment to facilitate wound healing, absorbs exudate, reduces risk of bacterial colonisation and pain.</td></tr><tr><td>12. Remove gloves by pulling them inside out. Dispose of in prepared bag.</td><td>Prevents contact of nurse's hands with material on gloves.</td></tr><tr><td>13. Assist patient to a comfortable position.</td><td>Promotes patient comfort.</td></tr><tr><td>14. Document all relevant information in patient's chart.</td><td>Provides relevant information about the patient and the wound, monitors healing process, guides wound management of the person as a whole, evaluates the success of management and fulfils legal requirement.</td></tr></tbody></table>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="performing-a-wound-dressing">PERFORMING A WOUND DRESSING<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#performing-a-wound-dressing" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>CLINICAL SKILL 30-2: Performing a wound dressing</p>
<p>DEMONSTRATES: The ability to apply a wound dressing maintaining aseptic technique</p>
<p>DOMAIN/S (AUS): Professional Practice and Provision and Coordination of Care</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="skill-30-3">SKILL 30-3<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#skill-30-3" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="assessment-management-and-prevention-of-skin-tears">Assessment, management and prevention of skin tears<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#assessment-management-and-prevention-of-skin-tears" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="delegation-considerations">DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delegation-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The management and prevention of skin tears can be undertaken by all healthcare professionals. Check organisational policies regarding which wound care interventions can be delegated to health workers. The assessment of a person with or at risk of skin tears requires the problem-solving and knowledge-application skills of a registered nurse.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Examination gloves</li>
<li>Apron</li>
<li>Facemask and protective eyewear (optional)</li>
<li>Normal saline</li>
<li>Sterile cotton tip</li>
<li>Contaminated-waste bag</li>
<li>Black fine-tip permanent marker</li>
<li>Limb protector</li>
<li>Wound dressing (choice is dependent on wound characteristics including level of exudate, condition of wound bed, location and size of wound, condition of periwound skin, mobility, etc)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="steps">STEPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Explain procedure to patient.</li>
<li>Assess size and location of wound.</li>
<li>Position patient comfortably.</li>
<li>Place disposable contaminated-waste bag within reach of work area. Fold top of bag to make cuff.</li>
<li>Put on face mask and protective eyewear, if required, and wash hands thoroughly.</li>
<li>Control bleeding and clean the wound:
a. Stop bleeding by applying firm pressure. Elevate the limb, if applicable, above heart level.
b. Clean the wound by gently irrigating with warm normal saline. Carefully clean under the skin flap to remove foreign debris or blood clots.
c. Pat dry the surrounding skin.</li>
<li>Realign (if possible) any skin or flap.
a. Carefully realign by rolling the skin flap with a moist, sterile cotton bud. The use of a moistened cotton bud assists with approximation of the flap edge.
b. Do not stretch the skin to 'make it fit'. Otherwise, the skin flap will shrink back on itself or it may tear off completely.
c. If the skin flap cannot be realigned, apply moist wound-dressing principles to promote wound healing.</li>
<li>Assess the degree of tissue loss and skin or flap colour:
a. Using the STAR Skin Tear Classification System (see Figure 30-19), select the skin tear category that best describes the type of skin tear you are treating.
b. Note the colour of the skin flap. If the skin or flap colour is pale, dusky or darkened when compared with the person's normal surrounding skin, this may indicate reduced blood flow (ischaemia) or the presence of a blood clot (haematoma), which may affect the skin or flap viability.
c. If the skin or flap colour is pale, dusky or darkened, reassess in 24â€“48 hours or during the first dressing change.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="rationale">RATIONALE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rationale" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Decreases anxiety.</p>
<p>Helps to plan for type and amount of supplies required.</p>
<p>Ensures easy disposal of soiled dressings.</p>
<p>Protects nurse from splashes and reduces risk of transfer of infection between patients.</p>
<p>The aim of wound cleansing is to remove both organic and inorganic debris from the wound and periwound skin to facilitate wound healing, and to make wound assessment easier so that the size and extent of the wound can be visualised.</p>
<p>Provides a combination of subjective and objective data to assess effectiveness of wound management plan and to plan appropriate interventions.</p>
<p>FUNDAMENTALS OF NURSING: CLINICAL SKILLS WORKBOOK</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>9. Assess the surrounding skin condition for fragility, swelling, discolouration or bruising. This information will assist you when selecting an appropriate dressing.</td><td>A person's overall medical condition may affect how quickly the wound is likely to heal. This will guide the management and preventive strategies you decide to use.</td></tr><tr><td>10. Assess the person, their wound and their healing environment.</td><td>Reduces the risk of trauma on removal of the dressing and increases the ability of the dressing to absorb any leakage from the wound.</td></tr><tr><td>11. Apply a dressing. Regardless of what type of dressing you select, you should follow these principles:</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Ensure the dressing extends over the wound edge by at least 1.5â€“2 cm.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Before applying the dressing, draw arrows on top of the dressing with a felt pen to indicate the direction of the skin flap and write the due date for removal. When removing the dressing, ensure that you remove it in the direction of the arrow to avoid pulling back the skin flap.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Leave in place for 5â€“7 days. Change earlier only if there is 75% leakage on the dressing.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Reapply a new dressing if healing is not established and leave the dressing intact for 5â€“7 days.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ If the wound is healed, leave it open and moisturise twice daily with a pH-neutral emollient.</td><td>Provides relevant information about the patient and the wound, monitors healing process, guides wound management of the person as a whole, evaluates the success of management and fulfils legal requirements.</td></tr><tr><td>12. Protect limbs:</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Apply a limb protector or tubular retention bandage to prevent further damage or to hold any dressing in situ.</td><td>People with fragile, thin, bruised or discoloured skin are at a high risk for further skin tears.</td></tr><tr><td>Many skin tears occur when performing normal daily activities such as bathing, dressing and transferring individuals at risk. Avoid wearing jewellery or a watch.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>13. Document the skin tear:</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>a. Document the skin tear category and location in the patientâ€™s record and wound-care assessment chart.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>b. Submit an incident report as required.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>14. Monitor the healing of the wound:</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>a. Check the dressing and surrounding skin regularly for signs of complications or infection, but leave the dressing intact unless an inspection is clinically indicated.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>b. Educate the patient about the signs and symptoms of complications or infection. Advise them to report problems, especially any increase in pain, warmth, odour, redness, purulent exudate or fever.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>15. Implement skin-tear prevention strategies, including the following:</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Assess and recognise risk.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Use extreme caution and a gentle touch.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Avoid direct contact with the skin: use slide sheets where possible to reduce the risk of friction or shearing forces on the skin, especially when transferring someone.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Protect fragile skin: if a person has fragile skin or has had repeated skin tears, encourage them to wear long sleeves and long trousers to protect their skin.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Apply a pH-neutral moisturiser and/or barrier cream at least twice daily. This will help to prevent dry skin.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Use soap-free alternatives; avoid using soaps and perfumed lotions as these can dry the skin. Instead, use a pH-neutral cleanser or moisturiser.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Avoid using adhesives. Adhesives may increase the risk of tearing the skin when they are removed. It is advisable to use a limb protector instead.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Use protective padding on furniture and equipment: pad bed rails, wheelchair arms and leg supports to reduce the risk of skin injuries.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Ensure adequate lighting. A well-lit environment helps to reduce risk of people bumping into furniture, doors or equipment.</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>SKIN INTEGRITY AND WOUND CARE 93</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>16. Provide continuing education:</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Help other staff members, patients and their family members understand the importance of identifying those at risk for skin tears, appropriate treatment and prevention strategies.</td><td>Provides relevant information about the patient and the wound, monitors healing process, guides wound management of the person as a whole, evaluates the success of management and fulfils legal requirement.</td></tr><tr><td>17. Document all relevant information in patient's chart.</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>

<p>Management
Puts on clean, disposable gloves and carefully controls any bleeding
Cleanses wound by gently irrigating with warm normal saline
Carefully cleanses under skin flap to remove foreign debris or blood clots
Pats dry the surrounding skin
Realignment: carefully realigns by rolling skin flap with moist, sterile cotton bud
Does not stretch skin flap
Non-realignment: applies moist wound dressing principles to promote wound healing
Applies an appropriate dressing |  |  |  |  |   |</p>

<p>SKILL 30-4</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="assessment-for-risk-of-pressure-injury">Assessment for risk of pressure injury<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#assessment-for-risk-of-pressure-injury" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="delegation-considerations">DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delegation-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The management and prevention of pressure injuries can be undertaken by all healthcare professionals. Check organisational policies regarding which wound care interventions can be delegated to health workers. The assessment of a person with or at risk for or with a pressure injury requires the problem-solving and knowledge-application skills of a registered nurse.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Pressure injury risk assessment tool</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="steps">STEPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>A comprehensive risk assessment for pressure injuries should be completed on admission for every patient using a risk assessment tool. Reassessment should be performed at the following intervals:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Acute careâ€”at least every 24 hours or sooner if the patient's health condition changes</li>
<li>Long-term careâ€”weekly for 4 weeks, then monthly in high care and quarterly in low care or whenever the patient's condition changes</li>
<li>Home-careâ€”weekly or at every nurse visit (if visiting less than weekly) and in response to changes in the patient's condition.</li>
</ul>
<ol start="2">
<li>Identify patient's risk of pressure injury including:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Alteration in mobility and activity</li>
<li>Contractures</li>
<li>Fractures</li>
<li>Injury</li>
<li>Neurological disease/deficit</li>
<li>Pain</li>
<li>Malnutrition</li>
<li>Dehydration</li>
<li>Oedema</li>
<li>Protein insufficiency</li>
<li>Weight loss</li>
<li>Obesity</li>
<li>Moisture</li>
<li>Drainage (fistulae, wounds)</li>
<li>Incontinence (urine, faeces)</li>
<li>Perspiration</li>
<li>Alteration in sensation and consciousness</li>
<li>Central nervous system injury</li>
<li>Cerebrovascular disease</li>
<li>Degenerative neurological disease</li>
<li>Drugs e.g. steroids, cytotoxics</li>
<li>Major surgery</li>
<li>Spinal cord injury</li>
<li>Comorbid conditions</li>
<li>Chronic heart failure</li>
<li>Chronic respiratory disease</li>
<li>Circulatory disease</li>
<li>Diabetes</li>
<li>Immune deficiency states</li>
<li>Impaired tissue oxygenation e.g. anaemia, smoking</li>
<li>Metastatic carcinoma</li>
<li>Peripheral arterial disease.</li>
</ul>
<p>Record the patient's level of risk (no risk/at risk/high risk/very high risk) on the risk assessment chart, patient's care plan and in the medical record.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="rationale">RATIONALE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rationale" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Document all skin assessments using a validated risk assessment tool to aid communication between professionals.</p>
<p>Ongoing assessment of the skin is necessary to detect early signs of pressure damage.</p>
<p>SKIN INTEGRITY AND WOUND CARE 97</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>3. Skin assessment includes:</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>a. Prepare the environment e.g. close curtains.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>b. Explain procedure to patient.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>c. Position patient comfortably to enable inspection of skin and ensure adequate lighting. Remove clothing as necessary to fully expose each area of skin being inspected.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>d. Begin assessment with questioning and inspection to identify any existing wounds (refer to Table 30-4).</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>e. Conduct a head-to-toe skin assessment with particular focus on skin covering bony prominences, e.g. sacrum, heels and greater trochanters (hips). Inspection involves observation of the skin and palpation with hands to detect the presence of moisture and colour changes and temperature differences in areas of the skin being inspected.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Check parts of the body covered by anti-embolic stockings, areas of the body where pressure, friction and shearing is exerted in the course of daily activities and other areas affected by equipment, footwear and clothing, i.e. skin around or under prosthetics, orthotics, skin traction, oxygen appliances, intravenous access, tapes and other objects in contact with the skin.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Look for the following characteristics:</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€” Reactive hyperaemia: when a red mark is found, relieve the pressure, check for blanching (the skin whitens under light finger pressure, which indicates the microcirculation is intact). Review in 30 minutes and the redness should have faded substantially. If the skin does not blanch or the hyperaemia (redness) does not fade, then a stage 1 pressure injury has been identified.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€” Localised heat, oedema and induration.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>f. Ask patient to identify any area of discomfort or pain.</td><td>Ensures privacy and patient comfort.</td></tr><tr><td>Reduces anxiety.</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Many different types of medical devices have been reported as having caused pressure injury.</p>
<p>Localised heat, oedema or induration (hardness), especially in darkly pigmented individuals, are early warning signs for pressure-injury development.</p>
<p>A number of studies have identified pain as a major factor for patients with pressure injuries, and pain over the site is a precursor to tissue breakdown.
Promotes patient comfort.
Documentation and communication allows for the timely intervention of preventive and therapeutic measures. This minimises the frequency of occurrence and the severity of pressure damage.
Timely implementation of pressure off-loading and management strategies is essential. Patients identified at risk for or with a pressure injury benefit from pressure off-loading strategies and a pressure injury prevention plan to reduce the risk of further tissue damage.
Provides relevant information about the patient and the wound, monitors healing process, guides wound management of the person as a whole, evaluates the success of management and fulfils legal requirement.  |
|  4. Reposition patient comfortably following procedure.
5. Document all skin assessments using a validated risk assessment tool. |   |
|  6. If evidence of pressure damage is noted, implement appropriate pressure off-loading and management strategies. |   |
|  7. Document all relevant information in patientâ€™s chart. |   |</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="assessment-for-risk-of-pressure-injury">ASSESSMENT FOR RISK OF PRESSURE INJURY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#assessment-for-risk-of-pressure-injury" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="medication-therapy">Medication therapy<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#medication-therapy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="overview">Overview<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#overview" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A medication is a substance used in the diagnosis, treatment, cure, relief or prevention of health alterations. The medication may be a prescription, a non-prescription (over-the-counter) or a complementary preparation. In fact, medications are the main treatments patients associate with restoration of health. Administration of medications is a fundamental part of nursing practice and nurses draw on knowledge from many life sciences to ensure safe, effective and appropriate medication outcomes for patients. Regardless of whether patients receive their healthcare in hospitals, clinics or the home, nurses play an essential role in medication therapy.</p>
<p>In the acute care setting nurses also ensure that patients are adequately prepared to administer their medications when they leave hospital. In addition, nurses teach patients about medications and their side effects, encourage patients to adhere to their medication regimen and oversee patient self-administration of medications. Nurses also assess the effects of medications in restoring or maintaining health.</p>
<p>One medication may have as many as four names: (1) generic name; (2) official name; (3) trade or brand name; and (4) chemical name. Medication administration commences with the prescription of the drug. Medication safety requires nurses to understand and recognise the class or category to which a medication is allocated. The classification of medications indicates a medication's effect on body systems, the desired effect of the medication and the symptoms that the medication relieves. Medication safety and medication administration must be accompanied by a valid and legal medication order. A medication order is a written instruction on a medication chart prepared by a doctor or other licensed prescriber who records the medication name, dose, route and frequency of administration.</p>
<p>Medications are available in a variety of preparations such as capsule, elixir, pessary, suppository, ointment, transdermal patch and intramuscular and subcutaneous injections. The form and preparation of the medication determines its route of administration and speed of absorption. A fundamental responsibility of the nurse in the medication administration process is to ensure that the medication is administered in a form that is appropriate to the patient.</p>
<p>The scheduling, preparation, dispensing and administration of medications in Australia and New Zealand are subject to regulation by national and state government agencies as well as healthcare institutional policies. Nurses are responsible for following national and state legal provisions when administering controlled substances or opioids/narcotics.</p>
<p>The nurse's responsibility within the medication safety process includes the appropriate secure storage of all medications. Regulated medications such as schedule 8 (opioids) and some schedule 4 medications are secured in locked cupboards. A register is maintained to record all medications placed in, withdrawn from and discarded from the controlled drugs cupboard.</p>
<p>Adequate preparation is essential to facilitate effective nursing care of the patient requiring medications. Adequate preparation includes gathering and preparing equipment, assessing patient knowledge, preparing the medication, performing the seven rights and three checks of medication administration, and monitoring the patient for complications following the administration of medication.</p>
<p>The psychomotor skills addressed in this chapter include administering oral medications (31-1), administering nasal instillations (31-2), administering ophthalmic medications (31-3), administering vaginal medications (31-4), administering rectal suppositories (31-5), using metered-dose inhalers (MDIs) (31-6), preparing injections (31-7), administering injections (31-8), adding medications to intravenous fluid containers (31-9), administering medications by intravenous bolus (31-10) and administering intravenous medications by piggyback/tandem set-up, intermittent intravenous infusion sets and mini-infusion pumps (31-11).</p>
<p>FUNDAMENTALS OF NURSING: CLINICAL SKILLS WORKBOOK</p>
<p>SKILL 31-1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="administering-oral-medications">Administering oral medications<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#administering-oral-medications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="delegation-considerations">DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delegation-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Administering medications by the oral route requires the problem-solving and knowledge-application abilities of professional nurses. In some states of Australia and New Zealand, client care attendants or enrolled nurses may legally be able to administer medications via this route. For this procedure, client assessment by the registered nurse is required as delegation may be inappropriate.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Medication trolley (if applicable)</li>
<li>Disposable medication cups</li>
<li>Glass of water, juice or preferred liquid</li>
<li>Drinking straw</li>
<li>Clean pill-crusher (if required)</li>
<li>Paper towels (for liquid medicines)</li>

<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>1. Assess for any contraindications to client receiving oral medication: Is client able to swallow? Is client suffering from nausea/vomiting? Is client diagnosed as having bowel inflammation or reduced peristalsis? Has client had recent gastrointestinal (GI) surgery? Does client have a nasogastric tube in situ on gastric drainage/suction?</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>a. Check the client's swallow, cough and gag reflexes if in doubt about client's ability to manage oral medications. Withhold medication if swallow, cough or gag is impaired and notify prescriber.</td><td>Alterations in GI function interfere with medication distribution, absorption and excretion. Clients with GI suction might not receive benefit from the medication because it may be suctioned from the GI tract before it can be absorbed.</td></tr><tr><td>2. Assess client's medical history, history of allergies, medication history and diet history.</td><td>These factors can influence how certain medications act. Information also reflects client's need for medications.</td></tr><tr><td>Critical decision point: Drug allergies should be listed on each page of the MAR, on an identification armband and prominently displayed on the client's medical record.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>3. Gather physical examination and laboratory data that may influence medication administration (e.g. checking blood pressure before administering antihypertensives).</td><td>Physical examination or laboratory data may contraindicate medication administration.</td></tr><tr><td>Critical decision point: If contraindications exist, withhold medication and inform prescriber.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>4. Assess client's knowledge of health and medication use.</td><td>Determines client's need for medication education. Also helps identify adherence to medication therapy at home. Assessment may reveal medication problems such as medication tolerance (where medication fails to achieve the desired effect), non-compliance, abuse, addiction or dependence.</td></tr><tr><td>5. Assess client's preferences for fluids.</td><td>Fluids ease swallowing and facilitate absorption from the GI tract. Fluid restrictions must be maintained.</td></tr><tr><td>6. Check accuracy and completeness of each MAR or computer printout with prescriber's written medication order. Check client's name, medication name and dose, route of administration and time for administration.</td><td>The medication order sheet is the most reliable source and only legal record of medications client is to receive.</td></tr><tr><td>7. Prepare medications:</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>a. Perform hand hygiene.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>b. Arrange medication tray and cups in medication preparation area (medication room or at the client's bedside if medicines are stored in a locked drawer there) or move medication trolley to outside client's room.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>c. Unlock medicine drawer or trolley.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>d. Prepare medication for one client at a time. Keep all pages of MARs for one client together.</td><td>Reduces transfer of microorganisms.</td></tr><tr><td>Organisation of equipment saves time and reduces error.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Medications are safeguarded when locked in cabinet or trolley.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Prevents preparation error.</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>MEDICATION THERAPY 101</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>e. Select correct medication. Compare label of medication with MAR.</td><td>Reading label and comparing it with order reduces error.</td></tr><tr><td>f. Calculate medication dose as necessary. Double-check calculation.</td><td>Double-checking may help reduce risk of error.</td></tr><tr><td>g. To prepare tablets or capsules, pour required number into bottle cap and transfer medication to medication cap. Do not touch medication with fingers. Extra tablets or capsules may be returned to bottle. For medications that need to be broken, use a gloved hand, or cut with a pill-cutting device (see illustration). Tablets that are to be broken in half must be prescored (identified by a manufactured line across the centre of the tablet).</td><td>Medications are very expensive; avoid waste. Some medicines may degrade if touched or may be harmful to the nurse (i.e. cytotoxic drugs).</td></tr><tr><td>h. To prepare unit-dose tablets or capsules, place packaged tablet or capsule directly over medicine cup and compress the wrapper to release medication (see illustration).</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>i. All tablets or capsules to be given to client at same time may be placed in one medicine cup except for those requiring preadministration assessments (e.g. pulse rate or blood pressure).</td><td>Keeping medications that require preadministration assessments separate from others makes it easier for the nurse to withhold medications as necessary.</td></tr><tr><td>j. If the client has difficulty swallowing, ask prescriber to substitute with liquid or dissolvable preparation. If liquid medications are not an option, use a clean pill-crushing device such as a mortar and pestle to grind tablets. Mix ground tablet in small amount of soft food.</td><td>Large tablets can be difficult to swallow. Ground tablet mixed with palatable soft food is usually easier to swallow. Note that not all tablets are safe to break up or crush, so this must be checked beforehand. Pill-crushing devices should be clean to prevent inadvertent exposure to other medicines that may have been in the pill-crusher previously.</td></tr><tr><td>Critical decision point: Not all medications can be crushed (e.g. capsules, enteric-coated drugs). Consult with pharmacist when in doubt. Choking or aspiration of particles of medication can also occur.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>k. Prepare liquids:</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(1) Remove bottle cap from container and place cap upside down.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(2) Hold bottle with label against palm of hand while pouring.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(3) Hold medication cup at eye level and fill to desired level on scale (see illustration). Scale should be even with fluid level at its surface or base of meniscus, not edges.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(4) Discard any excess liquid into sink. Wipe lip and neck of bottle with paper towel.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(5) Some liquid medications are in unit-dose containers. Draw up volumes of less than 10 mL in syringe without needle (see illustration).</td><td>Prevents contamination of inside of cap.</td></tr><tr><td>Spilled liquid will not soil or fade label.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Ensures accuracy of measurement.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Prevents contamination of bottle's contents and prevents bottle cap from sticking.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>l. When preparing controlled drugs, check controlled drug record for previous medication count and compare with supply available. Note that some clinical agencies require two staff to check controlled drugs at the bedside, but this is agency policy and is not regulated by law (except for blood products).</td><td>Controlled substance laws require careful monitoring of dispensed controlled drugs.</td></tr><tr><td>m. Check expiration date on all medications.</td><td>Medications used past expiration date may be inactive or harmful to client.</td></tr><tr><td>n. Compare MAR with prepared medication and container.</td><td>Reading label second time reduces error.</td></tr><tr><td>o. Return stock containers or unused unit-dose medications to shelf or drawer and read label again.</td><td>Third check of label reduces administration errors.</td></tr><tr><td>p. Do not leave medications unattended.</td><td>Nurse is responsible for safekeeping of drugs.</td></tr></tbody></table>

<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>8. Administering medications:</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>a. Take medications to client at correct time.</td><td>Medications are administered within 30 minutes before or after prescribed time to ensure intended therapeutic effect. Stat or single-order medications should be given at time ordered.</td></tr><tr><td>b. Identify client by comparing name on MAR with name on client's identification bracelet. Ask client to state name and any known allergies.</td><td>Identification bracelets are made at time of client's admission and are the most reliable source of identification. Replace any missing or faded identification bracelets.</td></tr><tr><td>c. Explain purpose of each medication and its action to client. Allow client to ask any questions about drugs.</td><td>Client has right to be informed, and client's understanding of purpose of each medication improves compliance with medication therapy.</td></tr><tr><td>d. Help client to sit or to lie on the side if sitting is contraindicated.</td><td>Sitting position prevents aspiration during swallowing.</td></tr><tr><td>e. Administer medications properly:</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(1) Client may wish to hold solid medications in hand or cup before placing in mouth.</td><td>Client can become familiar with medications by seeing each drug.</td></tr><tr><td>(2) Offer water or juice to help client swallow medications. Give cold carbonated water if available and not contraindicated.</td><td>Choice of fluid promotes client's comfort and can improve fluid intake. Carbonated water helps passage of tablet through oesophagus.</td></tr><tr><td>(3) For sublingually administered medications, have client place medication under tongue and allow it to dissolve completely. Caution client against swallowing tablet.</td><td>Medication is absorbed through blood vessels of undersurface of tongue. If swallowed, medication is destroyed by gastric juices or so rapidly detoxified by liver that therapeutic blood levels are not attained.</td></tr><tr><td>(4) For buccally administered drugs, have client place medication in mouth against mucous membranes of the cheek until it dissolves (see Figure 31-5). Avoid administering liquids until buccal medication has dissolved.</td><td>Buccal medications act locally on mucosa or systemically as they are swallowed in saliva.</td></tr><tr><td>(5) Mix powdered medications with liquids at bedside and give to client to drink.</td><td>When prepared in advance, powdered medications may thicken and even harden, making swallowing difficult.</td></tr><tr><td>(6) Caution client against chewing or swallowing lozenges.</td><td>Medication acts through slow absorption through oral mucosa, not gastric mucosa.</td></tr><tr><td>(7) Give effervescent powders and tablets immediately after dissolving.</td><td>Effervescence improves unpleasant taste of medication and often relieves GI problems.</td></tr><tr><td>f. If client is unable to hold medications, place medication cup to the lips and gently introduce each drug into the mouth, one at a time. Do not rush.</td><td>Administering single tablet or capsule eases swallowing and decreases risk of aspiration.</td></tr><tr><td>g. If tablet or capsule falls to the floor, discard it and repeat preparation.</td><td>Medication is contaminated when it touches floor.</td></tr><tr><td>h. Stay until client has completely swallowed each medication.</td><td>Nurse is responsible for ensuring that client receives ordered dosage. If left unattended, client may not take dose or may save medications, causing risk to health.</td></tr><tr><td>i. For highly acidic medications (e.g. aspirin), offer client non-fat snack (e.g. crackers) if not contraindicated by client's condition.</td><td>Reduces gastric irritation.</td></tr><tr><td>j. Help client return to comfortable position.</td><td>Maintains client's comfort.</td></tr><tr><td>k. Dispose of soiled supplies and perform hand hygiene.</td><td>Reduces transmission of microorganisms.</td></tr><tr><td>9. Return within 30 minutes to evaluate client's response to medications.</td><td>Evaluates medication's therapeutic benefit and can detect onset of side effects or allergic reactions.</td></tr><tr><td>10. Ask client or family member to identify medication name and explain purpose, action, dosage schedule and potential side effects of drug.</td><td>Determines level of knowledge gained by client and family.</td></tr><tr><td>11. Always notify prescriber when the client exhibits an adverse effect or allergic reaction, or with the onset of side effects. Withhold further doses.</td><td>Notification alerts prescriber to modify or discontinue medication.</td></tr></tbody></table>

and provides education where necessary</td></tr><tr><td>Explains actions at all stages of procedure</td></tr><tr><td>Gains patient consent</td></tr><tr><td>Returns to patient within 30 minutes to evaluate medicationâ€™s effects (expected and adverse)</td></tr><tr><td>Performs clinical procedure</td></tr><tr><td>Performs seven rights and three checks of medication administration</td></tr><tr><td>Offers appropriate fluid to aid swallowing</td></tr><tr><td>Remains with patient until all medications are swallowed</td></tr><tr><td>Fills patientâ€™s cup with beverage</td></tr></tbody></table>

<p>SKILL 31-2</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="administering-nasal-instillations">Administering nasal instillations<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#administering-nasal-instillations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="delegation-considerations">DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delegation-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Administration of nasal drops and ointments requires the problem-solving and knowledge-application abilities of professional nurses. In some states of Australia and New Zealand, client care attendants or enrolled nurses may legally be able to administer medications via this route. For this procedure, client assessment by the registered nurse is required as delegation may not be appropriate.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Prepared medication with clean dropper or spray container</li>
<li>Facial tissue</li>
<li>Disposable gloves (optional, only if client has extensive nasal drainage)</li>
<li>Medication administration record (MAR)</li>
<li>Penlight (to inspect nares; if ointment is to be applied to a specific lesion inside the nares)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="steps">STEPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>For nasal drops, determine which sinus is affected by referring to healthcare record.</li>
<li>Assess client's history of hypertension, heart disease, diabetes mellitus and hyperthyroidism.</li>
<li>Identify client; compare name on MAR with client's ID bracelet. Ask client to state name.</li>
<li>Using a penlight, inspect condition of nose and sinuses. Palpate sinuses for tenderness.</li>
<li>Assess client's knowledge regarding use of nasal instillations and technique for instillation and willingness to learn self-administration.</li>
<li>Explain procedure to client regarding positioning and sensations to expect, such as burning or stinging of mucosa or choking sensation as medication trickles into throat.</li>
<li>Perform hand hygiene. Arrange supplies and medications at bedside.</li>
<li>Instruct client to clear or blow nose gently unless contraindicated (e.g. risk of increased intracranial pressure or nosebleeds).</li>
<li>Administer nasal drops:</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Help client to supine position.
b. Position head properly:</p>
<p>(1) For access to posterior pharynx, tilt client's head backwards.
(2) For access to ethmoid or sphenoid sinus, tilt head back over edge of bed or place small pillow under client's shoulder and tilt head back (see illustration).
(3) For access to frontal and maxillary sinus, tilt head back over edge of bed or pillow with head turned towards side to be treated (see illustration).</p>
<p>c. Support client's head with non-dominant hand.
d. Instruct client to breathe through mouth.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="rationale">RATIONALE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rationale" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Affects client's position during drug instillation.</p>
<p>These conditions can contraindicate use of decongestants that stimulate central nervous system (CNS). Side effects of transient hypertension, tachycardia, palpitations and headache may occur.</p>
<p>Ensures that correct client receives medication.</p>
<p>Provides baseline to monitor effects of medication. Presence of discharge interferes with medication absorption.</p>
<p>May necessitate health teaching regarding use of medications. Motivation influences teaching approach.</p>
<p>Helps client anticipate experience of procedure to reduce anxiety.</p>
<p>Reduces transmission of microorganisms; ensures smooth, orderly procedure.</p>
<p>Removes mucus and secretions that can block distribution of medication.</p>
<p>Position provides access to nasal passages.</p>
<p>Position allows medication to drain into affected sinus.</p>
<p>Prevents straining of neck muscles.</p>
<p>Mouth breathing reduces chance of aspirating nasal drops into trachea and lungs.</p>
<p>MEDICATION THERAPY 107</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>e. Hold dropper 1 cm above nares and instil prescribed number of drops towards midline of ethmoid bone.</td><td>Avoids contamination of dropper. Instilling towards ethmoid bone facilitates distribution of medication over nasal mucosa.</td></tr><tr><td>f. Have client remain in supine position for 5 minutes.</td><td>Prevents premature loss of medication through nares.</td></tr><tr><td>g. Offer facial tissue to blot runny nose, but caution client against blowing nose for several minutes.</td><td>Allows maximal amount of medication to be absorbed.</td></tr><tr><td>10. Help client into a comfortable position after medication is absorbed.</td><td>Restores comfort.</td></tr><tr><td>11. Dispose of soiled supplies in appropriate container and wash hands.</td><td>Maintains neat, orderly environment. Reduces spread of microorganisms.</td></tr><tr><td>12. Observe client for onset of side effects 15â€“30 minutes after administration.</td><td>Drugs absorbed through mucosa can cause systemic reaction.</td></tr><tr><td>13. Ask if client is able to breathe through nose after decongestant administration. May be necessary to have client occlude one nostril at a time and breathe deeply.</td><td>Determines effectiveness of decongestant medication.</td></tr><tr><td>14. Inspect condition of nasal passages between instillations.</td><td>Condition of mucosa reveals response to medication.</td></tr><tr><td>15. Ask client to review risks of overuse of decongestants and methods for administration.</td><td>Feedback ensures that client can self-administer medications properly.</td></tr><tr><td>16. Have client demonstrate self-medication.</td><td>Feedback demonstrates learning.</td></tr><tr><td>RECORDING AND REPORTING</td><td>HOME CARE CONSIDERATIONS</td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Record medication name, concentration, number of drops, nostril into which medication was instilled and time of administration on MAR.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Record clientâ€™s response in nursesâ€™ notes.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Report any unusual systemic effects to nurse in charge or medical officer.</td><td>â€¢ Instruct client to expect timely resolution of problems. Instruct client on signs to observe of persistent or worsening problem. Clear nasal discharge indicates sinus problem. Yellow or greenish discharge indicates infection.</td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Use OTC nasal sprays or nose drops for only one client; bottles become easily contaminated with bacteria.</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>

<p>SKILL 31-3</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="administering-ophthalmic-medications">Administering ophthalmic medications<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#administering-ophthalmic-medications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="delegation-considerations">DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delegation-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Administration of eye drops and ointments requires the problem-solving and knowledge-application abilities of professional nurses. In some states of Australia and New Zealand, client care attendants or enrolled nurses may legally be able to administer medications via this route. For this procedure, client assessment by the registered nurse is required as delegation may not be appropriate.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Medication bottle with sterile eye dropper or ointment tube</li>
<li>Medicated intraocular disc</li>
<li>Cotton ball or tissue</li>
<li>Washbasin filled with warm water, and washcloth</li>
<li>Eye patch and tape (optional)</li>
<li>Disposable gloves</li>
<li>Medication administration record (MAR)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="steps">STEPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Review prescriber's medication order for number of drops (if a liquid) and eye/s to receive medication.</li>
<li>Identify client. Compare name on MAR with client ID band. Ask client to state name.</li>
<li>Assess condition of external eye structures. (May also be done just before drug instillation.)</li>
<li>Determine known allergies to any medications or to latex.</li>
<li>Determine whether client has any symptoms of visual alterations.</li>
<li>Assess client's level of consciousness and ability to follow directions.</li>
<li>Assess client's knowledge regarding medication therapy and desire to self-administer medication.</li>
<li>Assess client's ability to manipulate and hold dropper.</li>
<li>Explain procedure to client.</li>
<li>Perform hand hygiene and arrange supplies at bedside; put on disposable gloves.</li>
<li>Ask client to lie supine or sit back in chair with head slightly hyperextended.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="rationale">RATIONALE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rationale" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Ensures correct administration of medication.</p>
<p>Ensures that correct client receives medication.</p>
<p>Provides baseline data with which to compare response to medications. Indicates need to clean eye before medication.</p>
<p>Protects client from risk of allergic medication response. May require use of non-latex gloves.</p>
<p>Certain eye medications act to either lessen or increase these symptoms.</p>
<p>Restlessness during procedure increases risk of accidental eye injury.</p>
<p>Client's level of understanding may indicate need for health teaching.</p>
<p>Reflects client's ability to learn to self-administer medication.</p>
<p>Relieves anxiety about medication being instilled into eye.</p>
<p>Reduces transmission of microorganisms; ensures a smooth, orderly procedure.</p>
<p>Position provides easy access to eye for medication instillation and minimises drainage of medication through tear duct.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="critical-decision-point-do-not-hyperextend-the-neck-of-a-client-with-a-known-neck-problem-or-suspected-cervical-spine-injury">Critical decision point: Do not hyperextend the neck of a client with a known neck problem or suspected cervical spine injury.<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#critical-decision-point-do-not-hyperextend-the-neck-of-a-client-with-a-known-neck-problem-or-suspected-cervical-spine-injury" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol start="12">
<li>If crusts or drainage are present along eyelid margins or inner canthus, gently wash away. Soak any crusts that are dried and difficult to remove by applying damp washcloth or cotton ball over eye for a few minutes. Always wipe from inner to outer canthus.</li>
<li>Hold cotton ball or clean tissue in non-dominant hand on client's cheekbone just below lower eyelid.</li>
<li>With tissue or cotton resting below lower lid, gently press downwards with thumb or forefinger against bony orbit.</li>
<li>Ask client to look at ceiling and explain steps to client.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="a-instil-eye-drops">A. Instil eye drops:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-instil-eye-drops" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>(1) With dominant hand resting on client's forehead, hold filled medication eye dropper or ophthalmic solution approximately 1â€“2 cm above conjunctival sac (see illustration).
(2) Drop prescribed number of medication drops into conjunctival sac.
(3) If client blinks or closes eye or if drops land on outer lid margins, repeat procedure.</p>
<p>Crusts or drainage harbour microorganisms. Soaking allows easy removal and prevents pressure from being applied directly over eye. Cleaning from inner to outer canthus avoids entry of microorganism into lacrimal duct.</p>
<p>Cotton or tissue absorbs medication that escapes eye.</p>
<p>Technique exposes lower conjunctival sac. Retraction against bony orbit prevents pressure and trauma to eyeball and prevents fingers from touching eye.</p>
<p>Action retracts sensitive cornea up and away from conjunctival sac and reduces stimulation of blink reflex.</p>
<p>Helps prevent accidental contact of eye dropper with eye structures, thus reducing risk of injury to eye and transfer of infection to dropper. Ophthalmic medications are sterile.</p>
<p>Conjunctival sac normally holds 1 or 2 drops. Provides even distribution of medication across eye.</p>
<p>Therapeutic effect of drug is obtained only when drops enter conjunctival sac.</p>
<p>MEDICATION THERAPY 111</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>(4) After instilling drops, ask client to close eye gently.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(5) When administering medications that cause systemic effects, apply gentle pressure with finger and clean tissue on the clientâ€™s nasolacrimal duct for 30â€“60 seconds.</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>B. <strong>Instil eye ointment:</strong>
(1) Holding ointment applicator above lower lid margin, apply thin stream of ointment evenly along inner edge of lower eyelid on conjunctiva (see illustration) from the inner canthus to the outer canthus.
(2) Have client close eye and rub lid lightly in circular motion with cotton ball, if rubbing is not contraindicated.</p>
<p>C. <strong>Intraocular disc</strong>
(1) Application:
a. Open package containing the disc. Gently press your fingertip against the disc so that it adheres to your finger. Position the convex side of the disc on your fingertip (see illustration).
b. With your other hand, gently pull the clientâ€™s lower eyelid away from the eye. Ask client to look up.
c. Place the disc in the conjunctival sac, so that it floats on the sclera between the iris and lower eyelid (see illustration).
d. Pull the clientâ€™s lower eyelid out and over the disc (see illustration). | Helps to distribute medication. Squinting or squeezing of eyelids forces medication from conjunctival sac.
Prevents overflow of medication into nasal and pharyngeal passages. Prevents absorption into systemic circulation.</p>
<p>Distributes medication evenly across eye and lid margin.</p>
<p>Further distributes medication without traumatising eye.</p>
<p>Allows nurse to inspect disc for damage or deformity.</p>
<p>Prepares conjunctival sac for receiving medicated disc.</p>
<p>Ensures delivery of medication.</p>
<p>Ensures accurate medication delivery.  |
|  <strong>Critical decision point:</strong> You should not be able to see the disc at this time. Repeat Step 15C(1)d if you can see the disc.  |   |
|  (2) Removal:
a. Wash hands and put on gloves.
b. Explain procedure to client.
c. Gently pull on the clientâ€™s lower eyelid to expose the disc.
d. Using your forefinger and thumb of your opposite hand, pinch the disc gently and lift it out of the clientâ€™s eye (see illustration).</p>
<ol start="16">
<li>If excess medication is on eyelid, gently wipe it from inner to outer canthus.</li>
<li>If client had eye patch, apply clean one by placing it over affected eye so entire eye is covered. Tape securely without applying pressure to eye.</li>
<li>Remove gloves, dispose of soiled supplies in proper receptacle, and wash hands.</li>
<li>Note clientâ€™s response to instillation; ask if any discomfort was felt.</li>
<li>Observe response to medication by assessing visual changes and noting any side effects.</li>
<li>Ask client to discuss medicationâ€™s purpose, action, side effects and technique of administration.</li>
<li>Have client demonstrate self-administration of next dose. | Promotes comfort and prevents trauma to eye.</li>
</ol>
<p>Clean eye patch reduces chance of infection.</p>
<p>Maintains neat environment at bedside and reduces transmission of microorganisms.</p>
<p>Determines whether procedure was performed correctly and safely.</p>
<p>Evaluates effects of medication.</p>
<p>Determines clientâ€™s level of understanding.</p>
<p>Provides feedback regarding competency with skill.  |
|  RECORDING AND REPORTING | HOME CARE CONSIDERATIONS  |
|  â€¢ Record medication, concentration, number of drops, time of administration and eye (left, right or both) that received medication on MAR.
â€¢ Record appearance of eye in nursesâ€™ notes. | â€¢ If eye drops are stored in refrigerator, rewarm to room temperature before administering.
â€¢ Many clients lack confidence in their ability to instil drops without supervision. The nurse teaches others, such as a family member, to instil drops into the clientâ€™s eye.  |</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="administering-ophthalmic-medications">ADMINISTERING OPHTHALMIC MEDICATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#administering-ophthalmic-medications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
