<p>SKILL 31-4</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="administering-vaginal-medications">Administering vaginal medications<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#administering-vaginal-medications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="delegation-considerations">DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delegation-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Administering medications by the vaginal route requires knowledge and the necessary psychomotor skills. Although in some states of Australia and New Zealand client care attendants or enrolled nurses are legally able to administer medications via this route, delegation may be inappropriate and client assessment by registered nurses is essential.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Vaginal creams, foam, jelly or suppositories or irrigating solutions</li>
<li>Applicators</li>
<li>Disposable gloves</li>
<li>Tissues</li>
<li>Paper towel</li>
<li>Perineal pad</li>
<li>Drape</li>
<li>Water-soluble lubricants</li>
<li>Medication administration record (MAR)</li>
</ul>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>1. Review prescriber's order, including client's name, medication name, form (cream or suppository), route, dosage and time of administration.</td><td>Ensures safe and correct administration of medication.</td></tr><tr><td>2. Perform hand hygiene.</td><td>Reduces transfer of microorganisms.</td></tr><tr><td>Critical decision point: Rectal and vaginal suppositories may be stored near one another in the refrigerator. Vaginal suppositories are larger and more oval.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>3. Identify client; compare name on MAR with identification bracelet and ask name.</td><td>Ensures that correct client receives medication.</td></tr><tr><td>4. Inspect condition of external genitalia and vaginal canal (see Chapter 27).</td><td>Findings provide baseline data for monitoring effect of medication.</td></tr><tr><td>5. Assess client's ability to manipulate applicator or suppository and to position self to insert medication.</td><td>Mobility restriction indicates level of assistance required from nurse.</td></tr><tr><td>6. Explain procedure to client. Be specific if client plans to self-administer medication. (e.g. 'Please remove the foil covering before insertion').</td><td>Promotes understanding. Will enable client to self-administer medication if physically able.</td></tr><tr><td>7. Arrange supplies at bedside.</td><td>Ensures smooth procedure.</td></tr><tr><td>8. Close room curtain or door.</td><td>Provides privacy.</td></tr><tr><td>9. Assist client to lie in dorsal recumbent position.</td><td>Provides easy access to and good exposure of vaginal canal. Also allows suppository to dissolve without escaping through orifice.</td></tr><tr><td>10. Keep abdomen and lower extremities draped.</td><td>Minimises embarrassment.</td></tr><tr><td>11. Put on disposable gloves.</td><td>Prevents transmission of microorganisms between nurse and client.</td></tr><tr><td>12. Be sure vaginal orifice is well illuminated by room light or gooseneck lamp.</td><td>Proper insertion requires external genitalia to be seen.</td></tr><tr><td>13. Insert suppository with applicator:</td><td>Lubrication reduces friction against mucosal surfaces during insertion.</td></tr><tr><td>a. Remove suppository from foil wrapper and place suppository into the tip of the applicator; apply liberal amount of lubricant to smooth or rounded end. Lubricate applicator.</td><td>Exposes vaginal orifice.</td></tr><tr><td>b. With non-dominant gloved hand, gently retract labial folds.</td><td>Correct placement ensures equal distribution of medication along walls of vaginal cavity.</td></tr><tr><td>c. Hold the applicator by the cylinder and direct applicator initially down (towards the spine) and then back and up (towards the cervix). The aim is to insert the applicator along the posterior wall of vaginal canal 5 cm into vaginal canal.</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>MEDICATION THERAPY 115</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>d. When the applicator is in the appropriate position depress the plunger, remove the applicator with the plunger depressed and wipe away remaining lubricant from around orifice and labia.</td><td>Maintains comfort.</td></tr><tr><td>14. Apply cream or foam:</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>a. Fill cream or foam applicator following package directions.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>b. With non-dominant gloved hand, gently retract labial folds.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>c. With dominant gloved hand, insert applicator approximately 5â€“7.5 cm. Push applicator plunger to deposit medication into vagina (see illustration).</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>d. Withdraw applicator and place on paper towel. Wipe off residual cream from labia or vaginal orifice.</td><td>Dose is prescribed by volume in applicator.</td></tr><tr><td>Exposes vaginal orifice.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Allows equal distribution of medication along vaginal walls.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Residual cream on applicator may contain microorganisms.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>15. Remove gloves by pulling them inside out and discard in appropriate receptacle. Perform hand hygiene.</td><td>Reduces transfer of microorganisms.</td></tr><tr><td>16. Instruct client to remain on back for at least 10 minutes.</td><td>Medication will be distributed and absorbed evenly throughout vaginal cavity and not be lost through orifice.</td></tr><tr><td>17. If reusable applicator is used, wash with soap and warm water, rinse and store for this clientâ€™s future use.</td><td>Vaginal cavity is not sterile. Soap and water help remove bacteria and residual cream.</td></tr><tr><td>18. Offer client perineal pad when she resumes mobility.</td><td>Prevents vaginal discharge from spreading to clothing.</td></tr><tr><td>19. Inspect appearance of discharge of vaginal canal and condition of external genitalia between applications.</td><td>Evaluates whether vaginal medication effectively reduced irritation or inflammation of tissues.</td></tr><tr><td>RECORDING AND REPORTING</td><td>HOME CARE CONSIDERATIONS</td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Record medication name, dose, route and time of administration on MAR.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Record character of discharge on nursesâ€™ notes.</td><td>â€¢ Suppositories should be kept refrigerated but in a container away from children.</td></tr></tbody></table>

<p>SKILL 31-5</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="administering-rectal-suppositories">Administering rectal suppositories<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#administering-rectal-suppositories" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="delegation-considerations">DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delegation-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Administering medications by the rectal route requires the problem-solving and knowledge application abilities of professional nurses. In some states of Australia and New Zealand, client care attendants or enrolled nurses may legally be able to administer medications via this route. For this procedure, client assessment by the registered nurse is required as delegation may not be appropriate.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Rectal suppository</li>
<li>Lubricating jelly (water soluble)</li>
<li>Disposable gloves</li>
<li>Tissue</li>
<li>Drape</li>
<li>Medication administration record (MAR)</li>
</ul>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>1. Review prescriber's order, including client's name, medication name, form, route and time of administration.</td><td>Ensures safe and correct administration of medication.</td></tr><tr><td>2. Review healthcare record for relevant contraindications such as rectal surgery or bleeding.</td><td>Conditions contraindicate use of suppository.</td></tr><tr><td>3. Perform hand hygiene.</td><td>Reduces transfer of microorganisms.</td></tr><tr><td>4. Put on disposable gloves.</td><td>Prevents contact with infected faecal material.</td></tr><tr><td>5. Identify client; check name on MAR with client's identification bracelet and ask client's name.</td><td>Ensures that correct client receives medication.</td></tr><tr><td>6. Explain procedure. Be specific if client wishes to self-administer medication.</td><td>Promotes understanding and cooperation. Will enable client to self-administer medication if physically able.</td></tr><tr><td>7. Arrange supplies at bedside.</td><td>Ensures smooth procedure.</td></tr><tr><td>8. Close room curtain or door.</td><td>Maintains privacy and minimises embarrassment.</td></tr><tr><td>9. Help assume Sims' position. Keep client draped with only anal area exposed.</td><td>Exposes anus and helps client relax external anal sphincter. Maintains privacy and facilitates relaxation.</td></tr><tr><td>10. Examine condition of anus externally and palpate rectal walls as needed (see Chapter 27). If gloves become soiled, dispose of them by turning them inside out and placing them in appropriate receptacle.</td><td>Determines presence of active rectal bleeding. Palpation determines whether rectum is filled with faeces, which may interfere with suppository placement. Reduces transmission of infection.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Critical decision point: Generally, rectal suppository is contraindicated in the presence of active rectal bleeding. Unless suppository is for constipation, medication placed in a rectum filled with faeces may be poorly absorbed or prematurely expelled with defecation.</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>11. Put on disposable gloves (if previous gloves were discarded).</th><th>Minimises contact with faecal material and reduces transmission of microorganisms.</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>12. Remove suppository from wrapper and lubricate rounded end (see illustration). Lubricate index finger of dominant hand.</td><td>Lubrication reduces friction as suppository enters rectal canal.</td></tr><tr><td>13. Ask client to take slow deep breaths through mouth and relax anal sphincter.</td><td>Forcing suppository through constricted sphincter causes pain.</td></tr><tr><td>14. Retract buttocks with non-dominant hand. Insert suppository gently through anus, past internal sphincter and against rectal wall, 10 cm in adults, 5 cm in children and infants. May need to apply gentle pressure to hold buttocks together momentarily.</td><td>Suppository must be placed against rectal mucosa for eventual absorption and therapeutic action.</td></tr><tr><td>15. Withdraw finger and wipe anal area with tissue.</td><td>Provides comfort.</td></tr><tr><td>16. Discard gloves by turning them inside out, and dispose of them in appropriate receptacle.</td><td>Reduces transfer of microorganisms.</td></tr><tr><td>17. Ask client to remain flat or on side for 5 minutes.</td><td>Prevents expulsion of suppository.</td></tr><tr><td>18. If suppository contains laxative or faecal softener, place call light within reach.</td><td>Provides client with sense of control over elimination. Allows client to obtain assistance to bedpan or toilet.</td></tr><tr><td>19. Perform hand hygiene.</td><td>Reduces risk of transfer of infection.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>MEDICATION THERAPY 119</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>20. Return within 5 minutes to determine whether suppository was expelled.</td><td>Reinsertion may be necessary.</td></tr><tr><td>21. Observe for effects of suppository (e.g. bowel movement, relief of nausea) 30 minutes after administration.</td><td>Evaluates effectiveness of medication and relief of clientâ€™s symptoms.</td></tr><tr><td>RECORDING AND REPORTING</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Report occurrence of rectal bleeding to medical officer.</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="using-metered-dose-inhalers-mdis">Using metered-dose inhalers (MDIs)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#using-metered-dose-inhalers-mdis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="delegation-considerations">DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delegation-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Administering MDI and supervising clients who self-administer MDIs require the problem-solving and knowledge-application abilities of professional nurses. In some states of Australia and New Zealand, client care attendants or enrolled nurses may legally be able to administer medications via this route. For this procedure, client assessment by the registered nurse is required as delegation may not be appropriate.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>MDI with medication canister</li>
<li>Spacer (e.g. Volumatic) (optional)</li>
<li>Facial tissues (optional)</li>
<li>Washbasin or sink with warm water</li>
<li>Paper towel</li>
<li>Medication administration report (MAR)</li>
</ul>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>1. Review prescriber's order, including client's name, medication name, number of inhalations.</td><td>Ensures safe and correct administration of medication.</td></tr><tr><td>2. Identify client, compare name on MAR with client's ID bracelet and ask client's name.</td><td>Ensures that correct client receives medication.</td></tr><tr><td>3. Assess client's ability to hold, manipulate and depress canister and inhaler. Assess respiration and level of dyspnoea, and auscultate chest.</td><td>Any impairment of grasp or presence of hand tremors interferes with client's ability to depress canister within inhaler.</td></tr><tr><td>4. Assess client's readiness and ability to learn: client asks questions about medication, disease or complications; requests education in use of inhaler; is mentally alert; participates in own care. Client should not be fatigued, in pain or in respiratory distress. Assess level of understanding of technical vocabulary terms, and purpose and action of prescribed medications.</td><td>Affects client's ability to understand explanations and actively participate in teaching process. Mental or physical limitations affect client's ability to learn and the methods nurse uses for instruction. Knowledge of disease is essential for client to realistically understand use of inhaler.</td></tr><tr><td>5. Assess medication schedule and number of inhalations prescribed for each dose.</td><td>Influences explanations nurse provides for use of inhaler.</td></tr><tr><td>6. If previously instructed in self-administration of inhaled medicine, assess client's technique in using an inhaler.</td><td>Nurse's instruction may require only simple reinforcement, depending on client's level of dexterity.</td></tr><tr><td>7. Instruct client in comfortable environment by sitting in chair in hospital room or sitting at kitchen table in home.</td><td>Client will be more likely to remain receptive of nurse's explanations.</td></tr><tr><td>8. Provide adequate time for teaching session.</td><td>Prevents interruptions. Instruction should occur when client is receptive.</td></tr><tr><td>9. Perform hand hygiene and arrange equipment needed.</td><td>Reduces transfer of microorganisms; saves time.</td></tr><tr><td>10. Allow client opportunity to manipulate inhaler, canister and spacer device. Explain and demonstrate how canister fits into inhaler.</td><td>Client must be familiar with how to use equipment.</td></tr><tr><td>11. Explain what metered dose is, and warn client about overuse of inhaler, including medication side effects.</td><td>Client must not arbitrarily administer excessive inhalations because of risk of serious side effects. If medication is given in recommended doses, side effects are uncommon.</td></tr><tr><td>12. Explain steps for administering inhaled dose of medication (demonstrate steps when possible):</td><td>Use of simple, step-by-step explanations allows client to ask questions at any point during procedure.</td></tr><tr><td>a. Remove mouthpiece cover from inhaler.</td><td>Ensures fine particles are aerosolised.</td></tr><tr><td>b. Shake inhaler well.</td><td>Prepares the client's airway to receive the medication.</td></tr><tr><td>c. Have client take a deep breath and exhale.</td><td>Directs aerosol spray towards airway. Positioning the mouthpiece 2.5â€“5 cm from the mouth is considered the best way to deliver the medication.</td></tr><tr><td>d. Instruct the client to position the inhaler in one of two ways.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(1) Open lips and place inhaler in mouth with opening towards back of throat (see illustration).</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(2) Position the device 2.5â€“5 cm from the mouth (see illustration).</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>MEDICATION THERAPY 123</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>e. With the inhaler properly positioned, have client hold inhaler with thumb at the mouthpiece and the index and middle fingers at the top. This is called a three-point or lateral hand position.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>f. Instruct client to tilt head back slightly, inhale slowly and deeply through mouth and depress medication canister fully.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>g. Hold breath for approximately 10 seconds.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>h. Exhale through pursed lips.</td><td>MDIs work best when clients use a three-point or lateral hand position to activate canisters.</td></tr><tr><td>Medication is distributed to airways during inhalation. Inhalation through mouth rather than nose draws medication more effectively into airways.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Allows tiny drops of aerosol spray to reach deeper branches of airways.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Keeps small airways open during exhalation.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>13. Explain steps to administer inhaled dose of medication using a spacer such as a Volumatic (demonstrate when possible):</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>a. Remove mouthpiece cover from MDI and mouthpiece of spacer.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>b. Insert MDI into end of spacer.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>c. Shake inhaler well.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>d. Place spacer mouthpiece in mouth and close lips. Do not insert beyond raised lip on mouthpiece. Avoid covering small exhalation slots with the lips (see illustration).</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>e. Breathe normally through spacer mouthpiece.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>f. Depress medication canister, spraying one puff into spacer.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>g. Breathe in slowly and fully (for 5 seconds).</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>h. Hold full breath for 5â€“10 seconds.</td><td>Inhaler fits into end of spacer.</td></tr><tr><td>Spacer traps medication released from the MDI; the client then inhales the drug from the device. These devices deposit up to 80% more medication in the lungs rather than in the oropharynx.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Ensures fine particles are aerosolised.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Medication should not escape through mouth.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Allows client to relax before delivering medication.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Emits spray that allows finer particles to be inhaled. Large droplets are retained in spacer.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Ensures particles of medication are distributed to deeper airways.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Ensures full medication distribution.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Medications must be inhaled sequentially. First inhalation opens airways and reduces inflammation. Second or third inhalation penetrates deeper airways.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Medications are prescribed at intervals during day to provide constant drug levels and minimise side effects. Beta-adrenergic MDIs are used either on an â€˜as neededâ€™ basis or regularly every 4â€“6 h.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>14. Instruct client to wait 2â€“5 minutes between inhalations or as ordered by prescriber.</td><td>Results when inhalant is sprayed and inhaled incorrectly.</td></tr><tr><td>15. Instruct client against repeating inhalations before next scheduled dose.</td><td>Reduces buccal absorption of medication.</td></tr><tr><td>16. Explain that client may feel gagging sensation in throat caused by droplets of medication on pharynx or tongue.</td><td>Accumulation of spray around mouthpiece can interfere with proper distribution during use. Some medicines can also increase risk of oral candida (thrush) if not washed from mouth.</td></tr><tr><td>17. Instruct client to rinse mouth with water.</td><td>Clarifies misconceptions or misunderstanding.</td></tr><tr><td>18. Instruct client in removing medication canister and cleaning inhaler in warm water.</td><td>Return demonstration provides feedback for measuring clientâ€™s learning.</td></tr><tr><td>19. Ask if client has any questions.</td><td>Improves likelihood of compliance with therapy.</td></tr><tr><td>20. Have client explain and demonstrate steps in use of inhaler. Teach client how to check the volume of the inhaler.</td><td>Will allow client to recognise signs of overuse and need to seek medical support when medications are ineffective.</td></tr><tr><td>21. Ask client to explain medication schedule.</td><td>Determines status of breathing pattern and adequacy of ventilation.</td></tr><tr><td>22. Ask client to describe side effects of medication and criteria for calling prescriber.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>23. After medication instillation, assess clientâ€™s respirations and auscultate lungs.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>RECORDING AND REPORTING</td><td>HOME CARE CONSIDERATIONS</td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Document in nursesâ€™ notes what skills were taught and clientâ€™s ability to perform skills.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Record time when client used MDI (number of puffs).</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Report any undesirable effects from medication.</td><td>â€¢ Teach clients how to determine fullness of canisters, using displacement in water (see illustration below).</td></tr></tbody></table>

<p>SKILL 31-7</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="preparing-injections">Preparing injections<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#preparing-injections" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="delegation-considerations">DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delegation-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Preparing injections from ampoules and vials requires the problem-solving and knowledge-application abilities of professional nurses. In some states of Australia and New Zealand, client care attendants or enrolled nurses may legally be able to administer medications via this route. For this procedure, client assessment by the registered nurse is required as delegation may not be appropriate.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Medication in an ampoule:</li>
<li>Syringe and two needles (filter needle optional)</li>
<li>Small gauze pad or alcohol swab</li>
<li>Medication in a vial:</li>
<li>Syringe and two needles (filter needle optional)</li>
<li>Small gauze pad or alcohol swab</li>
<li>Diluent (e.g. normal saline or sterile water)</li>
<li>Both:</li>
<li>Medication administration record (MAR)</li>
</ul>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>1. Review order, including name and medication name, dose, route of administration and time of administration.</td><td>Ensures correct administration of medication.</td></tr><tr><td>2. Review pertinent information related to medication, including action, purpose, side effects and nursing implications.</td><td>Allows nurse to administer medication properly and to monitor client's response.</td></tr><tr><td>3. Check date of expiration of medication vial or ampoule.</td><td>Medication potency may increase or decrease when outdated.</td></tr><tr><td>4. Assess client's body build, muscle size and weight.</td><td>Determines type and size of syringe and needles for injection.</td></tr><tr><td>5. Perform hand hygiene.</td><td>Reduces transmission of microorganisms.</td></tr><tr><td>6. Prepare medication.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>A. Ampoule preparation</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(1) Tap top of ampoule lightly and quickly with finger until fluid moves from neck of ampoule (see illustration).</td><td>Dislodges any fluid that collects above neck of ampoule. All solution moves into lower chamber.</td></tr><tr><td>(2) Place small gauze pad around neck of ampoule.</td><td>Placing pad around neck of ampoule protects nurse's fingers from trauma as glass tip is broken off.</td></tr><tr><td>(3) Snap neck of ampoule quickly and firmly away from hands (see illustration).</td><td>Protects nurse's fingers and face from shattering glass.</td></tr><tr><td>(4) Draw up medication quickly.</td><td>System is open to airborne contaminants.</td></tr><tr><td>(5) Hold ampoule upside down, or set it on a flat surface. Insert syringe or filter needle (see agency policy) into centre of ampoule opening. Do not allow needle tip or shaft to touch rim of ampoule.</td><td>Broken rim of ampoule is considered contaminated. When ampoule is inverted, solution does dribble out if needle tip or shaft touches rim of ampoule.</td></tr><tr><td>(6) Aspirate medication into syringe by gently pulling back on plunger (see illustration).</td><td>Withdrawal of plunger creates negative pressure within syringe barrel, which pulls fluid into syringe.</td></tr><tr><td>(7) Keep needle tip under surface of liquid. Tip ampoule to bring all fluid within reach of the needle.</td><td>Prevents aspiration of air bubbles.</td></tr><tr><td>(8) If air bubbles are aspirated, do not expel air into ampoule.</td><td>Air pressure may force fluid out of ampoule and medication will be lost.</td></tr><tr><td>(9) To expel excess air bubbles, remove needle from ampoule. Hold syringe with needle pointing up. Tap side of syringe to cause bubbles to rise towards needle. Draw back slightly on plunger, and then push plunger upwards to eject air. Do not eject medication.</td><td>Withdrawing plunger too far will remove it from barrel. Holding syringe vertically allows fluid to settle in bottom of barrel. Pulling back on plunger allows fluid within needle to enter barrel so fluid is not expelled. Air at top of barrel and within needle is then expelled.</td></tr><tr><td>(10) If syringe contains excess medication, use sink for disposal. Hold syringe vertically with needle tip up and slanted slightly towards sink. Slowly eject excess medication into sink. Recheck medication level in syringe by holding it vertically.</td><td>Medication is safely dispersed into sink. Position of needle allows medication to be expelled without flowing down needle shaft. Rechecking fluid level ensures proper dose.</td></tr><tr><td>(11) Change needle on syringe.</td><td>New needle prevents tracking medication through skin and subcutaneous tissues. New needle is sharp and correct gauge and length.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>MEDICATION THERAPY 127</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><strong>B. Vial containing a solution</strong></td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>(1) Remove cap covering top of unused vial to expose sterile rubber seal, keeping rubber seal sterile. If reusing multidose vial, firmly and briskly wipe surface of rubber seal with alcohol swab and allow it to dry.</p>
<p>(2) Pick up syringe and remove needle cap. Pull back on plunger to draw amount of air into syringe equivalent to volume of medication to be aspirated from vial.</p>
<p>(3) With vial on flat surface, insert tip of needle with bevelled tip entering first through centre of rubber seal (see illustration). Apply pressure to tip of needle during insertion.</p>
<p>(4) Inject air into the vialâ€™s airspace, holding on to plunger. Hold plunger with firm pressure; plunger may be forced backwards by air pressure within the vial.</p>
<p>(5) Invert vial while keeping firm hold on syringe and plunger (see illustration). Hold vial between thumb and middle fingers of non-dominant hand. Grasp end of syringe barrel and plunger with thumb and forefinger of dominant hand to counteract pressure in vial.</p>
<p>(6) Keep tip of needle below fluid level.</p>
<p>(7) Allow air pressure from the vial to fill syringe gradually with medication. If necessary, pull back slightly on plunger to obtain correct amount of solution.</p>
<p>(8) When desired volume has been obtained, position needle into vialâ€™s airspace; tap side of syringe barrel carefully to dislodge any air bubbles. Eject any air remaining at top of syringe into vial.</p>
<p>(9) Remove needle from vial by pulling back on barrel of syringe.</p>
<p>(10) Hold syringe at eye level, at 90-degree angle, to ensure correct volume and absence of air bubbles. Remove any remaining air by tapping barrel to dislodge any air bubbles (see illustration). Draw back slightly on plunger; then push plunger upwards to eject air. Do not eject fluid.</p>
<p>(11) Change needle to appropriate gauge and length according to route of medication.</p>
<p>(12) For multidose vial, make label that includes date of mixing, concentration of medication per millilitre and nurseâ€™s initials. | Vial comes packaged with cap to prevent contamination of rubber seal. Cap cannot be replaced after seal removal. Allowing alcohol to dry prevents needle from being coated with alcohol and mixing with medication.</p>
<p>Air must first be injected into vial to prevent build-up of negative pressure in vial when aspirating medication.</p>
<p>Centre of seal is thinner and easier to penetrate. Injecting bevelled tip first and using firm pressure prevent coring of rubber seal, which could enter vial or needle.</p>
<p>Air must be injected before aspirating fluid. Injecting into vialâ€™s airspace prevents formation of bubbles and inaccuracy in dose.</p>
<p>Inverting vial allows fluid to settle in lower half of container. Position of hands prevents forceful movement of plunger and permits easy manipulation of syringe.</p>
<p>Prevents aspiration of air.
Positive pressure within vial forces fluid into syringe (unless vial has been used several times).</p>
<p>Forcefully striking barrel while needle is inserted in vial may bend needle. Accumulation of air displaces medication and causes dose errors.</p>
<p>Pulling plunger rather than barrel causes plunger to separate from barrel, resulting in loss of medication.
Holding syringe vertically allows fluid to settle in bottom of barrel. Pulling back on plunger allows fluid within needle to enter barrel so fluid is not expelled. Air at top of barrel and within needle is then expelled.</p>
<p>Inserting needle through a rubber stopper may dull bevelled tip. New needle is sharper. Because no fluid is along shaft, needle will not track medication through tissues. Ensures that future doses will be prepared correctly. Some medications must be discarded after certain number of days after mixing of vial.</p>
<p>Cap prevents contamination of rubber seal.</p>
<p>Prepares diluent for injection into vial containing powdered medication.
Diluent begins to dissolve and reconstitute medication.</p>
<p>Ensures proper dispersal of medication throughout solution. Shaking produces bubbles.
Once diluent has been added, concentration of medication (mg/mL) determines dose to be given.
Correct disposal of glass and needle prevents accidental injury to staff. Controls transmission of infection.  |
|  <strong>C. Vial containing a powder (reconstituting medications)</strong></p>
<p>(1) Remove cap covering vial of powdered medication.</p>
<p>(2) Draw up diluent into syringe following Steps 5B(2) to 5B(10).</p>
<p>(3) Insert tip of needle through centre of rubber seal of vial of powdered medication. Inject diluent into vial. Remove needle.</p>
<p>(4) Mix medication thoroughly. Roll in palms. Do not shake.</p>
<p>(5) Draw up the prescribed volume of reconstituted medication into syringe.</p>
<ol start="7">
<li>Dispose of soiled supplies. Place broken ampoule and/or used vials and used needle in puncture-proof and leakproof sharps container. Clean work area and perform hand hygiene. |   |</li>
</ol>
<p>FUNDAMENTALS OF NURSING: CLINICAL SKILLS WORKBOOK</p>

<p>SKILL 31-8</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="administering-injections">Administering injections<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#administering-injections" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="delegation-considerations">DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delegation-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Administering injections requires the problem-solving and knowledge-application abilities of professional nurses. For this procedure, delegation to nurse assistants is inappropriate. In some states of Australia and New Zealand, client care attendants or enrolled nurses may legally be able to administer medications via this route. For this procedure, client assessment by the registered nurse is required as delegation may not be appropriate.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Proper size syringe and needle:</li>
<li>Subcutaneous (subcut): Syringe (1â€“3 mL) and needle (25 to 26 gauge)</li>
<li>Intramuscular (IM): Syringe 2â€“3 mL for adult, 0.5â€“1 mL for infants and small children. Two needles: 21 to 24 gauge</li>
<li>Intradermal (ID): 1 mL tuberculin syringe with preattached 26 or 27 gauge needle</li>
<li>Small gauze pad and/or alcohol swab</li>
<li>Vial or ampoule of medication or skin test solution</li>
<li>Disposable gloves</li>
<li>Medication administration record (MAR)</li>
</ul>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><strong>For all injections</strong></td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<ol>
<li>Review prescriberâ€™s medication order for clientâ€™s name, medication name, dose, time and route of administration.</li>
<li>Assess clientâ€™s history of and known response to allergies.</li>
<li>Observe verbal and non-verbal responses towards receiving injection.</li>
<li>Assess for contraindications.</li>
</ol>
<p>A. For subcutaneous injections
Assess for factors such as circulatory shock or reduced local tissue perfusion. Assess adequacy of clientâ€™s adipose tissue.</p>
<p>B. For intramuscular injections
Assess for factors such as muscle atrophy, reduced blood flow or circulatory shock.
5. Prepare correct medication dose from ampoule or vial (see Skill 31-7). Check carefully. Be sure all air is expelled.
6. Identify client; check identification bracelet with MAR and ask clientâ€™s name.
7. Explain steps of procedure and tell client injection will cause a slight burning or sting.
8. Close room curtain or door.
9. Wash hands thoroughly; apply disposable gloves.
10. Keep sheet or gown draped over body parts not requiring exposure.
11. Select appropriate injection site. Inspect skin surface over sites for bruises, inflammation or oedema.
a. <em>subcut</em>: Palpate sites for masses or tenderness. Avoid these areas. For daily insulin, rotate site daily. Be sure needle is correct size by grasping skinfold at site with thumb and forefinger. Measure fold from top to bottom; needle should be half length.
b. <em>IM</em>: Note integrity and size of muscle and palpate for tenderness or hardness. Avoid these areas. If injections are given frequently, rotate sites.
c. <em>ID</em>: Note lesions or discolourations of forearm. Select site three to four fingerwidths below antecubital space and a bandwidth above wrist. | Ensures safe and correct administration of medication.
Certain substances have similar compositions; nurse should not administer any substance with known allergic response.
Injections can be painful. Anxiety can increase pain.</p>
<p>Reduced tissue perfusion interferes with medication absorption and distribution. Physiological changes of ageing or client illness may influence the amount of SC tissue a client possesses. This influences methods of administering injections.
Atrophied muscle absorbs medication poorly. Factors interfering with blood flow to muscles impair medication absorption.
Ensures that medication is sterile. Preparation techniques differ for ampoule and vial.
Ensures correct client receives ordered medication.</p>
<p>Helps minimise clientâ€™s anxiety.
Provides privacy.
Reduces transfer of microorganisms.
Selection of correct injection site may require exposure of body parts.  |</p>
<p>MEDICATION THERAPY 131</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Critical decision point: Injection sites should be free of abnormalities that may interfere with medication absorption. Sites used repeatedly can become hardened from lipohypertrophy (increased growth in fatty tissue). An ID site should be clear so that results of skin test can be seen and interpreted correctly.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>12. Help client to comfortable position:</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>a. subcut: Have client relax arm, leg or abdomen, depending on site chosen for injection.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>b. IM: Have client lie flat, on side or prone, depending on site chosen.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>c. ID: Have client extend elbow and support it and forearm on flat surface.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>d. Talk with client about subject of interest.</td><td>Relaxation of site minimises discomfort.</td></tr><tr><td>Reduces strain on muscle and minimises discomfort of injections.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Stabilises injection site for easiest accessibility.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Distraction reduces anxiety.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Critical decision point: Ensure that clientâ€™s position is not contraindicated by medical condition.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>13. Relocate site using anatomical landmarks.</td><td>Injection into correct anatomical site prevents injury to nerves, bones and blood vessels.</td></tr><tr><td>14. Clean site with an antiseptic swab. Apply swab at centre of the site and rotate outwards in a circular direction for about 5 cm (see illustration).</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Note: Some agencies may not require the use of alcohol swabs before giving an injection, but the evidence for this is not clear so many agencies will still require this step.</td><td>Mechanical action of swab removes secretions containing microorganisms.</td></tr><tr><td>15. Hold swab or gauze between third and fourth fingers of non-dominant hand.</td><td>Gauze or swab remains readily accessible when needle is withdrawn.</td></tr><tr><td>16. Remove needle cap from needle by pulling it straight off.</td><td>Prevents needle from touching and contaminating sides of cap.</td></tr><tr><td>17. Hold syringe between thumb and forefinger of dominant hand:</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>a. subcut: Hold as dart, palm down (see illustration) or hold syringe across tops of fingertips.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>b. IM: Hold as dart, palm down.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>c. ID: Hold bevel of needle pointing up.</td><td>Quick, smooth needle insertion minimises discomfort.</td></tr><tr><td>With bevel up, medication is less likely to be deposited into tissues below dermis.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>18. Administer injection:</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>A. Subcutaneous</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(1) For average-size client, spread skin tightly across injection site or pinch skin with non-dominant hand.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(2) Inject needle quickly and firmly at 45- to 90-degree angle. Then release skin, if pinched.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(3) For obese client, pinch skin at site and inject needle at 90-degree angle below tissue fold.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(4) Inject medication slowly.</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>B. Intramuscular:
(1) Position non-dominant hand at proper anatomical landmarks and pull skin down to administer in a Z-track.
(2) If clientâ€™s muscle mass is small, grasp body of muscle between thumb and fingers.
(3) Insert needle quickly at 90-degree angle into muscle. After needle enters site, grasp lower end of syringe barrel with non-dominant hand. Move dominant hand to end of plunger. Avoid moving syringe while slowly pulling back on plunger to aspirate drug (see illustration). If blood appears in syringe, remove needle, discard medication and syringe and repeat procedure. | Needle penetrates tight skin more easily than loose skin. Pinching skin elevates subcutaneous tissue and may desensitise area.
Injecting medication into compressed tissue irritates nerve fibres.
Obese clients have fatty layer of tissue above subcutaneous layer.
Aspiration of heparin injection may cause the needle to move, creating tissue damage and bleeding (haematoma).
Speeds insertion and reduces discomfort. Creates zigzag path through tissues that seals needle track to avoid leaking of medication into subcutaneous tissue.
Ensures that medication reaches muscle mass.
Properly performed injection requires smooth manipulation of syringe parts. Movement of syringe may displace needle and cause discomfort. Aspiration of blood into syringe indicates IV placement of needle; subcut and IM injections are not for IV use (dermis is relatively vascular).  |
|  Critical decision point: If blood appears in syringe (indicating needle is in the bloodstream rather than into the muscle), remove needle and dispose of medication and syringe correctly. Repeat preparation procedure.  |   |</p>
<p>FUNDAMENTALS OF NURSING: CLINICAL SKILLS WORKBOOK</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>(4) Inject medication slowly.</td><td>Slow injection reduces pain and tissue trauma.</td></tr><tr><td>(5) Smoothly and steadily withdraw needle and release skin.</td><td>Support of tissues around infection site minimises discomfort during needle withdrawal. Some advocate use of dry gauze to minimise client discomfort associated with alcohol on non-intact skin.</td></tr><tr><td>C. Intradermal</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(1) With non-dominant hand, stretch skin over site with forefinger or thumb.</td><td>Needle pierces tight skin more easily.</td></tr><tr><td>(2) With needle almost against client's skin, insert it slowly at a 5- to 15-degree angle until resistance is felt. Then advance needle through epidermis to approximately 3 mm below skin surface. Needle tip can be seen through skin.</td><td>Ensures needle tip is in dermis.</td></tr><tr><td>(3) Inject medication slowly. Normally, resistance is felt. If not, needle is too deep; remove and begin again.</td><td>Slow injection minimises discomfort at site. Dermal layer is tight and does not expand easily when solution is injected.</td></tr><tr><td>(4) While injecting medication, notice that small bleb approximately 6 mm resembling mosquito bite appears on skin's surface (see illustration).</td><td>Bleb indicates medication is deposited in dermis.</td></tr><tr><td>19. Withdraw needle while applying alcohol swab or gauze gently over site. Support of tissue around injection site minimises discomfort during needle withdrawal.</td><td>Some advocate the use of dry gauze to minimise client discomfort associated with alcohol on non-intact skin.</td></tr><tr><td>20. Do not massage site after subcut injection of heparin or insulin or after IM or ID injection.</td><td>Massage of site after heparin injection may cause bleeding; massage after insulin injection may increase absorption of insulin. Massage of IM site may cause underlying tissue damage. Massage of ID site may disperse medication into underlying tissue and alter test results.</td></tr><tr><td>21. Help client to comfortable position.</td><td>Gives client sense of wellbeing.</td></tr><tr><td>22. Discard uncapped needle or needle enclosed in safety shield and attached syringe into puncture and leakproof receptacle.</td><td>Needles should not be recapped before disposal. Safety shields prevent needle-stick injuries.</td></tr><tr><td>23. Remove disposable gloves and perform hand hygiene.</td><td>Reduces transmission of microorganisms.</td></tr><tr><td>24. Stay with client for 3â€“5 minutes and observe for any adverse reactions.</td><td>Severe anaphylactic reaction is characterised by dyspnoea, wheezing and circulatory collapse.</td></tr><tr><td>25. Ask whether client feels any acute pain, burning, numbness or tingling at injection site.</td><td>Continued discomfort may indicate injury to underlying bones or nerves.</td></tr><tr><td>26. Inspect site, noting any bruising or induration.</td><td>Bruising or induration indicates complication associated with injection. Notify nurse in charge or medical officer. Provide warm compress to site.</td></tr><tr><td>27. Return to evaluate client's response to medication in 10â€“30 minutes. IM medications absorb quickly; undesired effects may also develop rapidly.</td><td>Nurse's observations determine efficacy of medication action.</td></tr><tr><td>28. Ask client to explain purpose and effects of medication.</td><td>Evaluates client's understanding of information taught.</td></tr><tr><td>29. For ID injections, use skin pencil and draw circle around perimeter of injection site. Read site within 48â€“72 hours of injection.</td><td>Site must be read at various intervals to determine test results. Pencil mark makes site easy to find.</td></tr><tr><td>RECORDING AND REPORTING</td><td>HOME CARE CONSIDERATIONS</td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Chart medication dose, route, site, time and date given in medication record.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Report any undesirable effects from medication to nurse in charge or medical officer.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Record client's response to medications in nurses' notes.</td><td>â€¢ Clients with hypertrophy of the skin from repeated insulin injections (common with beef or pork formulations) should be taught not to use the site for 6 months.</td></tr></tbody></table>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="skill-31-9">SKILL 31-9<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#skill-31-9" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="adding-medications-to-intravenous-fluid-containers">Adding medications to intravenous fluid containers<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#adding-medications-to-intravenous-fluid-containers" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="delegation-considerations">DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delegation-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Adding medications to IV fluid containers requires the problem-solving and knowledge-application abilities of professional nurses. For this procedure, delegation to nurse assistants is inappropriate. (In some institutions the pharmacist may add medications to primary containers of IV solutions.)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Vial or ampoule of prescribed medication</li>
<li>Syringe of appropriate size (5â€“20 mL)</li>
<li>Sterile interlink cannula or needle (19 to 21 gauge) with special filters (optional)</li>
<li>Correct diluent (e.g. sterile water, normal saline)</li>
<li>Sterile IV fluid container of ordered fluid volume</li>
<li>Alcohol or antiseptic swab</li>
<li>Label to attach to IV bag or bottle</li>
<li>Medication administration record (MAR)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="steps">STEPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Check prescriberâ€™s order to determine type of IV solution to use and type of medication and dosage.</li>
<li>Collect information necessary to administer drug safely, including action, purpose, side effects, normal dose, time of peak onset and nursing implications.</li>
<li>When more than one medication is to be added to IV solution, assess for compatibility of medications.</li>
<li>Assess clientâ€™s systemic fluid balance, as reflected by skin hydration and turgor, bodyweight, pulse, blood pressure and urine output.</li>
<li>Assess clientâ€™s history of medication allergies.</li>
<li>Assess IV insertion site for signs of infiltration or phlebitis.</li>
<li>Perform hand hygiene and use gloves if this is agency policy (i.e. for cytotoxic or antibiotic medicines).</li>
<li>Assemble supplies in medication room (or other area as designated by clinical agency).</li>
<li>Prepare prescribed medication from vial or ampoule (see Skill 31-7).</li>
<li>Identify client by reading identification band and asking name. Compare with MAR.</li>
<li>Assess clientâ€™s understanding of purpose of medication therapy.</li>
<li>Add medication to new container (usually done in medication room):</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Solution in a bag: locate medication injection port on plastic IV solution bag. Port has small stopper at end. Do not select port for the IV tubing insertion or air vent.
b. Solution in a bottle: locate injection site on IV solution bottle, which is often covered by a cap.
c. Wipe off port or injection site with alcohol/antiseptic swab (see illustration).
d. Remove needle cap or sheath from syringe and insert needle of syringe or needleless device through centre of injection port or site; inject medication (see illustration).
e. Withdraw syringe from bag or bottle.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="rationale">RATIONALE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rationale" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Clientâ€™s overall physical condition dictates type of IV solution used. Ensures safe and accurate medication administration.</p>
<p>Allows nurse to give medication safely and to monitor clientâ€™s response to therapy.</p>
<p>Medications are often incompatible when mixed together. Chemical reactions that occur result in clouding or crystallisation of IV fluids. Check clinical agency policy for approved medication compatibility list.</p>
<p>Danger of continuous IV infusions is that fluids may infuse too rapidly, causing circulatory overload.</p>
<p>IV administration of medications causes rapid effects. Allergic response can be immediate.</p>
<p>An intact, properly functioning site ensures medication is given safely.</p>
<p>Reduces transfer of microorganisms.</p>
<p>Ensures orderly procedure, with less likelihood of contaminating supplies.</p>
<p>Ensures accurate delivery of medication.</p>
<p>Ensures correct client receives medication.</p>
<p>May reveal need for education.</p>
<p>Medication injection port is self-sealing to prevent introduction of microorganisms after repeated use.</p>
<p>Accidental injection of medication through main tubing port or air vent can alter pressure within bottle and cause fluid leaks through air vent. Cap seals bottle to maintain its sterility.</p>
<p>Reduces risk of introducing microorganisms.</p>
<p>Injection of needle into sides of port may produce leak and lead to fluid contamination.</p>
<p>FUNDAMENTALS OF NURSING: CLINICAL SKILLS WORKBOOK</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>f. Mix medication and IV solution by holding bag or bottle and turning it gently end to end.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>g. Complete medication label with name and dose of medication, date, time and nurse's initials and attach to bottle or bag (see illustration). Optional (check agency policy): Apply a flow strip that identifies the time the solution was hung and intervals indicating fluid levels. Spike bag or bottle with IV tubing and prime the tubing with the fluid.</td><td>Allows even distribution of medication.</td></tr><tr><td>Label can be easily read during infusion of solution. Informs nurses and other healthcare workers of contents of bag or bottle. Priming the line removes the air within the tubing which reduces risk of air embolism.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Critical decision point: Do not use felt-tip markers on plastic surfaces. The ink can penetrate the plastic and leak into the IV solution.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>13. Bring assembled items to client's bedside and check client's name against the prescriber's orders.</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<ol start="14">
<li>Prepare client by explaining that medication is to be given through existing IV line or one to be started. Explain that no discomfort should be felt during medication infusion. Encourage client to report symptoms of discomfort.</li>
<li>Regulate infusion at prescribed rate.</li>
<li>Add medication to existing container:
a. Prepare vented IV bottle or plastic bag:
(1) Check volume of solution remaining in bottle or bag.
(2) Close off IV infusion clamp.
(3) Wipe off medication port with an alcohol or antiseptic swab.
(4) Insert syringe needle or needleless device through injection port and inject medication.
(5) Lower bag or bottle from IV pole and gently mix. Rehang bag.
b. Complete medication label and attach it to bag or bottle.
c. Regulate infusion to desired rate.</li>
<li>Properly dispose of equipment and supplies. Do not cap needle on syringe. Specially sheathed needles are discarded as a unit with needle covered.</li>
<li>Perform hand hygiene.</li>
<li>Observe client for signs or symptoms of adverse reaction.</li>
<li>Observe for signs and symptoms of fluid volume excess.</li>
<li>Periodically return to client's room to assess IV insertion site and rate of infusion.</li>
<li>Observe for signs or symptoms of IV infiltration. | Ensures correct client receives ordered medication.
Most IV medications do not cause discomfort when diluted. Pain at insertion site may be early indication of infiltration.
Prevents rapid infusion of fluid.
Ensures the appropriate minimal volume is available to dilute medication adequately.
Prevents medication from directly entering circulation as it is injected into bag or bottle.
Mechanically removes microorganisms that could enter container during needle insertion.
Injection port is self-sealing and prevents fluid leaks.
Ensures medication is evenly distributed.
Informs nurses and doctors of contents of bag or bottle.
Prevents rapid infusion of fluid.
Proper disposal of needle prevents injury to nurse and client. Capping of needles increases risk of needle-stick injuries.
Reduces transmission of microorganisms.
IV medications can cause rapid effects.
Rapid uncontrolled infusion can cause circulatory overload.
Over time IV site may become infiltrated or cannula may become malpositioned. Flow rate may change according to client's position or volume left in container.
Infiltrated medications can injure tissue.  |
|  RECORDING AND REPORTING  |   |
|  â€¢ Record solution and medication added to parenteral fluid on appropriate form.
â€¢ Report any adverse reactions to nurse in charge or prescriber.  |   |</li>
</ol>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="adding-medications-to-intravenous-fluid-containers">ADDING MEDICATIONS TO INTRAVENOUS FLUID CONTAINERS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#adding-medications-to-intravenous-fluid-containers" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>CLINICAL SKILL 31-9: Adding medications to intravenous fluid containers</p>
<p>DEMONSTRATES: The ability to effectively and safely add medications to intravenous fluid containers</p>
<p>DOMAIN/S (AUS): Professional Practice and Provision and Coordination of Care</p>
<p>DOMAIN/S (NZ): Professional responsibility; management of nursing care; interpersonal relationships; interprofessional healthcare and quality improvement</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="administering-medications-by-intravenous-bolus">Administering medications by intravenous bolus<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#administering-medications-by-intravenous-bolus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="delegation-considerations">DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delegation-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Administering medications by intravenous bolus requires the problem-solving and knowledge-application abilities of professional nurses. For this procedure, delegation to nurse assistants is inappropriate.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="definitions">DEFINITIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#definitions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Bolus</strong>: method of rapid IV medication administration; refers to the concentration or amount of medication.</p>
<p><strong>Flush</strong>: solution (usually 5â€“10 mL normal saline) is slowly administered to check patency of cannula; to flush medication from cannula or to create a lock (saline or heparin).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>IV medication (existing infusion):</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Disposable gloves</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Medication in vial or ampoule</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Syringe</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Needleless device or sterile needles (21 and 25 gauge)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Antiseptic swab</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Watch with second-hand or digital readout</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Medication administration record (MAR)</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>IV flush (IV lock):</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Disposable gloves</li>
<li>Medication in vial or ampoule</li>
<li>Syringe</li>
<li>Vial of appropriate flush solution (5â€“10 mL saline most common, but heparin may also be used; if heparin is used, most common concentration is 10â€“100 units; check agency policy)</li>
<li>Needleless device or sterile needles (21 and 25 gauge)</li>
<li>Alcohol or antiseptic swab</li>
<li>Watch with second-hand or digital readout</li>
<li>Medication administration record (MAR)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="steps">STEPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Check the prescriberâ€™s order for type, dosage, route and time of medication.</li>
<li>Assess IV insertion site for signs of infiltration or phlebitis.</li>
<li>If medication is to be pushed into an IV line, assess the patency of the line.</li>
<li>Prepare ordered medication from vial or ampoule (see Skill 31-7). Read directions carefully for proper IV dilution of medications.</li>
<li>After drawing up medications, remove the needle (for needleless system) otherwise apply a small-gauge needle to the syringe (this system is rarely used).</li>
<li>Perform hand hygiene. Put on gloves.</li>
<li>Check clientâ€™s identification by looking at identification bracelet and asking name and any known allergies.</li>
<li>Administer medications by IV medication (existing infusion):</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Select injection port of IV tubing closest to client. (Circle on port may indicate site for needle insertion.) If add-on 0.22 micrometre filter is used, give medication below filter next to client.
b. Clean injection port with antiseptic swab. Allow to dry.
c. Connect syringe to IV line (needleless) or insert needle of syringe containing prepared drug through centre of injection port (see illustration).
d. Check patency (Box 31-17) to ensure safe and adequate medication administration.
e. Leave concurrent compatible infusion running and inject medication slowly over several minutes as per directions on medication package. Use watch to time administration (see illustration).
f. After injecting medication, withdraw syringe, and recheck fluid infusion rate.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="rationale">RATIONALE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rationale" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Ensures safe and accurate medication administration.</strong></p>
<p>Confirming the placement of the IV catheter and the integrity of the surrounding tissue ensures that the medication is administered safely.</p>
<p>The IV line must be patent for medication to reach venous circulation effectively.</p>
<p>Directions can be found in Australian Injectable Handbook, from package instructions or in MIMS Annual.</p>
<p>Used to insert through IV line with needle system only.</p>
<p>During IV bolus administration, risk of blood exposure is low. However, nurse may manipulate IV dressing or expose site while completing other activities. Gloves reduce exposure.</p>
<p>Ensures that medication is administered to correct client.</p>
<p><strong>Allows for easier fluid aspiration to obtain blood return. Injection ports are self-sealing and will not leak.</strong></p>
<p><strong>Prevents introduction of microorganisms during needle insertion.</strong></p>
<p><strong>Prevents damage to portâ€™s diaphragm and subsequent leakage.</strong></p>
<p>Final check that medication is being delivered into the bloodstream.</p>
<p><strong>Ensures safe medication infusion. Rapid injection of IV medication can prove fatal.</strong></p>
<p>Injection of bolus may alter rate of fluid infusion. Rapid fluid infusion can cause circulatory overload.</p>
<p>FUNDAMENTALS OF NURSING: CLINICAL SKILLS WORKBOOK</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>9. Administer medications into IV cannula (non-concurrent infusion) (IV lock or a needleless system):</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><strong>A. Prepare flushing solutions</strong>
(1) Flushing with heparin:
a. Prepare syringe with heparin flush solution as per prescriber's orders.
b. Prepare 2 syringes with 5â€“10 mL of normal saline.</p>
<p>(2) Flushing with saline only:
a. Prepare 2 syringes with 5â€“10 mL of normal saline each.</p>
<p><strong>B. IV lock</strong>
(1) Clean lock's rubber diaphragm with antiseptic swab.
(2) Insert needle of syringe containing normal saline through centre of diaphragm (only for needle-based systems)
(3) Pull back gently on syringe plunger and look for blood return. | Flush solution keeps heparin lock patent after medication is administered.</p>
<p>Prevents introduction of microorganisms during needle insertion.</p>
<p>Determines whether IV needle or catheter is positioned in vein.  |
|  <strong>Critical decision point:</strong> At times a heparin lock will not yield a blood return even though the lock is patent.  |   |
|  (4) Flush reservoir with saline by pushing slowly on plunger. | Clears needle and reservoir of blood.  |
|  <strong>Critical decision point:</strong> Observe closely the area of skin above the IV catheter. Note any puffiness or swelling as the reservoir is flushed, which could indicate infiltration into the tissues, requiring removal of the catheter.  |   |
|  (5) Remove needle and syringe.
(6) Clean lock's diaphragm with antiseptic swab.
(7) Insert needle of syringe containing prepared medication through centre of diaphragm (see illustration).
(8) Inject medication bolus slowly over several minutes. (Each medication has recommended rate for bolus administration. Check package directions.) Use watch to time administration.
(9) After administering bolus, withdraw syringe.
(10) Clean lock's diaphragm with antiseptic swab.
(11) Repeat injection of normal saline.
(12) <em>Heparin flush</em>: insert needle of syringe containing heparin through diaphragm. Inject heparin slowly, and remove syringe.</p>
<p><strong>C. IV needleless valve cap</strong>
(1) Insert syringe (without a needle) containing normal saline into the valve.
(2) Flush reservoir with saline by pushing slowly on plunger.
(3) Remove the syringe.
(4) Insert syringe containing prepared medication into the valve.
(5) Inject medication slowly over several minutes. Follow precautions in Step 9B(8).
(6) After administering bolus, withdraw syringe.
(7) Repeat injection of 1 mL of normal saline.
(8) See Step 9B(12).
(9) Replace sterile cap over valve. | Prevents transmission of infection.
Using centre of diaphragm prevents leakage.</p>
<p>Rapid injection of IV medication can result in death.</p>
<p>Prevents transmission of microorganisms.
Flushes reservoir and needle of medication.
Maintains patency of needle by inhibiting clot formation.</p>
<p>Clears reservoir of any blood.</p>
<p>Rapid injection of IV drug can result in death.  |
|  RECORDING AND REPORTING  |   |
|  â€¢ Record medication, dose, time and route on appropriate form.
â€¢ Report any side effects immediately to prescriber, because they could be life-threatening.  |   |</p>
<p>MEDICATION THERAPY 141</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="administering-medications-by-intravenous-bolus">ADMINISTERING MEDICATIONS BY INTRAVENOUS BOLUS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#administering-medications-by-intravenous-bolus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>CLINICAL SKILL 31-10: Administering medications by intravenous bolus</p>
<p>DEMONSTRATES: The ability to effectively and safely administer medications by intravenous bolus</p>
<p>DOMAIN/S (AUS): Professional Practice and Provision and Coordination of Care</p>
<p>DOMAIN/S (NZ): Professional responsibility; management of nursing care; interpersonal relationships; interprofessional healthcare and quality improvement</p>
<p>PERFORMANCE CRITERIA: (numbers indicate National Competency Standards for the Registered Nurse)</p>
