<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="administering-intravenous-medications-by-piggyback-tandem-set-up-intermittent-intravenous-infusion-sets-and-mini-infusion-pumps">Administering intravenous medications by piggyback/tandem set-up, intermittent intravenous infusion sets and mini-infusion pumps<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#administering-intravenous-medications-by-piggyback-tandem-set-up-intermittent-intravenous-infusion-sets-and-mini-infusion-pumps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="delegation-considerations">DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delegation-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Administering medications by IV fluid by piggyback/tandem set-up, intermittent intravenous infusion sets and mini-infusion pumps requires the problem-solving and knowledge-application abilities of professional nurses. For this procedure, delegation is inappropriate.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Piggyback, tandem or mini-infusion pump</p>
<ul>
<li>Gloves (for connecting IV tubing)</li>
<li>Medication prepared in 5â€“150 mL labelled infusion bag or syringe</li>
<li>Short microdrip or macrodrip tubing set for piggyback/tandem</li>
<li>Needleless device</li>
<li>Needles (21 or 23 gauge, only if stopcocks or other needleless methods are not available)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="step-5">STEP 5<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#step-5" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Check prescriberâ€™s order to determine type of IV solution to be used, type of medication, dose, route and time of administration.</li>
<li>Collect information necessary to administer medication safely, including action, purpose, side effects, normal dose, time of peak onset and nursing implications.</li>
<li>Assess patency of clientâ€™s existing IV infusion line (Box 31-17).</li>
<li>Assess IV insertion site for signs of infiltration or phlebitis: redness, pallor, swelling, tenderness on palpation.</li>
<li>Assess clientâ€™s history of medication allergies.</li>
<li>Assemble supplies at bedside. Inform client that medication will be given through IV equipment.</li>
<li>Perform hand hygiene and put on gloves.</li>
<li>Check name on MAR with clientâ€™s identification bracelet and ask clientâ€™s name and any known allergies.</li>
<li>Assess clientâ€™s understanding of purpose of medication therapy.</li>
<li>Explain purpose of medication and side effects to client and explain that medication is to be given through existing IV line. Encourage client to report symptoms of discomfort at site.</li>
<li>Administer infusion:</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="a-piggyback-or-tandem-infusion">A. Piggyback or tandem infusion<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-piggyback-or-tandem-infusion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>(1) Connect infusion tubing to medication bag. Allow solution to fill tubing by opening regulator flow clamp (priming).</p>
<ul>
<li>Stopcocks</li>
<li>Mini-infusion pump</li>
<li>Adhesive tape (optional)</li>
<li>Alcohol or antiseptic swab</li>
<li>IV pole or rack</li>
<li>Medication administration record (MAR)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="volume-control-administration-set">Volume-control administration set<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#volume-control-administration-set" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Gloves (for connecting IV tubing)</li>
<li>Burette</li>
<li>Infusion tubing (may have needleless system attachment)</li>
<li>Syringe (5â€“20 mL)</li>
<li>Vial or ampoule of ordered medication</li>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="rationale">RATIONALE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rationale" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Clientâ€™s overall physical condition dictates type of IV solution used. Ensures safe and accurate medication administration.</p>
<p>Allows nurse to give medication safely and to monitor clientâ€™s response to therapy.</p>
<p>IV line must be patent for medication to reach venous circulation effectively.</p>
<p>Confirmation of placement of IV needle or catheter and integrity of surrounding tissues ensures medication is administered safely.</p>
<p>Effects of medications can develop rapidly after IV infusion. Nurse should be aware of clients at risk.</p>
<p>Medication preparation is not usually required. Nurse may assemble infusion tubing and bag of medication in medication room or clientâ€™s room. Allows client to understand procedure and minimises anxiety.</p>
<p>Reduces transmission of infection. During handling of IV tubing there is some risk of blood exposure.</p>
<p>Ensures medication is administered to correct client.</p>
<p>May reveal need for education.</p>
<p>Keeps client informed of planned therapies.</p>
<p>Infusion tubing should be filled/primed with solution and free of air bubbles to prevent air embolus.</p>
<p>FUNDAMENTALS OF NURSING: CLINICAL SKILLS WORKBOOK</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>(2) Hang piggyback medication bag above level of primary fluid bag. (Hook may be used to lower main bag.) Hang tandem infusion at same level as primary fluid bag (see illustration).</td><td>Height of fluid bag affects rate of flow.</td></tr><tr><td>(3) Connect tubing of piggyback or tandem infusion to appropriate connector on primary infusion line:</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>a. Stopcock: Wipe off stopcock port with alcohol swab and connect tubing. Turn stopcock to open position.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>b. Needleless system: Wipe off needleless port, and insert tip of piggyback or tandem infusion tubing (see illustration).</td><td>Stopcock eliminates need for needle.</td></tr><tr><td>(4) Regulate flow rate of medication solution by adjusting regulator clamp. (Usually medication should infuse within 20â€“90 min.) Make your client comfortable and stay with them for 3â€“5 mins to watch for signs of allergic reaction.</td><td>Establishes route for IV medication to enter main IV line.</td></tr><tr><td>(5) After medication has infused, check flow regulator on primary infusion. Back-check valve on piggyback stops flow of the primary infusion until second medication infuses. The tandem and primary infusions flow together until the tandem set empties.</td><td>Provides slow, intermittent infusion of medication in 20â€“90 min; maintains therapeutic blood levels. Read medication package insert for specific information on how long to infuse the medication.</td></tr><tr><td>(6) Regulate main infusion line to desired rate, if necessary.</td><td>Valve prevents backup of medication into main infusion line. Checking flow rate ensures proper administration of IV fluids.</td></tr><tr><td>(7) Leave secondary bag and tubing in place for future medication administration or discard in appropriate containers.</td><td>Infusion of piggyback may interfere with the main line infusion rate.</td></tr><tr><td>B. Volume-control administration set (e.g. burette)</td><td>Establishment of secondary line produces route for microorganisms to enter main line. Repeated changes in tubing increase risk of infection transmission (check clinical agency policy).</td></tr><tr><td>(1) Assemble supplies in medication room.</td><td>Controls risk of contaminating IV solution.</td></tr><tr><td>(2) Prepare medication from vial or ampoule (see Skill 31-7).</td><td>Ensures medication is sterile.</td></tr><tr><td>(3) Explain procedure to client. Encourage client to report symptoms of discomfort at site. Check clientâ€™s name against prescriberâ€™s orders and assess clientâ€™s condition to ascertain if it is appropriate to administer medication.</td><td>Keeps client informed of planned therapies.</td></tr><tr><td>(4) Fill burette chamber with desired amount of fluid (50â€“100 mL) by opening clamp between chamber and main IV bag (see illustration).</td><td>Small volume of fluid dilutes IV medication and reduces risk of too-rapid infusion.</td></tr><tr><td>(5) Close clamp and check to be sure clamp on air vent of chamber is open.</td><td>Prevents additional leakage of fluid into chamber. Air vent allows fluid in chamber to exit at regulated rate.</td></tr><tr><td>(6) Clean injection port on top of chamber with antiseptic swab.</td><td>Prevents introduction of microorganisms during medication insertion.</td></tr><tr><td>(7) Remove needle cap or sheath and insert syringe needle through port, then inject medication (see illustration). Gently rotate chamber between hands. If burette has a needleless valve then inject medication directly into the burette with the syringe only.</td><td>Rotating mixes medication with solution in chamber to ensure equal distribution.</td></tr><tr><td>(8) Regulate IV infusion rate to allow medication to infuse at the required rate.</td><td>For optimal therapeutic effect, medication should infuse in prescribed time interval.</td></tr><tr><td>(9) Label chamber with name of medication, dosage, total volume including diluent and time of administration.</td><td>Alerts nurses to medication being infused. Prevents other medications from being added to chamber.</td></tr><tr><td>(10) Dispose of uncapped needle or needle enclosed in safety shield and syringe in proper container. Remove gloves and wash your hands.</td><td>Prevents accidental needle-stick injuries and transfer of microorganisms.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>MEDICATION THERAPY 145</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>(11) Make your client comfortable and stay with them for 3â€“5 minutes to ensure that they have not had any adverse reactions. During the infusion ensure you check the infusion rate and condition of the IV site.</td><td>Ensures timely intervention can occur in the case of allergy or infiltrated IV site.</td></tr><tr><td>(12) After the medicine has infused, check and regulate the flow of the primary infusion. Leave secondary bag and tubing in place for future medicine administration or discard according to agency policy.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>C. Mini-infusor/syringe driver administration</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(1) Connect prefilled syringe to mini-infusion tubing.</td><td>Special tubing designed to fit syringe delivers medication to main IV line.</td></tr><tr><td>(2) Carefully apply pressure to syringe plunger, allowing tubing to fill with medication.</td><td>Ensures tubing is free of air bubbles to prevent air embolus.</td></tr><tr><td>(3) Place syringe into mini-infusor/syringe driver pump (follow product directions). Be sure syringe is secure.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(4) Connect mini-infusion tubing to main IV line.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(a) Stopcock: Wipe off stopcock port with alcohol swab and connect tubing. Turn stopcock to open position.</td><td>Stopcock reduces risk of needle-stick injuries.</td></tr><tr><td>(b) Needleless system: Wipe off needleless port and insert tip of mini-infusor tubing.</td><td>Needleless system reduces risk of needle-stick injuries.</td></tr><tr><td>(5) Explain purpose of medication and side effects to client and explain that medication is to be given through existing IV line. Ask client to report symptoms of discomfort at site. Check clientâ€™s name against prescriberâ€™s orders and assess clientâ€™s condition to ascertain if it is appropriate to administer medication.</td><td>Informs client of planned therapies and assesses if medicine is given to the correct client.</td></tr><tr><td>(6) Hang infusion pump with syringe on IV pole alongside main IV bag. Press button on pump to begin infusion. Optional: set alarm.</td><td>Pump automatically delivers medication at safe, constant rate based on volume in syringe. (Alarm is used if medication is delivered into heparin/saline lock.)</td></tr><tr><td>(7) Remove disposable gloves. Wash hands.</td><td>Reduces transmission of infection.</td></tr><tr><td>12. Observe client for signs of adverse reactions.</td><td>IV medications act rapidly.</td></tr><tr><td>13. During infusion, periodically check infusion rate and condition of IV site.</td><td>IV must remain patent for proper medication administration. Development of infiltration necessitates discontinuing infusion.</td></tr><tr><td>RECORDING AND REPORTING</td><td>HOME CARE CONSIDERATIONS</td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Record medication, dose, route and time administered on MAR.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Record volume of fluid in medication bag or chamber on intake and output form.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Report any adverse reactions to nurse in charge or prescriber.</td><td>â€¢ Ensure that all needles contaminated by blood are disposed of in puncture-resistant containers (e.g. small sharps container, or if not available a coffee tin while a sharps container is being organised).</td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Piggyback tubing and intravenous container should be disposed of in non-puncture container or according to agency policy.</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>

<p>CLINICAL SKILL 31-11: Administering intravenous medications by piggyback/tandem set-up, intermittent intravenous infusion sets and mini-infusion pumps</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="promoting-mobility">Promoting mobility<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#promoting-mobility" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="overview">Overview<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#overview" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Mobility is an important body function that is often taken for granted. It is not until mobility is impaired, through either injury or deterioration, that the importance of mobility is fully realised. For this reason, it is important to maintain the musculoskeletal and nervous systems at an optimal level. The musculoskeletal and nervous systems coordinate the body mechanics responsible for balance, posture and body alignment and allow the patient to perform many physical activities including activities of daily living (ADLs), lifting, bending and movement.</p>
<p>Mobility and immobility are defined by the patient's ability to move around freely. When assessing a patient's mobility, these terms represent the endpoints of the scale, with degrees of immobility in the middle of the range. Nurses must be able to relate the effects of mobility and immobility on body systems and as an aspect of psychosocial development. Mobility can be dependent on patient progress. Some patients may fluctuate and move up and down the mobility range, which affects their care needs and potentially increases the length of their stay in a care environment.</p>
<p>An understanding of mobility requires an overview of body mechanics and how the musculoskeletal and nervous systems regulate body movement. Nurses need a good understanding of body mechanics, as it allows them to provide expert care to patients and to prevent risk of injury to the musculoskeletal system that can occur when patients have impaired mobility. The correct use of body mechanics is important for the safety of nurses and patients; incorrect use can lead to injury and impair the nurse's ability to transfer and position patients.</p>
<p>This chapter explores the psychomotor skills that are required when caring for patients who have impaired mobility. The skills addressed include applying elastic stockings (33-1), positioning patients in bed (33-2) and transfer techniques (33-3). Elastic stocking compression promotes venous return from the peripheries and is an effective method of preventing deep vein thrombosis in patients with deep vein insufficiency or who undergo extended periods of immobility. The chapter demonstrates the use of body mechanics to protect both nurse and patient safety when the nurse performs transfer duties such as repositioning the patient, as well as the safe lifting and transfer of patients with impaired mobility. A variety of patient transfer methods are covered, including using a lifting machine to prevent musculoskeletal injury to the nurse or patient during transfer.</p>
<p>PROMOTING MOBILITY 149</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="skill-33-1">SKILL 33-1<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#skill-33-1" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="applying-elastic-stockings">Applying elastic stockings<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#applying-elastic-stockings" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="delegation-considerations">DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delegation-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Applying elastic stockings can be delegated to nurse assistants. The following information should be given when delegating this task:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Avoid activities that promote venous stasis (e.g. crossing legs, wearing garters or placing pillows under the knees).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>When possible, elevate legs to improve venous return.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Do not massage legs.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Elevate legs before applying stockings.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Avoid wrinkles in the stockings.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Observe for allergic reactions, skin irritation and thrombophlebitis.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Tape measure</li>
<li>Talcum powder</li>
<li>Elastic support stockings (proper size)</li>
</ul>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>1. Assess patient for risk factors for venous thromboembolism to determine need for elastic stockings.</td><td>Potential candidates for elastic stockings are patients who have an alteration in one of the elements of Virchow's triad.</td></tr><tr><td>2. Observe for signs, symptoms and conditions that might contraindicate the use of elastic stockings:</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<ul>
<li>Dermatitis or open skin lesion</li>
<li>Recent skin graft</li>
<li>Disproportionately large thighs</li>
<li>Decreased circulation in lower extremities (e.g. peripheral vascular disease) as evidenced by cyanotic, cool extremities | Elastic stockings may aggravate skin condition or cause it to spread. Also, medication and dressings may need to be applied to lesion.
Continuous pressure is necessary to keep graft adherent to recipient bed, but pressure should not be so firm as to cause death of graft.
Elastic stockings may not fit correctly, causing excessive pressure and constriction around thighs, thereby reducing venous return.
Elastic stockings may further impede circulation.  |
|  3. Obtain medical prescription. | May be needed for legal or reimbursement reasons.  |
|  4. Assess patient's or caregiver's understanding of application of elastic stockings. | Identifies potential educational needs of patient or caregiver.  |
|  5. Assess and document condition of patient's skin and circulation to legs (i.e. presence of pedal pulses, oedema, discolouration of skin, temperature, lesions or cuts). | Identifies a baseline for skin integrity and quality of peripheral pulses in lower extremities.  |
|  6. Explain procedure and reasons for applying stockings. | Reduces anxiety and encourages patient cooperation.  |
|  7. Use tape measure to measure patient's legs to determine proper stocking size. | Stockings must be measured according to manufacturer's directions. Elastic stockings come in two lengths: knee length and thigh length. The choice of length depends on the prescription.  |
|  Critical decision point: Compare patient's measurements with the manufacturer's sizing chart. If too large, stockings will not adequately support extremities. If too small, stockings may impede circulation. The optimum stocking pressure is 20â€“30 mmHg at the ankle, decreasing to 8 mmHg at the middle to upper thigh. This change in pressure produces the greatest increase in venous flow velocity that is both safe and practical.  |   |
|  8. Perform hand hygiene. | Reduces transmission of microorganisms.  |
|  9. Position patient in supine position. Elevate head of bed to comfortable level. | Promotes good body mechanics for nurse. Patient position eases application. Also, the stockings should be applied before standing to prevent stagnation of blood in lower extremities. If patient has been standing, patient should sit in chair or lie in bed for 15 minutes with legs elevated before applying elastic stockings.  |</li>
</ul>
<p>FUNDAMENTALS OF NURSING: CLINICAL SKILLS WORKBOOK</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>10. After legs are cleaned, apply small amount of talcum powder to legs and feet, provided that patient does not have sensitivity to talcum powder.</td><td>Talcum powder reduces friction and allows for easier application of stockings.</td></tr><tr><td>11. Apply stockings.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>a. Turn elastic stocking inside out by placing one hand into sock, holding toe of sock with other hand, and pulling (see illustration). Leave the toe of the stocking tucked inside to form a pocket.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>b. Place patient's toes into foot of elastic stocking, making sure that sock is smooth (see illustration).</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>c. Slide remaining portion of sock over patient's foot, being sure that the toes are covered. Make sure the foot fits into the toe and heel position of the sock. Sock will now be right side out (see illustration).</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>d. Slide sock up over patient's calf until sock is completely extended. Be sure sock is smooth and no ridges are present (see illustration).</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>e. Instruct patient not to roll socks partially down.</td><td>Allows easier application of stocking.</td></tr><tr><td>Wrinkles in sock can impede circulation to lower region of extremity.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>If toes remain uncovered, they will become constricted by elastic and their circulation can be reduced.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Ridges impede venous return and can counteract overall purpose of elastic stocking.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Rolling sock partially down has a constricting effect and can impede venous return.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Maintains proper body alignment and promotes comfort. Reduces transmission of microorganisms.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Wrinkles lead to increased pressure and alter circulation.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>12. Reposition patient to position of comfort and wash hands.</td><td>Ensures patient is adapting to stockings and is not experiencing any discomfort from stockings.</td></tr><tr><td>13. Inspect stocking to make sure there are no wrinkles or binding at top of stocking.</td><td>Determines ability to perform skill accurately.</td></tr><tr><td>14. Observe patient's reaction to stockings.</td><td>Stockings may shift or be too tight, and this step ensures skin and circulation are intact.</td></tr><tr><td>15. Observe patient or caregiver applying stockings.</td><td>Wearing shoes/slippers decreases risk of patient slipping.</td></tr><tr><td>16. Remove stockings at least once a shift, and assess skin and circulatory status.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>17. Ensure shoes/slippers are available for patient.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>RECORDING AND REPORTING</td><td>HOME CARE CONSIDERATIONS</td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Record date and time of stocking application and stocking length and size in nurses' notes (flow sheet may be used).</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Record condition of skin and circulatory assessment, including pulses, temperature, sensation, movement, capillary refill and calf circumference at application and each shift.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Report changes indicating a decline in circulation.</td><td>â€¢ Instruct patients to have two pairs of stockingsâ€”one pair to wear, the other to wash.</td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Instruct patients that if there are bodyweight changes greater than 4.5 kg, stockings should be remeasured.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Remind patients to put on stockings before getting up for the morning or sitting for prolonged periods. As the day progresses, leg swelling may increase and may make stocking application difficult. (It may be helpful to remind patients that they may have noticed this swelling when wearing shoes.)</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>PROMOTING MOBILITY 151</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="applying-elastic-stockings">APPLYING ELASTIC STOCKINGS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#applying-elastic-stockings" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<p>SKILL 33-2</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="positioning-patients-in-bed">Positioning patients in bed<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#positioning-patients-in-bed" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="delegation-considerations">DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delegation-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The task of moving and positioning patients in bed can be delegated to assistants. A risk assessment should be conducted on all patients requiring assistance with positioning. A 'no lift' policy has been implemented in most facilities. Equipment such as lifting machines should be used whenever repositioning poses a risk to the patient and to the staff.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Slide sheets</li>
<li>Pillows</li>
<li>Other support devices as necessary (e.g. hand splints, sandbags, wedge pillows, trochanter rolls)</li>
<li>Lifting devices if required</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="steps">STEPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Assess patient's body alignment and comfort level while patient is lying down.</li>
<li>Assess for risk factors that may contribute to complications of immobility:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Paralysis: hemiparesis resulting from stroke; decreased sensation</li>
<li>Impaired mobility: traction or arthritis or other contributing disease processes</li>
<li>Impaired circulation</li>
<li>Age: very young, older adults</li>
<li>Patient's level of consciousness</li>
</ul>
<ol start="3">
<li>Assess patient's physical ability to help with moving and positioning.</li>
<li>Explain procedure to patient.</li>
<li>Adjust the bed height to between mid-thigh and hip height.</li>
<li>Remove all pillows and devices used in previous position.</li>
<li>Get extra help as needed.</li>
<li>Position patient in bed.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="a-patient-assisted-bed-slide-one-nurse">A. Patient-assisted bed slide (one nurse):<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-patient-assisted-bed-slide-one-nurse" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>(1) Place patient supine with head of bed flat.
(2) Remove pillow from under head and shoulders and place pillow at head of bed.
(3) Ask or assist the patient to fold his or her arms across the chest.
(4) Fold a slide sheet in half and tuck under the patient's shoulders and hips with the fold facing towards the patient's feet.
(5) Ask or assist the patient to roll to the side to pull the slide sheet into position.
(6) Have the patient roll back to supine position and bend their knees.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="rationale">RATIONALE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rationale" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Provides baseline data for later comparisons. Determines ways to improve position and alignment.</p>
<p>Increased risk factors require patient to be repositioned more frequently.</p>
<p>Paralysis impairs movement; muscle tone changes; sensation is affected. Because of difficulty in moving and poor awareness of involved body part, patient is unable to protect and position body part for self.</p>
<p>Traction or arthritic changes of affected extremity result in decreased range of joint motion.</p>
<p>Decreased circulation predisposes patient to pressure injury.</p>
<p>Premature and young infants require frequent turning because their skin is fragile. Normal physiological changes associated with ageing predispose older adults to greater risks of developing complications of immobility.</p>
<p>Determines need for special aids or devices. Patients with altered levels of consciousness may not understand instructions and may be unable to help.</p>
<p>Enables nurse to use patient's mobility and strength. Determines need for additional help. Ensures patient and nurse safety.</p>
<p>Helps to decrease anxiety and increase cooperation.</p>
<p>Raises level of work towards nurse's centre of gravity.</p>
<p>Reduces interference from bedding during positioning procedure.</p>
<p>Provides for patient and nurse safety.</p>
<p>Enables nurse to assess body alignment. Reduces gravity's pull on patient's upper body.</p>
<p>Prevents striking patient's head against head of bed.</p>
<p>Slide sheets reduce friction and reduce the force required to move the patient.</p>
<p>PROMOTING MOBILITY 153</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>(7) Stand at the end of the bed and support the patient's feet.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(8) Ask the patient to extend the legs while holding the feet against the mattress. The patient will push himself or herself up the bed.</td><td>Where possible, patients should be encouraged to move themselves.</td></tr><tr><td>B. Bed slide (two nurses):</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(1) Place patient supine with head of bed flat.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(2) Remove pillow from under head and shoulders and place pillow at head of bed.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(3) Ask or assist the patient to fold his or her arms across the chest.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(4) Tuck two slide sheets (on top of each other) under the length of the patient's body.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(5) Ask or assist the patient to cross their legs (i.e. if rolling to the left, cross right over left). Roll the patient to the side and pull the slide sheet into position over the mattress.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(6) Roll the patient back to a supine position.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(7) Stand at the top end of the bed corners and gather the ends of the top slide sheet with palms down.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(8) In a controlled manner and with arms straight, both nurses should lunge backwards on the count of three, transferring weight from the front foot to the back foot, moving the patient towards the head of the bed.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(9) Tuck the slide sheets under the patient and pull them out from beneath the patient. Replace pillows and position the patient to a position of comfort and safety.</td><td>Enables nurse to assess body alignment. Reduces gravity's pull on patient's upper body.</td></tr><tr><td>Prevents striking patient's head against head of bed.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Slide sheets reduce friction and reduce the force required to move the patient.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Face in the direction of movement to prevent spinal twisting.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Assuming a broad stance increases stability and balance. Use of large muscle groups and shifting weight reduces the force needed to move load.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Increases comfort, improves ventilation and increases patient's opportunity to socialise or relax.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Prevents flexion contractures of cervical vertebrae.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Prevents shoulder dislocation from effect of downward pull of unsupported arms, promotes circulation by preventing venous pooling and prevents flexion contractures of arms and wrists.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Supports lumbar vertebrae and decreases flexion of vertebrae.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Prevents hyperextension of knee and occlusion of popliteal artery from pressure from bodyweight.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Prevents prolonged pressure of mattress on heels.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>C. Position patient in supported semi-Fowler's position (see illustration):</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(1) Elevate head of bed 45â€“60 degrees.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(2) Rest head against mattress or on small pillow.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(3) Use pillows to support arms and hand if patient does not have voluntary control or use of hands and arms.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(4) Position pillow at lower back.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(5) Place small pillow or roll under thigh.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(6) Place small pillow or roll under ankles.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Critical decision point: To keep feet in proper alignment, place footboard at bottom of patient's feet.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>D. Position hemiplegic patient in supported semi-Fowler's position:</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(1) Elevate head of bed 45â€“60 degrees.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(2) Position patient in sitting position as straight as possible, with support for affected shoulder.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(3) Position head on small pillow with chin slightly forwards. If patient is totally unable to control head movement, hyperextension of the neck must be avoided.</td><td>Increases comfort, improves ventilation and increases patient's opportunity to relax.</td></tr><tr><td>Counteracts tendency to slump towards affected side.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Improves ventilation and cardiac output; decreases intracranial pressure. Improves patient's ability to swallow and helps to prevent aspiration of food, liquids and gastric secretions.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Prevents hyperextension of neck. Too many pillows under head may cause or worsen neck flexion contracture.</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>FUNDAMENTALS OF NURSING: CLINICAL SKILLS WORKBOOK</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>(4) Provide support for involved arm and hand on overbed table in front of patient. If transfer is to wheelchair, arms of chair can provide support. Place arm away from patient's side and support elbow with pillow.</td><td>Paralysed muscles do not automatically resist pull of gravity as they do normally. As a result, shoulder subluxation, pain and oedema may occur.</td></tr><tr><td>a. Position flaccid hand in normal resting position with wrist slightly extended, arches of hand maintained and fingers partially flexed; may use section of rubber ball cut in half; clasp patient's hands together.</td><td>Maintains hand in functional position. Prevents contractures.</td></tr><tr><td>b. Position spastic hand with wrist in neutral position or slightly extended; fingers should be extended with palm down or may be left in relaxed position with palm up.</td><td>Maintains hand in functional position. Inhibits flexor spasticity.</td></tr><tr><td>(5) Flex knees and hips by using pillow or folded blanket under knees.</td><td>Ensures proper alignment. Flexion prevents prolonged hyperextension, which could impair joint mobility.</td></tr><tr><td>(6) Support feet in dorsiflexion with firm pillow or footboard.</td><td>Prevents footdrop. Stimulation of ball of foot by hard surface has tendency to increase muscle tone in patient with extensor spasticity of lower extremity.</td></tr><tr><td>E. Position patient in supine position:</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(1) Place patient on back with head of bed flat.</td><td>Necessary for placing patient in supine position.</td></tr><tr><td>(2) Place small rolled towel under lumbar area of back.</td><td>Provides support for lumbar spine.</td></tr><tr><td>(3) Place pillow under upper shoulders, neck or head.</td><td>Maintains correct alignment and prevents flexion contractures of cervical lumbar spine.</td></tr><tr><td>(4) Place trochanter rolls or sandbags parallel to lateral surface of patient's thighs.</td><td>Reduces external rotation of hip.</td></tr><tr><td>(5) Place small pillow or roll under ankle to elevate heels.</td><td>Reduces pressure on heels, helping to prevent pressure sores.</td></tr><tr><td>(6) Support feet in dorsiflexion with firm pillow or footboard.</td><td>Prevents footdrop.</td></tr><tr><td>(7) Place pillows under pronated forearms, keeping upper arms parallel to patient's body (see illustrations).</td><td>Reduces internal rotation of shoulder and prevents extension of elbows. Maintains correct body alignment.</td></tr><tr><td>(8) Place hand rolls in patient's hands. Consider physical therapy referral for use of hand splints.</td><td>Reduces extension of fingers and abduction of thumb. Maintains thumb slightly adducted and in opposition to fingers.</td></tr><tr><td>F. Position hemiplegic patient in supine position:</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(1) Place head of bed flat.</td><td>Necessary for positioning in supine position.</td></tr><tr><td>(2) Place folded towel or small pillow under shoulder or affected side.</td><td>Decreases possibility of pain, joint contracture and subluxation. Maintains mobility in muscles around shoulder to permit normal movement patterns.</td></tr><tr><td>(3) Keep affected arm away from body with elbow extended and palm up. (Alternative is to place arm out to side, with elbow bent and hand towards head of bed.)</td><td>Maintains mobility in arm, joints and shoulder to permit normal movement patterns. (Alternative position counteracts limitation of ability of arm to rotate outwards at shoulder (external rotation). External rotation must be present to raise arm overhead without pain.)</td></tr><tr><td>(4) Place folded towel under hip of involved side.</td><td>Diminishes effect of spasticity in entire leg by controlling hip position. Slight flexion breaks up abnormal extension pattern of leg. Extensor spasticity is most severe when patient is supine.</td></tr><tr><td>(5) Support feet with soft pillows at right-angle to leg, and keep heels off bed or use heel protectors.</td><td>Maintains foot in dorsiflexion and prevents footdrop. Pillows prevent stimulation to ball of foot by hard surface, which has tendency to increase muscle tone in patient with extensor spasticity extremity.</td></tr><tr><td>G. Position patient in prone position:</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(1) Roll patient over arm positioned close to body, with elbow straight and hand under hip. Position on abdomen in centre of bed.</td><td>Positions patient correctly so alignment can be maintained.</td></tr><tr><td>(2) Turn patient's head to one side and support head with small pillow (see illustration).</td><td>Reduces flexion or hyperextension of cervical vertebrae.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>PROMOTING MOBILITY 155</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>(3) Place small pillow under patientâ€™s abdomen below level of diaphragm (see illustration).</td><td>Reduces pressure on breasts of some female patients and decreases hyperextension of lumbar vertebrae and strain on lower back. Maintains leg in correct alignment. Prevents pressure on bony prominence.</td></tr><tr><td>(9) Place sandbag parallel to plantar surface of dependent foot.</td><td>Maintains dorsiflexion of foot. Prevents footdrop.</td></tr><tr><td>J. Position patient in Simsâ€™ (semiprone) position:</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(1) Lower head of bed completely.</td><td>Provides for proper body alignment while patient is lying down.</td></tr><tr><td>(2) Place patient in supine position.</td><td>Prepares patient for position.</td></tr><tr><td>(3) Position patient in lateral position, lying partially on abdomen.</td><td>Patient is rolled only partially on abdomen.</td></tr><tr><td>(4) Place small pillow under patientâ€™s head.</td><td>Maintains proper alignment and prevents lateral neck flexion.</td></tr><tr><td>(5) Place pillow under flexed upper arm, supporting arm level with shoulder.</td><td>Prevents internal rotation of shoulder. <div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="positioning-patients-in-bed">POSITIONING PATIENTS IN BED<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#positioning-patients-in-bed" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>CLINICAL SKILL 33-2: Positioning patients in bed</p>
<p>DEMONSTRATES: The ability to reposition a patient in bed</p>
<p>DOMAIN/S (AUS): Professional Practice and Provision and Coordination of Care</p>
<p>DOMAIN/S (NZ): Professional responsibility; management of nursing care; interpersonal relationships; interprofessional healthcare and quality improvement</p>
<p>PERFORMANCE CRITERIA: (numbers indicate National Competency Standards for the Registered Nurse)</p>
<p>AUS 2.3, 5.1, 5.2, 5.3, 6.3, 7.1, 7.3, 7.5, 7.6, 7.7</p>
<p>NZ 1.1, 1.2, 1.3, 1.4, 1.5, 2.1, 2.2, 2.3, 2.4, 2.5, 2.6, 2.7, 2.8, 2.9, 3.1, 3.2, 3.3, 4.1, 4.2, 4.3</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="transfer-techniques">Transfer techniques<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#transfer-techniques" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="delegation-considerations">DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delegation-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The task of moving and positioning patients in bed can be delegated to assistants. A risk assessment should be conducted on all patients requiring assistance with positioning. A 'no lift' policy has been implemented in most facilities. Equipment such as lifting machines should be used whenever repositioning poses a risk to the patient and to the staff.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Transfer belt (if needed), sling or lap board (as needed), non-skid shoes, bath blankets, pillows, lifting equipment when necessary</li>
<li>Wheelchair: position chair at 45-degree angle to bed, lock brakes, remove footrests, lock bed brakes</li>
<li>Stretcher: position at right-angle (90 degrees) to bed, lock brakes on stretcher, lock brakes on bed</li>
<li>Mechanical/hydraulic lift: use frame, canvas strips or chains, and hammock or canvas strips</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="steps">STEPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Assess the patient for the following:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Muscle strength</li>
<li>Joint mobility</li>
<li>Presence of paralysis or paresis</li>
<li>Orthostatic hypotension</li>
<li>Activity tolerance</li>
<li>Level of consciousness</li>
<li>Level of comfort</li>
<li>Ability to follow instructions</li>
</ul>
<ol start="2">
<li>
<p>Identify patients at greatest risk of problems with transferral.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Explain procedure to patient.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Close door or curtain.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Perform hand hygiene.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Transfer patient.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>A. Assisting patient into sitting position on side of bed:</p>
<p>(1) With patient in supine position, raise head of bed 30 degrees.</p>
<p>(2) Where possible, patients should be encouraged to move themselves into position or assist as much as possible.</p>
<p>(3) Turn patient to side, facing nurse on side of bed on which patient will be sitting (see illustration).</p>
<p>(4) Stand opposite patient's hips. Turn diagonally so that nurse faces patient and far corner of foot of bed.</p>
<p>(5) Place feet apart with foot closer to head of bed in front of other foot.</p>
<p>(6) Place arm nearer head of bed under patient's shoulder, supporting head and neck.</p>
<p>(7) Place other arm over patient's thighs (see illustration).</p>
<p>(8) Move patient's lower legs and feet over side of bed. Pivot towards rear leg, allowing patient's upper legs to swing downwards.</p>
<p>(9) At same time, shift weight to rear leg and elevate patient (see illustration).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="rationale">RATIONALE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rationale" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Provides information relative to patient's abilities, physical status, ability to comprehend, and the number of people needed to provide safe transferral.</p>
<p>Provides information relative to patients who may require intervention beyond the care provider (e.g. physiotherapy department).</p>
<p>Promotes cooperation, encourages assistance and enhances understanding of procedure.</p>
<p>Maintains privacy.</p>
<p>Reduces transfer of microorganisms.</p>
<p>Decreases amount of work needed by patient and nurse to raise patient to sitting position.</p>
<p>Prepares patient to move to side of bed and protects patient from falling.</p>
<p>Places nurse's centre of gravity nearer patient. Reduces twisting of nurse's body because nurse is facing direction of movement.</p>
<p>Increases balance and allows nurse to transfer weight as patient is brought to sitting position on side of bed.</p>
<p>Maintains alignment of head and neck as nurse brings patient to sitting position.</p>
<p>Supports hip and prevents patient from falling backwards during procedure.</p>
<p>Decreases friction and resistance. Weight of patient's legs when off bed provides gravity to lower legs, and weight of legs helps pull upper body into sitting position.</p>
<p>Allows nurse to transfer weight in direction of motion.</p>
<p>PROMOTING MOBILITY 159</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>(10) Remain in front of patient until patient regains balance.</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>B. Transfer patient from bed to chair:
(1) Adjust the bed slightly higher than the chair. Assist patient to sitting position on side of bed. Have chair in position at 45-degree angle to bed and ensure brakes are on.
(2) Apply transfer belt or other transfer aids, if needed. | Reduces risk of falling.</p>
<p>Positions chair within easy access for transfer.</p>
<p>Transfer belt allows nurse to maintain stability of patient during transfer and reduces risk of falling. Patient's arm should be in sling if flaccid paralysis is present.  |
|  Critical decision point: If patient has immobile lower leg (i.e. cast, paralysis), transfer towards the stronger leg.  |   |
|  (3) Ensure that patient has stable, non-skid shoes. Weightbearing, or stronger, leg is placed forwards, with weaker foot back.
(4) Spread feet apart.
(5) Flex hips and knees, aligning feet and knees with patient's feet (see illustration).
(6) Grasp transfer belt from underneath, if used, or reach through patient's axillae and place hands on patient's scapulae.
(7) Rock patient up to standing position on count of three while straightening hips and legs and keeping knees slightly flexed (see illustration). Patient is instructed to use hands to push up if possible.
(8) Maintain stability of patient's weak or paralysed leg with knee.
(9) Pivot on foot further from chair.
(10) Instruct patient to use armrests on chair for support and ease themselves into chair (see illustration).
(11) Flex hips and knees while lowering patient into chair (see illustration).
(12) Assess patient for proper alignment for sitting position. Provide support for paralysed extremities. Lap board or sling will support flaccid arm. Stabilise leg with bath blanket or pillow.
(13) Praise patient's progress, effort, performance.</p>
<p>C. Use mechanical/hydraulic lift to transfer patient from bed to chair (two nurses):
(1) Bring lift to bedside. Before using lift, be thoroughly familiar with its operation.
(2) Position chair near bed and allow adequate space to manoeuvre hoist.
(3) Raise bed to safe working height with mattress flat. Lower side rails. | Non-skid soles decrease risk of slipping during transfer. Always have patients wear shoes during transfer; bare feet increase risk of falls. Patient will stand on weightbearing, or stronger, leg.</p>
<p>Ensures balance with wide base of support.</p>
<p>Flexion of knees and hips lowers nurse's centre of gravity to object to be raised; aligning knees with patient's allows for stabilisation of knees when patient stands.</p>
<p>Transferring patient with hands on scapulae reduces pressure on axillae and maintains patient stability. Patients with upper-extremity paralysis or paresis should never be lifted by or under arms. Transfer belt is grasped at each side to provide movement of patient at centre of gravity.</p>
<p>Rocking motion gives patient's body momentum and requires less muscular effort to transfer patient.</p>
<p>Ability to stand can often be maintained in paralysed or weak limb with support of knee to stabilise.</p>
<p>Maintains support of patient while allowing adequate space for patient to move.</p>
<p>Increases patient stability.</p>
<p>Prevents injury to nurse from poor body mechanics.</p>
<p>Prevents injury to patient from poor body alignment.</p>
<p>Continued support and encouragement provide incentive for patient perseverance.</p>
<p>Prepares environment for safe use of lift and subsequent transfer.</p>
<p>Allows nurse to use proper body mechanics.  |
|  Critical decision point: Assess all tubes, making sure that they will not be inadvertently pulled, tangled or strained during transfer.  |   |
|  (4) Roll patient laterally towards one nurse.
(5) Place sling evenly under patient's back (follow manufacturer's guidelines for correct positioning of the sling) and then roll patient to opposite side to position sling. | Positions patient for use of lift sling.</p>
<p>Place sling under patient's centre of gravity and greatest portion of bodyweight.  |</p>
<p>FUNDAMENTALS OF NURSING: CLINICAL SKILLS WORKBOOK</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>(6) Roll patient supine on sling and position hoist over patient. Lower boom and attach sling to frame with the head end attached first. Raise patient's knees and feed the leg sections of the sling under the thighs and attach to frame.</td><td>Sling should extend from shoulders to knees to support patient's bodyweight equally.</td></tr><tr><td>(7) Elevate head of bed.</td><td>Positions patient in sitting position.</td></tr><tr><td>(8) Ask or assist patient to fold their arms over the chest.</td><td>To prevent injury during transfer.</td></tr><tr><td>(9) Pump hydraulic handle using long, slow, even strokes, or activate electronic hoist until patient is raised off bed ensuring the head is supported (see illustration).</td><td>Moves patient from bed to chair.</td></tr><tr><td>(10) Use steering handle to pull lift from bed and manoeuvre to chair.</td><td>Safely guides patient into back of chair as seat descends.</td></tr><tr><td>(11) Slowly lower patient into chair (see illustration).</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(12) Detach sling from frame and remove hoist. Pull leg straps to the side, tilt patient forward to slide out the sling.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(13) Reposition the patient to a position of comfort and safety.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>7. Perform hand hygiene.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>8. With each transfer, assess patient's tolerance and level of tiredness.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>9. With each transfer, evaluate patient's alignment.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>RECORDING AND REPORTING</td><td>HOME CARE CONSIDERATIONS</td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Record each transfer and position change, including amount of assistance needed and patient's response.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Record and report any signs of pressure injury over areas such as bony prominences.</td><td>â€¢ Teach family the importance of body mechanics for safety of themselves and the patient.</td></tr></tbody></table>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="transfer-techniques">TRANSFER TECHNIQUES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#transfer-techniques" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
