<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="hygiene">Hygiene<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hygiene" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="overview">Overview<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#overview" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Maintenance of personal hygiene is necessary for a person's comfort, safety and wellbeing. Well people are capable of meeting their own hygiene needs, but ill or physically challenged people may require assistance. A variety of personal and sociocultural factors influence a patient's hygiene practices. The nurse determines a patient's ability to perform self-care and provides hygiene care according to the patient's needs and preferences. In the home setting, the nurse helps the patient and their family adapt hygiene techniques.</p>
<p>Hygiene care requires close contact with the patient, so the nurse uses communication skills to promote a caring therapeutic relationship and uses time with the patient for teaching and counselling. The nurse can integrate other nursing activities into hygiene care, including patient assessment and interventions such as range-of-motion (ROM) exercises, inspection of pressure points or inspection and care of intravenous sites. While providing hygiene, the nurse must preserve as much of the patient's independence as possible, ensure their privacy, convey respect and foster physical comfort as well as dignity.</p>
<p>Hygiene care is important for a patient to feel comfortable, refreshed and renewed, so the nurse avoids making hygiene care a simple routine. Instead, the nurse synthesises knowledge, previous experience with patients, critical thinking attitudes and standards in judging the most effective way to provide effective hygiene. For example, a middle-aged woman with abdominal pain who had major surgery only 24 hours previously will require a different approach to hygiene from an older adult who has left-sided paralysis. During the nurse's assessment all critical thinking elements are considered in understanding the patient's needs and in making appropriate nursing diagnoses. In addition, while hygiene is being administered, the nurse makes important observations (e.g. the condition of the patient's skin, the patient's ability to move and initiate activities) and uses them when making clinical judgements about the patient's overall nursing care.</p>
<p>The skills covered in this chapter are some of the most personal elements of patient care that nurses will encounter. It is important for nurses to maintain a professional attitude towards practice at all times in order to decrease patient and practitioner discomfort and to enhance the patient's experience of their care. The skills addressed include bathing a patient (34-1), perineal care (34-2), menstrual hygiene (34-3), administering a back rub (34-4), performing nail and foot care (34-5), providing oral hygiene (34-6), performing mouth care for an unconscious or debilitated client (34-7), caring for the patient with contact lenses (34-8) and making an occupied bed (34-9).</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260125-b5c66682.jpeg" alt="img-6.jpeg"></p>
<p>FUNDAMENTALS OF NURSING: CLINICAL SKILLS WORKBOOK</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="skill-34-1">SKILL 34-1<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#skill-34-1" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="bathing-a-patient">Bathing a patient<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bathing-a-patient" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="delegation-considerations">DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delegation-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Bathing may be undertaken by nurse assistants under the guidance of the registered nurse (Division 1).</p>
<ul>
<li>Inform caregiver about early signs of impaired skin integrity, and tell caregiver to have nurse reassess the skin when changes are noted.</li>
<li>Warn against massaging reddened areas.</li>
<li>Review type of bath, patient's ability to participate and any safety precautions needed.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Two washcloths</li>
<li>Two bath towels</li>
<li>Bath blanket</li>
<li>Soap and soap dish</li>
<li>Toiletry items (deodorant, powder, lotion, cologne)</li>
<li>Clean hospital gown or patient's own pyjamas or gown</li>
<li>Dirty linen bag</li>
<li>Disposable gloves (when risk of contacting body fluids)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="steps">STEPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Assess patient's tolerance for activity, discomfort level, cognitive ability and musculoskeletal function.</li>
<li>Review orders for specific precautions concerning patient's movement or positioning.</li>
<li>Explain procedure, and ask patient for suggestions on how to prepare supplies. If partial bath, ask how much of bath patient wishes to complete.</li>
<li>Adjust room temperature and ventilation, close room doors and windows and draw room divider curtain.</li>
<li>Prepare equipment and supplies.</li>
<li>Bath patient.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="a-complete-or-partial-bed-bath">A. Complete or partial bed bath<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-complete-or-partial-bed-bath" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<p>(1) Offer patient bedpan or urinal. Provide towel and washcloth.
(2) Wash hands. If patient's skin is soiled with drainage or body secretions, wear disposable gloves. Ensure patient is not allergic to latex.
(3) Lower side rail closest to you, and help patient into a comfortable position, maintaining body alignment. Bring patient towards side closest to nurse. Place hospital bed in high position.
(4) Loosen top covers at foot of bed. Place bath blanket over top sheet. Fold and remove top sheet from under blanket. If possible, have patient hold bath blanket while withdrawing sheet. Optional: Use top sheet when bath blanket is not available.
(5) If top sheet is to be reused, fold it for replacement later. If not, place in dirty linen bag, taking care not to allow linen to contact uniform.
(6) Remove patient's gown or pyjamas. If an extremity is injured or has reduced mobility, begin removal from unaffected side. If patient has intravenous (IV) tube, remove gown from arm without IV first; then lower IV container or remove from pump and slide gown covering affected arm over tubing and container. Rehang IV container and check flow rate or reset pump rate. Do not disconnect tubing.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="rationale">RATIONALE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rationale" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<p>Determines patient's ability to perform self-care and level of assistance required from nurse. Also determines type of bath to administer (e.g. tub bath or partial bed bath).</p>
<p>Prevents accidental injury to patient during bathing activities. Determines level of assistance required by patient.</p>
<p>Promotes patient's cooperation and participation.</p>
<p>A warm room that is free of drafts prevents rapid loss of body heat during bathing. Privacy ensures patient's mental and physical comfort.</p>
<p>Avoids interrupting procedure or leaving patient unattended to retrieve missing equipment.</p>
<p>Patient will feel more comfortable after voiding. Prevents interruption of bath.</p>
<p>Reduces transmission of microorganisms.</p>
<p>Aids nurse's access to patient. Maintains patient's comfort throughout procedure. Nurse does not have to reach across bed, thus minimising strain on back muscles.</p>
<p>Removal of top covers prevents them from becoming soiled or moist during bath. Blanket provides warmth and privacy.</p>
<p>Proper disposal prevents transmission of microorganisms.</p>
<p>Provides full exposure of body parts during bathing. Undressing unaffected side first allows easier manipulation of gown over body part with reduced range of motion (ROM).</p>
<p>HYGIENE 165</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>(7) Pull side rail up. Fill washbasin two-thirds full with warm water. Have patient place fingers in water to test temperature tolerance. Place plastic container of bath lotion in bathwater to warm, if desired.</td><td>Raising side rail maintains patient's safety as nurse leaves bedside. Warm water promotes comfort, relaxes muscles and prevents unnecessary chilling. Testing temperature prevents accidental burns. Bathwater warms lotion for application to patient's skin.</td></tr><tr><td>(8) Remove pillow if allowed, and raise head of bed 30â€“45 degrees. Place bath towel under patient's head. Place second bath towel over patient's chest.</td><td>Removal of pillow makes it easier to wash patient's ears and neck. Placement of towels prevents soiling of bed linen and bath blanket.</td></tr><tr><td>(9) Fold washcloth around fingers of nurse's hand to form mitt (see illustration). Immerse mitt in water and wring thoroughly.</td><td>Mitt retains water and heat better than loosely held washcloth; keeps cold edges from brushing against patient and prevents splashing.</td></tr><tr><td>(10) Wash patient's eyes with plain warm water. Ask whether patient is wearing contact lenses. If so, perform eye care as described in Skill 34-8. Use different section of mitt for each eye. Move mitt from inner to outer canthus (see illustration). Soak any crusts on eyelid for 2â€“3 min with damp cloth before attempting removal. Dry eye thoroughly but gently.</td><td>Soap irritates eyes. Use of separate sections of mitt reduces infection transmission. Bathing eye from inner to outer canthus prevents secretions from entering nasolacrimal duct. Pressure can cause internal injury.</td></tr><tr><td>(11) Ask whether patient prefers to use soap on face. Wash, rinse and dry well forehead, cheeks, nose, neck and ears. (Men may wish to shave at this point or after bath.)</td><td>Soap tends to dry face, which is exposed to air more than other body parts.</td></tr><tr><td>(12) Remove bath blanket from patient's arm that is closest to nurse. Place bath towel lengthwise under arm.</td><td>Prevents soiling of bed.</td></tr><tr><td>(13) Wash arm with soap and water using long, firm strokes from distal to proximal areas (fingers to axilla; see illustration). Raise and support arm as needed while thoroughly washing axilla.</td><td>Soap lowers surface tension and facilitates removal of debris and bacteria when friction is applied during washing. Long, firm strokes stimulate circulation. Movement of arm exposes axilla and exercises joint's normal ROM.</td></tr><tr><td>(14) Rinse and dry arm and axilla thoroughly. If patient uses deodorant or talcum powder, apply it.</td><td>Alkaline residue from soap discourages growth of normal skin bacteria. Excess moisture causes skin maceration or softening. Deodorant controls body odour.</td></tr><tr><td>(15) Fold bath towel in half, and lay it on bed beside patient. Place basin on towel. Immerse patient's hand in water. Allow hand to soak for 3â€“5 minutes before washing hand and fingernails (see Skill 34-5). Remove basin and dry hand well.</td><td>Soaking softens cuticles and calluses of hand, loosens debris beneath nails and enhances feeling of cleanliness. Thorough drying removes moisture from between fingers.</td></tr><tr><td>(16) Raise side rail, and move to other side of bed. Lower side rail, and repeat Steps 12â€“15 for other arm.</td><td>Warm water maintains patient's comfort. Clean water reduces microorganism transmission.</td></tr><tr><td>(17) Check temperature of bathwater, and change water if necessary.</td><td>Draping prevents unnecessary exposure of body parts. Towel maintains warmth and privacy. Secretions and dirt collect easily in areas of tight skinfolds. Skinfolds are susceptible to excoriation if breasts are pendulous.</td></tr><tr><td>(18) Cover patient's chest with bath towel, and fold bath blanket down to umbilicus. With one hand, lift edge of towel away from chest. With mitted hand, bathe chest using long, firm strokes. Take special care to wash skinfolds under female patient's breasts. It may be necessary to lift breast upwards while washing underneath it. Keep patient's chest covered between wash and rinse periods. Dry well.</td><td>Prevents chilling and exposure of body parts.</td></tr><tr><td>(19) Place bath towel lengthwise over chest and abdomen. (Two towels may be needed.) Fold blanket down to just above pubic region.</td><td>Moisture and sediment that collect in skinfolds predispose skin to maceration and irritation.</td></tr><tr><td>(20) With one hand, lift bath towel. With mitted hand, bathe abdomen, giving special attention to umbilicus and abdominal folds. Stroke from side to side. Keep abdomen covered between washing and rinsing. Dry well.</td><td>Maintains patient's warmth and comfort. Dressing affected side first allows easier manipulation of gown over body part with reduced ROM.</td></tr><tr><td>(21) Dress patient in clean gown or pyjama top. If one extremity is injured or immobilised, always dress affected side first. This step may be omitted until completion of bath; gown should not become soiled during remainder of bath.</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>FUNDAMENTALS OF NURSING: CLINICAL SKILLS WORKBOOK</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>(22) Cover chest and abdomen with top of bath blanket. Expose near leg by folding blanket towards midline. Be sure perineum is draped.</td><td>Prevents unnecessary exposure.</td></tr><tr><td>(23) Bend patientâ€™s leg at knee by positioning nurseâ€™s arm under leg. While grasping patientâ€™s heel, elevate leg from mattress slightly and slide bath towel lengthwise under leg. Ask patient to hold foot still. Place bath basin on towel on bed and secure its position next to foot to be washed.</td><td>Towel prevents soiling of bedclothes. Support of joint and extremity during lifting prevents strain on musculoskeletal structures. Sudden movement by patient could spill bathwater. (Omit this step if patient is unable to hold leg in basin.)</td></tr><tr><td>(24) With one hand supporting lower leg, raise it and slide basin under lifted foot. Make sure foot is firmly placed on bottom of basin. Allow foot to soak while washing leg. If patient is unable to hold leg, do not immerse; simply wash with washcloth (see illustration).</td><td>Proper positioning of foot prevents pressure being applied from edge of basin against calf. Soaking softens calluses and rough skin.</td></tr><tr><td>(25) Unless contraindicated, use long, firm strokes in washing from ankle to knee and from knee to thigh. Dry well.</td><td>Promotes venous return.</td></tr><tr><td>Critical decision point: Patients with history of deep-vein thromboses or hypercoagulation disorders should not have their lower extremities washed with long, firm strokes.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(26) Clean foot, making sure to wash between toes. Clean and clip nails as needed (see Skill 34-5). Dry well. If skin is dry, apply lotion. Do not massage any reddened area on patientâ€™s skin.</td><td>Secretions and moisture may be present between toes. Lotion helps retain moisture and soften skin.</td></tr><tr><td>(27) Raise side rail, and move to other side of the bed. Lower side rail, and repeat Steps 22â€“26 for other leg and foot.</td><td>Decreased bathwater temperature can cause chilling. Clean water reduces microorganism transmission.</td></tr><tr><td>(28) Cover patient with bath blanket, raise side rail for patientâ€™s safety and change bathwater.</td><td>Exposes back and buttocks for bathing.</td></tr><tr><td>(29) Lower side rail. Help patient into a prone or side-lying position (as applicable). Place towel lengthwise along patientâ€™s side.</td><td>Prevents contact with microorganisms in body secretions.</td></tr><tr><td>(30) Put on disposable gloves if not done previously.</td><td>Maintains warmth, and prevents unnecessary exposure. Skinfolds near buttocks and anus may contain faecal secretions that harbour microorganisms.</td></tr><tr><td>(31) Keep patient draped by sliding bath blanket over shoulders and thighs. Wash, rinse and dry back from neck to buttocks using long, firm strokes (see illustration). Clean buttocks and anus (see Skill 34-2). Give a back rub (see Skill 34-4). Change bathwater.</td><td>Changing water prevents transfer of microorganisms from anal area to genitalia.</td></tr><tr><td>(32) Help patient into a side-lying or supine position. Cover chest and upper extremities with towel and lower extremities with bath blanket. Expose only genitalia. (If patient can wash, covering entire body with bath blanket may be preferable.) Wash, rinse and dry perineum (see Skill 34-2). Pay special attention to skinfolds. Apply water-repellent ointment to area exposed to moisture.</td><td>Maintains patientâ€™s privacy. Patients capable of performing partial bath usually prefer to wash their own genitalia. Water-repellent ointments protect skin from moisture.</td></tr><tr><td>(33) Dispose of gloves in receptacle.</td><td>Prevents transmission of infection.</td></tr><tr><td>(34) Apply additional body lotion or oil as desired.</td><td>Moisturising lotion prevents dry, chapped skin.</td></tr><tr><td>(35) Help patient to dress. Comb patientâ€™s hair. Women may want to apply makeup.</td><td>Promotes patientâ€™s body image.</td></tr><tr><td>(36) Make patientâ€™s bed (see Skill 34-9).</td><td>Provides clean environment.</td></tr><tr><td>(37) Remove soiled linen, and place in dirty linen bag. Clean and replace bathing equipment. Replace call light and personal possessions. Leave room as clean and comfortable as possible.</td><td>Prevents transmission of infection. Clean environment promotes patientâ€™s comfort. Keeping call light and articles of care within reach promotes patientâ€™s safety.</td></tr><tr><td>(38) Wash hands.</td><td>Reduces transmission of microorganisms.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>HYGIENE 167</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><strong>B. Bath or whirlpool bath or shower</strong></td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>(1) Consider patientâ€™s condition, and review orders for precautions concerning patientâ€™s movement or positioning.</p>
<p>(2) Check bath or shower for cleanliness. Use cleaning techniques outlined in agency policy. Place rubber mat on bath or shower bottom. Place disposable bath mat or towel on floor in front of bath or shower.</p>
<p>(3) Collect all hygiene aids, toiletry items and linen requested by patient. Place within easy reach of bath or shower.</p>
<p>(4) Help patient to bathroom if necessary. Have patient wear dressing gown and slippers to bathroom.</p>
<p>(5) Demonstrate how to use call signal for assistance.</p>
<p>(6) Place â€˜occupiedâ€™ sign on bathroom door.</p>
<p>(7) Provide shower seat or bath chair if needed (see illustration). Fill bath halfway with warm water. If sensation is normal, ask patient to test water and adjust temperature if water is too warm. Explain which tap controls hot water. If patient is taking shower, turn shower on and adjust water temperature before patient enters shower unit.</p>
<p>(8) Instruct patient to use safety bars when getting into and out of bath or shower. Caution patient against use of bath oil in bathwater.</p>
<p>(9) Instruct patient not to remain in bath longer than 20 minutes. Check on patient every 5 minutes.</p>
<p>(10) Return to bathroom when patient signals, and knock before entering.</p>
<p>(11) For patient who is unsteady, drain bath of water before patient attempts to get out of it. Place bath towel over patientâ€™s shoulders. Help patient get out of bath as needed, and help with drying. If patient is weak or unstable, have a nurse assistant help.</p>
<p>(12) Help patient as needed in donning clean gown or pyjamas, slippers and dressing gown. (In home setting, patient may wear ordinary clothing.)</p>
<p>(13) Help patient to room and comfortable position in bed or chair.</p>
<p>(14) Clean bath or shower according to agency policy. Whirlpool baths may require special cleaning. Remove soiled linen and place in dirty linen bag. Discard disposable equipment in proper receptacle. Place â€˜unoccupiedâ€™ sign on bathroom door. Return supplies to storage area.</p>
<p>(15) Wash hands.</p>
<ol start="7">
<li>
<p>Observe skin, paying particular attention to areas that were previously soiled, reddened or showed early signs of breakdown.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Observe ROM during bath.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Ask patient to rate level of comfort. | Prevents accidental injury to patient during bathing.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>Cleaning prevents transmission of microorganisms. Mats prevent slipping and falling.</p>
<p>Placing items close at hand prevents possible falls when patient reaches for equipment.</p>
<p>Assistance prevents accidental falls. Wearing dressing gown and slippers prevents chilling.</p>
<p>Bathrooms are equipped with signalling devices in case patient feels faint or weak or needs immediate assistance. Patients prefer privacy during bath if safety is not jeopardised.</p>
<p>Maintains patientâ€™s privacy.</p>
<p>Adjusting water temperature prevents accidental burns. Older adults and patients with neurological alterations (e.g. spinal cord injury) are at high risk of burns as a result of reduced sensation. Use of aids facilitates bathing and minimises physical exertion.</p>
<p>Prevents slipping and falling. Oil causes bath surfaces to become slippery.</p>
<p>Prolonged exposure to warm water may cause vasodilation and pooling of blood, leading to lightheadedness or dizziness.</p>
<p>Provides privacy.</p>
<p>Prevents accidental falls. Patient may become chilled as water drains.</p>
<p>Maintains warmth to prevent chilling.</p>
<p>Maintains relaxation gained from bathing.</p>
<p>Prevents transmission of infection through soiled linen and moisture.</p>
<p>Reduces transfer of microorganisms.</p>
<p>Techniques used during bathing should leave skin clean and clear.</p>
<p>Measures joint mobility.  |
|  RECORDING AND REPORTING | HOME CARE CONSIDERATIONS  |
|  â€¢ Record bath on flow sheet. Note level of assistance required.
â€¢ Record condition of skin and any significant findings (e.g. reddened areas, bruises, naevi or joint or muscle pain).
â€¢ Report evidence of alterations in skin integrity to nurse in charge or doctor. | â€¢ Assess patientâ€™s bath and shower areaâ€”are grab bars, shower chair or handheld shower needed?  |</p>

<p>CLINICAL SKILL 34-1: Bathing a patient</p>
<p>DEMONSTRATES: The ability to effectively perform a partial or complete bed bath or assisted patient shower</p>
<p>DOMAIN/S (AUS): Professional Practice and Provision and Coordination of Care</p>
<p>DOMAIN/S (NZ): Professional responsibility; management of nursing care; interpersonal relationships; interprofessional healthcare and quality improvement</p>
<p>PERFORMANCE CRITERIA: (numbers indicate National Competency Standards for the Registered Nurse)</p>
<p>AUS 2.3, 5.1, 5.2, 5.3, 6.3, 7.1, 7.3, 7.5, 7.6, 7.7</p>
<p>NZ 1.1, 1.2, 1.3, 1.4, 1.5, 2.1, 2.3, 2.4, 2.7, 3.1, 3.2, 3.3, 4.1, 4.2</p>

<p>SKILL 34-2</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="perineal-care">Perineal care<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#perineal-care" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="delegation-considerations">DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delegation-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Perineal care can be undertaken by nurse assistants under the guidance of the registered nurse (Division 1).</p>
<ul>
<li>Instruct caregiver in proper way to position male and female patients.</li>
<li>Inform caregiver about proper positioning of indwelling catheter during perineal care.</li>
<li>Instruct caregiver to inform nurse if any perineal drainage, excoriation or rash is observed.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Washbasin</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Soap dish with soap</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Two or three washcloths</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Bath towel</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Bath blanket</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Waterproof pad or bedpan</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Toilet paper or nappy wipes</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Disposable gloves</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Additional supplies are needed when perineal care is given other than during a bath:</p>
<ul>
<li>Cotton balls or swabs</li>
<li>A solution bottle or container filled with warm water or prescribed rinsing solution</li>
<li>Waterproof bag</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="steps">STEPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Identify patients at risk of developing infection of genitalia, urinary tract or reproductive tract (e.g. uncircumcised male, presence of indwelling catheter, faecal incontinence).</li>
<li>Assess patient's cognitive and musculoskeletal function.</li>
<li>Assess genitalia for signs of inflammation, skin breakdown or infection (see Chapter 29).</li>
<li>Assess patient's knowledge of importance of perineal hygiene.</li>
<li>Explain procedure and its purpose to patient.</li>
<li>Prepare necessary equipment and supplies.</li>
<li>Pull curtain around patient's bed, or close room door. Assemble supplies at bedside.</li>
<li>Raise bed to comfortable working position. Lower side rail, and help patient into a side-lying position, placing towel lengthwise along patient's side and keeping patient covered with bath blanket or top sheet.</li>
<li>Put on disposable gloves.</li>
<li>If faecal material is present, enclose in a fold of underpad or toilet paper, and remove with disposable wipes or toilet paper. Clean buttocks and anus, washing front to back (see illustration). Clean, rinse and dry area thoroughly. If needed, place an absorbent pad under patient's buttocks. Remove and discard underpad and replace with clean one.</li>
<li>If patient has had urinary or bowel incontinence, apply thin layer of skin barrier containing petrolatum or zinc oxide over anal and perineal skin.</li>
<li>Change gloves when they are soiled.</li>
<li>Prepare to undertake perineal care.</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Raise side rail. Fill washbasin with warm water.</p>
<p>b. Place washbasin and toilet paper on overbed table. Place washcloths in basin.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="rationale">RATIONALE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rationale" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Secretions that accumulate on surface of skin surrounding genitalia act as reservoirs for infection. Tissues traumatised by surgery or by presence of foreign object provide route for introduction of infectious organisms.</p>
<p>Determines patient's ability to perform self-care and determines level of assistance required from nurse.</p>
<p>Determines extent of perineal care required by patient.</p>
<p>Patients at risk of infection in perineal area may be unaware of importance of cleanliness. Reflects patient's need for education.</p>
<p>Helps minimise anxiety during procedure that is often embarrassing to nurse and patient.</p>
<p>As used when administering a bed bath.</p>
<p>Maintains patient's privacy and ensures orderly procedure.</p>
<p>Facilitates good body mechanics. Provides easy access to genitalia.</p>
<p>Eliminates transmission of microorganisms.</p>
<p>Cleaning reduces transmission of microorganisms from anus to urethra or genitalia.</p>
<p>Protects skin from maceration and irritants in urine or stool.</p>
<p>Prevents patient from falling.</p>
<p>Proper water temperature prevents burns to perineum.</p>
<p>Equipment placed within nurse's reach prevents accidental spills.</p>
<p>HYGIENE 171</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>14. Provide perineal care.</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>A. Female perineal care</p>
<p>(1) Help patient to dorsal recumbent position.
(2) Lower side rail, and help patient flex knees and spread legs. Work within restrictions or limitations in patientâ€™s ability to assume this position.
(3) Fold top sheet down towards foot of bed, and raise patientâ€™s gown above genital area.
(4) â€˜Diamondâ€™ drape patient by placing bath blanket with one corner between patientâ€™s legs, one corner pointing towards each side of bed, and one corner over patientâ€™s chest (see illustration). Tuck side corners around patientâ€™s legs and under hips.
(5) Fold lower corner of bath blanket up between patientâ€™s legs onto abdomen. Wash and dry patientâ€™s upper thighs.
(6) Wash labia majora. Use non-dominant hand to gently retract labia from thigh; with dominant hand, wash carefully in skinfolds. Wipe in direction from perineum to rectum (front to back). Repeat on opposite side using separate section of washcloth. Rinse and dry area thoroughly.
(7) Separate labia with non-dominant hand to expose urethral meatus and vaginal orifice. With dominant hand, wash downwards from pubic area towards rectum in one smooth stroke (see illustration). Use separate section of cloth for each stroke. Clean thoroughly around labia minora, clitoris and vaginal orifice.
(8) If patient uses bed pan, pour warm water over perineal area. Dry perineal area thoroughly, using front-to-back method.
(9) Fold lower corner of bath blanket back between patientâ€™s legs and over perineum. Ask patient to lower legs and assume comfortable position.</p>
<p>B. Male perineal care</p>
<p>(1) Lower side rails, and help patient into supine position. Note restriction in mobility.
(2) Fold top sheet down towards foot of bed, and raise patientâ€™s gown above genital area. Drape patient with bath blanket.
(3) Fold top half of bath blanket down below the penis. Wash and dry patientâ€™s upper thighs.
(4) Gently raise penis, and place bath towel underneath. Gently grasp shaft of penis. If patient is uncircumcised, retract foreskin (see illustration). If patient has an erection, defer procedure until later.
(5) Wash tip of penis at urethral meatus first. Using circular motion, clean from meatus outwards (see illustration). Discard washcloth, and repeat with clean cloth until penis is clean. Rinse and dry gently.
(6) Return foreskin to its natural position. | Provides easy access to genitalia.
Provides full exposure of female genitalia. Minimise degree of abduction in female if position causes pain because of arthritis or reduced joint mobility.
Exposes perineal area for easy accessibility.
Prevents unnecessary exposure of body parts and maintains patientâ€™s warmth and comfort during procedure.
Minimises transmission of microorganisms. Keeping patient draped until procedure begins minimises anxiety. Build-up of perineal secretions can soil surrounding skin surfaces.
Skinfolds may contain body secretions that harbour microorganisms. Wiping from perineum to rectum (front to back) reduces chance of transmitting faecal organisms to urinary meatus.
Cleaning method reduces transfer of microorganisms to urinary meatus. (For menstruating women or patients with indwelling urinary catheters, clean with cotton balls.)
Rinsing removes soap and microorganisms more effectively than wiping. Retained moisture harbours microorganisms.
Provides full exposure of male genitalia.
Exposes perineal area for easy accessibility. Draping promotes comfort and minimises patientâ€™s anxiety.
Minimises transmission of microorganisms. Keeping patient draped until procedure begins minimises anxiety. Build-up of perineal secretions can soil surrounding skin surfaces.
Towel prevents moisture from collecting in inguinal area. Gentle but firm handling reduces chance of patient having an erection. Secretions capable of harbouring microorganisms collect underneath foreskin.
Direction of cleaning moves from area of least contamination to area of most contamination, preventing microorganisms from entering urethra.
Tightening of foreskin around shaft of penis can cause local oedema and discomfort.  |</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="menstrual-hygiene">Menstrual hygiene<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#menstrual-hygiene" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="delegation-considerations">DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delegation-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The client may wish to perform self-care with partial assistance.</p>
<p>Menstrual hygiene can be undertaken by nurse assistants under the guidance of the registered nurse (Division 1).</p>
<ul>

<li>Inform caregiver to report any heavy discharge.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<li>Disposable gloves</li>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="steps">STEPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Close curtains or door to room.</li>
<li>Assemble supplies at the bedside. Fold down the top of the rubbish bag to form a cuff.</li>
<li>Assess client's cognitive and musculoskeletal function.</li>
<li>Explain procedure and its purpose to client.</li>
<li>Ask client about her normal pattern of menstrual care and whether she would prefer to change sanitary ware herself.</li>
<li>Position bed to a comfortable working height.</li>
<li>Wash hands. Apply disposable gloves.</li>
<li>Use of sanitary pads</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Lower or remove underwear.
b. Remove used sanitary pad. Assess per vagina (PV) loss and dispose of pad in rubbish bag (see illustrations).
c. Assess perineal area for extra perineal care/washing required.
d. If washing is required, place a waterproof pad under the client, wash perineum with a washcloth and dry with a towel (see Skill 34-2).
e. Apply clean pad to underwear using self-adhesive strips.
f. Replace underwear.
g. Remove gloves and dispose in rubbish bag. Wash hands.
h. Help client return to a comfortable position.</p>
<ol start="9">
<li>Use of tampons</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Lower or remove underwear.
b. With client lying on her side, part labia with non-dominant hand to view the outlet of the vagina.
c. Remove used tampon by grasping the cord with fingers of dominant hand. Draw the cord outwards and downwards (towards client's feet) until the tampon emerges.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="rationale">RATIONALE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rationale" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Ensures client privacy.</p>
<p>Ensures orderly procedure and facilitates disposal of contaminated material.</p>
<p>Determines client's ability to perform self-care and determines level of assistance required from nurse. Pain relief may be required for positioning.</p>
<p>Minimises anxiety and embarrassment about need for assistance.</p>
<p>Involves client in own care, gives sense of control over preferences.</p>
<p>Facilitates good body mechanics, provides good access to the perineal area.</p>
<p>Reduces transmission of infectious organisms. Gloves prevent contact with microorganisms contained in blood and body fluids.</p>
<p>Based on area of pad saturated, time taken to soak pad.</p>
<p>Determines extent of care required by client.</p>
<p>Reduces transmission of infectious organisms.</p>
<p>Promotes comfort and reduces embarrassment.</p>
<p>Provides access to perineum.</p>
<p>FUNDAMENTALS OF NURSING: CLINICAL SKILLS WORKBOOK</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>d. Assess PV loss. Wrap tampon in toilet paper and dispose of in rubbish bag (see illustrations).</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>e. Unwrap new tampon.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>f. Hold the tampon by cord end, with cord across palm of hand and index finger guiding the cord-end dimple of tampon. Illustrations 9fA and 9fB show non-applicator tampons and illustration 9fC compares non-applicator tampon with applicator tampon. Once applicator tampon is inserted into the vagina, gentle finger pressure on sliding cylinder causes tampon to be released into the distal part of the vagina. Cardboard cylinder is then removed and discarded (see illustrations 9fDâ€“F).</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>g. Insert the tampon in the vagina, angling upwards and backwards, following the vaginal canal.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>h. Insert to the length of the index finger or applicator tube.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>i. Cord will emerge externally as a guide to placement and to facilitate removal.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>j. Replace underwear.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>k. Remove gloves and dispose of in rubbish bag. Wash hands.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>l. Help client return to a comfortable position.</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<ol start="10">
<li>If client has participated in care, offer her a bowl and washcloth for her own handwashing.</li>
<li>Ask if client feels sense of cleanliness.</li>
<li>Ask about and observe for any signs of pain, dysfunction or infection in perineal area. | Based on saturation of tampon, time taken to soak tampon.</li>
</ol>
<p>Reduces transmission of infectious organisms.
Promotes comfort and reduces embarrassment.
Promotes hygiene and comfort, reduces microorganism transmission from body fluids to linens and furniture.
Evaluates clientâ€™s comfort levels.  |
|  RECORDING AND REPORTING | SAFETY CONSIDERATIONS  |
|  â€¢ Record PV loss in fluid charts if heavy; estimate volume.
â€¢ Adjust the nursing care plan regularly to accommodate the changing need for menstrual care. | â€¢ At night, care should include a pad of extra absorbency to facilitate an undisturbed sleep for the client. Super-absorbent tampons should be avoided due to the link with toxic shock syndrome.  |

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="administering-a-back-rub">Administering a back rub<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#administering-a-back-rub" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="delegation-considerations">DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delegation-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Administering a back rub can be delegated to nurse assistants under the guidance of the registered nurse (Division 1),</p>
<ul>
<li>Registered nurse (RN) should assess for any possible contraindication to back rub.</li>
<li>Inform caregiver to report any change in vital signs or behaviour during back rub.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Moisturising lotion or lubricant</li>
<li>Sphygmomanometer and stethoscope</li>
<li>Bath towel</li>
<li>Bath blanket</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="steps">STEPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Identify factors or conditions such as rib or vertebral fractures, burns, reddened areas on the skin or open wounds and status post coronary artery (CA) bypass that contraindicate back rub.</li>
<li>Explain procedure and desired position to patient. Determine whether patient is comfortable with heavy massage stroke.</li>
<li>Adjust bed to high, comfortable position.</li>
<li>Adjust light, temperature and sound within room.</li>
<li>Lower side rail and help patient into a prone or side-lying (Sims') position with back towards you. Close curtain around bed.</li>
<li>Assess patient's heart rate (HR), respiratory rate (RR) and blood pressure (BP).</li>
<li>Expose patient's back, shoulders, upper arms and buttocks. Cover remainder of body with bath blanket. Lay towel alongside patient's back.</li>
<li>Wash hands in warm water. Warm lotion in hands or by placing container under warm water. Place small amount of lotion in hands.</li>
<li>Explain to patient that lotion will feel cool and wet.</li>
<li>Apply hands first to sacral area, massaging in circular motion. Stroke upwards from buttocks to shoulders. Massage over scapulae with smooth, firm stroke. Continue in one smooth stroke to upper arms and laterally along sides of back down to iliac crests (see illustration). Do not allow your hands to leave patient's skin. Continue massage pattern for at least 3 minutes.</li>
<li>Knead skin by gently grasping tissue between your thumb and fingers. Knead upwards along one side of spine from buttocks to shoulders and around nape of neck. Knead or stroke downwards towards sacrum. Repeat along other side of back.</li>
<li>End massage with long stroking movements for an additional 3 minutes, and tell patient you are ending massage.</li>
<li>If lying on side, ask patient to turn to opposite side, and massage other hip.</li>
<li>Wipe excess lubricant from patient's back with bath towel. Retie gown or help with pyjamas. Help patient to comfortable position. Raise side rails as needed, and open curtain. Lower bed.</li>
<li>Dispose of soiled towel and wash hands.</li>
<li>Ask patient about comfort. Note any areas of muscle pain or tension.</li>
<li>Reassess pulse and BP.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="recording-and-reporting">RECORDING AND REPORTING<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#recording-and-reporting" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Record response to massage and condition of skin.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="rationale">RATIONALE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rationale" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Massage of sensitive tissues might lead to further tissue injury. Massaging reddened areas of skin increases breaks in capillaries in underlying tissues. An increase in heart rate and systolic and diastolic blood pressure occurs in post-CA bypass patients.</p>
<p>Helps promote relaxation.</p>
<p>Ensures proper body mechanics and prevents strain on back muscles.</p>
<p>Environmental distractions can prevent patient from relaxing. Position makes it easier to apply necessary pressure to back muscles. Privacy promotes relaxation.</p>
<p>Decreased HR, RR and BP are usual following even a 3-minute back rub. Assessment establishes baseline.</p>
<p>Prevents unnecessary exposure of body parts and prevents excess lotion from touching bedclothes.</p>
<p>Cold causes muscle tension.</p>
<p>Warning patient reduces startled response.</p>
<p>Gentle, firm pressure applied to all muscle groups promotes relaxation. Continuous contact with skin's surface is soothing and stimulates circulation to tissues.</p>
<p>Kneading increases circulation. Motion is soothing and relieving.</p>
<p>Long stroking is most soothing.</p>
<p>Excess lotion can be an irritant. Comfortable position enhances back rub's effects.</p>
<p>Promotes infection control.</p>
<p>Degree of relief gained depends on length of massage, patient's ability to relax and degree of discomfort before massage.</p>
<p>Gentle back massage may increase HR and systolic BP.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="home-care-considerations">HOME CARE CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#home-care-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Massage is an easy technique to teach a family member to promote patient's relaxation at any time of the day.</li>
</ul>
<p>180 FUNDAMENTALS OF NURSING: CLINICAL SKILLS WORKBOOK</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="administering-a-back-rub">ADMINISTERING A BACK RUB<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#administering-a-back-rub" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

towel</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Assists patient to dress</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Assesses patientâ€™s comfort level</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Reassess patientâ€™s pulse and blood pressure</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>

<p>SKILL 34-5</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="performing-nail-and-foot-care">Performing nail and foot care<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#performing-nail-and-foot-care" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="delegation-considerations">DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delegation-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Nail and foot care of the non-diabetic patient can be undertaken by nurse assistants under the guidance of the registered nurse (Division 1). If the patient is diabetic, this should not be delegated.</p>
<ul>
<li>Instruct caregiver in proper way to use nail clippers.</li>
<li>Instruct caregiver to report immediately any cuts in skin.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Washbasin</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Emesis basin</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Washcloth</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Bath or face towel</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Nail clippers</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Orange stick</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Emery board or nail file</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Body lotion</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Disposable bath mat</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Paper towels</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Disposable gloves</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="steps">STEPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Inspect all surfaces of fingers, toes, feet and nails. Pay particular attention to areas of dryness, inflammation or cracking. Also inspect areas between toes, heels and soles of feet.</li>
<li>Assess colour and temperature of toes, feet and fingers. Assess capillary refill of nails. Palpate radial and ulnar pulse of each hand and dorsalis pedis pulse of foot; note character of pulses.</li>
<li>Observe patient's gait. Have patient walk down hall or walk straight line (if able).</li>
<li>Ask female patients whether they use nail polish and polish remover frequently.</li>
<li>Assess type of footwear worn by patients. Are socks worn? Are shoes tight or ill-fitting? Are garters or knee-high stockings worn? Is footwear clean?</li>
<li>Identify patient's risk of foot or nail problems:</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Older adult
b. Diabetes mellitus
c. Heart failure, renal disease
d. Cerebrovascular accident, stroke</p>
<ol start="7">
<li>Assess type of home remedies patient uses for existing foot problems:</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Over-the-counter liquid preparations to remove corns
b. Cutting of corns or calluses with razor blade or scissors
c. Use of oval corn pads
d. Application of adhesive tape</p>
<ol start="8">
<li>Assess patient's ability to care for nails or feet: visual alterations, fatigue, musculoskeletal weakness.</li>
<li>Assess patient's knowledge of foot and nail care practices.</li>
<li>Explain procedure to patient, including fact that proper soaking requires several minutes.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="rationale">RATIONALE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rationale" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Integrity of feet and nails determines frequency and level of hygiene required. Heels, soles and sides of feet are prone to irritation from ill-fitting shoes.</p>
<p>Assesses adequacy of blood flow to extremities. Circulatory alterations may change integrity of nails and increase patient's chance of localised infection when break in skin integrity occurs.</p>
<p>Painful disorders of feet can cause limping or unnatural gait.</p>
<p>Chemicals in these products can cause excessive dryness.</p>
<p>Types of shoes and footwear may predispose patient to foot and nail problems (e.g. infection, areas of friction, ulcerations).</p>
<p>Certain conditions increase likelihood of foot or nail problems.</p>
<p>Poor vision, lack of coordination or inability to bend over contribute to difficulty in performing foot and nail care. Normal physiological changes of ageing also result in nail and foot problems.</p>
<p>Vascular changes associated with diabetes mellitus reduce blood flow to peripheral tissues. Break in skin integrity places diabetic at high risk of skin infection.</p>
<p>Both conditions can increase tissue oedema, particularly in dependent areas (e.g. feet). Oedema reduces blood flow to neighbouring tissues.</p>
<p>Presence of residual foot or leg weakness or paralysis results in altered walking patterns. Altered gait pattern causes increased friction and pressure on feet.</p>
<p>Certain preparations or applications may cause more injury to soft tissue than initial foot problem.</p>
<p>Liquid preparations can cause burns and ulcerations.</p>
<p>Cutting of corns or calluses may result in infection caused by break in skin integrity.</p>
<p>Oval pads may exert pressure on toes, thereby decreasing circulation to surrounding tissues.</p>
<p>Skin of older adult is thin and delicate and prone to tearing when adhesive tape is removed.</p>
<p>Determines patient's ability to perform self-care and degree of assistance required from nurse.</p>
<p>Determines patient's need for health teaching.</p>
<p>Patient must be willing to place fingers and feet in basins for 10â€“20 minutes. Patient may become anxious or fatigued.</p>
<p>HYGIENE 183</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="performing-nail-and-foot-care">PERFORMING NAIL AND FOOT CARE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#performing-nail-and-foot-care" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<p>SKILL 34-6</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="providing-oral-hygiene">Providing oral hygiene<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#providing-oral-hygiene" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="delegation-considerations">DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delegation-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Brushing teeth can be delegated to nurse assistants under the guidance of the registered nurse (Division 1).</p>
<ul>
<li>Instruct caregiver in proper way to provide toothbrushing.</li>
<li>Instruct caregiver in how to recognise impaired integrity of oral mucosa.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Soft-bristled toothbrush</li>
<li>Non-abrasive fluoride toothpaste</li>
<li>Dental floss</li>
<li>Glass with cool water</li>
<li>Normal saline or fluoride mouthwash (optional; follow patient's preference)</li>
<li>Emesis basin</li>
<li>Face towel</li>
<li>Paper towels</li>
<li>Disposable gloves</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="steps">STEPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Wash hands and put on disposable gloves.</li>
<li>Inspect integrity of lips, teeth, buccal mucosa, gums, palate and tongue (see Chapter 27).</li>
<li>Identify presence of common oral problems:
a. Dental cariesâ€”chalky white discolouration of tooth or presence of brown or black discolouration
b. Gingivitisâ€”inflammation of gums
c. Periodontitisâ€”receding gum lines, inflammation, gaps between teeth
d. Halitosisâ€”bad breath
e. Cheilosisâ€”cracking of lips
f. Stomatitisâ€”inflammation of the mouth</li>
<li>Remove gloves and wash hands.</li>
<li>Assess risk of oral hygiene problems (see Table 34-7).</li>
<li>Determine patient's oral hygiene practices:
a. Frequency of toothbrushing and flossing
b. Type of toothpaste used
c. Last dental visit
d. Frequency of dental visits
e. Type of mouthwash or moistening preparation.</li>
<li>Assess patient's ability to grasp and manipulate toothbrush. (For older adult, try 30 seconds of toothbrush assessment).</li>
<li>Prepare equipment at bedside.</li>
<li>Explain procedure to patient and discuss preferences regarding use of hygiene aids.</li>
<li>Place paper towels on overbed table, and arrange other equipment within easy reach.</li>
<li>Raise bed to comfortable working position. Raise head of bed (if allowed) and lower side rail. Move patient, or help patient move closer. Side-lying position can be used.</li>
<li>Place towel over patient's chest.</li>
<li>Apply gloves.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="rationale">RATIONALE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rationale" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Reduces transmission of microorganisms.</p>
<p>Determines status of patient's oral cavity and extent of need for oral hygiene.</p>
<p>Helps determine type of hygiene patient requires and information patient requires for self-care.</p>
<p>Prevents spread of microorganisms.</p>
<p>Certain conditions increase likelihood of impaired oral cavity integrity and need for preventive care.</p>
<p>Allows nurse to identify errors in technique, deficiencies in preventive oral hygiene and patient's level of knowledge regarding dental care.</p>
<p>Lemon-glycerin preparations can be detrimental. Glycerin is an astringent that dries and shrinks mucous membranes and gums. Lemon exhausts salivary reflex and can erode tooth enamel. Mouthwash provides pleasant aftertaste but can dry mucosa after extended use if it has an alcohol base.</p>
<p>Determines level of assistance required. Toothbrush test useful in assessing dexterity and strength.</p>
<p>Some patients feel uncomfortable about having the nurse care for their basic needs. Patient involvement with procedure minimises anxiety.</p>
<p>Raising bed and positioning patient prevent nurse from straining muscles. Semi-Fowler's position helps prevent patient from choking or aspirating.</p>
<p>Keeps patient's clothing clean and dry.</p>
<p>Prevents contact with microorganisms or blood in saliva.</p>
<p>HYGIENE 187</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>14. Apply toothpaste to brush, holding brush over emesis basin. Pour small amount of water over toothpaste.</td><td>Moisture helps distribute toothpaste over tooth surfaces.</td></tr><tr><td>15. Patient may help by brushing. Hold toothbrush bristles at 45-degree angle to gum line (see illustration). Be sure tips of bristles rest against and penetrate under gum line. Brush inner and outer surfaces of upper and lower teeth by brushing from gum to crown of each tooth. Clean biting surfaces of teeth by holding top of bristles parallel with teeth and brushing gently back and forth (see illustration). Brush sides of teeth by moving bristles back and forth (see illustration).</td><td>Angle allows brush to reach all tooth surfaces and to clean under gum line where plaque and tartar accumulate. Back-and-forth motion dislodges food particles caught between teeth and along chewing surfaces.</td></tr><tr><td>16. Have patient hold brush at 45-degree angle and lightly brush over surface and sides of tongue. Avoid initiating gag reflex.</td><td>Microorganisms collect and grow on tongue's surface and contribute to bad breath. Gagging may cause aspiration of toothpaste.</td></tr><tr><td>17. Allow patient to rinse mouth thoroughly by taking several sips of water, swishing water across all tooth surfaces and spitting into emesis basin.</td><td>Irrigation removes food particles.</td></tr><tr><td>18. Allow patient to gargle to rinse mouth with mouthwash as desired.</td><td>Mouthwash leaves pleasant taste in mouth.</td></tr><tr><td>19. Help wipe patient's mouth.</td><td>Promotes sense of comfort.</td></tr><tr><td>20. Allow patient to floss (see illustration).</td><td>Reduces tartar on tooth surfaces.</td></tr><tr><td>21. Allow patient to rinse mouth thoroughly with cool water and spit into emesis basin. Help wipe patient's mouth.</td><td>Irrigation removes plaque and tartar from oral cavity.</td></tr><tr><td>22. Help patient into comfortable position, remove emesis basin and bedside table, raise side rail and lower bed to original position.</td><td>Provides for patient comfort and safety.</td></tr><tr><td>23. Wipe off overbed table, discard soiled linen and paper towels in appropriate containers, remove soiled gloves and return equipment to proper place.</td><td>Proper disposal of soiled equipment prevents spread of infection.</td></tr><tr><td>24. Wash hands.</td><td>Reduces transmission of microorganisms.</td></tr><tr><td>25. Ask patient whether any area of oral cavity feels uncomfortable or irritated.</td><td>Pain indicates more chronic problem.</td></tr><tr><td>26. Put on gloves and inspect condition of oral cavity.</td><td>Determines effectiveness of hygiene and rinsing.</td></tr><tr><td>27. Ask patient to describe proper hygiene techniques.</td><td>Evaluates patient's learning.</td></tr><tr><td>28. Observe patient brushing.</td><td>Evaluates patient's ability to use correct technique.</td></tr><tr><td>RECORDING AND REPORTING</td><td>HOME CARE CONSIDERATIONS</td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Record procedure on flow sheet. Note condition of oral cavity in nurses' notes.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Report bleeding or presence of lesions to nurse in charge or doctor.</td><td>â€¢ Assess oral cavity at each visit to determine the effects of medications on the structures of the oral cavity.</td></tr></tbody></table>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="providing-oral-hygiene">PROVIDING ORAL HYGIENE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#providing-oral-hygiene" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>CLINICAL SKILL 34-6: Providing oral hygiene</p>
<p>DEMONSTRATES: The ability to effectively perform mouth and oral care</p>
<p>DOMAIN/S (AUS): Professional Practice and Provision and Coordination of Care</p>
<p>DOMAIN/S (NZ): Professional responsibility; management of nursing care; interpersonal relationships; interprofessional healthcare and quality improvement</p>
<p>PERFORMANCE CRITERIA: (numbers indicate National Competency Standards for the Registered Nurse)</p>
<p>AUS 2.3, 5.1, 5.2, 5.3, 6.3, 7.1, 7.3, 7.5, 7.6, 7.7</p>
<p>NZ 1.1, 1.2, 1.3, 1.4, 1.5, 2.1, 2.3, 2.4, 2.6, 2.7, 2.8, 3.1, 3.2, 3.3, 4.1, 4.2</p>
