<p>SKILL 34-7</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="performing-mouth-care-for-an-unconscious-or-debilitated-client">Performing mouth care for an unconscious or debilitated client<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#performing-mouth-care-for-an-unconscious-or-debilitated-client" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="delegation-considerations">DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delegation-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Brushing teeth of an unconscious or debilitated patient can be delegated to nurse assistants under the supervision of the registered nurse (RN) (Division 1).</p>
<ul>
<li>After RN checks for gag reflex, inform caregiver about proper way to position patients for mouth care.</li>
<li>Instruct caregiver in how to use the oral suction catheter for clearing oral secretions.</li>
<li>Instruct caregiver in how to recognise impaired integrity of oral mucosa.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Anti-infective solution (e.g. diluted hydrogen peroxide) that loosens crusts</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Small soft-bristled toothbrush</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Sponge toothette or tongue blade wrapped in single layer of gauze</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Padded tongue depressor</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Face towel</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Paper towels</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Emesis basin</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Water glass with cool water</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Water-soluble lip lubricant</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Small-bulb syringe (optional)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Suction machine equipment (optional)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Disposable gloves (three pairs)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Eye shield or goggles</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="steps">STEPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Wash hands. Put on disposable gloves and goggles or eye shield.</li>
<li>Test for presence of gag reflex by placing tongue blade on back half of tongue. Patients with impaired gag reflex require oral care as well. The nurse determines the type of suction apparatus needed at the bedside to protect the patient's airway against aspiration.</li>
<li>Inspect condition of oral cavity (see Chapter 27).</li>
<li>Remove gloves. Wash hands.</li>
<li>Assess patient's risk of oral hygiene problems (see Table 34-7).</li>
<li>Position patient on side (Sims' position) with head turned well towards dependent side and head of bed lowered. Raise side rail.</li>
<li>Explain procedure to patient.</li>
<li>Wash hands and apply disposable gloves.</li>
<li>Place paper towels on overbed table and arrange equipment. If needed, turn on suction machine and connect tubing to suction catheter.</li>
<li>Pull curtain around bed, or close room door.</li>
<li>Raise bed to its highest horizontal level; lower side rail.</li>
<li>Position patient close to side of bed; turn patient's head towards mattress.</li>
<li>Place towel under patient's head and emesis basin under chin.</li>
<li>Carefully separate upper and lower teeth with padded tongue blade by inserting blade, quickly but gently, between back molars. Insert when patient is relaxed, if possible. Do not use force. Never use fingers to separate patient's teeth.</li>
<li>Clean mouth using brush or sponge toothettes moistened with peroxide and water (see illustration). Clean chewing and inner tooth surfaces first. Clean outer tooth surfaces. Swab roof of mouth, gums and inside cheeks. Gently swab or brush tongue but avoid stimulating gag reflex (if present). Moisten clean swab or toothette with water to rinse. (Bulb syringe may also be used to rinse.) Repeat rinse several times.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="rationale">RATIONALE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rationale" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Reduces transmission of microorganisms. Gloves prevent contact with microorganisms in blood or saliva.</p>
<p>Reveals whether patient is at risk of aspiration.</p>
<p>Determines condition of oral cavity and need for hygiene.</p>
<p>Prevents spread of infection.</p>
<p>Certain conditions increase likelihood of alterations in integrity of oral cavity structures and may require more frequent care.</p>
<p>Allows secretions to drain from mouth instead of collecting in back of pharynx. Prevents aspiration.</p>
<p>Allows debilitated patient to anticipate procedure without anxiety. Unconscious patient may retain ability to hear.</p>
<p>Reduces transfer of microorganisms.</p>
<p>Prevents soiling of table top. Equipment prepared in advance ensures smooth, safe procedure.</p>
<p>Provides privacy.</p>
<p>Use of good body mechanics with bed in high position prevents injury.</p>
<p>Proper positioning of head prevents aspiration.</p>
<p>Prevents soiling of bedclothes.</p>
<p>Prevents patient from biting down on nurse's fingers and provides access to oral cavity.</p>
<p>Brushing action removes food particles between teeth and along chewing surfaces. Swabbing helps remove secretions and crusts from mucosa and moistens mucosa. Repeated rinsing removes peroxide that can be irritating to mucosa.</p>
<p>HYGIENE 191</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>16. Suction secretions as they accumulate, if necessary.</td><td>Suction removes secretions and fluid that can collect in posterior pharynx.</td></tr><tr><td>17. Apply thin layer of water-soluble jelly to lips (see illustration).</td><td>Lubricates lips to prevent drying and cracking.</td></tr><tr><td>18. Inform patient that procedure is completed.</td><td>Provides meaningful stimulation to unconscious or less responsive patient.</td></tr><tr><td>19. Remove gloves and discard in proper receptacle.</td><td>Prevents transmission of infection.</td></tr><tr><td>20. Reposition patient comfortably, raise side rail and return bed to original position.</td><td>Maintains patientâ€™s comfort and safety.</td></tr><tr><td>21. Clean equipment and return to its proper place. Place soiled linen in proper receptacle.</td><td>Proper disposal of soiled equipment prevents spread of infection.</td></tr><tr><td>22. Wash hands.</td><td>Reduces transmission of microorganisms.</td></tr><tr><td>23. Put on gloves, and inspect oral cavity.</td><td>Determines efficacy of cleansing. Once thick secretions are removed, underlying inflammation or lesions may be revealed.</td></tr><tr><td>24. Ask debilitated patient if mouth feels clean.</td><td>Evaluates level of comfort.</td></tr><tr><td>25. Assess patientâ€™s respirations on an ongoing basis.</td><td>Ensures early recognition of aspiration.</td></tr><tr><td>RECORDING AND REPORTING</td><td>HOME CARE CONSIDERATIONS</td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Record procedure, including pertinent observations (e.g. presence of bleeding gums, dry mucosa, ulcerations, crusts on tongue).</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Report any unusual findings to nurse in charge or doctor.</td><td>â€¢ Irrigate cavity with bulb syringe.</td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Mouth care should be given at least twice a day.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Caregivers can get non-prescription oral care solutions (e.g. carbamide peroxide solutions) at most chemists/pharmacies. Have caregivers demonstrate positioning patient to prevent aspiration.</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="performing-mouth-care-for-an-unconscious-or-debilitated-client">PERFORMING MOUTH CARE FOR AN UNCONSCIOUS OR DEBILITATED CLIENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#performing-mouth-care-for-an-unconscious-or-debilitated-client" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>CLINICAL SKILL 34-7: Performing mouth care for an unconscious or debilitated client</p>
<p>DEMONSTRATES: The ability to effectively provide mouth care for an unconscious or debilitated client and reduce the potential for oral infection or irritation</p>
<p>DOMAIN/S (AUS): Professional Practice and Provision and Coordination of Care</p>
<p>DOMAIN/S (NZ): Professional responsibility; management of nursing care; interpersonal relationships; interprofessional healthcare and quality improvement</p>
<p>PERFORMANCE CRITERIA: (numbers indicate National Competency Standards for the Registered Nurse)</p>
<p>AUS 2.3, 5.1, 5.2, 5.3, 6.3, 7.1, 7.3, 7.5, 7.6, 7.7</p>
<p>NZ 1.1, 1.2, 1.3, 2.1, 2.2, 2.3, 2.4, 2.6, 2.7, 2.8, 3.1, 3.2, 3.3, 4.1, 4.2</p>

<p>SKILL 34-8</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="caring-for-the-patient-with-contact-lenses">Caring for the patient with contact lenses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#caring-for-the-patient-with-contact-lenses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="delegation-considerations">DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delegation-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Caring for eye prostheses can be delegated to nurse assistants.</p>
<ul>
<li>Instruct caregiver in proper way to care for eye prostheses.</li>
<li>Stress to caregiver that careful handling of these devices is of utmost importance to prevent physical injury to the patient and damage to the devices.</li>
<li>Inform caregiver of types of findings to report (e.g. eye pain, eye socket drainage).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Clean lens storage container</li>
<li>Bath towel</li>
<li>Suction cup (optional)</li>
<li>Sterile saline solution</li>
<li>Sterile lens cleaning solution</li>
<li>Sterile lens rinsing solution</li>
<li>Sterile lens disinfectant</li>
<li>Sterile enzyme solution (depends on care regimen)</li>
<li>Sterile wetting solution (depends on care regimen)</li>
<li>Cotton ball or cotton bud</li>
<li>Emesis basin</li>
<li>Disposable gloves</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="steps">STEPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Place towel just below patient's face.</li>
<li>Stand at patient's side. Inspect eye, or ask patient whether contact lens is in place. Unconscious or confused patients should be carefully assessed; lenses are often difficult to assess if clear (untinted).</li>
<li>Ask whether patient feels any eye discomfort, and assess length of time patient normally wears lenses.</li>
<li>Ask whether patient is able to manipulate and hold contact lens.</li>
<li>Assess patient for any unusual visual signs/symptoms (reduced visual acuity, blurred vision, pain photophobia).</li>
<li>Assess types of medications prescribed for patient: sedatives, hypnotics, muscle relaxants, antihistamines, anticholinergics and antidepressants.</li>
<li>After lenses are removed (see Step 11), inspect eye for signs of corneal irritation (e.g. redness, pain, swelling of eyelids and conjunctivae, discharge and excess watering). If pain persists or worsens after removal of lenses, an immediate referral to the ophthalmologist should be made.</li>
<li>Discuss procedure with patient.</li>
<li>Have patient assume supine or sitting position in bed or chair.</li>
<li>Assemble supplies at bedside.</li>
<li>Remove lenses.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="a-soft-lenses">A. Soft lenses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-soft-lenses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>(1) Wash hands. Put on disposable gloves if there are cuts, scratches or dermatological lesions on nurse's hands.
(2) Add a few drops of sterile saline solution to patient's eye.
(3) Tell patient to look straight ahead.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="rationale">RATIONALE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rationale" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Catches lens if one should accidentally fall from eye.</p>
<p>Lenses are generally comfortable to wear, and patient may forget they are in place. Prolonged wear may cause injury to eye.</p>
<p>Scratched lens can cause corneal irritation and abrasion. Accumulation of dust or debris between lens and cornea causes irritation. Continuous wearing of certain types of lenses can irritate cornea.</p>
<p>Determines level of assistance required in care.</p>
<p>May indicate underlying visual alteration or need to change lens prescription. A reduction in visual acuity calls for referral.</p>
<p>Sedatives, hypnotics and muscle relaxants reduce blink reflex and thus reduce lubrication of cornea. Antihistamines, anticholinergics and antidepressants can reduce tear production.</p>
<p>Signs/symptoms indicate corneal irritation or abrasion. Severe pain may indicate corneal epithelium disruption or infection.</p>
<p>Patient can help plan by explaining technique that may aid removal and insertion. Patient may be anxious as nurse retracts eyelids and manipulates lenses.</p>
<p>Provides easy access for nurse while retracting eyelids and manipulating lenses.</p>
<p>Provides easy access to supplies.</p>
<p>Reduces transmission of microorganisms.</p>
<p>Lubricates eye to facilitate lens removal.</p>
<p>Eases tipping of lens during removal.</p>
<p>HYGIENE 195</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>(4) Using middle finger, retract lower eyelid.</td><td>Exposes lower edge of lens.</td></tr><tr><td>(5) With pad of index finger of same hand, slide lens off cornea onto white of eye.</td><td>Positions lens for easy grasping. Use of finger pad (rather than fingernail) prevents injury to cornea and damage to lens.</td></tr><tr><td>(6) Pull upper eyelid down gently with thumb of other hand, and compress lens slightly between thumb and index finger.</td><td>Causes soft lens to double up. Air enters underneath lens to release suction.</td></tr><tr><td>(7) Gently pinch lens, and lift out.</td><td>Protects lens from damage. Avoid allowing lens edges to stick together. Soft lenses can be easily torn.</td></tr><tr><td>(8) Clean and rinse lens. Place lens in proper storage case compartment: R for right lens and L for left lens (see illustration).</td><td>Ensures proper lens will be reinserted into correct eye. Proper storage prevents cracking or tearing.</td></tr><tr><td>a. After removing one lens from case, apply one or two drops of cleaning solution to lens in palm of hand (use cleaner recommended by lens manufacturer or eye-care practitioner).</td><td>Removes tear components, including mucus, lipids and proteins that collect on lens.</td></tr><tr><td>b. Rub lens gently but thoroughly on both sides for 20â€“30 seconds. Use index finger (soft lenses) or little finger or cotton bud soaked with cleaning solution (rigid lenses) to clean inside lens. Be careful not to turn lens wrong side out or touch or scratch lens with fingernail.</td><td>It is easier to manipulate and clean lens using fingertips. Cleans microorganisms from all surfaces.</td></tr><tr><td>c. Holding lens over emesis basin, rinse thoroughly with manufacturer-recommended rinsing solution (soft lenses) or cold tap water (rigid lenses).</td><td>Removes debris and cleaning solution from lens surface. Rinsing methods and solutions differ for each type of lens.</td></tr><tr><td>d. Place lens in proper storage case compartment and fill with storage solution recommended by manufacturer or eye-care practitioner.</td><td>Disinfects lens, removes residue, enhances wetability of lens and prevents scratches to lens that can be caused by a dry case.</td></tr><tr><td>(9) Repeat Steps (2) to (8) for other lens. Secure cover over storage case. Label with patientâ€™s name and room number.</td><td>Proper storage prevents damage to or loss of lenses.</td></tr><tr><td>(10) Dispose of towel, remove gloves and wash hands.</td><td>Reduces transmission of infection.</td></tr><tr><td>B. Rigid lenses</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(1) Wash hands, and put on gloves if needed.</td><td>Reduces transmission of microorganisms.</td></tr><tr><td>(2) Be sure lens is positioned directly over cornea. If lens is not positioned directly over cornea, have patient close eyelids, place index and middle fingers of one hand on eyelid just beside the lens and beneath it and gently but firmly massage lens back into place.</td><td>Correct position of lens allows easy removal from eye.</td></tr><tr><td>(3) Place index finger on outer corner of patientâ€™s eye, and draw skin gently back towards ear.</td><td>Tightens eyelid against eyeball.</td></tr><tr><td>(4) Tell patient to blink. Do not release pressure on eyelid until blink is completed.</td><td>Manoeuvre should cause lens to dislodge and pop out. Lid margins must clear top and bottom of lens until the blink.</td></tr><tr><td>(5) If lens fails to pop out, gently retract eyelid beyond edges of lens. Press lower eyelid gently against lower edge of lens.</td><td>Pressure causes upper edge of lens to tip forwards.</td></tr><tr><td>(6) Allow both eyelids to close slightly, and grasp lens as it rises from eye. Cup lens in hand.</td><td>Manoeuvre causes lens to slide off easily. Protects lens from breakage.</td></tr><tr><td>(7) A lens suction cup can be used to remove lenses from the eyes of confused or unconscious patients. Gently apply suction cup to lens surface, and lift out.</td><td>The lenses may not have the same prescription. Proper storage prevents breaking, scratching, chipping and discolouration.</td></tr><tr><td>(8) Clean and rinse lens (see Step 11A(8)). Place lens in proper storage case compartment: R for right lens and L for left lens. Centre lens in storage case, convex side down.</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>FUNDAMENTALS OF NURSING: CLINICAL SKILLS WORKBOOK</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>(9) Repeat Steps (2) to (8) for other lens. Secure cover over storage case. Label with patient's name and room number.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(10) Dispose of towel, remove gloves and wash hands.</td><td>Proper storage prevents damage to or loss of lenses.</td></tr><tr><td>Reduces spread of infection and keeps patient's environment neat.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>12. Insert lenses</td><td></td></tr><tr><td><strong>A. Soft lenses</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(1) Remove right lens from storage case and rinse with recommended rinsing solution; inspect lens for foreign materials, tears or other damage.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(2) Check that lens is not inverted (inside out). Apply wetting agent (sterile saline).</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(3) Using middle or index finger of opposite hand, retract upper lid until iris is exposed.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(4) Use middle finger of the hand holding lens to pull down lower lid.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(5) Tell patient to look straight ahead; gently place lens directly on cornea; release lids slowly, starting with lower lid.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(6) Tell patient to close eyes slowly and roll them towards lens if not on the cornea.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(7) Tell patient to blink a few times.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(8) Ask patient to open eyes. Check for blurred vision or discomfort.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(9) Repeat Steps (1) to (8) for left eye.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(10) Discard used solution in the storage case.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(11) Wash lens case with soap and a scrubber. Rinse case in sterile saline or a known disinfectant. Store dry.</td><td>Soft lens is inverted if the edge has a lip; it is in proper position if curve is even from base to rim.</td></tr><tr><td>Ensures lens is centred, free of trapped air and comfortable.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td><strong>B. Rigid lenses</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(1) Remove right lens from storage case; attempt to lift lens straight up (see illustration).</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(2) Rinse with recommended rinsing solution; inspect lens for foreign material or chips.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(3) Wet lens on both sides, using prescribed wetting solution.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(4) Place right lens concave side up on tip of index finger of dominant hand (see illustration).</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(5) Instruct patient to look straight ahead while retracting both upper and lower lids; place lens gently over centre of cornea (see illustration).</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(6) Ask patient to close eyes briefly and avoid blinking.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(7) Ask patient to open eyes. Check for blurred vision or discomfort.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(8) Repeat Steps (1) to (7) for left eye.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(9) Discard used solution. See Step 12A(11) for case cleansing.</td><td>Prevents multiplication of amoebae and bacteria.</td></tr><tr><td>Sliding lens out of case can cause scratches on the surface.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Hot water causes lens to warp.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Inner surface of lens should face up so that it is applied against cornea.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Helps to secure position of lens.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>13. Ask patient whether lens feels comfortable after removal and reinsertion of lenses.</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<ol start="14">
<li>Inspect eye (over time) for signs of ocular infection.</li>
<li>Assess patient's visual acuity (see Chapter 27).</li>
<li>Observe patient for signs of eye injury. | Determines if any debris is caught between lens and cornea. Lens should be removed if patient experiences discomfort.
Determines improvement in visual perception.  |
|  RECORDING AND REPORTING | HOME CARE CONSIDERATIONS  |
|  â€¢ Record or report any signs/symptoms of visual alterations or corneal irritation noted during procedure.
â€¢ Record on nursing care plan times of lens insertion and removal if patient is going to surgery or special procedure. | â€¢ Patients must be taught not to wear lenses in presence of noxious or irritating vapours or fumes because these irritants can cause damage to lens surface.  |</li>
</ol>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="caring-for-the-patient-with-contact-lenses">CARING FOR THE PATIENT WITH CONTACT LENSES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#caring-for-the-patient-with-contact-lenses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

SKILL 34-9</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="making-an-occupied-bed">Making an occupied bed<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#making-an-occupied-bed" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="delegation-considerations">DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delegation-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Making an occupied bed can be undertaken by nurse assistants under the guidance of the registered nurse (Division 1).</p>
<ul>
<li>Inform caregiver how to properly position patients during occupied bedmaking procedure.</li>
<li>Tell caregiver what to do if wound drainage, dressing material, drainage tubes or intravenous (IV) tubing becomes dislodged or is found in the bedclothes.</li>
<li>Instruct caregiver on what to do if patient becomes tired.</li>
<li>Stress safety procedures, e.g. location of call system for easy access in the event that staff assistance is needed.</li>
<li>Instruct caregiver to report any changes in patient's level of consciousness, breathing patterns, level of pain or dizziness.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Dirty linen bag(s)</li>
<li>Mattress pad (needs to be changed only when soiled)</li>
<li>Bottom sheet (flat or fitted)</li>
<li>Drawsheet</li>
<li>Top sheet</li>
<li>Blanket</li>
<li>Bedspread</li>
<li>Waterproof pads and/or bath blankets (optional)</li>
<li>Pillowcases</li>
<li>Bedside chair or table</li>
<li>Disposable gloves (optional)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="steps">STEPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Determine whether patient is incontinent or has excess drainage on bedclothes.</li>
<li>Check chart for orders or specific precautions for movement and positioning.</li>
<li>Explain procedure to patient, noting that patient will be asked to turn on side to roll over bedclothes.</li>
<li>Prepare needed equipment and supplies.</li>
<li>Wash hands.</li>
<li>Assemble and arrange equipment on bedside chair or table. Remove unnecessary equipment.</li>
<li>Draw room curtain around bed or close door.</li>
<li>Lower side rail on near side of bed. Remove call light.</li>
<li>Adjust bed height to comfortable working position.</li>
<li>Loosen top sheet at foot of bed.</li>
<li>Remove bedspread and blanket separately by folding them into squares and placing them in dirty linen bag (if not to be reused). Do not allow bedclothes to contact uniform. Do not fan or shake bedclothes.</li>
<li>If blanket and bedspread are to be reused, fold by bringing top and bottom edges together. Fold into neat squares and place over back of chair.</li>
<li>Cover patient with bath blanket in following manner. Unfold bath blanket over top sheet. Ask patient to hold top edge of bath blanket. If patient is unable to help, tuck top of bath blanket under shoulder. Grasp top sheet under bath blanket at patient's shoulders, and bring down to foot of bed. Remove, and discard it into linen bag. Optional: Patient may be covered with loosened top sheet if bath blanket is not available.</li>
<li>With help from another nurse, slide mattress towards head of bed.</li>
<li>Position patient on their side on far side of bed, facing away. Adjust pillow under head. Be sure furthest side rail is up.</li>
<li>Loosen bottom sheet, moving from head to foot of bed.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="rationale">RATIONALE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rationale" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Determines need for protective waterproof pads or extra bath blankets on bed.</p>
<p>Ensures safety and use of proper body mechanics for nurse and patient.</p>
<p>Minimises anxiety and promotes cooperation.</p>
<p>Minimises spread of infection.</p>
<p>Provides for smooth procedure and ensures comfort.</p>
<p>Maintains privacy, thus promoting emotional and physical comfort.</p>
<p>Provides easy access to bed and bedclothes.</p>
<p>Minimises strain on nurse's back. It is easier to remove and apply bedclothes evenly to bed in flat position.</p>
<p>Makes bedclothes easier to remove.</p>
<p>Reduces transmission of microorganisms.</p>
<p>Facilitates replacement and prevents wrinkling.</p>
<p>Bath blanket provides warmth and keeps body parts covered during bedclothes removal.</p>
<p>If mattress slides towards foot of bed when head of bed is raised, it is difficult to tuck bedclothes in and is uncomfortable for patient.</p>
<p>Provides space for placement of clean linen. Side rail ensures safety.</p>
<p>FUNDAMENTALS OF NURSING: CLINICAL SKILLS WORKBOOK</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>17. Fanfold first drawsheet and then bottom sheet towards patient (see illustration). Tuck edges of linen just under buttocks, back and shoulders. Do not fanfold mattress pad if it is to be reused.</td><td>Provides maximum work space for placing clean linen. Later, when patient turns to other side, soiled linen can easily be removed.</td></tr><tr><td>18. Wipe off moisture on mattress with towel and appropriate disinfectant.</td><td>Reduces transmission of microorganisms.</td></tr><tr><td>19. Apply clean linen to exposed half of bed:</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>a. Place clean mattress pad on bed by folding it lengthwise with centre crease in middle of bed. Fanfold top layer over mattress. (If pad is reused, simply smooth out wrinkles.)</td><td>Applying linen over bed in successive layers minimises energy and time nurse uses in bedmaking.</td></tr><tr><td>b. Unfold bottom sheet lengthwise so centre crease is situated lengthwise along centre of bed. Fanfold sheet's top layer towards centre of bed alongside patient (see illustration). Smooth bottom layer of sheet over mattress, and bring edge over near side. Allow sheet's edge to hang about 25 cm over mattress edge. Lower hem of bottom sheet should lie seam down and even with bottom edge of mattress.</td><td>Proper positioning of linen on one side ensures that adequate linen will be available to cover opposite side of bed. Keeping seam edges down eliminates irritation to patient's skin.</td></tr><tr><td>20. Mitre bottom sheet at head of bed:</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>a. Face head of bed diagonally. Place hand away from head of bed under top corner of mattress, near mattress edge, and lift.</td><td>Mitred corner cannot be loosened easily, even if patient moves about frequently in bed.</td></tr><tr><td>b. With other hand, tuck top edge of bottom sheet smoothly under mattress so side edges of sheet above and below mattress would meet if brought together.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>c. Face side of bed, and pick up top edge of sheet at approximately 45 cm down from top of mattress (see illustration).</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>d. Lift sheet, and lay it on top of mattress to form neat triangular fold, with lower base of triangle even with mattress side edge (see illustration).</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>e. Tuck lower edge of sheet, which is hanging free below mattress, under mattress (see illustration). Tuck with palms down without pulling triangular fold.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>f. Hold part of sheet covering side edge of mattress in place with one hand. With other hand, pick up top of triangular linen fold, and bring it down over side of mattress. Tuck this portion of sheet under mattress (see illustrations).</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>21. Tuck remaining part of sheet under mattress, moving towards foot of bed. Keep sheet smooth.</td><td>Folds of sheet are a source of irritation.</td></tr><tr><td>22. Optional: Open drawsheet so it unfolds in half. Lay centre fold along middle of bed lengthwise, and position sheet so it will be under buttocks and torso (see illustration). Fanfold top layer towards patient with edge alongside back. Smooth bottom layer out over mattress and tuck excess edge under mattress (keep palms down).</td><td>Drawsheet is used to lift and reposition patient. Placement distributes most of bodyweight over sheet.</td></tr><tr><td>23. Place waterproof pad over drawsheet with centre fold against patient's side. Fanfold far half towards patient.</td><td>Used to protect bedclothes from soiling.</td></tr><tr><td>24. Raise side rail on working side, and go to other side.</td><td>Maintains safety.</td></tr><tr><td>25. Lower side rail. Help patient to roll slowly onto other side, over folds of linen (see illustration).</td><td>Exposes opposite side of bed for removal of soiled linen and placement of clean linen.</td></tr><tr><td>26. Loosen edge of soiled linen from underneath mattress.</td><td>Makes linen easier to remove.</td></tr><tr><td>27. Without allowing dirty linen to touch uniform, remove soiled linen by folding it into a bundle or square, with soiled side turned in. Discard it into linen bag.</td><td>Reduces transmission of microorganisms.</td></tr><tr><td>28. Spread clean, fanfolded linen smoothly over edge of mattress from head to foot of bed (see illustration).</td><td>Smooth linen will not irritate patient's skin.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>HYGIENE 201</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>29. Help patient roll back into supine position. Reposition pillow.</td><td>Patient's comfort is maintained.</td></tr><tr><td>30. Mitre corner of bottom sheet at foot of bed (see Step 20). When tucking corner, be sure sheet is smooth and free of wrinkles.</td><td>Wrinkles and folds can cause mechanical irritation to skin.</td></tr><tr><td>31. Facing side of bed, grasp remaining edge of bottom sheet, keep back straight, and pull as excess linen is tucked under mattress. Proceed from head to foot of bed. (Avoid lifting mattress during tucking to ensure fit.) Mitre remaining corners, keeping bottom sheet smooth.</td><td>Proper use of body mechanics while tucking linen prevents injury to nurse.</td></tr><tr><td>32. Smooth fanfolded drawsheet over bottom sheet. Grasp edge of sheet with palms down, lean back and tuck sheet under mattress. Tuck from middle to top and to bottom.</td><td>Tucking first at top or bottom may pull sheet sideways, causing poor fit.</td></tr><tr><td>33. Place top sheet over patient with centre fold lengthwise down middle of bed. Open sheet from head to foot, and unfold it over patient (see illustration).</td><td>Sheet should be equally distributed over bed by correctly positioning centre fold.</td></tr><tr><td>34. Without allowing dirty linen to touch uniform, ask patient to hold clean top sheet, or tuck sheet around shoulders. Remove bath blanket, and discard it into linen bag.</td><td>Sheet prevents exposure of body parts. Having patient hold sheet encourages participation in care.</td></tr><tr><td>35. Place blanket on bed, unfolding it so that crease runs lengthwise along middle of bed. Unfold blanket to cover patient. Top edge should be parallel with edge of top sheet and 15â€“20 cm down from top sheet's edge.</td><td>Blanket should be placed to cover patient completely and provide adequate warmth.</td></tr><tr><td>36. Place bedspread over bed according to Step 35. Be sure top edge extends about 2.5 cm above blanket's edge. Tuck top edge over and under top edge of blanket.</td><td>Bedspread gives bed neat appearance and provides extra warmth.</td></tr><tr><td>37. Make cuff by turning edge of top sheet down over top edge of blanket and bedspread.</td><td>Smooth cuff protects patient's face from rubbing against blanket or bedspread.</td></tr><tr><td>38. Standing on one side at foot of bed, lift mattress corner slightly with one hand, and tuck top bedclothes under mattress. Top sheet and blanket are tucked under together. Be sure they are loose enough to allow for movement of patient's feet. Horizontal toe pleat may be made (see illustration).</td><td>Tucking all top bedclothes together gives neat appearance. Pressure sores can develop on patient's toes and heels from feet rubbing between tight-fitting bed sheets.</td></tr><tr><td>39. Make modified mitred corner with top sheet, blanket and bedspread:</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>a. Pick up side edge of top sheet, blanket and bedspread approximately 45 cm up from foot of mattress. Lift to form triangular fold, and lay it on bed.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>b. Tuck lower edge of sheet, which is hanging free below mattress, under mattress. Do not pull triangular fold.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>c. Pick up triangular fold, and bring it down over mattress while holding bedclothes in place along side of mattress. Do not tuck tip of triangle.</td><td>Modified mitred corner secures top bedclothes but keeps an even edge of blanket and top sheet draped over mattress.</td></tr><tr><td>40. Raise side rail. Make other side of bed; spread top sheet, blanket and bedspread out evenly; fold top edge of bedspread over blanket, and make cuff with top sheet (see Step 37); make modified mitred corner at foot of bed (see Step 39).</td><td>Side rail protects patient from accidental falls.</td></tr><tr><td>41. Change pillowcase:</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>a. Have patient raise head. While supporting neck with one hand, remove pillow.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>b. Remove soiled case and discard into linen bag.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>c. Grasp clean pillowcase at centre of closed end. Gather case, turning it inside out over hand holding it. With same hand, pick up middle of one end of pillow. Pull pillowcase down over pillow with other hand and be sure pillow corners fit evenly in corners of pillowcase.</td><td>Prevents injury during flexion and extension of neck.</td></tr><tr><td>42. Support patient's head under neck, and place pillow under head.</td><td>Method makes it easy to slide pillowcase over pillow. Poorly fitting case constricts fluffing and expansion of pillow.</td></tr><tr><td>43. Place call light within patient's reach; return bed to comfortable position.</td><td>Prevents hyperextension of neck muscles.</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>Ensures safety and comfort.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>FUNDAMENTALS OF NURSING: CLINICAL SKILLS WORKBOOK</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="making-an-occupied-bed">MAKING AN OCCUPIED BED<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#making-an-occupied-bed" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="nutrition">Nutrition<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#nutrition" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="overview">Overview<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#overview" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The body requires fuel to provide energy for cellular metabolism and repair, organ function, growth and body movement. Florence Nightingale understood the importance of nutrition, stressing the nurse's role in the science and art of feeding during the mid-1800s (Dossey, 1999). Since then, the nurse's role in nutrition and diet therapy has changed. In the early 19th century, the description of a calorie as a unit of energy obtained from food moved nutrition into the realm of science (Stacey, 1994). Malnutrition is now recognised as a disease that needs specific treatment (Inman-Felton &amp; Smith, 1997). In some illnesses, such as type 2 diabetes mellitus or mild hypertension, diet therapy may be the major treatment for disease control. Other conditions, such as inflammatory bowel disease, may require specialised nutrition support such as enteral nutrition (EN) or parenteral nutrition. Standards now exist that clearly designate the standard of care for the promotion of optimal nutrition in all healthcare patients.</p>
<p>Nurses are in an excellent position to recognise signs of poor nutrition and to take steps to initiate change. Close contact with patients and their families enables nurses to make observations about patients' physical status, food intake, weight changes and response to therapy. When making clinical decisions relating to nutrition, nurses must integrate knowledge from nursing and other disciplines, previous experience and information gathered from patients and families regarding customary food preferences, as well as recent dietary history. The use of professional standards, such as recommended dietary intakes, the Australian Guide to Healthy Eating and other dietary guidelines, and the number of recommended daily servings provide help in maintaining good health.</p>
<p>Enteral nutrition refers to nutrients given via the gastrointestinal (GI) tract. EN is the preferred method of meeting nutritional needs if the patient's GI tract is functioning, because it provides physiological, safe and economical nutrition support.</p>
<p>The psychomotor skills covered in this chapter are concerned with assisting a patient who is unable to consume nutrients from the traditional oral route. The skills addressed include inserting a small-bore nasoenteric tube for enteral feedings (skill 36-1), administering enteral feedings via nasoenteric tubes (skill 36-2) and administering enteral feedings via gastrostomy and jejunostomy tubes (skill 36-3).</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260125-fc52c15d.jpeg" alt="img-7.jpeg"></p>
<p>FUNDAMENTALS OF NURSING: CLINICAL SKILLS WORKBOOK</p>
<p>SKILL 36-1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="inserting-a-small-bore-nasoenteric-tube-for-enteral-feedings">Inserting a small-bore nasoenteric tube for enteral feedings<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#inserting-a-small-bore-nasoenteric-tube-for-enteral-feedings" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="delegation-considerations">DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delegation-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This task requires the problem-solving and knowledge-application skills of professional nurses. For this reason, delegation of this task to nurse assistants is inappropriate.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Nasogastric or nasointestinal tube (8â€“12 Fr) with guide wire or stylet</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>60 mL or larger Luer-lock or catheter-tip syringe</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Hypoallergenic tape and tincture of benzoin</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>pH indicator strip</p>
</li>

<p>Glass of water and straw</p>
</li>

<p>Emesis basin</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="steps">STEPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Assess patient for the need for enteral tube feeding: NBM or insufficient intake for more than 5 days, functional GI tract, unable to ingest sufficient nutrients.</li>
<li>Assess patient for appropriate route of administration:
a. Close each nostril alternately, and ask patient to breathe.
b. Assess for gag reflex.
c. Inspect nares for any irritation or obstruction.
d. Review patient's medical history for nasal problems and risk of aspiration.</li>
<li>Review doctor's order for type of tube and enteral feeding schedule.</li>
<li>Wash hands.</li>
<li>Explain procedure to patient.</li>
<li>Stand on same side of bed as naris for insertion, and help patient into high-Fowler's position unless contraindicated. Place pillow behind head and shoulders.</li>
<li>Place bath towel over chest. Keep tissues within reach.</li>
<li>Determine length of tube to be inserted and mark with tape: measure distance from tip of nose to earlobe to xiphoid process of sternum (see illustration).</li>
<li>Prepare nasogastric or nasointestinal tube for intubation:
a. Plastic tubes should not be iced.
b. Inject 10 mL of water from 30 mL or larger Luer-lock or catheter-tip syringe into the tube.
c. Make certain that guide wire is securely positioned against weighted tip and that both Luer-lock connections are snugly fitted together.</li>
<li>Cut tape 10 cm long.</li>
<li>Put on clean gloves.</li>
<li>Dip tube with surface lubricant into glass of water.</li>
<li>Insert tube through nostril to back of throat (posterior nasopharynx). Aim back and down towards ear.</li>
<li>Flex patient's head towards chest after tube has passed through nasopharynx.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="rationale">RATIONALE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rationale" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Identifying patients who need tube feedings before they become nutritionally depleted may help to prevent complications related to malnutrition.</p>
<p>Evaluates nares for patency.</p>
<p>Nares may be obstructed. Assessment determines which naris to use.</p>
<p>Identifies ability to swallow and risk of aspiration.</p>
<p>Nurse may seek doctor's order to change route of nutritional support or to place tube past the stomach into the intestine with increased risk of aspiration.</p>
<p>Procedure and tube feedings require a doctor's order.</p>
<p>Reduces transfer of microorganisms.</p>
<p>Reduces anxiety and helps patient to assist in insertion.</p>
<p>Allows easier manipulation of tube. Fowler's position reduces risk of aspiration and promotes effective swallowing.</p>
<p>Prevents soiling of gown. Insertion of tube may produce tears.</p>
<p>Length approximates distance from nose to stomach in 98% of patients. For duodenal or jejunal placement, an additional 20â€“30 cm is required.</p>
<p>Tubes will become stiff and inflexible, causing trauma to mucous membranes.</p>
<p>Aids in guide wire or stylet insertion.</p>
<p>Promotes smooth passage of tube into GI tract. Improperly positioned stylet can induce serious trauma.</p>
<p>Reduces transmission of microorganisms.</p>
<p>Activates lubricant to facilitate passage of tube into naris to GI tract.</p>
<p>Natural contours facilitate passage of tube into GI tract; reduces gagging by patient.</p>
<p>Closes off glottis and reduces risk of tube entering trachea.</p>
<p>NUTRITION 207</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Critical decision point: Encourage patient to swallow by giving small sips of water or ice chips when possible. Advance tube as patient swallows. Rotate tube 180 degrees while inserting.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>15. Emphasise need to mouth-breathe and swallow during the procedure.</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<ol start="16">
<li>Advance tube each time patient swallows until desired length has been passed. Do not force tube. If resistance is met or patient starts to cough, choke or become cyanotic, stop advancing the tube and pull tube back.</li>
<li>Check for position of tube in back of throat with penlight and tongue blade.</li>
<li>Perform measures to verify placement of tube:
a. Inject 30 mL of air into the tube, and aspirate GI contents with a syringe.
b. Measure pH of aspirated GI contents (see illustration).
c. X-ray verification of placement may be necessary. | Helps facilitate passage of tube and alleviates patientâ€™s fears during the procedure.
Reduces discomfort and trauma to patient.
Tube may be coiled, kinked or entering trachea.
Gastric contents are usually cloudy and grassy green or tan to off-white; in contrast, intestinal fluid is usually deep golden yellow and is more clear than gastric fluid (see Figure 36-11). Fasting gastric pH is usually in a range of 1â€“4; only infrequently is it greater than 6. In contrast, intestinal sites usually have a pH of 7 or greater.  |
|  Critical decision point: Auscultation is no longer considered a reliable method for verification of tube placement because a tube inadvertently placed in the lungs, pharynx or oesophagus can transmit a sound similar to that of air entering the stomach (Tho and others, 2011).  |   |
|  19. Apply tincture of benzoin or other skin adhesive to tip of patientâ€™s nose and tube. Allow to dry.</li>
<li>Remove gloves, and secure tube with tape, avoiding pressure on naris.
a. Split one end of tape lengthwise 5 cm. Place the intact end of tape over bridge of patientâ€™s nose. Wrap each of the 5 cm strips around tube as it exits nose (see illustration).
b. Fasten end of nasogastric tube to patientâ€™s gown by looping rubber band around tube in slip knot. Pin rubber band to gown (see illustration).</li>
<li>For intestinal placement, position patient on right side when possible until radiological confirmation of correct placement has been verified. Otherwise, help patient into a comfortable position. | Helps tape adhere better. Protects skin.
A properly secured tube allows the patient more mobility and prevents trauma to nasal mucosa.
Securing tape to nares prevents tissue necrosis.
Reduces traction on the naris if tube moves.
Promotes passage of the tube into the small intestine (duodenum or jejunum).  |
|  Critical decision point: Leave guide wire or stylet in place until correct position is ensured by X-ray. Never attempt to reinsert partially or fully removed guide wire or stylet while feeding tube is in place.  |   |
|  22. Obtain X-ray of abdomen.</li>
<li>Put on gloves, and administer oral hygiene (see Chapter 34). Clean tubing at nostril.</li>
<li>Remove gloves, dispose of equipment and wash hands.</li>
<li>Inspect naris and oropharynx for any irritation after insertion.</li>
<li>Ask whether patient feels comfortable.</li>
<li>Observe patient for any difficulty breathing or gagging. | Placement of tube is verified by X-ray examination.
Promotes patient comfort and integrity of oral mucous membranes.
Reduces transmission of microorganisms.
If insertion was difficult, irritation of naris or oropharynx may have occurred.
Evaluates patientâ€™s level of comfort.
Malposition of the tube may cause these symptoms.  |
|  RECORDING AND REPORTING | HOME CARE CONSIDERATIONS  |
|  â€¢ Record and report type and size of tube placed, location of distal tip of tube, patientâ€™s tolerance of procedure, pH value and confirmation of tube position by X-ray. | â€¢ Placement may be verified on the basis of pH recordings. A small amount of water may be instilled via the feeding tube while the patient is carefully observed for coughing or gagging.
â€¢ The patient and care provider should be instructed to report pH values that fall outside an established range and to report any difficulties that occur during the feeding.  |</li>
</ol>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="administering-enteral-feedings-via-nasoenteric-tubes">Administering enteral feedings via nasoenteric tubes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#administering-enteral-feedings-via-nasoenteric-tubes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="delegation-considerations">DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delegation-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This task requires the problem-solving and knowledge-application skills of professional nurses. For this reason, delegation of this task to nurse assistants is inappropriate.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Disposable feeding bag and tubing or ready-to-hang system</li>
<li>30 mL or larger Luer-lock or catheter-tip syringe</li>
<li>Stethoscope</li>
<li>pH indicator strip</li>
<li>Infusion pump (required for intestinal feedings): use pump designed for tube feedings</li>
<li>Prescribed enteral feedings</li>
<li>Gloves</li>
<li>Equipment to obtain blood glucose by finger-stick</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="steps">STEPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Assess patient's need for enteral tube feedings: impaired swallowing, decreased level of consciousness, head or neck surgery, facial trauma, surgeries of upper alimentary canal.</li>
<li>Auscultate for bowel sounds before feeding.</li>
<li>Obtain baseline weight and laboratory values. Assess patient for fluid volume excess or deficit, electrolyte abnormalities and metabolic abnormalities such as hyperglycaemia.</li>
<li>Verify doctor's order for formula, rate, route and frequency. Laboratory data and bedside assessments, such as finger-stick blood glucose measurement, are also ordered by the doctor.</li>
<li>Explain procedure to patient.</li>
<li>Wash hands.</li>
<li>Prepare feeding container to administer formula:
a. Have tube feeding at room temperature.
b. Connect tubing to container as needed or prepare ready-to-hang container.
c. Shake formula container well, and fill container and tubing with formula (see illustration).</li>
<li>Place patient in high-Fowler's position, or elevate head of bed 30 degrees.</li>
<li>Determine tube placement:
a. Aspirate gastric contents to check for gastric residual (see illustration). Return aspirated contents to stomach unless the volume exceeds 150 mL.
b. Measure pH of aspirated GI contents.
c. Observe the aspirate's appearance.
d. Consider the results from pH testing and the aspirate's appearance together.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="rationale">RATIONALE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rationale" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Identify patients who need tube feedings before they become nutritionally depleted.</p>
<p>Absent bowel sounds may indicate decreased ability of GI tract to digest or absorb nutrients.</p>
<p>Enteral feedings are to restore or maintain a patient's nutritional status. Provides objective data to measure effectiveness of feedings.</p>
<p>Tube feedings, laboratory tests and bedside tests must be ordered by doctor.</p>
<p>Well-informed patient is more cooperative and at ease.</p>
<p>Reduces transmission of microorganisms.</p>
<p>Cold formula may cause gastric cramping and discomfort because the liquid is not warmed by mouth and oesophagus.</p>
<p>Tubing must be free of contamination to prevent bacterial growth.</p>
<p>Filling the tubing with formula prevents excess air from entering GI tract.</p>
<p>Elevated head helps prevent aspiration.</p>
<p>Presence of gastric secretions indicates that the distal end of the tube is in the stomach. Residual volume indicates whether gastric emptying is delayed. Delayed gastric emptying may be reflected by 150 mL or more remaining in the patient's stomach.</p>
<p>Fasting gastric pH is usually equal to or less than 4; it is only infrequently greater than 6; in contrast, intestinal aspirates usually have a pH equal to or greater than 7.</p>
<p>Gastric fluid is usually cloudy and grassy green or tan to off-white in colour; in contrast, intestinal fluid is usually deep golden yellow and is more clear than gastric contents (see Figure 36-11).</p>
<p>An aspirate with a low pH and a typical gastric fluid colour indicates a high probability of gastric placement; in contrast, a golden-coloured aspirate with a high pH indicates a high probability of intestinal placement.</p>
<p>NUTRITION 211</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Critical decision point: Auscultation is no longer considered a reliable method for verification of placement of tube because air in tube inadvertently placed in lungs, pharynx or oesophagus can transmit sound similar to that of air entering stomach.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>10. Initiate feeding:</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>A. Bolus or intermittent feeding
(1) Pinch proximal end of the feeding tube.
(2) Remove plunger from syringe and attach barrel of syringe to end of tube.
(3) Fill syringe with measured amount of formula. Release tube and hold syringe high enough to allow it to empty gradually by gravity, refill, repeat until prescribed amount has been delivered to the patient.
(4) If feeding bag is used, hang feeding bag on an IV pole. Fill bag with prescribed amount of formula, and allow bag to empty gradually over at least 30 minutes.</p>
<p>B. Continuous-drip method
(1) Hang feeding bag and tubing on IV pole.
(2) Connect distal end of tubing to the proximal end of the feeding tube.
(3) Connect tubing through infusion pump (see illustration) and set rate.</p>
<ol start="11">
<li>Advance tube feeding gradually.</li>
<li>When feeding is complete, flush the tubing with 30 mL water. Chart the amount of water on the fluid balance chart.</li>
<li>When tube feedings are not being administered, cap or clamp the proximal end of the feeding tube.</li>
<li>Administer water via feeding tube as ordered with diluted formula.</li>
<li>Rinse bag and tubing with warm water whenever feedings are interrupted.</li>
<li>Measure amount of aspirate (residual) every 4 hours.</li>
<li>Monitor finger-stick blood glucose every 6 hours until maximum administration rate is reached and maintained for 24 hours. Monitor blood sugar level (BSL). Obtain medical direction for reportable BSL.</li>
<li>Monitor intake and output every 24 hours.</li>
<li>Weigh patient daily until maximum administration rate is reached and maintained for 24 hours; then weigh patient 3 times per week.</li>
<li>Observe return of normal laboratory values. | Prevents air from entering patientâ€™s stomach.</li>
</ol>
<p>Gradual emptying of tube feeding by gravity from syringe or feeding bag reduces risk of abdominal discomfort, vomiting or diarrhoea induced by bolus or too-rapid infusion of tube feedings.</p>
<p>Continuous feeding method is designed to deliver prescribed hourly rate of feeding. This method reduces risk of abdominal discomfort. Patients who receive continuous drip feedings should have residuals checked every 4 h and tube placement verified.</p>
<p>Tube feedings should be advanced gradually to prevent diarrhoea and gastric intolerance to formula.
Reduces the risk of sediment forming and blocking the tubing.</p>
<p>Prevents air from entering stomach between feedings.</p>
<p>Provides patient with source of water to help maintain fluid and electrolyte balance.
Rinsing bag and tubing with warm water clears old tube feedings and reduces bacterial growth.
Evaluates tolerance of tube feeding.
Alerts nurse to patientâ€™s tolerance of glucose.</p>
<p>Intake and output are indications of fluid balance or fluid volume excess or deficit.
Weight gain is indicator of improved nutritional status; however, sudden gain of more than 900 g in 24 hours usually indicates fluid retention.
Improving laboratory values (e.g. albumin, transferrin and prealbumin) indicate an improved nutritional status.  |
|  RECORDING AND REPORTING | HOME CARE CONSIDERATIONS  |
|  â€¢ Record amount and type of feeding, patientâ€™s response to tube feeding, patency of tube and any side effects. Report patientâ€™s tolerance and adverse effects. | â€¢ Ask patient or care provider about any symptoms or discomfort during enteral feedings. Reinforce instruction to contact nurse if symptoms or discomfort occur.  |</p>
<p>212 FUNDAMENTALS OF NURSING: CLINICAL SKILLS WORKBOOK</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="administering-enteral-feedings-via-nasoenteric-tubes">ADMINISTERING ENTERAL FEEDINGS VIA NASOENTERIC TUBES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#administering-enteral-feedings-via-nasoenteric-tubes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>CLINICAL SKILL 36-2: Administering enteral feedings via nasoenteric tubes</p>
<p>DEMONSTRATES: The ability to effectively administer an enteral feed via the nasoenteric route</p>
<p>DOMAIN/S (AUS): Provision and Coordination of Care</p>
<p>DOMAIN/S (NZ): Professional responsibility; management of nursing care; interpersonal relationships; interprofessional healthcare and quality improvement</p>
<p>PERFORMANCE CRITERIA: (numbers indicate National Competency Standards for the Registered Nurse)</p>
<p>AUS 5.1, 5.2, 5.3, 6.2, 6.3, 6.4, 7.1, 7.2, 7.8, 8.1, 8.2</p>
<p>NZ 1.1, 1.2, 1.3, 1.5, 2.1, 2.2, 2.3, 2.4, 3.1, 3.2, 3.3, 4.1, 4.2</p>
