<p>SKILL 36-3</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="administering-enteral-feedings-via-gastrostomy-or-jejunostomy-tube">Administering enteral feedings via gastrostomy or jejunostomy tube<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#administering-enteral-feedings-via-gastrostomy-or-jejunostomy-tube" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="delegation-considerations">DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delegation-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This task requires the problem-solving and knowledge-application skills of professional nurses. For this reason, delegation to nurse assistants is inappropriate.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Disposable feeding container or ready-to-hang bag</li>
<li>30 mL or larger Luer-lock or catheter-tip syringe</li>
<li>Formula</li>
<li>Infusion pump: use pump designed for tube feedings</li>
<li>pH indicator strips</li>
<li>Stethoscope</li>
<li>Gloves</li>
<li>Equipment to obtain blood glucose by finger-stick</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="steps">STEPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Assess patient's need for enteral tube feedings (see Skill 36-2): impaired swallowing, decreased level of consciousness, surgeries of upper alimentary tract, need for long-term enteral nutrition.</li>
<li>Auscultate for bowel sounds before feeding. Consult doctor if bowel sounds are absent.</li>
<li>Obtain baseline weight and laboratory values.</li>
<li>Verify doctor's order for formula, rate, route and frequency.</li>
<li>Explain procedure to patient.</li>
<li>Prepare feeding container to administer formula:
a. Have tube feeding at room temperature.
b. Connect tubing to container as needed, or prepare ready-to-hang bag.
c. Fill container and tubing with formula.</li>
<li>Elevate head of bed 30â€“45 degrees.</li>
<li>Verify tube placement:
A. Gastrostomy tube: Aspirate gastric secretions; observe their appearance and check pH; return aspirated contents to stomach unless the volume exceeds 150 mL.
B. Jejunostomy tube: Aspirate intestinal secretions, observe their appearance and check pH.</li>
<li>Flush with 30 mL of water.</li>
<li>Initiate feedings:
A. Syringe feedings
(1) Pinch proximal end of gastrostomy tube.
(2) Remove plunger and attach barrel of syringe to end of tube, then fill syringe with formula.
(3) Allow syringe to empty gradually. Refill until prescribed amount has been delivered to patient.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="rationale">RATIONALE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rationale" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Identifies patients who need tube feedings before they become nutritionally depleted. Enteral feeding preserves the function and mass of the gut, promotes wound healing, diminishes hypermetabolism in burn injuries and may decrease infection in critically ill patients.</p>
<p>Absence of bowel sounds may indicate decreased or absent peristalsis and increased risk of aspiration or abdominal distension.</p>
<p>Enteral feedings are to restore or maintain nutritional status. Provides objective data to measure effectiveness of feedings.</p>
<p>Tube feedings must be ordered by doctors.</p>
<p>Well-informed patient is more cooperative and feels more at ease.</p>
<p>Cold formula may cause gastric cramping and discomfort because the liquid is not warmed by mouth and oesophagus.</p>
<p>Tubing must be free of contamination to prevent bacterial growth.</p>
<p>Placement of formula through tubing prevents excess air from entering gastrointestinal tract.</p>
<p>Elevating patient's head helps prevent chance of aspiration.</p>
<p>Gastric fluid is usually cloudy and grassy green or tan to off-white in colour; in contrast, intestinal fluid is usually deep golden yellow and more clear than gastric fluid (see Figure 36-11).</p>
<p>Presence of intestinal fluid indicates that the end of the tube is in the small intestine (i.e. duodenum or jejunum). Generally the intestinal residual is very small (10 mL or less). If fluid tests acidic on pH test, looks like gastric fluid or the residual volume is large (more than 10 mL), displacement of the tube into the stomach may have occurred.</p>
<p>Usually gastrostomy and jejunostomy feedings are given continuously to ensure proper absorption. However, initial feedings may be given by bolus to assess patient's tolerance to formula. See Skill 36-2 for guidelines to advance enteral feedings.</p>
<p>NUTRITION 215</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>B. Continuous drip method</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(1) Fill feeding container with enough formula for 4 hours of feeding. In summer, unless air-conditioning is available, this is reduced to 2-hourly to reduce the risk of contamination.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(2) Hang container on IV pole, and clear tubing of air.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(3) Thread tubing on pump according to manufacturer's directions.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(4) Connect tubing to end of feeding tube.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(5) Begin infusion at prescribed rate.</td><td>This reduces the risk of sediment forming and blocking the tube.</td></tr><tr><td>11. Following completion of feeding, flush the tube with 30 mL water. Chart additional water on fluid balance chart.</td><td>Report any drainage, redness, swelling or displacement of the tube to the doctor.</td></tr><tr><td>12. Assess skin around tube exit site. The skin around the tube should be cleaned daily with warm water and mild soap. Dressings around the exit site are not recommended.</td><td>Prevents transmission of microorganisms.</td></tr><tr><td>Evaluates tolerance of tube feeding.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>13. Dispose of supplies, and wash hands.</td><td>Alerts nurse to patient's tolerance of glucose.</td></tr><tr><td>14. Measure the amount of aspirate (residual) every 4 hours.</td><td>Intake and output are indications of fluid balance or fluid volume excess.</td></tr><tr><td>15. Monitor finger-stick blood glucose every 6 hours until maximum administration rate is reached and maintained for 24 hours.</td><td>Weight gain is indicator of improved nutritional status; however, a sudden gain of more than 900 g in 24 hours usually indicates fluid retention.</td></tr><tr><td>16. Monitor intake and output every 24 hours.</td><td>Improving laboratory values (albumin, transferrin, prealbumin) indicate an improved nutritional status.</td></tr><tr><td>17. Weigh patient daily until maximum administration rate is reached and maintained for 24 hours; then weigh patient 3 times per week.</td><td>Enteral tubes can cause uncomfortable pressure areas on patient's nares.</td></tr><tr><td>18. Observe return of normal laboratory values.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>19. Inspect site for signs of pressure.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>RECORDING AND REPORTING</td><td>HOME CARE CONSIDERATIONS</td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Record amount and type of feeding and patient's response to tube feeding, patency of tube and any side effects.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Report to oncoming nursing staff: type of feeding, status of feeding tube, patient's tolerance, adverse effects.</td><td>â€¢ Ask patient or care provider about any symptoms or discomfort during enteral feeding. Reinforce instruction to contact nurse if symptoms or discomfort occur.</td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Instruct patient or care provider in how to care for gastrostomy or jejunostomy tube site and symptoms to report.</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="administering-enteral-feedings-via-gastrostomy-or-jejunostomy-tube">ADMINISTERING ENTERAL FEEDINGS VIA GASTROSTOMY OR JEJUNOSTOMY TUBE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#administering-enteral-feedings-via-gastrostomy-or-jejunostomy-tube" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>CLINICAL SKILL 36-3: Administering enteral feedings via gastrostomy or jejunostomy tubes</p>
<p>DEMONSTRATES: The ability to effectively administer an enteral feed via the gastrostomy or jejunostomy route</p>
<p>DOMAIN/S (AUS): Provision and Coordination of Care</p>
<p>DOMAIN/S (NZ): Professional responsibility; management of nursing care; interpersonal relationships; interprofessional healthcare and quality improvement</p>
<p>PERFORMANCE CRITERIA: (numbers indicate National Competency Standards for the Registered Nurse)</p>
<p>AUS 5.1, 5.2, 5.3, 6.2, 6.3, 6.4, 7.1, 7.2, 7.8, 8.1, 8.2</p>
<p>NZ 1.1, 1.2, 1.3, 1.5, 2.1, 2.2, 2.3, 2.4, 3.1, 3.2, 3.3, 4.1, 4.2</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="bowel-elimination">Bowel elimination<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bowel-elimination" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="overview">Overview<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#overview" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Regular elimination of bowel waste products is essential for normal body functioning. Alterations in elimination are often early signs or symptoms of problems within the gastrointestinal (GI) or other body systems. Because bowel function depends on the balance of several factors, elimination patterns and habits vary among individuals. Nurses may care for patients who have, or are at risk of, elimination problems because of emotional stress (anxiety or depression), physiological changes in the GI tract, surgical alteration of intestinal structures, other prescribed therapy or disorders impairing defecation.</p>
<p>To manage patients' elimination problems, the nurse must understand normal elimination and factors that promote, impede or cause alterations in elimination. Many factors influence the process of bowel elimination, such as age, GI infection, diet, physical activity, medications and psychological factors. Knowledge of these factors enables the nurse to anticipate measures required to maintain a normal elimination pattern. Supportive nursing care respects the patient's privacy and emotional needs. Measures designed to promote normal elimination should also minimise discomfort.</p>
<p>The skills presented in this chapter relate to the nursing care associated with assisting a patient with bowel elimination. The skills addressed include administering a prepared enema (37-1), pouching an ostomy (37-2) and inserting and maintaining a nasogastric tube (for decompression) (37-3). Adequate preparation is essential in assisting with these skills in terms of both gathering equipment and explaining the procedure to the patient, given the personal nature of most of them. If the nurse has been successful in establishing a therapeutic relationship with a patient, the patient should feel comfortable discussing the intimate details often associated with bowel elimination and will not be embarrassed as the nurse helps with their elimination needs. The patient will have a feeling of comfort and freedom from pain as their elimination needs are met within the limits of their condition and treatment.</p>
<p>BOWEL ELIMINATION 219</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="skill-37-1">SKILL 37-1<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#skill-37-1" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="administering-a-prepared-enema">Administering a prepared enema<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#administering-a-prepared-enema" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="delegation-and-other-considerations">DELEGATION AND OTHER CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delegation-and-other-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>This task requires the problem-solving and knowledge-application skills of registered nurses. For this reason, delegation of this task to nurse assistants or personal care workers is inappropriate.</p>
<ul>
<li>Position patient, being particularly aware of those who have mobility restrictions.</li>
<li>Use gloves to prevent the transmission of pathogens.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Disposable gloves</li>
<li>Water-soluble lubricant</li>
<li>Waterproof, absorbent pad to cover bed sheets</li>
<li>Blanket or large towel to cover patient</li>
<li>Toilet paper</li>
<li>Bed pan, bedside commode or access to toilet</li>
<li>Washbasin, washcloths, towel and soap (if person cannot get to the bathroom)</li>
<li>Prepackaged enema</li>
<li>Prepackaged enema container with rectal tip</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="steps">STEPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Assess status of patient: last bowel movement, normal bowel patterns, presence of haemorrhoids, immobility, external anal sphincter control, abdominal pain.</li>
<li>Assess for presence of increased intracranial pressure, glaucoma or recent rectal or prostate surgery.</li>
<li>Determine patient's level of understanding of purpose of the need for an enema.</li>
<li>Liaise with medical staff about need for an enema. Obtain written order.</li>
<li>Collect appropriate equipment.</li>
<li>Correctly identify patient and explain procedure.</li>
<li>Provide privacy by closing curtains around bed or closing door.</li>
<li>Raise bed to appropriate working height for nurse. Raise side rail on opposite side and assist patient into left side-lying (Sims') position with right knee flexed. Children may also be placed in dorsal recumbent position.</li>
<li>Cleanse hands using an alcoholic hand lotion. Put on gloves.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="rationale">RATIONALE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rationale" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Determine factors indicating need for enema and influencing the type of enema used. An enema should only be used when less-invasive methods have been used and have not resulted in relief of constipation.</p>
<p>Conditions contraindicate use of enemas.</p>
<p>Allows nurse to plan for appropriate teaching measures.</p>
<p>Order by doctor is required. Determines number and type of enema to be given.</p>
<p>Information promotes patient cooperation and reduces anxiety.</p>
<p>Reduces embarrassment for patient.</p>
<p>Promotes good body mechanics and patient safety. Allows enema solution to flow downwards by gravity along natural curve of sigmoid colon and rectum, thus improving retention of solution.</p>
<p>Reduces transmission of microorganisms.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="critical-decision-point-if-patient-is-suspected-of-having-poor-sphincter-control-position-on-bed-pan-patient-will-have-difficulty-retaining-enema-solution">Critical decision point: If patient is suspected of having poor sphincter control, position on bed pan. Patient will have difficulty retaining enema solution.<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#critical-decision-point-if-patient-is-suspected-of-having-poor-sphincter-control-position-on-bed-pan-patient-will-have-difficulty-retaining-enema-solution" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol start="10">
<li>Place waterproof pad under hips and buttocks.</li>
<li>Cover patient with bath blanket, exposing only rectal area, so anus is clearly visible.</li>
<li>Place bed pan or commode in easily accessible position. If patient will be using the toilet, ensure that toilet is free. (If patient will be getting up to go to bathroom, place patient's slippers and dressing gown in easily accessible position.)</li>
<li>Administer enema:
(1) Remove plastic cap from rectal tip of prepackaged disposableâ€”you may also need to remove a seal on the container. Tip is already lubricated, but more jelly can be applied as needed.
(2) Gently separate buttocks and locate rectum. Instruct patient to relax by breathing out slowly through mouth.</li>
</ol>
<p>Prevents soiling of bedclothes.</p>
<p>Provides warmth, reduces exposure of body parts and allows patient to feel more relaxed and comfortable.</p>
<p>Used in case patient is unable to retain enema solution.</p>
<p>Lubrication provides for smooth insertion of rectal tube without causing rectal irritation or trauma.</p>
<p>Breathing out promotes relaxation of external rectal sphincter.</p>

withdraws rectal tube</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Helps patient to bathroom or positions patient on bedpan</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Assists with perineal care as required</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Inspects colour, consistency and amount of stool and fluid passed</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="pouching-an-ostomy">Pouching an ostomy<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pouching-an-ostomy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="delegation-considerations">DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delegation-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Pouching an ostomy, especially a newly established ostomy, requires the problem-solving and knowledge-application skills of a registered nurse (RN). Delegation is inappropriate. Pouching of an established ostomy can be delegated to enrolled nurses.</p>
<ul>
<li>Help caregiver in selecting appropriate pouch and skin barrier.</li>
<li>Inform caregiver of the signs of stomal and peristomal skin changes that should be reported to an RN.</li>
<li>Have caregiver monitor and report characteristics and volume of ostomy output.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="equipment-see-illustration">EQUIPMENT (SEE ILLUSTRATION)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment-see-illustration" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Pouch, clear drainable colostomy/ileostomy in correct size for two-piece system or custom cut-to-fit one-piece type with attached skin barrier</li>
<li>Pouch closure device, such as clamp</li>
<li>Adhesive remover (optional)</li>
<li>Clean disposable gloves</li>
<li>Deodorant</li>
<li>Gauze pads or washcloth</li>
<li>Towel or disposable waterproof barrier</li>
<li>Basin with warm tap water</li>
<li>Scissors</li>
<li>Skin barrier paste (pectin)</li>
<li>Sealant wipes</li>
</ul>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>1. Assemble equipment and close room curtains or door.</td><td>Optimises use of time; conserves patient's and nurse's energy. Provides privacy.</td></tr><tr><td>2. Auscultate for bowel sounds.</td><td>Documents presence of peristalsis.</td></tr><tr><td>3. Observe skin barrier and pouch for leakage and length of time in place. Depending on type of pouching system used, the nurse may have to remove the pouch to fully observe the stoma (such as with an opaque pouch). Clear pouches permit the viewing of the stoma without their removal.</td><td>May indicate need for different type of pouch or sealant.</td></tr><tr><td>4. Observe stoma for colour, swelling, trauma and healing; stoma should be moist and reddish-pink. Assess type of stoma. Stomas can be flush with the skin or be a bud-like protrusion on the abdomen (see illustration for a normal bud stoma).</td><td>Stoma characteristics should be one of the factors to consider when selecting an appropriate pouching system.</td></tr><tr><td>5. Measure the stoma with each pouching change. Follow pouch manufacturer's directions and measuring guide as to which pouch to use based on patient's stoma size.</td><td>Determines correct-size equipment, preventing trauma to stoma.</td></tr><tr><td>6. Observe abdominal incision (if present).</td><td>Relationship to stoma determines proper placement of pouch.</td></tr><tr><td>7. Observe effluent from stoma and keep a record of intake and output. Ask patient about skin tenderness.</td><td>Pouches should be emptied when one-third to half full, because the weight of contents may dislodge the skin seal, and ostomy drainage is irritating to the skin. Also, pouches collect flatus (gas), which needs to be expelled because it can disrupt the skin seal.</td></tr><tr><td>8. Avoid unnecessary changing of the entire pouching system. A one-piece pouch with attached skin barriers or the skin barrier of a two-piece pouching system should be changed every 3-7 days, not daily.</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="critical-decision-point-do-not-put-holes-in-ostomy-pouch-for-flatus-to-escape">Critical decision point: Do not put holes in ostomy pouch for flatus to escape.<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#critical-decision-point-do-not-put-holes-in-ostomy-pouch-for-flatus-to-escape" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>|  9. Assess abdomen for best type of pouching system to use. Consider:
a. Contour and peristomal plane
b. Presence of scars, incisions</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>c. Location and type of stoma</th><th>Determines pouching system selection and need for other equipment.</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>10. Assess the patient's self-care ability to determine the best type of pouching system to use.</td><td>Patients who have difficulty using their hands or who have limited vision may find a one-piece system or a precut pouch and skin barrier more desirable to use; others prefer being able to keep the skin barrier in place for several days, changing just the pouch, and therefore prefer the two-piece system.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>FUNDAMENTALS OF NURSING: CLINICAL SKILLS WORKBOOK</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>11. After skin barrier and pouch removal, assess skin around stoma, noting scars, folds, skin breakdown and peristomal suture line, if present.</td><td>Determines need for barrier paste to increase adherence of pouch to skin or to fill in irregularities.</td></tr><tr><td>12. Determine patient's emotional response and knowledge and understanding of an ostomy and its care.</td><td>Assists in determining extent to which patient is able to participate in care and need for teaching and information clarification.</td></tr><tr><td>13. Explain procedure to patient; encourage patient's interaction and questions.</td><td>Lessens anxiety and promotes patient's participation.</td></tr><tr><td>14. Position patient either standing or supine and drape. If seated, position either on or in front of the toilet.</td><td>When patient is supine, fewer wrinkles allow for ease of application of pouching system; maintains patient's dignity.</td></tr><tr><td>15. Use alcoholic hand wash solution and put on disposable gloves.</td><td>Reduces transmission of microorganisms.</td></tr><tr><td>16. Place towel or disposable waterproof barrier under the patient if supine.</td><td>Protects bedclothes.</td></tr><tr><td>17. Remove used pouch and skin barrier gently by pushing the skin away from the barrier. An adhesive remover may be used to facilitate removal of the skin barrier.</td><td>Reduces trauma; jerking irritates the skin and can cause tears, especially in older patients.</td></tr><tr><td>18. Clean peristomal skin gently with warm tap water using gauze pads or clean washcloth; do not scrub the skin; dry completely by patting the skin with gauze or towel.</td><td>Avoid use of soap because it leaves a residue on the skin that interferes with pouch adhesion to the skin. Skin must be dry; pouch does not adhere to wet skin. If blood appears on the gauze pad, do not be alarmed; the stoma, if rubbed, may ooze some blood from the cleaning process. Bleeding into the pouch is abnormal. The stoma's surface is a highly vascular mucous membrane.</td></tr><tr><td>19. Measure the stoma for correct size of pouching system needed, using the manufacturer's measuring guide (see illustration).</td><td>Ensures accuracy in determining correct pouch size needed. Stoma shrinks and does not reach final size for 6-8 weeks.</td></tr><tr><td>20. Select appropriate pouch for patient based on patient assessment. With a custom cut-to-fit pouch, use an ostomy guide to cut opening on the pouch 1.5-3 mm larger than stoma before removing backing. Prepare pouch by removing backing from barrier and adhesive (see illustration). With ileostomy, apply thin circle of barrier paste around opening in pouch; allow to dry.</td><td>The paste facilitates seal and protects skin. Correct size of pouch opening keeps drainage off skin and lessens risk of damage to stoma during peristalsis or activity. Pouch and skin barrier are changed whenever leaking. Can also be changed before or after tub bath or shower. Stool is alkaline and this irritates the skin; faecal bacteria can colonise on the skin and increase risk of infection. Change when patient is comfortable; before a meal is better, because this avoids increased peristalsis and chance of evacuation during the pouch change.</td></tr><tr><td>21. Apply the skin barrier and pouch (see steps below). If creases next to stoma occur, use barrier paste to fill in; allow to dry for 1-2 minutes.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Critical decision point: If patient has surgical incision near stoma, the skin barrier may have to be trimmed for fit.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>A. For one-piece pouching system</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(1) Use skin sealant wipes on skin directly under where adhesive skin barrier of pouch will be applied; allow to dry.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(2) Hold pouch by skin barrier, centre over stoma, and press down gently on barrier; bottom of pouch should point towards patient's knees. Press the adhesive backing smoothly against the skin, starting from the bottom and working up and around the sides.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(3) Maintain gentle finger pressure around the barrier for 1-2 minutes.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>B. For two-piece pouching system</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(1) Apply flange (barrier with adhesive) as in steps above for one-piece system. Then snap on pouch and maintain finger pressure.</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<ol start="22">
<li>Apply non-allergic paper tape around the pectin barrier paste in a 'picture frame' method. Half the tape should be on the skin barrier and half on the patient's skin. Some patients may prefer a belt attached to the pouch for extra security rather than tape. | Creates wrinkle-free, secure seal; decreases irritation from the adhesive on skin.
'Picture framing' the pectin skin barrier adds to the security of keeping the pouch system attached securely.  |</li>
</ol>

<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Critical decision point: Be sure belt is not too tight by placing two fingers between belt and skin.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>23. Although many ostomy pouches are odour proof, some nurses and patients like to put a small amount of ostomy deodorant into the pouch. This includes presence of adequate toileting facilities, flushable toilet and number and location of toilets.</td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Caution the patient that most ostomy pouches and barriers cannot be flushed down the toilet; they clog the system. Dispose of used ostomy pouch according to local sanitation regulations.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Instruct patient to use a washcloth or any soft material to clean around stoma.</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>

<p>SKILL 37-3</p>
<p>Inserting and maintaining a nasogastric tube (for decompression)</p>
<p>DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS
Inserting and maintaining a nasogastric (NG) tube requires the problem-solving and knowledge-application skills of registered nurses. Enrolled nurses may measure and record the drainage from the NG tube and provide oral and nasal hygiene and comfort measures.</p>
<p>EQUIPMENT</p>
<ul>
<li>No. 14 or no. 16 Fr NG tube (smaller lumen catheters are not used for decompression in adults because they must be able to remove thick secretions)</li>
<li>Water-soluble lubricating jelly</li>
<li>pH test strips (measure gastric aspirate acidity)</li>
</ul>
<p>Tongue blade</p>
<ul>
<li>Torch</li>
<li>Catheter-tipped syringe</li>
<li>2.5 cm wide hypoallergenic tape</li>
<li>Safety pin and rubber band/tape</li>
<li>Clamp, drainage bag or suction machine or pressure gauge if wall suction is to be used</li>
<li>Bath towel</li>
<li>Glass of water with straw</li>
<li>Facial tissues</li>
<li>Vomit basin</li>
<li>Disposable gloves</li>
</ul>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>1. Pull curtain around the bed or close room door.</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<ol start="2">
<li>Inspect condition of patient's nasal and oral cavity.</li>
<li>Ask whether patient has had history of nasal surgery and note whether deviated nasal septum is present.</li>
<li>Palpate patient's abdomen for distension, pain and rigidity. Auscultate for bowel sounds.</li>
<li>Assess patient's level of consciousness and ability to follow instructions. | Provides privacy.
Baseline condition of nasal and oral cavity determines need for special nursing measures for oral hygiene after tube placement.
Nurse should insert tube into uninvolved nasal passage.
Procedure may be contraindicated if surgery is recent.
Baseline determination of level of abdominal distension later serves as comparison once tube is inserted.
Determines patient's ability to assist in procedure.  |
|  Critical decision point: If patient is confused, disoriented or unable to follow commands, get help from another staff member to insert the tube.  |   |
|  6. Check medical record for order, type of NG tube to be placed and whether tube is to be attached to suction or drainage bag.</li>
<li>Gather equipment at the bedside.</li>
<li>Identify patient and explain procedure.</li>
<li>Use alcoholic hand wash solution and apply disposable gloves.</li>
<li>Position patient in high-Fowler's position (if not contraindicated, e.g. patient with a spinal injury) with pillows behind head and shoulders. Raise bed to a horizontal level comfortable for the nurse.</li>
<li>Stand on patient's right side if right-handed, left side if left-handed.</li>
<li>Place bath towel over patient's chest; give facial tissues to patient. Have vomit basin nearby.</li>
<li>Instruct patient to relax and breathe normally while occluding one naris. Then repeat this action for other naris. Select nostril with greater air flow.</li>
<li>Measure distance to insert tube: measure distance from tip of nose to earlobe to xiphoid process (see illustration). | Procedure requires a written medical order. Adequate decompression depends on NG suction.
Identification prevents error of placing tube in wrong patient. Explanation gains patient's cooperation and lessens possibility that patient will remove tube.
Reduces transmission of microorganisms.
Promotes patient's ability to swallow during procedure. Good body mechanics prevent injury to nurse or patient.
Allows easiest manipulation of tubing.
Prevents soiling of patient's gown. Tube insertion through nasal passages may cause eye-watering and coughing with increased salivation.
Tube passes more easily through naris that is more patent.
Tube should extend from nares to stomach; distance varies with each patient.  |</li>
</ol>
<p>BOWEL ELIMINATION 229</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>15. Mark length of tube to be inserted with small piece of tape placed so it can be easily removed.</td><td>Marks amount of tube to be inserted from nares to stomach.</td></tr><tr><td>16. Cut a 10 cm piece of tape. Split one end down the middle lengthwise 5 cm. Place on bed rail or bedside table.</td><td>Tape will be used after tube insertion to anchor the tube securely.</td></tr><tr><td>17. Curve 10â€“15 cm of end of tube tightly around index finger, then release.</td><td>Curving tube tip aids insertion and decreases stiffness of tube.</td></tr><tr><td>18. Lubricate 7â€“10 cm of end of tube with water-soluble lubricating jelly.</td><td>Minimises friction against nasal mucosa and aids insertion of tube.</td></tr><tr><td>19. Alert patient that procedure is to begin.</td><td>Decreases patient anxiety and increases patient cooperation.</td></tr><tr><td>20. Initially instruct patient to extend neck back against pillow; insert tube slowly through naris with curved end pointing downwards (see illustration).</td><td>Facilitates initial passage of tube through naris and maintains clear airway for open naris.</td></tr><tr><td>21. Continue to pass tube along floor of nasal passage, aiming down towards ear. When resistance is felt, apply gentle downward pressure to advance tube (do not force past resistance).</td><td>Minimises discomfort of tube rubbing against upper nasal turbinates. Resistance is caused by posterior nasopharynx. Downward pressure helps tube curl around corner of nasopharynx.</td></tr><tr><td>22. If resistance is met, try to rotate the tube and see if it advances. If still resistant, withdraw tube, allow patient to rest, re-lubricate tube and insert into other naris.</td><td>Forcing against resistance can cause trauma to mucosa. Resting helps relieve patientâ€™s anxiety.</td></tr><tr><td>Critical decision point: If unable to insert tube in either naris, stop procedure and notify doctor.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>23. Continue insertion of tube until just past the nasopharynx by gently rotating tube towards opposite naris.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>a. Stop tube advancement, allow patient to relax and provide tissues.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>b. Explain to patient that next step requires the patient to swallow. Give patient glass of water unless contraindicated.</td><td>Relieves patientâ€™s anxiety; eye-watering is natural response to mucosal irritation, and excessive salivation may occur because of oral stimulation.</td></tr><tr><td>Sipping of water aids passage of NG tube into oesophagus.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>24. With tube just above oropharynx, instruct patient to flex head forwards, take a small sip of water and swallow. Advance tube 2â€“5 cm with each swallow of water. If patient is not allowed fluids, instruct to dry-swallow or suck air through straw. Advance tube with each swallow.</td><td>Flexed position closes off upper airway to trachea and opens oesophagus. Swallowing closes epiglottis over trachea and helps move the tube into the oesophagus. Swallowing water reduces gagging or choking. Water can be removed later from stomach by suction.</td></tr><tr><td>25. If patient begins to cough, gag or choke, withdraw slightly and stop tube advancement. Instruct patient to breathe easily and take sips of water.</td><td>Tubing may accidentally enter larynx and initiate cough reflex. Gagging is eased by swallowing water. Risk of aspiration increases if vomiting occurs.</td></tr><tr><td>Critical decision point: If vomiting occurs, help patient clear airway; oral suctioning may be needed. Do not proceed until airway is cleared.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>26. If patient continues to cough during insertion, pull tube back slightly.</td><td>Tube may enter larynx and obstruct airway.</td></tr><tr><td>27. If patient continues to gag, check back of pharynx using torch and tongue blade.</td><td>Tube may coil around itself in back of throat and stimulate gag reflex.</td></tr><tr><td>28. After patient relaxes, continue to advance tube to the desired distance.</td><td>Tip of tube should be within stomach to decompress properly.</td></tr><tr><td>29. Once tube is correctly advanced, remove tape used to mark length of tube and place the prepared split tape with non-split side on nose. Anchor with one of split ends while checking tube placement.</td><td>Tube should be partially anchored before placement is checked.</td></tr><tr><td>30. Checking tube placement: check institutional policy for preferred methods for checking tube placement (for decompression).</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>a. Ask patient to talk.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>b. Inspect posterior pharynx for presence of coiled tube.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>c. Aspirate gently back on syringe to obtain gastric contents, observing colour (see illustration).</td><td>Patient is unable to talk if NG tube has passed through vocal cords.</td></tr><tr><td>Tube is pliable and can coil up in back of pharynx instead of advancing into oesophagus.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Gastric contents are usually cloudy and green, but may be off white, tan, bloody or brown. Aspiration of contents provides means to measure fluid pH and thus determine tube tip placement in gastrointestinal tract.</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>

<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>d. Measure pH of aspirate with colour-coded pH paper with range of whole numbers 1â€“11 (see illustration).</td><td>Other common aspirate colours include the following: duodenal placement (yellow or bile-stained), oesophagus (may or may not have saliva-appearing aspirate).</td></tr><tr><td>Gastric aspirates have highly acidic pH values, preferably 4 or less in adults and 5 or less in children, compared with intestinal aspirates, which are usually greater than 4, or respiratory secretions, which are usually greater than 5.5 (Gilbertson and others, 2011; Phang and others, 2004).</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>e. Patient going to the operating room often has tube clamped.</td></tr><tr><td>Prevents tissue necrosis. Measurement of the tube length from nares to connector is an alternative method.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>c. Remove gloves and apply alcoholic hand wash.</td><td>The mark or tube length is to be used as a guide to indicate whether displacement may have occurred.</td></tr><tr><td>35. Observe amount and character of contents draining from NG tube. Ask whether patient feels nauseated.</td><td>Reduces transmission of microorganisms.</td></tr><tr><td>36. Palpate patientâ€™s abdomen periodically, noting any distension, pain and rigidity, and auscultate for the presence of bowel sounds. Turn off suction while auscultating.</td><td>Determines whether tube is decompressing stomach of contents.</td></tr><tr><td>Determines success of abdominal decompression and the return of peristalsis.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>37. Inspect condition of nares and nose.</td><td>Evaluates onset of skin and tissue irritation.</td></tr><tr><td>38. Observe position of tubing.</td><td>Determines whether tension is being applied to nasal structures.</td></tr><tr><td>39. Ask whether patient feels sore throat or irritation in pharynx.</td><td>Evaluates level of patientâ€™s discomfort.</td></tr><tr><td>40. Discontinuation of NG tube:</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>a. Verify order to discontinue NG tube.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>b. Explain procedure to patient and reassure that removal is less distressing than insertion.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>c. Apply alcoholic hand wash and put on disposable gloves.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>d. Disconnect NG tube from drainage bag. Remove tape from bridge of nose and unpin tube from gown.</td><td>Written medical order required for procedure.</td></tr><tr><td>Minimises anxiety and increases cooperation. Tube passes out smoothly.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Reduces transmission of microorganisms.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Have tube free of connections before removal.</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="urinary-elimination">Urinary elimination<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#urinary-elimination" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="overview">Overview<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#overview" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Normal elimination of urinary waste is a basic function that most people take for granted. When the renal system fails to function properly, virtually all organ systems will eventually be affected. Patients with urinary problems most commonly have disturbances in the act of micturition that involve a failure to store urine or a failure to empty urine. These disturbances result from impaired bladder function, obstruction to urine outflow or inability to voluntarily control micturition. Some patients may have permanent or temporary changes in the normal pathway of urinary excretion.</p>
<p>Patients with alterations in urinary elimination may also suffer emotionally from body image changes, so the nurse must provide understanding and sensitivity to all patients' needs. The nurse must understand the reasons for problems and find acceptable solutions. The nurse's approach to a patient's elimination needs must consider cultural, social and gender habits. The nurse will need knowledge of concepts beyond the anatomy and physiology of the urinary system to give appropriate care, including infection control, hygiene measures, growth and development, and psychosocial influences.</p>
<p>The most common cause of urinary tract infection is the introduction of instruments into the urinary tract. For example, the introduction of a catheter through the urethra provides a direct route for microorganisms. With an indwelling bladder catheter, bacteria ascend along the outside of the catheter on the urethral wall or travel up the catheter's lumen. The catheter interferes with the normal voiding mechanism, which acts as a defence against organisms entering the urethra. Local irritation to the urethra or bladder further predisposes tissue to bacterial invasion. This demonstrates the importance of maintaining extremely high standards of hygiene and infection control when nursing patients with elimination-assist devices.</p>
<p>This chapter explores the psychomotor skills that focus on the specific care of patients with urinary elimination needs. The skills addressed include collecting a midstream (clean-voided) urine specimen (38-1), inserting a straight or indwelling catheter (38-2) and applying a sheath/condom drainage device (38-3).</p>
<p>URINARY ELIMINATION 235</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="skill-38-1">SKILL 38-1<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#skill-38-1" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="collecting-a-midstream-clean-voided-urine-specimen">Collecting a midstream (clean-voided) urine specimen<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#collecting-a-midstream-clean-voided-urine-specimen" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="delegation-considerations">DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delegation-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>If appropriate, an alert patient who is physically able may be instructed to collect the specimen.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Soap or cleaning solution, washcloth and towel or disposable cleansing towel</li>
<li>Sterile specimen collection jar with lid</li>
<li>Non-sterile gloves</li>
<li>If the person cannot collect the specimen themselves, a bed pan, bedside commode or specimen hat</li>
<li>Completed specimen label</li>
</ul>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>1. Assess status of patient:</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>a. When patient last voided</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>b. Level of awareness or developmental stage</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>c. Mobility, balance and physical limitations.</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<ol start="2">
<li>
<p>Assess patientâ€™s understanding of purpose of test and method of collection.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Explain procedure to patient:
a. Reason midstream specimen is needed
b. Ways patient and family can assist
c. Ways to obtain specimen free of faeces</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Provide fluids to drink Â½ hour before collection unless contraindicated (i.e. fluid restriction) if patient does not feel urge to void.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Ask the person to go to the toilet/bathroom or provide privacy for patient by closing door or bed curtain.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Put on non-sterile gloves and help non-ambulatory patients with perineal care. Help female patient onto bedpan. Perform hand hygiene.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Open the sterile specimen container, placing cap with sterile inside surface up; do not touch inside of container or cap (see Chapter 29).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Assist or ask the patient to independently clean perineum and collect specimen:</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>A. Female
(1) Spread labia with thumb and forefinger of non-dominant hand.
(2) Clean area with soap and water or moistened disposable towel moving from front (above urethral orifice) to back (towards anus) (see illustration).
(3) While continuing to hold labia apart, patient should initiate stream and after stream is achieved, pass container into stream and collect 30â€“60 mL (see illustration).</p>
<p>B. Male
(1) Hold penis with one hand and, using circular motion, clean end of penis, moving from centre to outside (see illustration). In uncircumcised men, the foreskin should be retracted prior to cleaning.
(2) After patient has initiated urine stream, pass specimen collection container into stream, and collect 30â€“60 mL (see illustration). | May indicate bladder fullness.
Reveals patientâ€™s ability to cooperate during procedure.
Determines level of assistance.
Information allows you to clarify misunderstandings and promotes patient cooperation.
Helps patient understand the procedure.</p>
<p>Faeces change characteristics of urine and may cause abnormal values.
Improves likelihood of patient being able to void.</p>
<p>Privacy allows patient to relax and produce specimen more quickly.
Prevents transmission of microorganisms to nurse, provides easy access to perineal area to collect specimen.</p>
<p>Aseptic technique is essential to maintain sterility of equipment and specimen. Contaminated specimen is most frequent reason for inaccurate reporting of urine cultures and sensitivities.</p>
<p>Provides access to urethral meatus.
Clean from area of least contamination to area of greatest contamination, to decrease bacterial levels.</p>
<p>Initial stream flushes out microorganisms that accumulate at urethral meatus and prevents transfer into specimen.</p>
<p>Clean from area of least contamination to area of greatest contamination, to decrease bacterial levels.</p>

Patient finishes voiding in bedpan or toilet. If foreskin was retracted for specimen collection, it must be replaced over the glans.</td><td>Prevents contamination of specimen with skin flora. <div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="collecting-a-midstream-clean-voided-urine-specimen">COLLECTING A MIDSTREAM (CLEAN-VOIDED) URINE SPECIMEN<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#collecting-a-midstream-clean-voided-urine-specimen" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>CLINICAL SKILL 38-1: Collecting a midstream (clean-voided) urine specimen</p>
<p>DEMONSTRATES: The ability to effectively collect a midstream urine sample with minimal contamination</p>
<p>DOMAIN/S (AUS): Provision and Coordination of Care</p>
<p>DOMAIN/S (NZ): Professional responsibility; management of nursing care; interpersonal relationships</p>
<p>PERFORMANCE CRITERIA: (numbers indicate National Competency Standards for the Registered Nurse)</p>
<p>AUS 5.1, 5.2, 5.3, 6.3, 7.1, 7.5, 7.6, 7.7, 8.2</p>
<p>NZ 1.1, 1.2, 1.3, 1.5, 2.3, 2.4, 2.7, 3.1, 3.2, 3.3</p>

SKILL 38-2</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="inserting-a-straight-or-indwelling-catheter">Inserting a straight or indwelling catheter<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#inserting-a-straight-or-indwelling-catheter" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="delegation-considerations">DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delegation-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Catheterisation requires the problem-solving and knowledge application skills of registered nurses. Insertion of a urinary catheter normally requires a medical request.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Catheterisation kit containing the following sterile items:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Gloves (extra pair optional)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Drapes, one fenestrated</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Lubricant (usually water-based for women and xylocaine gel (2%) in a pre-filled syringe for men)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Antiseptic cleaning solution (aqueous chlorhexidine or Normal saline)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Gauze swabs</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Forceps</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Syringe with sterile water to inflate the balloon of indwelling catheter</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Catheter of correct size and type for procedure (i.e. intermittent or indwelling)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Sterile urinary bag</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Catheter strap or other catheter-securing device</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Receptacle or basin (usually bottom of disposable catheterisation tray)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Blanket/large towel to cover patient</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="steps">STEPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Assess status of patient:
a. Time of last urination; ask patient, check fluid balance chart or palpate bladder
b. Level of awareness or developmental stage
c. Mobility and physical limitations of patient
d. Patient's gender and age
e. Distended bladder
f. Perineum erythema, drainage and odour
g. Any pathological condition that may impair passage of catheter (e.g. enlarged prostate in men)
h. Allergies</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Review patient's medical record, including medical request and nurses' notes.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Assess patient's knowledge of the purpose of catheterisation.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Explain procedure to patient.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Arrange for extra nursing personnel to help as necessary.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Begin monitoring fluid balance.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Perform hand hygiene.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Close curtain or door.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Raise bed to appropriate working height.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Facing patient, stand on left side of bed if right-handed (on right side of bed if left-handed). Clear the bedside table and arrange equipment.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Raise side rail on opposite side of bed, and put side rail down on working side.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Place waterproof pad under patient.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Position patient.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="a-female-patient">A. Female patient<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-female-patient" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>(1) Help into dorsal recumbent position (supine with knees flexed). Ask patient to relax thighs so the hips can be externally rotated.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="rationale">RATIONALE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rationale" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Bladder fullness may be detected with deep palpation above the symphysis pubis.</p>
<p>Reveals the patient's ability to cooperate and level of explanation needed.</p>
<p>Affect way the nurse positions patient.</p>
<p>Determines catheter size: see Box 38-4.</p>
<p>Causes pain. Can indicate need to insert catheter if patient is unable to void independently.</p>
<p>Determines condition of the perineum.</p>
<p>Obstruction prevents passage of catheter through urethra into the bladder.</p>
<p>Determines allergy to antiseptic, tape, latex and lubricant. Betadine allergies are common; if the patient is unaware of allergy, ask if allergic to shellfish.</p>
<p>Determines purpose of inserting catheter. Assess for previous catheterisation, including catheter size, response of patient and time of last catheterisation.</p>
<p>Reveals need for patient instruction.</p>
<p>Promotes cooperation.</p>
<p>Patient may be unable to assume positioning for procedure.</p>
<p>Catheterised patients are at risk of urinary complications.</p>
<p>Reduces transmission of microorganisms.</p>
<p>Offers privacy, reduces embarrassment and aids in relaxation during procedure.</p>
<p>Promotes use of proper body mechanics.</p>
<p>Successful catheter insertion requires nurse to assume comfortable position with all equipment easily accessible. The materials in the kit are arranged in sequence of use.</p>
<p>Promotes patient safety.</p>
<p>Prevents soiling of bedclothes.</p>
<p>Provides good view of perineal structures.</p>
<p>Legs may be supported with pillows to reduce muscle tension and promote comfort.</p>
<p>FUNDAMENTALS OF NURSING: CLINICAL SKILLS WORKBOOK</p>

<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>25. Place sterile tray and contents on sterile drape.</td><td>Provides easy access to supplies during catheter insertion. Dominant hand remains sterile.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>27. Pick up catheter with gloved dominant hand 8â€“10 cm from catheter tip. Hold end of catheter loosely coiled in palm of dominant hand (optional: may grasp catheter with forceps).</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<ol start="28">
<li>Insert catheter:
<strong>A. Female patient</strong>
(1) Slowly insert catheter through urethral meatus (see illustration).
(2) Advance catheter a total of 5â€“8 cm in adult or until urine flows out of catheterâ€™s end. When urine appears, advance catheter another 2â€“5 cm. Do not force against resistance. | Female urethra is short. Appearance of urine indicates that catheter tip is in bladder or lower urethra. Advancement of catheter ensures bladder placement.  |
|  Critical decision point: If no urine appears, check that catheter is in vagina. If misplaced, leave catheter in vagina as landmark indicating where not to insert, and insert another (you will need to start the procedure again unless you have another nurse attending who can open another sterile catheter onto the sterile field).  |   |
|  (3) Release labia, and hold catheter securely with non-dominant hand. Inflate balloon if retention catheter is used (see illustration). Only put in the amount of sterile water that is indicated on the catheter.
<strong>B. Male patient</strong>
(1) Lift penis to position perpendicular to patientâ€™s body and apply light traction (see illustration).
(2) Slowly insert catheter through urethral meatus.
(3) Advance catheter 18â€“23 cm in adult or until urine flows out catheterâ€™s end. If resistance is felt, withdraw catheter; do not force it through urethra. When urine appears, advance catheter another 2â€“5 cm. | Bladder or sphincter contraction may cause accidental expulsion of catheter.
Over-inflation of the balloon may cause it to burst or block off the drainage holes of the catheter. Under-inflation can result in the catheter falling out.
Straightens urethral canal to ease catheter insertion.
The adult male urethra is long. It is normal to meet resistance at the prostatic sphincter. When resistance is met, nurse should hold catheter firmly against sphincter without forcing catheter. After a few seconds, the sphincter relaxes, and the catheter is advanced. Appearance of urine indicates catheter tip is in bladder or urethra. Further advancement of catheter ensures proper placement.  |</li>
</ol>
<p>FUNDAMENTALS OF NURSING: CLINICAL SKILLS WORKBOOK</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="applying-a-sheath-condom-drainage-device">Applying a sheath/condom drainage device<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#applying-a-sheath-condom-drainage-device" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="delegation-considerations">DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delegation-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Applying a sheath/condom can be delegated to enrolled nurses, the person if he is able or a family carer in the home context.</p>
<ul>
<li>Ensure that person/caregiver knows standard precautions guidelines relating to body fluids.</li>
<li>Clarify that skin of penile shaft is intact and free of swelling, redness or open lesions before sheath/condom drainage device is applied.</li>
<li>Clarify the person's/caregiver's understanding of how to apply the adhesive strip that secures the sheath/condom drainage device.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Sheath/condom drainage device kit</li>
<li>Latex/silicone condom sheath (proper size) (check for possible rubber or latex allergy)</li>
<li>Skin preparation solution or swab (may be required)</li>
<li>Urinary collection bag with tubing or leg bag with straps</li>
<li>Basin with warm water and soap</li>
<li>Towels and washcloths</li>
<li>Non-sterile disposable gloves</li>
<li>Bath blanket</li>
<li>Scissors and/or personal trimmer (patient's own)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="steps">STEPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Assess urinary elimination patterns, patient's ability to voluntarily urinate and continence.</li>
<li>Provide privacy by closing door or bed curtains.</li>
<li>Assess mental status of patient so appropriate teaching related to sheath device can be implemented.</li>
<li>Assess condition of penis.</li>
<li>Assess patient's knowledge of the purpose of a sheath device.</li>
<li>Explain procedure to patient.</li>
<li>Perform hand hygiene.</li>
<li>Raise bed to appropriate working height. Raise side rail on opposite side of bed, and lower rail on working side.</li>
<li>Help patient into supine position. Place bath blanket over upper torso. Fold bed sheets so that lower extremities are covered; only genitalia should be exposed.</li>
<li>Prepare urinary drainage collection for connection to sheath/condom. Clamp off all drainage exit ports. Secure collection bag to bed frame; bring drainage tubing up through side rails onto bed. Prepare leg bag for connection to sheath/condom if necessary.</li>
<li>Put on non-sterile gloves. Assess the required size of the sheath/condom using the manufacturer's guide.</li>
<li>Wash area with soap and water or ask the patient to do this for himself if he is able (see Skill 38-2), and dry thoroughly.</li>
<li>Clip hair at base of penis. In some cases, shaving the hair at the base of the penis may be necessary.</li>
<li>Roll sheath/condom onto penisâ€”try to keep the glans centrally within the sheath. You may need to put gentle tension on the penis to keep it straight within the sheath. As the adhesive is on the inside of the sheath/condom, you need to gently press the sheath onto the shaft of the penis as you unroll it (see illustrations).</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="rationale">RATIONALE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rationale" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Patients who are incontinent are at high risk of skin breakdown.</p>
<ul>
<li>Maintains patient's self-esteem.</li>
</ul>
<p>Some male patients may be incontinent only at night. Teaching can be implemented to instruct patient on self-application.</p>
<p>Provides a baseline to compare changes in condition of skin after condom application.</p>
<p>Reveals need for patient instruction.</p>
<ul>
<li>Reduces anxiety and promotes cooperation.</li>
</ul>
<p>Reduces transmission of microorganisms.</p>
<p>Promotes patient safety and proper use of body mechanics by nurse.</p>
<p>Promotes patient comfort and prevents unnecessary exposure of body parts.</p>
<p>Provides easy access to drainage equipment after sheath/condom is applied.</p>
<p>Sheath/condoms come in a variety of sizes (circumference and length). It is very important to use the correct size for comfort and so that the sheath/condom remains in place for the required period of time.</p>
<p>Removes irritating secretions. Rubber/latex sheath rolls onto dry skin more easily. The adhesive will adhere to dry skin. Be aware of possible latex allergy.</p>
<p>Hair adheres to sheath/condom and is pulled during sheath/condom removal or may get caught as sheath/condom is applied.</p>
<p>Make sure that the foreskin remains over the glans to protect the glans from the adhesive on the inside of the sheath/condom.</p>
<p>Gentle pressure and the heat from your hand will help make sure that the adhesive is well applied to the penile shaft.</p>
<p>Critical decision point: Allow 2â€“5 cm of space between tip of glans penis and end of sheath/condom (see illustration, Step 14).</p>

<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>15. Connect drainage tubing to end of sheath/condom. Be sure sheath/condom is not twisted.
