<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="fluid-electrolyte-and-acid-base-balance">Fluid, electrolyte and acid-base balance<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fluid-electrolyte-and-acid-base-balance" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="overview">Overview<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#overview" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Fluid, electrolyte and acid-base balance is essential for the maintenance of all body systems and normal physiological processes. This balance is maintained by the intake and output of water and electrolytes and regulation by the renal and pulmonary systems. Imbalance may result from multiple factors, including illness, altered fluid intake or prolonged episodes of vomiting or diarrhoea. Nurses require a comprehensive understanding of the distribution of body fluids, the constituents of body fluids and electrolyte balance to safely care for their patients. Knowledge and understanding of the mechanisms that contribute to fluid, electrolyte and acid-base imbalance are essential. Nurses must assume that each patient has a fluid and electrolyte imbalance until proven otherwise. A comprehensive assessment of each patient's fluid and electrolyte status will facilitate the nurse's capacity to clearly articulate at any point throughout a shift the clinical indicators that prove or disprove a patient's fluid and electrolyte balance or imbalance.</p>
<p>Although fluid, electrolyte and acid-base imbalance can occur in all settings, changes in the acute care delivery system place more demanding expectations on the nurse. Today, the nurse must manage each patient's complex medical care in a shorter span of time while also being expected to perform more difficult technological skills. The nurse monitors and manages fluid, electrolyte and acid-base balance through the maintenance of strict fluid balance records, the review of serum electrolyte and renal function serum assays, and the enteral and parenteral administration of fluids.</p>
<p>Fluids and electrolytes may be replaced through infusion directly into the blood rather than via the digestive system. Parenteral replacement includes total parenteral nutrition (TPN), intravenous (IV) fluid and electrolyte therapy (crystalloids) and blood and blood component (colloids) administration.</p>
<p>The goal of IV fluid administration is to correct or prevent fluid and electrolyte disturbances. It enables direct access to the vascular system, permitting the infusion of continuous fluids over a period of time. IV fluid therapy must be closely regulated because of continual changes in the patient's fluid and electrolyte balance. The skills addressed in this chapter relate to nursing care associated with assisting the patient to maintain fluid, electrolyte and acid-base balance.</p>
<p>Adequate preparation is essential to facilitate effective nursing care of the patient requiring an IV catheter and fluids. Adequate preparation includes gathering and preparing equipment, assessing patient knowledge, initiating the IV infusion, regulating the infusion flow rate, maintaining the IV system and monitoring the patient for complications associated with IV therapy. The psychomotor skills addressed in this chapter include subcutaneous infusion (hypodermoclysis) (39-1), initiating a peripheral intravenous infusion (39-2), regulating intravenous flow rate (39-3), changing intravenous solution and infusion tubing (39-4) and changing a peripheral intravenous dressing (39-5).</p>
<p>FUNDAMENTALS OF NURSING: CLINICAL SKILLS WORKBOOK</p>
<p>SKILL 39-1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="subcutaneous-infusion-hypodermoclysis">Subcutaneous infusion (hypodermoclysis)*<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#subcutaneous-infusion-hypodermoclysis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="delegation-considerations">DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delegation-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Initiating SC infusion requires the problem-solving and knowledge-application skills of professional nurses. In Australia, a registered nurse is able to insert SC cannulas. Refer to relevant agency policy.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="steps">STEPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="preparing-the-sc-solution">Preparing the SC solution<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#preparing-the-sc-solution" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Check solution using the seven rights of drug administration (see Chapter 31). Check type of fluid, amount, rate and route of administration with written doctor's orders.</li>
<li>Check solution for colour, clarity and expiration date. Check bag for leaks, which is best done before reaching the bedside.</li>
<li>Assess patient's history of allergies.</li>
<li>Open infusion set, maintaining sterility of both ends of tubing. Many sets allow for priming of tubing without removal of end cap.</li>
<li>Place roller clamp about 2â€“5 cm below drip chamber and move roller clamp to 'off' position (see illustration at Step 16 of Skill 39-2).</li>
<li>Remove protective sheath over IV-giving set tubing.</li>
<li>Insert infusion set into fluid bag. Remove protector cap from tubing insertion spike (keeping spike sterile), and insert spike into opening of IV bag (see illustration at Step 18 of Skill 39-2).</li>
<li>Prime infusion tubing by filling with IV solution. Compress drip chamber and release, allowing it to fill one-third to half full.</li>
<li>Slowly release roller clamp to allow fluid to travel from drip chamber through tubing to needle or catheter adapter. Line can be primed without removing tubing protector cap. Return roller clamp to 'off' position after tubing is primed (filled with solution).</li>
<li>Be certain tubing is clear of air and air bubbles.</li>
<li>Remove tubing protector cap and replace with 'threader link cannula' or 'lever lock cannula' leaving the protector on end of these until ready to attach to the 'Interlink injection site', which is an interlink connector attached to the subcutaneous cannula.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="rationale">RATIONALE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rationale" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Solutions are medications and should be carefully checked by two nurses to reduce risk of error.</p>
<p>Type of fluid: the most appropriate solutions are sodium chloride 0.9% or 0.45%, and 2.5% glucose in 0.45% sodium chloride.</p>
<p>Rate: the usual rate is only 1 mL/minute per site, with maximum of 1.5 L in 24 hours using a single site or 3 L in 24 hours if using two sites.</p>
<p>Solutions that are discoloured, contain particles, or are expired are not to be used. Leaky bags present an opportunity for infection and must not be used.</p>
<p>May reveal information that affects insertion of devices, such as allergy to iodine, adhesive or latex.</p>
<p>Prevents bacteria from entering infusion equipment.</p>
<p>Close proximity of roller clamp to drip chamber allows more-accurate regulation of flow rate. Moving clamp to 'off' prevents accidental spillage of fluid and decreases amount of air bubbles when priming line.</p>
<p>Provides access for insertion of infusion tubing into solution.</p>
<p>Prevents contamination of solution from contaminated insertion spike.</p>
<p>Creates suction effects; fluid enters drip chamber to prevent air from entering tubing.</p>
<p>Slow fill of tubing decreases turbulence and chance of bubble formation. Removes air from tubing and permits tubing to fill with solution. Closing the clamp prevents accidental loss of fluid.</p>
<p>Prevents bubble formation in the cannula.</p>
<p>Prepares the IV-giving set for connection to the SC cannula. Maintains system sterility.</p>
<p>FLUID, ELECTROLYTE AND ACID-BASE BALANCE 251</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><strong>Insertion of SC catheter</strong></td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<ol start="12">
<li>Perform hand hygiene and use aseptic technique; observe standard precautions.</li>
<li>Explain procedure and expected outcomes to patient
Assess patientâ€™s perception of possible discomfort and site preference.</li>
<li>Select appropriate insertion site.
a. Suitable sites are abdomen, upper chest, above the breast, over an intercostal space and over the scapula; thighs; and the outer aspect of the upper arm.
b. Unsuitable sites include those with pre-existing oedema, lymphoedemata, previous radiotherapy site, skin damage, swelling or scarring, mastectomy site or close to a stoma. Sites over bony prominences or near a joint are also unsuitable.</li>
<li>Consider the application of EMLA (topical anaesthetic) cream for patients with needle phobia.</li>
<li>Prime the SC catheter:
a. Draw 1.5 mL of normal saline into syringe. Inject 1 mL normal saline via the sterile Interlink injection cap into the SC cannula and tubing.
b. Clamp tubing to maintain normal saline in cannula and tubing.
c. Detach syringe. Be careful not to contaminate distal end of tubing.</li>
<li>Put on gloves.</li>
<li>Clean insertion site (see illustration):
a. Using a firm, circular motion (middle to outwards), clean with alcohol, and allow to dry.
b. Clean again, using same method, with povidoneâ€“iodine solution and allow to dry; refrain from touching the cleaned site.
c. If the patient is allergic to iodine, use 70% alcohol and allow to dry for 60 seconds.</li>
<li>Using thumb and index finger, pinch the skin and tissue around the insertion site, creating a roll of about 1.25â€“2.5 cm in diameter.</li>
<li>Insert the entire length of the catheter at a 45-degree angle with the bevel of the needle up.</li>
<li>Remove the stylet (needle) and discard carefully into the sharps disposal container</li>
<li>Check SC placement:
a. Cleanse Interlink injection cap and attach syringe containing remaining normal saline.
b. Draw back to ensure the over-the-needle cannula is not placed in a blood vessel. If blood appears in tubing, remove the over-the-cannula needle, discard used equipment and re-site.
c. If blood does not appear in tubing, flush tubing with remaining 0.5 mL of normal saline.
<strong>Commencing the SC infusion</strong></li>
<li>Attach the IV giving set to the SC cannula.</li>
<li>If SC fluids are ordered, remove the protective tubing from the â€˜threaded link cannulaâ€™ or â€˜lever lock cannulaâ€™ on the patient end of the IV-giving set and connect it to the â€˜Interlink injection siteâ€™ (bung/cap) which should now be on the end of the SC cannula. Adjust the flow rate as desired. | Reduces transmission of microorganisms.
Determines level of emotional support and patient education required.
The SC infusion should be sited in a position with good lymphatic drainage to maximise absorption.
Any site where tissue viability or perfusion is compromised and absorption is affected should be avoided.
EMLA cream makes subcutaneous cannulation relatively painless; must be applied at least 1 to 1.5 hours before the proposed procedure.
Priming the IV line ensures that normal saline will fill dead space and air will not be administered.
Reduces transmission of microorganisms.
Reduces the risk of transfer of transient micro-organisms and resident microorganisms from skin to subcutaneous tissues. Povidoneâ€“iodine reduces skin surface bacteria; touching the cleaned area introduces organisms from nurseâ€™s glove. Povidoneâ€“iodine must dry to be effective in reducing microbial counts. Use of alcohol reduces the possible adverse effects of povidoneâ€“iodine.
Pinching the skin elevates the SC tissue and ensures cannulation into SC tissue above the underlying fascia.
Shallower positioning, i.e. less than 45Â°, may shorten the life of the infusion site.
Reduces the risk of needle-stick injury and cross-infection.
Ensures that cannula has not entered a capillary or vein.
Flushing ensures effective hypodermoclysis.
To connect the fluid to the cannula.
Prompt connection of infusion set maintains sterility.  |</li>
</ol>
<p>FUNDAMENTALS OF NURSING: CLINICAL SKILLS WORKBOOK</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>25. Subcutaneous fluids should be administered via gravity using a standard administration set (20 drops/mL).</td><td>The administration of SC fluids relies on the permeability of the subcutaneous tissues to gravity-fed fluids. SC fluids should never be given via an infusion pump.</td></tr><tr><td>26. Curl a loop of tubing alongside the SC cannula and apply transparent dressing, ensuring that needle and tubing are well anchored.</td><td>Creating a loop in the tubing around the needle site avoids inadvertent dislodgement of the needle. Dressing the insertion site with a clear occlusive dressing allows for regular observation of the site.</td></tr><tr><td>27. Write insertion date on dressing; attach label on IV line with SC fluid in progress.</td><td>Tape on top of tape makes it easier to access hub/tubing junction. Securing loop of tubing reduces risk of dislodging catheter.</td></tr><tr><td>28. Check order for SC fluids; calculated drops per minute and commence infusion. Document on infusion record and fluid balance chart.</td><td>Noting date of insertion clearly communicates change times for IV tubing. Attaching a label with the SC fluid in progress decreases risk for errors in infusing incorrect fluids; labelling of fluids and lines has been recognised to increase the safe administration of fluids.</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Managing the SC infusion</strong></td><td>The administration line should be labelled with the date and time of commencement, and this should also be documented in the patient's health records; this assists in the identification of time and date for change of line.</td></tr><tr><td>29. Check the site within 30 minutes of commencement of infusion and at regular times thereafter.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>a. Check site within 30 minutes of commencement of hypodermoclysis to assess skin integrity.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>b. Check site at least 2-hourly for signs of redness, induration, tenderness, bleeding, oedema or leaking.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>c. A minimum of 4-hourly, check vital signs and analysis of FBC to determine level of hydration.</td><td>Regular observation of site will ensure identification of early signs of inflammation (erythema), oedema or poor absorption (hard SC swelling) and need for re-siting of the SC cannula.</td></tr><tr><td>Redness, swelling or inflammation at infusion site may be due to local reaction to cannula and may require the use of a Teflon cannula to reduce inflammatory response.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Tenderness at infusion site may require the position of the cannula to be adjusted/re-sited as the cannula may have been inserted intradermally (at too shallow an angle).</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Analysis of 4-hourly vital signs aids in the early identification and response to pulmonary oedema, hypovolaemia and the monitoring of clinical progress.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Changing SC sites according to unit policy will decrease risk of infection. Sites should be rotated to minimise tissue damage.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>30. Infusion site and giving sets are usually changed every 48-72 hours. The site must be changed according to unit policy regardless of its duration, and when any complications are observed.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td><strong>Discontinuing a continuous infusion</strong></td><td>Discontinuation of a continuous infusion will be undertaken based on doctor's orders.</td></tr><tr><td>31. Check written order for discontinuation.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>32. Gather equipment:</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Alcohol swabs</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Gloves</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Interlink cannula (if leaving SC site in situ)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ 3 mL syringe (for saline flush) (if leaving SC site in situ)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ 5 mL 0.9% normal saline for injection (if leaving SC site in situ).</td><td>Patient's awareness of the procedure will reduce anxiety and increase cooperation.</td></tr><tr><td>Reduces transmission of microorganisms.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>33. Explain procedure and expected outcomes to the patient and/or family.</td><td>Gentle removal of transparent dressing first will limit any damage to the skin.</td></tr><tr><td>34. Perform hand hygiene. Put on gloves.</td><td>Immediate discarding of cannula into correct receptacle reduces risk of cross-infection.</td></tr><tr><td>35. Stop continuous infusion: disconnect IV tubing.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Remove Interlink threaded lock cannula from 'Interlink injection site'.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>36. Remove SC cannula:</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>a. Remove transparent dressing.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>b. Pull out over-the-needle cannula.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>c. Discard into medical waste container.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>d. Apply pressure if bleeding or fluid leakage, followed by application of band-aid or small dressing.</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>

<p>CLINICAL SKILL 39-1: Subcutaneous infusion (hypodermoclysis)</p>
<p>DEMONSTRATES: The ability to safely and effectively administer subcutaneous fluids</p>

<p>FUNDAMENTALS OF NURSING: CLINICAL SKILLS WORKBOOK</p>
<p>SKILL 39-2</p>
<p>Initiating a peripheral intravenous (IV) infusion</p>
<p>DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS</p>
<p>Initiating IV therapy requires the problem-solving and knowledge-application skills of professional nurses. For this procedure, delegation is inappropriate. In Australia, a registered nurse (RN) is required to be accredited before being able to routinely cannulate. All nurses should, however, be aware of all the components of initiating a peripheral IV infusion, for they are usually required to collect the equipment and assist the medical officer or accredited RNs throughout the procedure. Refer to relevant agency policy. Note that many acute care agencies have an IV trolley which contains all possible equipment and supplies.</p>
<p>EQUIPMENT</p>
<ul>
<li>Special patient gown with press-studs at shoulder seams (makes removal with IV tubing easier)</li>
<li>IV infusion chart</li>
<li>Prescribed IV fluid (with time tape attached)</li>
<li>Over-the-needle catheter (ONC) for venepuncture (gauge will vary with patient's body size and reason for IV fluid administration)</li>
</ul>
<p>For IV fluid infusion:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Administration set (choice depends on type of solution and rate of administration; infants and children require microdrip tubing, which provides 60 drops/mL)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Extension tubing (used when a longer IV line is necessary)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Alcohol and povidone-iodine cleaning swabs or sticks (Rosenthal, 2003).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>EMLA cream</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Towel (to place under patient's hand or arm)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>IV pole, rolling or ceiling-mounted</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Disposable gloves</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Tourniquet (can be a source of contamination; use a single-use product)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Arm board, if needed (used to maintain wrist or elbow joint position</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Non-allergenic tape</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Needle disposal container (sharps container)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Transparent dressing (e.g. Opsite, Tegaderm)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>'Interlink injection site' (also called IV bung/plug/cap); connects to IV cannula; allows needless connection to the IV cannula.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>'Lever lock cannula' or 'threaded lock cannula'; attaches to the IV-giving set and connects the giving set to the cannula. Note that the giving set is never directly attached to the IV cannula without either of these Interlink connections</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>1â€“3 mL of normal saline</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>5 mL syringes with Interlink needle</p>
</li>
</ul>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Assessment</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>1. Review doctor's order for type and amount of IV fluid, rate of fluid administration and purpose of infusion. In addition, follow the seven rights for administration of medications (see Chapter 31).</td><td>A prescription for peripheral IV fluids must be made by a doctor before the implementation of this procedure. Assists in selection of appropriate access device</td></tr><tr><td>2. Review clinical data for indications of type of fluid and electrolyte imbalance and reason for prescribed infusion; e.g. admission diagnosis, signs and symptoms (e.g. bodyweight, blood pressure, pulse, skin turgor, urine output, fluid balance chart, serum electrolytes, full blood countâ€”haemoglobin [Hb] and haematocrit [Hct]).</td><td>Nurse is fully aware of reason for the prescribed solution and rate of infusion and ongoing monitoring required. Provides baseline data for later evaluation of change in fluid and electrolyte status.</td></tr><tr><td>3. Assess patient's history of allergies.</td><td>May reveal information that affects insertion of devices, such as allergy to iodine, adhesive or latex.</td></tr><tr><td>4. Assess patient's previous or perceived experience with IV therapy and arm placement preference.</td><td>Determines level of emotional support and patient education required.</td></tr><tr><td>5. Consider the application of EMLA cream for children and patients with needle phobia.</td><td>Although the application of EMLA cream makes IV cannulation relatively painless, it must be applied at least 1 to 1.5 hours before the proposed procedure. It is effective for up to 4 hours post application. Not recommended for infants under 3 months of age.</td></tr><tr><td>6. Determine whether patient is to undergo any planned surgery or is to receive blood infusion later.</td><td>Allows placement of appropriate-size catheter (i.e. 18 or 16 gauge for surgery) which will not interfere with medical procedures.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>FLUID, ELECTROLYTE AND ACID-BASE BALANCE 257</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>7. Assess for the following risk factors: child or older adult, presence of heart failure or renal failure or low platelet count.</td><td>Persons at extremes in age develop fluid imbalances more rapidly because of a proportionately larger ECF volume; persons with heart failure and acute kidney disease may require fluid restriction and cannot adapt to sudden increases in vascular volume. A low platelet count predisposes patients to bleeding at IV site.</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Preparation of patient</strong></td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<ol start="8">
<li>Prepare patient and family by explaining the procedure, its purpose and what is expected of patient.</li>
<li>Help patient into comfortable sitting or supine position.</li>
<li>Change patientâ€™s gown to the more easily removed gown with press-studs at the shoulder.</li>
<li>Perform hand hygiene.</li>
<li>Organise equipment on clean, clutter-free bedside stand or overbed table. | Decreases anxiety and promotes cooperation.
Use of a special IV gown facilitates safe removal of the gown.
Reduces transmission of microorganisms.
Reduces risk of contamination and accidents.
Maintains sterility of equipment and reduces spread of microorganisms.
IV solutions are medications and should be carefully checked by two nurses to reduce risk of error.
Solutions that are discoloured, contain particles or are expired are not to be used. Leaky bags present an opportunity for infection and must not be used.
Prevents bacteria from entering infusion equipment and bloodstream.
Close proximity of roller clamp to drip chamber allows more-accurate regulation of flow rate. Moving clamp to â€˜offâ€™ prevents accidental spillage of fluid and decreases amount of air bubbles when priming line.
Provides access for insertion of infusion tubing into solution.
Prevents contamination of solution from contaminated insertion spike.
Creates suction effects; fluid enters drip chamber to prevent air from entering tubing.
Slow fill of tubing decreases turbulence and chance of bubble formation. Removes air from tubing and permits tubing to fill with solution. Closing the clamp prevents accidental loss of fluid.
Large air bubbles can act as emboli.
Prepares the IV-giving set for connection to the IV cannula.
Maintains system sterility.  |
|  <strong>Preparing the IV solution</strong></li>
<li>Check IV solution and any prescribed additives, using the seven rights of drug administration (see Chapter 31).</li>
<li>Check solution for colour, clarity and expiration date. Check bag for leaks, which is best done before reaching the bedside.</li>
<li>Open infusion set, maintaining sterility of both ends of tubing. Many sets allow for priming of tubing without removal of end cap.</li>
<li>Place roller clamp about 2â€“5 cm below drip chamber and move roller clamp to â€˜offâ€™ position (see illustrations).</li>
<li>Remove protective sheath over IV-giving set tubing port on plastic IV solution bag (see illustration). For bottled IV solution, remove metal cap and metal and rubber disks beneath cap.</li>
<li>Insert infusion set into fluid bag or bottle. Remove protector cap from tubing insertion spike (keeping spike sterile), and insert spike into opening of IV bag (see illustration).</li>
<li>Prime infusion tubing by filling with IV solution. Compress drip chamber and release, allowing it to fill one-third to half full.</li>
<li>Slowly release roller clamp to allow fluid to travel from drip chamber through tubing to needle or catheter adapter. Line can be primed without removing tubing protector cap. Return roller clamp to â€˜offâ€™ position after tubing is primed (filled with IV fluid).</li>
<li>Be certain tubing is clear of air and air bubbles. To remove small air bubbles, firmly tap IV tubing where air bubbles are located. Check entire length of tubing to ensure that all air bubbles are removed (see llustration).</li>
<li>Remove tubing protector cap and replace with â€˜threader link cannulaâ€™ or â€˜lever lock cannulaâ€™, leaving the protector on end of these until ready to attach to the â€˜Interlink injection siteâ€™, which is an Interlink connector attached to the IV cannula. |   |</li>
</ol>
<p>FUNDAMENTALS OF NURSING: CLINICAL SKILLS WORKBOOK</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Insertion of IV catheter/cannula</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>23. Put on disposable gloves.</td><td>Reduces transmission of microorganisms.</td></tr><tr><td>24. Identify accessible vein for IV placement. Apply tourniquet 10â€“15 cm above the proposed insertion site (see illustration). Check for presence of radial pulse. Option: Apply blood pressure cuff instead of tourniquet. Inflate to a level just below patientâ€™s normal diastolic pressure.</td><td>Tourniquet should be tight enough to impede venous return but not occlude arterial flow.</td></tr><tr><td>25. Select the vein.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>a. Use the most distal site in the non-dominant arm, if possible.</td><td>Venepuncture should be performed distal to proximal, which increases the availability of other sites for future IV therapy.</td></tr><tr><td>b. Avoid:</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ areas that are painful to palpation</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ areas that interfere with patientâ€™s activities of daily living (ADLs) or planned procedures.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ sites distal to previous venepuncture site</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ sclerosed or hardened cord-like veins</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ infiltrated site or phlebotic vessels, bruised areas and areas of venous valves or bifurcation</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ fragile dorsal veins in older adults and vessels in an extremity with compromised circulation (e.g. in cases of mastectomy, dialysis graft or paralysis).</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>c. Select a vein large enough for catheter placement.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>d. Palpate the vein by pressing downwards and noting the resilient, soft bouncy feeling as the pressure is released. Always use the same finger to palpate.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>e. Promote venous distension by instructing the patient to open and close the fist several times, lowering the patientâ€™s arm in a dependent position, rubbing or stroking the patientâ€™s arm from distal to proximal below proposed site.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>26. Release tourniquet temporarily and carefully. Clip arm hair with scissors (if necessary). Do not shave area.</td><td>Prevents interruption of venous flow while preparing IV site. Hair impedes venepuncture or adherence of dressing. Shaving can cause microabrasions and predispose patient to infection.</td></tr><tr><td>27. Clean insertion site (see illustration):</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>a. Using a firm, circular motion (middle to outwards) clean with alcohol and allow to dry.</td><td>Povidone-iodine reduces skin surface bacteria; touching the cleaned area introduces organisms from nurseâ€™s hand. Povidone-iodine must dry to be effective in reducing microbial counts.</td></tr><tr><td>b. Clean again, using same method, with povidone-iodine solution and allow to dry; refrain from touching the cleaned site.</td><td>Use of alcohol improves visualisation of the IV site and reduces the possible adverse effects of povidone-iodine.</td></tr><tr><td>If the patient is allergic to iodine, use 70% alcohol and allow to dry for 60 seconds.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>28. Reapply tourniquet.</td><td>Tourniquet time should be as short as possible. Avoid the use of a tourniquet in areas of compromised circulation. The tourniquet should not interfere with arterial blood flow to the extremity.</td></tr><tr><td>29. Perform venepuncture. Anchor vein by placing thumb over vein and by stretching the skin against the direction of insertion 5â€“7.5 cm distal to the site.</td><td>Places needle parallel to vein. When vein is punctured, risk of puncturing posterior vein wall is reduced.</td></tr><tr><td>30. To puncture the vein, the catheter is held in the dominant hand. With the bevel up, the skin is entered in the direction of the vein at a 30- to 45-degree angle (see illustration).</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>FLUID, ELECTROLYTE AND ACID-BASE BALANCE 259</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>31. After just entering into the vein the angle of the catheter is reduced until it is nearly parallel to the skin. If the vein appears to roll (move), the venepuncture is commenced applying counter-tension against the skin just below the entry site using the non-dominant hand.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>32. The catheter is advanced into the vein until blood is seen in the flash back chamber of the catheter (see illustration).</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>33. After the vein is entered, the needle is left stationary and the plastic catheter (over the needle) is advanced into the vein. The plastic catheter should slide forward easily and should not be forced into the vein.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>34. The tourniquet should now be released.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>35. Gentle pressure is applied over the vein proximal to the entry site whilst the needle is removed from the catheter and disposed of into the sharps container. The needle should never be reinserted into the catheter as there is a risk of shearing off a part of the plastic catheter causing an embolus.</td><td>Prevents risk of exposure to blood.</td></tr><tr><td>36. Attach the â€˜Interlink injection siteâ€™ (bung/cap) to the IV cannula and flush the IV line.</td><td>Flushing will reaffirm patency and decrease risk of intra-cannula clotting.</td></tr><tr><td>37. If IV fluids are ordered, remove the protective tubing from the â€˜threaded link cannulaâ€™ or â€˜lever lock cannulaâ€™ on the patient end of the IV-giving set and connect it to the â€˜Interlink injection siteâ€™ (bung/cap) which should now be on the end of the IV cannula. Adjust the flow rate as desired.</td><td>Prompt connection of infusion set maintains patency of vein. Maintains sterility.</td></tr><tr><td>38. If no IV fluids are ordered, flush IV cannula with 1â€“3 mL of sterile normal saline (saline lock), using an Interlink needle through the â€˜Interlink injection siteâ€™ (bung/cap).</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>39. Tape the catheter in place using a transparent (clear) dressing.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>a. Carefully remove adherent backing.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>b. Apply one edge of dressing and then gently smooth remaining dressing over site, leaving end of â€˜Interlink injection siteâ€™ (bung/cap) uncovered (see illustration).</td><td>Transparent dressing allows early observation for phlebitis. Securing the catheter and tubing prevents movement and tension on the device, reducing mechanical irritation and possible phlebitis or infection. It is advisable not to use the â€˜chevronâ€™ taping technique.</td></tr><tr><td>40. Curl a loop of tubing alongside the arm and place a second piece of tape to secure tubing in two places (see illustration).</td><td>Tape on top of tape makes it easier to access hub/tubing junction. Securing loop of tubing reduces risk of dislodging catheter from accidental pull.</td></tr><tr><td>42. Label the IV site with the date, time and initials.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Critical decision point: No more than three attempts at inserting an IV should be made by a single nurse (check agency policy).</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>43. Release roller clamp slowly to begin infusion at a rate to maintain patency of IV line (not necessary with a heparin/ saline lock).</td><td>Permits venous flow and prevents clotting of vein and obstruction of flow of IV solution.</td></tr><tr><td>Critical decision point: Be sure to calculate rate so as not to infuse IV solution too rapidly or too slowly.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>44. Note date and time, gauge size and size of catheter and placement of IV line and dressing.</td><td>Documents when IV was inserted and when subsequent changes in IV cannula are required (check agency policy).</td></tr><tr><td>45. Dispose of used needles in appropriate sharps container. Discard supplies in contaminated waste bin. Remove gloves and perform hand hygiene.</td><td>Reduces transmission of microorganisms and protects staff from injury.</td></tr></tbody></table>

<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>46. Observe patient every hour to determine if fluid is infusing correctly.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>a. Check if correct amount of solution is infused as prescribed by looking at time tape.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>b. Count flow rate.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>c. Check patency of IV catheter or needle: briefly compress cannulated vein proximal to site. Observe for slowing or cessation of IV rate.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>d. Also observe patient during compression of vessel for signs of discomfort.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>e. Inspect insertion site for absence of infiltration, phlebitis, or inflammation (Table 39-19).</td><td>Compression results in mechanical obstruction of vein. When IV catheter is patent, compression results in slowing or cessation of flow rate. No change in flow rate may indicate infiltration.</td></tr><tr><td>Provides continuous evaluation of type and amount of fluid delivered to patient. Hourly inspection prevents accidental fluid overload or inadequate infusion rate and identifies early incidence of vein inflammation or tissue damage.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>47. Observe patient every hour to determine response to therapy (i.e. measure vital signs, conduct postprocedure assessments).</td><td>IV fluids and additives are given to maintain or restore fluid and electrolyte balance. They can also cause unexpected effects, which can be serious.</td></tr><tr><td>RECORDING AND REPORTING</td><td>HOME CARE CONSIDERATIONS</td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Documentation:</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€” sign the infusion therapy chart; complete the time and date started (see illustration)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€” complete and attach a change of line label to the IV tubing</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€” enter the IV fluid type and volume onto the fluid balance chart</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€” document the insertion site and date in the patient record/care plan/infusion chart</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€” attach an IV time label to the IV bag.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Record patientâ€™s response to IV fluid, amount infused in shift report; integrity and patency of system every hour or according to agency policy.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Report to oncoming nursing staff: type of fluid, flow rate, status of venepuncture site, amount of fluid remaining in present solution, expected time to hang next IV bag or bottle and any side effects.</td><td>See Box 39-6.</td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Teach caregiver to apply pressure with sterile gauze if catheter falls out and, if patient is on anticoagulant therapy, to tape several pieces of sterile gauze in place for at least 20 minutes or until bleeding stops.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Teach patient and caregiver to perform bed bath without getting IV tubing wet. For showering, the patient must insert hand and forearm into a plastic bag. Tape bag in place to ensure that IV site is completely covered. IV pumps are not designed to be located in moist bathroom environments during the bathing or showering process. Refer to relevant agency policy for management practices.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Teach patient and family to monitor fluid balance using household measuring devices.</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>

<p>CLINICAL SKILL 39-2: Initiating a peripheral intravenous (IV) infusion</p>
<p>DEMONSTRATES: The ability to effectively and safely initiate a peripheral intravenous infusion</p>
<p>DOMAIN/S (AUS): Professional Practice and Provision and Coordination of Care</p>
<p>DOMAIN/S (NZ): Professional responsibility; management of nursing care; interpersonal relationships; interprofessional healthcare and quality improvement</p>
<p>PERFORMANCE CRITERIA: (numbers indicate National Competency Standards for the Registered Nurse)</p>

<p>FLUID, ELECTROLYTE AND ACID-BASE BALANCE 263
SKILL 39-3</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="regulating-intravenous-flow-rate">Regulating intravenous flow rate<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#regulating-intravenous-flow-rate" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="delegation-considerations">DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delegation-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Regulating IV therapy requires the problem-solving and knowledge-application skills of professional nurses. For this procedure, delegation is inappropriate.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>IV infusion chart with IV order</li>
<li>Watch with second hand</li>
<li>Paper and pencil</li>
<li>IV infusion pump (optional)</li>
<li>Volume-control device (optional)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="steps">STEPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Observe for patency of IV line and needle or catheter:
a. Compress cannulated vein slightly proximal to the end of the catheter and observe the drip chamber.</li>
<li>Check patient's medical record for correct solution, any additives and time of infusion. Record also shows time over which each litre is to infuse.</li>
<li>Check patient's knowledge of how positioning of the IV site affects flow rate.</li>
<li>Verify with patient how venepuncture site feels (e.g. determine whether there is pain or burning).</li>
<li>Have paper and pencil to calculate flow rate.</li>
<li>Know calibration (drop factor) in drops per millilitre of infusion set:
A. Microdrip: 60 drops/mL
B. Macrodrip: 20 drops/mL</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="rationale">RATIONALE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rationale" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>For fluid to infuse at proper rate, IV line and cannula must be free of kinks, knots and clots.</p>
<p>Cessation of drops from drip chamber indicates cannula is in vein. If fluid continues to drip, infiltration may be present.</p>
<p>Seven rights of drug administration ensure correct fluids are given to correct patient.</p>
<p>Fosters patient participation in maintaining most effective position of arm with IV equipment.</p>
<p>Pain or burning may be early indication of phlebitis. Includes patient in decision making.</p>
<p>The beginning student is unfamiliar with IV fluid rates and should use mathematical calculations to obtain correct rate.</p>
<p>Microdrip tubing, also called paediatric tubing, universally delivers 60 drops/mL and is used when small or very precise volumes are to be infused. Macrodrip tubing should be used when large quantities or fast rates are necessary.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="critical-decision-point-know-the-drip-rate-of-the-infusion-sets-your-agency-uses-calculations-must-be-checked-by-two-nurses">Critical decision point: Know the drip rate of the infusion sets your agency uses; calculations must be checked by two nurses.<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#critical-decision-point-know-the-drip-rate-of-the-infusion-sets-your-agency-uses-calculations-must-be-checked-by-two-nurses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol start="7">
<li>Determine hourly rate by dividing volume by hours; for example:</li>
</ol>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1000</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1000\mathrm{mL}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">1000</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mL</span></span></span></span></span></span> over 8 hours = 125 mL/h</p>
<p>3 L over 24 hours = 3000/24 = 125 mL/h</p>
<ol start="8">
<li>Select following formula to calculate flow rate (drops per minute, DPM) after determining mL/h:</li>
</ol>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mtext>Flow&nbsp;rate&nbsp;(DPM)</mtext><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mtext>Vol/h</mtext><mo>Ã—</mo><mtext>Drop&nbsp;factor</mtext></mrow><msup><mtext>Time&nbsp;in&nbsp;minutes</mtext><mo>âˆ—</mo></msup></mfrac></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\text{Flow rate (DPM)} = \frac{\text{Vol/h} \times \text{Drop factor}}{\text{Time in minutes}^*}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Flow&nbsp;rate&nbsp;(DPM)</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.113em; vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.427em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Time&nbsp;in&nbsp;minutes</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7619em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mbin mtight">âˆ—</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Vol/h</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">Ã—</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Drop&nbsp;factor</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">â€‹</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>*Note:</p>
<p>(a) If time is per hour, the hour will be multiplied by 60 to convert the time into minutes.
(b) If the time is already in minutes, no further conversion is required.</p>
<p>E.g.: Using 20 drop factor infusion set</p>
<p>(a) <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>125</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">h</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">125\mathrm{mL/h}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">125</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mL/h</span></span></span></span></span></span> using drop factor of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>20</mn><mo>=</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">20 =</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">20</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span></span></span></span></span></p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>125</mn><mo>Ã—</mo><mn>20</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">h</mi><mo>Ã—</mo><mn>60</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>42</mn><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">M</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\frac{125 \times 20}{1\ \mathrm{h} \times 60} = 42\ \mathrm{DPM}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0908em; <p>(b) <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>100</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">100\mathrm{mL}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">100</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mL</span></span></span></span></span></span> over 20 minutes using drop factor of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>20</mn><mo>=</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">20 =</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">20</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span></span></span></span></span></p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>100</mn><mo>Ã—</mo><mn>20</mn></mrow><mn>20</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>100</mn><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">M</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\frac{100 \times 20}{20} = 100\ \mathrm{DPM}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0074em; <p>E.g.: Using 60 drop factor infusion set</p>
<p>(a) <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>125</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">h</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">125\mathrm{mL/h}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">125</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mL/h</span></span></span></span></span></span> using drop factor of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>60</mn><mo>=</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">60 =</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">60</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span></span></span></span></span></p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>125</mn><mo>Ã—</mo><mn>60</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">h</mi><mo>Ã—</mo><mn>60</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>125</mn><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">M</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\frac{125 \times 60}{1\ \mathrm{h} \times 60} = 125\ \mathrm{DPM}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0908em; vertical-align: -0.7693em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3214em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mspace">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">h</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">Ã—</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord">60</span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">125</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">Ã—</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord">60</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">â€‹</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7693em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">125</span><span class="mspace">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">DPM</span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>(b) <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>100</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">100\mathrm{mL}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">100</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mL</span></span></span></span></span></span> over 20 mins using drop factor of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>60</mn><mo>=</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">60 =</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">60</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span></span></span></span></span></p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>100</mn><mo>Ã—</mo><mn>60</mn></mrow><mn>20</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>300</mn><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">M</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\frac{100 \times 60}{20} = 300\ \mathrm{DPM}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0074em; vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3214em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">20</span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">100</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">Ã—</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord">60</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">â€‹</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">300</span><span class="mspace">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">DPM</span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>Provides even infusion of fluid over prescribed hourly rate.</p>
<p>Once hourly rate has been determined, the formulas for drops per minute (DPM) gives correct flow rate.</p>
<p>FUNDAMENTALS OF NURSING: CLINICAL SKILLS WORKBOOK</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>9. Place adhesive or fluid indicator tape on IV bag next to volume markings (see illustration).</td><td>Time-taping IV bag gives nurse visual cue as to whether fluids are being administered over correct period of time. Time tapes should be used for all IV infusions, including those on therapies infused via electronic infusion devices.</td></tr><tr><td>Critical decision point: Do not use felt-tip pens or permanent markers on IV bags, because ink could contaminate the solution.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>10. Time flow rate by counting drops in drip chamber for 1 minute by watch, then adjust roller clamp to increase or decrease rate of infusion (see illustration).</td><td>Determines whether fluids are being administered too slowly or too fast.</td></tr><tr><td>11. Follow manufacturer's directions for set-up of the infusion (see illustration) using infusion controller or pumps in your organisation:</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>a. Drip regulator must be open while infusion controller or pump is in use.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>b. Monitor infusion rates and IV site for infiltration according to agency policy.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>c. Assess patency and integrity of system when alarm sounds.</td><td>Infusion pumps move fluid by compressing and milking IV tubing, thus propelling fluid through tubing.</td></tr><tr><td>Infusion controllers or pumps are not infallible and do not replace frequent, accurate nursing assessments.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Infusion pumps may continue to infuse IV fluids after an infiltration has begun.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Alarm indicates that electronic eye has noted imprecise number of drops from drip chamber, an empty solution bag or bottle, kink in tubing, closed drip regulator, infiltrated, clotted catheter and/or air in the tubing.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Critical decision point: Special infusion tubing is required for some pumps (check agency policy).</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>12. Follow this procedure for volume-control device (burette):</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>a. Place burette between IV bag and insertion spike of infusion set (see illustration).</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>b. Place 2 hours allotment of fluid into burette.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>c. Assess system at least hourly; add fluid to burette. Regulate flow rate.</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<ol start="13">
<li>Observe patient for signs of overhydration or dehydration to determine response to therapy and restoration of fluid and electrolyte balance.</li>
<li>Evaluate for signs of infiltration: inflammation at site, clot in catheter, kink or knot in infusion tubing. | Prevents IV line from running dry if nurse does not return in exactly 60 minutes. In addition, if there is accidental increase in flow rate, patient receives at most only a 2-hour allotment of fluid.
Reduces risk of sudden increase in fluid volume.
Signs and symptoms of dehydration or overhydration warrant changing rate of fluid infused.
Prevents decrease or cessation of flow rate.  |
|  RECORDING AND REPORTING | HOME CARE CONSIDERATIONS  |
|  â€¢ Record name of solution, rate of infusion, DPM and mL/h in nurses' notes every shift or according to agency policy.
â€¢ Record IV fluid administered every hour on the fluid balance chart.
â€¢ Immediately record in nurses' notes any new IV fluid rates.
â€¢ Document use of any infusion-controlling device and number on that device.
â€¢ At change of shift or when leaving on break, report rate of infusion and amount remaining in bag to be infused to nurse in charge or next nurse assigned to care for patient. | â€¢ Ensure that patient is able and willing to operate the infusion device (if applicable) and administer IV therapy, or that there is a reliable caregiver or nursing support personnel at home to provide this IV therapy care.
â€¢ Teach patient and primary caregiver to time DPM using watch with second hand.  |</li>
</ol>

<p>CLINICAL SKILL 39-3: Regulating intravenous flow rate</p>
<p>DEMONSTRATES: The ability to effectively and safely regulate the flow rate of an intravenous infusion</p>
<p>DOMAIN/S (AUS): Professional Practice and Provision and Coordination of Care</p>
<p>DOMAIN/S (NZ): Professional responsibility; management of nursing care; interpersonal relationships; interprofessional healthcare and quality improvement</p>
<p>PERFORMANCE CRITERIA: (numbers indicate National Competency Standards for the Registered Nurse)</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="changing-intravenous-solution-and-infusion-tubing">Changing intravenous solution and infusion tubing<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#changing-intravenous-solution-and-infusion-tubing" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="delegation-considerations">DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delegation-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Changing IV solutions and tubing requires the problem-solving and knowledge-application skills of professional nurses. For this procedure, delegation is inappropriate.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Bag of IV solution as ordered by doctor</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Time tape</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Infusion tubing</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>J-loop, or short extension tubing (if necessary)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>'Lever lock cannula' or 'threaded lock cannula'; attaches to the IV-giving set and connects the giving set to the cannula.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Normal saline flush:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Syringes</li>
<li>Transparent IV dressing</li>
<li>Tape</li>
<li>Disposable non-sterile gloves</li>
