<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Changing IV solution</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>1. Check doctor's orders.</td><td>Ensures that correct solution will be used.</td></tr><tr><td>Incompatibilities can cause physical, chemical and therapeutic patient changes.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Reveals need for patient instruction.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>2. Determine the compatibility of all IV fluids and additives by consulting appropriate literature or the pharmacy.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>3. Determine patient's understanding of need for continued IV therapy.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>4. Assess patency of current IV access site.</td><td>If patency is not verified, a new IV access site may be needed.</td></tr><tr><td>Notify doctor.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>5. Have next solution prepared at least 30 minutes before needed. If prepared in pharmacy, ensure it has been delivered to the patient's hospital unit. Check that solution is correct and properly labelled. Check solution expiry date.</td><td>Adequate planning reduces risk of clot formation in vein caused by empty IV bag. Checking prevents medication error.</td></tr><tr><td>6. Prepare to change solution when less than 50 mL of fluid remains in bottle or bag.</td><td>Prevents air from entering tubing and vein from clotting from lack of flow.</td></tr><tr><td>7. Prepare patient and family by explaining the procedure, its purpose and what is expected of patient.</td><td>Decreases anxiety and promotes cooperation.</td></tr><tr><td>8. Be sure drip chamber is at least half full.</td><td>Provides fluid to vein while bag is changed.</td></tr><tr><td>9. Perform hand hygiene.</td><td>Reduces transmission of microorganisms.</td></tr><tr><td>10. Prepare new solution for changing. If using plastic bag, remove protective cover from IV tubing port. If using glass bottle, remove metal cap and metal and rubber disks. Determine sterility of bag. Check seven rights of drug administration. Make sure prescribed additives and an additive label have been added. Check solution for colour, clarity, expiry date.</td><td>Permits quick, smooth and organised change from old to new solution. IV solutions are medications and as such should be carefully checked to reduce risk of error.</td></tr><tr><td>11. Move roller clamp to stop flow rate.</td><td>Prevents solution remaining in drip chamber from emptying while changing solutions.</td></tr><tr><td>12. Remove old IV fluid container from IV pole.</td><td>Brings work to nurse's eye level.</td></tr><tr><td>13. Quickly remove spike from old solution bag or bottle and, without touching tip, insert spike into new bag or bottle.</td><td>Reduces risk of solution in drip chamber running dry and maintains sterility.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><strong>Critical decision point: If spike is contaminated, a new IV tubing set is required.</strong></p>
<p>|  14. Hang new bag or bottle of solution. | Gravity assists with delivery of fluid into drip chamber.
Reduces risk of air embolus. Use of an air-eliminating filter also reduces this risk.  |
| --- | --- |
|  15. Check for air in tubing.
a. If bubbles form, they can be removed by closing the roller clamp, stretching the tubing downwards, and tapping the tubing with the finger (the bubbles rise in the fluid to the drip chamber).
b. For a larger amount of air, use a pair of forceps below the injection port of the IV tubing, insert a needle and syringe into a port below the air and aspirate the air into the syringe; remove forceps. Swab port with alcohol and allow to dry before inserting needle into port. Reduce air in tubing by priming slowly instead of allowing a wide-open flow.  |   |</p>
<p>FUNDAMENTALS OF NURSING: CLINICAL SKILLS WORKBOOK</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>16. Make sure drip chamber is one-third to half full. If the drip chamber is too full, pinch off tubing below the drip chamber, invert the container, squeeze the drip chamber, hang up the flask/bottle and insert giving set into the flask.</td><td>Reduces risk of air entering tubing.</td></tr><tr><td>17. Release roller clamp and regulate flow to prescribed rate.</td><td>Maintains measures to restore fluid balance and deliver IV fluid as ordered.</td></tr><tr><td>18. Observe patient for signs of overhydration or dehydration to determine response to IV fluid therapy.</td><td>Provides ongoing evaluation of patient's fluid and electrolyte status.</td></tr><tr><td>19. Observe IV system for patency and development of complications (e.g. infiltration or phlebitis).</td><td>Provides ongoing evaluation of IV system.</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Changing IV tubing</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>20. Determine when new infusion set is needed:</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>a. Agency policy will indicate frequency of routine change for IV administration sets and heparin flushes.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>b. Puncture of infusion tubing.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>c. Contamination of tubing.</td><td>Tubing change no more often than 72-hour intervals unless blood/blood products or TPN has been infused (Pearson, 1996).</td></tr><tr><td>Punctured tubing results in fluid leakage and bacterial contamination.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Contamination of tubing allows entry of bacteria into patient's bloodstream.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>21. Observe for occlusions in existing tubing. Such occlusions can occur after infusion of packed red cells, whole blood, albumin or other blood components.</td><td>Whole blood or blood component product can occlude or partially occlude tubing, because viscous solutions adhere to walls of tubing and decrease the size of the lumen.</td></tr><tr><td>23. Prepare patient and family by explaining the procedure, its purpose and what is expected of patient.</td><td>Decreases anxiety, promotes cooperation and prevents sudden movement of extremity, which could dislodge IV needle or catheter.</td></tr><tr><td>24. Perform hand hygiene.</td><td>Reduces transmission of microorganisms.</td></tr><tr><td>25. Open new infusion set, keeping protective coverings over infusion spike, remove protection from connector at patient end of giving set and attach to 'lever lock cannula' or 'threaded lock cannula'.</td><td>Provides nurse with ready access to new infusion set and maintains sterility of infusion set.</td></tr><tr><td>26. Put on non-sterile, disposable gloves.</td><td>Reduces risk of exposure to HIV, hepatitis and other blood-borne bacteria.</td></tr><tr><td>27. If needle or catheter hub is not visible, remove IV dressing. Do not remove tape securing needle or catheter to skin.</td><td>Catheter or needle hub must be accessible to provide smooth transition when removing old and inserting new tubing.</td></tr><tr><td><strong>28. For IV infusion:</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>a. Move roller clamp on new IV tubing to 'off' position.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>b. Slow rate of infusion by regulating drip rate on old tubing. Be sure rate is at keep vein open (KVO) rate, usually around 20 mL/h.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>c. With old tubing in place, compress drip chamber and fill chamber.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>d. Remove old tubing from solution and hang or tape drip chamber on IV pole 90 cm above IV site.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>e. Place insertion spike of new tubing into old solution bag opening, and hang solution bag on IV pole.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>f. Compress and release drip chamber on new tubing; slowly fill drip chamber one-third to half full.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>g. Slowly open roller clamp, flush tubing with solution. Usually no need to remove protective cap from 'lever lock cannula' or 'threaded lock cannula'.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>h. Turn roller clamp on old tubing to 'off' position.</td><td>Prevents spillage of solution after bag or bottle is spiked.</td></tr><tr><td>Prevents complete infusion of solution that remains in tubing, which can increase risk of occlusion of IV catheter or needle.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Provides surplus of fluid in drip chamber so there is enough fluid to maintain IV patency while changing tubing.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Allows fluid to continue to flow through IV catheter while nurse is preparing new tubing.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Permits flow of fluid from solution into new infusion tubing.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Allows drip chamber to fill and promotes rapid, smooth flow of solution through new tubing.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Removes air from tubing and replaces it with fluid.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Prevents spillage of fluid as tubing is removed from needle or catheter hub.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Removes air to prevent introduction into the vein.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td><strong>29. For heparin lock:</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>a. Swab 'lever lock cannula' or 'threaded lock cannula' (bung/injection cap) with alcohol.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>b. Insert syringe with 1â€“3 mL saline and inject through the bung into the loop or short extension tubing.</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>FLUID, ELECTROLYTE AND ACID-BASE BALANCE 269</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>30. Stabilise hub of catheter or needle and apply pressure over vein just above insertion site. Gently pull out old tubing (see illustration). Maintain stability of hub and quickly insert 'lever lock cannula' or 'threaded lock cannula' on the IV-giving set into the 'Interlink injection site' (bung) on the cannula (see illustrations). Re-tape IV tubing along arm.</td><td>Prevents accidental displacement of catheter or needle.</td></tr><tr><td>31. Open roller clamp on new tubing. Allow solution to run rapidly for 30-60 seconds.</td><td>Prevents clot formation in catheter or needle and backflow of blood.</td></tr><tr><td>32. Regulate IV drip according to doctor's orders and monitor rate hourly (see illustration).</td><td>Permits IV solution to enter catheter to prevent catheter occlusion.</td></tr><tr><td>33. If necessary, apply new dressing.</td><td>Maintains infusion flow at prescribed rate.</td></tr><tr><td>34. Discard old tubing in contaminated waste bin.</td><td>Reduces risk of bacterial infection from skin.</td></tr><tr><td>35. Remove and dispose of gloves. Wash hands.</td><td>Reduces accidental transmission of microorganisms.</td></tr><tr><td>36. Evaluate flow rate and observe connection site for leakage.</td><td>Maintains prescribed rate of flow of IV fluid and determines if fit is secure.</td></tr><tr><td>RECORDING AND REPORTING</td><td>HOME CARE CONSIDERATIONS</td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Record changing of tubing and solution on patient's record. A special parenteral therapy flow sheet may be used.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Place a piece of tape or preprinted label with the date and time of tubing change and attach to tubing below the level of drip chamber.</td><td>â€¢ Emphasise to patient and family the importance of changing solutions when IV tubing still contains fluid.</td></tr></tbody></table>

<p>CLINICAL SKILL 39-4: Changing intravenous solution and infusion tubing</p>
<p>DEMONSTRATES: The ability to effectively and safely change intravenous solution and infusion tubing</p>
<p>DOMAIN/S (AUS): Professional Practice and Provision and Coordination of Care</p>
<p>DOMAIN/S (NZ): Professional responsibility; management of nursing care; interpersonal relationships; interprofessional healthcare and quality improvement</p>

<p>SKILL 39-5</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="changing-a-peripheral-intravenous-dressing">Changing a peripheral intravenous dressing<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#changing-a-peripheral-intravenous-dressing" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="delegation-considerations">DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delegation-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Changing a peripheral IV dressing requires the problem-solving and knowledge-application skills of professional nurses. For this procedure, delegation is inappropriate.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Povidone-iodine swab/stick according to agency policy</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Alcohol swab/stick</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Adhesive remover (if needed)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Strips of non-allergenic tape</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Disposable gloves</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>For gauze dressing:</p>
<ul>
<li>Sterile 5 cm Ã— 5 cm gauze pad</li>
</ul>
<p>OR</p>
<p>For transparent dressing:</p>
<ul>
<li>Sterile transparent dressing</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="steps">STEPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Determine when dressing was last changed. Many institutions require nurse to write date and time on dressing and date the device was first placed.</li>
<li>Observe present dressing for moisture and intactness.</li>
<li>Observe IV system for proper functioning or complications: kinks in infusion tubing or IV catheter. Palpate the catheter site through the intact dressing for inflammation or after subjective complaints of pain or burning.</li>
<li>Inspect exposed catheter site for swelling or infiltration.</li>
<li>Assess patient's understanding of need for continued IV infusion.</li>
<li>Explain procedure and purpose to patient and family. Explain that affected extremity must be held still and how long procedure will take.</li>
<li>Perform hand hygiene. Put on disposable gloves.</li>
<li>Remove tape, gauze and/or transparent dressing from old dressing one layer at a time, leaving tape that secures IV needle or catheter in place. Be cautious if catheter tubing becomes tangled between two layers of dressing. When removing transparent dressing, hold catheter hub and tubing with non-dominant hand.</li>
<li>Observe insertion site for signs and/or symptoms of infection, namely redness, swelling and exudate.</li>
<li>If infiltration, phlebitis or clot occurs or if ordered by doctor, discontinue infusion.</li>
<li>If IV is infusing properly, gently remove any tape securing needle or catheter. Stabilise needle or catheter with one hand. Use adhesive remover to clean skin and remove adhesive residue, if needed.</li>
<li>Keep one finger over catheter at all times until tape or dressing is replaced.</li>
<li>Using circular motion, clean peripheral IV insertion site with alcohol, then povidone-iodine solution (check that patient is not allergic to iodine) starting at insertion site and working outwards, creating concentric circles (see illustration). Allow each solution to dry for 2 minutes.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="rationale">RATIONALE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rationale" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Provides information regarding length of time present dressing has been in place. Transparent occlusive dressing usually only changed when integrity has been breached; central venous catheter (CVC) changed weekly (Rosenthal, 2003).</p>
<p>Moisture is a medium for bacterial growth and renders dressing contaminated.</p>
<p>Unexplained decrease in flow rate requires the nurse to investigate placement and patency of the IV catheter. Pain can be associated with both phlebitis and infiltration.</p>
<p>Indicates fluid infusing into surrounding tissues. Will require removal of IV catheter.</p>
<p>Determines need for patient instruction.</p>
<p>Decreases anxiety, promotes cooperation and gives patient timeframe around which personal activities can be planned.</p>
<p>Reduces transmission of microorganisms.</p>
<p>Prevents accidental displacement of catheter or needle.</p>
<p>Exposes venepuncture site. Stabilisation prevents accidental displacement of catheter or needle. Adhesive residue decreases ability of new tape to adhere tightly to skin.</p>
<p>Prevents decannulation from vein.</p>
<p>Circular motion prevents cross-contamination from skin bacteria near venepuncture site.</p>
<p>Critical decision point: Do not tape over connection of access tubing or port to IV catheter.</p>
<p>FLUID, ELECTROLYTE AND ACID-BASE BALANCE 273</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>14. Apply new transparent or gauze dressing. (Tape the catheter in place using a transparent (clear) dressing.)</td><td>Ensures protection of IV site and reduces chance of infection.</td></tr><tr><td>15. Remove and discard gloves and used materials into contaminated waste bin.</td><td>Reduces transmission of microorganisms.</td></tr><tr><td>16. Anchor IV tubing with additional pieces of tape. <div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="oxygenation">Oxygenation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#oxygenation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="overview">Overview<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#overview" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Oxygen is required to sustain life. The function of the cardiac and respiratory systems is to supply the body's oxygen demands. Cardiopulmonary physiology involves delivery of deoxygenated blood to the right side of the heart and the pulmonary circulation, and movement of oxygenated blood from the lungs to the left side of the heart and the tissues. Blood is oxygenated through the mechanisms of ventilation, respiration, perfusion and transport of respiratory gases. Neural and chemical regulators control the rate and depth of respiration in response to changing tissue oxygen demands. Three factors that affect oxygenation are hyperventilation, hypoventilation and hypoxia.</p>
<p>The promotion of lung expansion, mobilisation of secretions and maintenance of a patent airway help patients to meet their oxygenation needs. Some patients, however, require oxygen therapy to keep a healthy level of tissue oxygenation. Oxygen therapy involves the delivery of oxygen using a variety of sources, including nasal cannula, nasal catheters and face masks. Nurses can measure the effectiveness of oxygen therapy by monitoring pulse oximetry. In addition, patients who are unable to maintain their airway may require the nurse to clear or suction oropharyngeal and nasopharyngeal secretions.</p>
<p>Life-threatening emergency situations arise in the presence of inadequate oxygenation and perfusion. A cardiac arrest is the sudden cessation of cardiac output and circulation. When this occurs, oxygen is not delivered to tissues, carbon dioxide is not transported from tissues, tissue metabolism becomes anaerobic, and metabolic and respiratory acidosis occurs. Permanent heart, brain and other tissue damage occurs within 4â€“6 minutes. The nurse must initiate basic and/or advanced life support skills in the presence of a cardiac arrest.</p>
<p>This chapter explores the psychomotor skills that focus on specific nursing care associated with the maintenance and supply of adequate oxygenation and perfusion. The skills addressed include suctioning (40â€“1), care of patients with chest tubes (40â€“2), applying a nasal cannula or oxygen mask (40â€“3), using home liquid oxygen equipment (40â€“4) and cardiopulmonary resuscitationâ€”basic life support (40â€“5).</p>
<p>OXYGENATION 277</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="skill-40-1">SkILL 40-1<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#skill-40-1" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="sectioning">Sectioning<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sectioning" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="delegation-considerations">DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delegation-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Suctioning requires the problem-solving and knowledge-application skills of professional nurses. Delegation is inappropriate.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Appropriate-size suction catheter (smallest diameter that will remove secretions effectively) or Yankauer catheter (oral suction)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Small Y adapter (if catheter does not have a suction-control port)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Two sterile gloves or one sterile and one non-sterile glove</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Sterile basin</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Sterile normal saline solution or water (about 50 mL)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Clean towel</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Portable or wall suction</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Connecting tube (1.5 metres)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Nasal or oral airway (if indicated)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Mask or face shield</p>
</li>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="steps">STEPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Assess signs and symptoms of upper and lower airway obstruction requiring nasotracheal or orotracheal suctioning, including respiratory rate or adventitious sounds, nasal secretions, drooling, gastric secretions or vomitus in mouth.</li>
</ol>
<p>Assess signs and symptoms associated with hypoxia and hypercapnia: increased respiratory rate and/or increased pulse rate, decreased depth of breathing, low oxygen saturations, elevated blood pressure, pallor, cyanosis and dyspnoea, apprehension, anxiety, decreased ability to concentrate, lethargy, decreased level of consciousness (especially acute), increased fatigue, dizziness, behavioural changes (especially irritability).</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Determine factors that normally influence upper or lower airway functioning.</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Fluid status
b. Lack of humidity
c. Infection
d. Anatomy</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>
<p>Assess patient's understanding of procedure.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Obtain medical prescription if indicated by agency policy.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Explain to patient how procedure will help clear airway and relieve breathing problems and that temporary coughing, sneezing, gagging or shortness of breath is normal. Encourage patient to cough out secretions. Practise coughing, if able. Splint surgical incisions, if necessary.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Help patient to assume position comfortable for nurse and patient (usually semi-Fowler's or sitting upright with head hyperextended, unless contraindicated).</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="rationale">RATIONALE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rationale" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Physical signs and symptoms result from decreased oxygen to tissues as well as pooling of secretions in upper and lower airways.</p>
<p>Fluid overload may increase amount of secretions. Dehydration promotes thicker secretions.</p>
<p>The environment influences secretion formation and gas exchange, necessitating airway suctioning when patient cannot clear secretions effectively.</p>
<p>Patients with respiratory infections are prone to increased secretions that are thicker and sometimes more difficult to expectorate.</p>
<p>Abnormal anatomy can impair normal drainage of secretions. For example, nasal swelling, a deviated septum or facial fractures may impair nasal drainage. Tumours in or around the lower airway may impair secretion removal by occluding or externally compressing the lumen of the airway.</p>
<p>Reveals need for patient instruction and encourages cooperation.</p>
<p>Some institutions require a medical prescription for tracheal suctioning.</p>
<p>Encourages cooperation and minimises risks, anxiety and pain.</p>
<p>Reduces stimulation of gag reflex, decreases patient discomfort, assists secretion drainage and prevents aspiration and nurse strain. Hyperextension facilitates insertion of catheter into trachea.</p>
<p>FUNDAMENTALS OF NURSING: CLINICAL SKILLS WORKBOOK</p>

Positioning: In some instances turning patientâ€™s head to right helps nurse suction left mainstem bronchus; turning head to left helps nurse suction right mainstem bronchus. If resistance is felt after insertion of catheter for maximum recommended distance, catheter has probably hit carina. Pull catheter back 1 cm before applying suction.</td><td>Application of suction pressure while introducing catheter into trachea increases risk of damage to mucosa and increases risk of hypoxia because of removal of entrained oxygen present in airways. Epiglottis is open on inspiration and facilitates insertion into trachea. Patient should cough. If patient gags or becomes nauseated, catheter is most likely in oesophagus and must be removed.</td></tr><tr><td>Critical decision point: Use nasal approach and perform tracheal suctioning before pharyngeal suctioning whenever possible. The mouth and pharynx contain more bacteria than the trachea does. If copious oral secretions are present before beginning the procedure, suction mouth with Yankauer suction device.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(3) Apply intermittent suction for up to 10â€“15 seconds by placing and releasing non-dominant thumb over vent of catheter and slowly withdrawing catheter while rotating it back and forth between dominant thumb and forefinger. Encourage patient to cough. Replace oxygen device, if applicable.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(4) Rinse catheter and connecting tubing with normal saline or water until cleared.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(5) Assess for need to repeat suctioning procedure. Allow adequate time between suction passes for ventilation and oxygenation. Ask patient to deep-breathe and cough. Replace the oxygen delivery device.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(6) When pharynx and trachea are sufficiently cleared of secretions, perform oropharyngeal suctioning to clear mouth of secretions. Do not suction nose again after suctioning mouth.</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>C. Tracheostomy tubeâ€”permanent and longstanding
(1) Hyperoxygenate patient before suctioning (approx. 30 seconds) (Pierce, 2007) if patient is being administered supplemental oxygen.
(2) Open swivel adapter or if necessary remove oxygen or humidity delivery device with non-dominant hand. If a closed system suction device is in place, no disconnection is necessary. The catheter is inserted through the plastic sheath which protects the catheter.
(3) Without applying suction, gently but quickly insert catheter using dominant thumb and forefinger into artificial airway (best to time catheter insertion with inspiration) until resistance is met or patient coughs; then pull back 1 cm.
(4) Apply suction either intermittently or continuously. Continuous suction may retrieve more secretions but increases volume of gas suctioned. Intermittent suction can be applied by placing and releasing non-dominant thumb over vent of catheter. Intermittent suction is recommended if catheter is in contact with tracheal walls and not in lumen of the tracheostomy tube. Slowly withdraw catheter while rotating it back and forth between dominant thumb and forefinger (Pierce, 2007). Encourage patient to cough. Watch for respiratory distress. | Intermittent suction and rotation of catheter prevent injury to mucosa. If catheter â€˜grabsâ€™ mucosa, remove thumb to release suction. Suctioning longer than 10 seconds can cause cardiopulmonary compromise, usually from hypoxaemia or vagal overload.</p>
<p>Removes secretions from catheter. Secretions that remain in suction catheter or connecting tubing decrease suctioning efficiency.</p>
<p>Observe for alterations in cardiopulmonary status. Suctioning can induce hypoxaemia, arrhythmias, laryngospasm and bronchospasm. Deep-breathing reventilates and reoxygenates alveoli. Repeated passes clear the airway of excessive secretions but can also remove oxygen and may induce laryngospasm.</p>
<p>Removes upper airway secretions. More microorganisms are generally present in mouth.</p>
<p>Preoxygenation converts large proportion of resident lung gas to 100% oxygen to offset amount used in metabolic consumption while oxygenation is interrupted during suctioning.</p>
<p>Exposes artificial airway.</p>
<p>Application of suction pressure while introducing catheter into trachea increases risk of damage to tracheal mucosa, as well as increased hypoxia related to removal of entrained oxygen present in airways. Pulling back stimulates cough and removes catheter from mucosal wall.</p>
<p>Rotation of catheter exposes inlet of catheter to an increased surface area to retrieve more secretions.  |
|  Critical decision point: If patient develops respiratory distress during the suction procedure, immediately withdraw catheter and supply additional oxygen and breaths as needed. Oxygen can be administered directly through the catheter in an emergency. Disconnect suction and attach oxygen at prescribed flow rate through the catheter.  |   |</p>
<p>FUNDAMENTALS OF NURSING: CLINICAL SKILLS WORKBOOK</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>(5) Close swivel adapter or replace oxygen delivery device. Encourage patient to deep-breathe, if able.</td><td>Reoxygenates and re-expands alveoli. Suctioning can cause hypoxaemia and atelectasis.</td></tr><tr><td>(6) Rinse catheter and connecting tubing with normal saline until clear. Use continuous suction.</td><td>Removes catheter secretions. Secretions left in tubing decrease suction and provide environment for microorganism growth. Secretions left in connecting tube decrease suctioning efficiency.</td></tr><tr><td>(7) Assess patientâ€™s cardiopulmonary status for secretion clearance and complications. Repeat Steps (1) to (6) once or twice more to clear secretions. If more than one suction pass is needed (and closed system suction is not in situ), use a new suction catheter for each pass. Allow adequate time (at least 1 full minute) between suction passes for ventilation and re-oxygenation. Replace oxygen delivery device during rest times.</td><td>Suctioning can induce arrhythmias, hypoxia and bronchospasm and impair cerebral circulation or adversely affect haemodynamics. Repeated passes with suction catheter clear airway of excessive secretions and promote improved oxygenation.</td></tr><tr><td>(8) Perform nasopharyngeal and oropharyngeal suctioning. After nasopharyngeal and oropharyngeal suctioning is performed, catheter is contaminated; do not reinsert into tracheostomy tube.</td><td>Removes upper airway secretions.</td></tr><tr><td>16. When suctioning is completed, roll catheter around fingers of dominant hand. Pull glove off inside out so that catheter remains coiled in glove. Pull off other glove over first glove in same way to seal in contaminants. Discard in contaminated waste receptacle. Turn off suction device.</td><td>Reduces transmission of microorganisms.</td></tr><tr><td>17. Remove towel, place in appropriate receptacle and reposition patient as indicated by patientâ€™s condition. Nurse may need to wear clean gloves for personal care.</td><td>Reduces transmission of microorganisms. Promotes comfort.</td></tr><tr><td>18. If indicated, readjust oxygen to original level because patientâ€™s blood oxygen level should have returned to baseline.</td><td>Simsâ€™ position encourages drainage and reduces risk of aspiration.</td></tr><tr><td>19. Discard remainder of normal saline into appropriate receptacle. If basin is disposable, place into appropriate receptacle. If basin is reusable, rinse and place in soiled utility room.</td><td>Prevents absorption atelectasis and oxygen toxicity while allowing patient time to re-oxygenate blood.</td></tr><tr><td>20. Remove goggles and mask or face shield. Discard disposable items and perform hand hygiene.</td><td>Reduces transmission of microorganisms.</td></tr><tr><td>21. Ask patient if breathing is easier and if congestion is decreased.</td><td>Provides subjective confirmation that airway obstruction is relieved with suctioning procedure.</td></tr><tr><td>24. Observe airway secretions.</td><td>Provides data to document presence or absence of respiratory tract infection.</td></tr><tr><td>RECORDING AND REPORTING</td><td>HOME CARE CONSIDERATIONS</td></tr><tr><td>â€¢ Record amount, consistency, colour and odour of secretions and patientâ€™s response to procedure; document patientâ€™s presuctioning and postsuctioning respiratory status.</td><td>â€¢ In an emergency, normal saline can be made at home by adding 2 teaspoons of table salt to 1 litre of boiled water. This solution should be freshly made and not stored.</td></tr></tbody></table>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="care-of-patients-with-chest-tubes">Care of patients with chest tubes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#care-of-patients-with-chest-tubes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="delegation-considerations">DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delegation-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This task requires the problem-solving and knowledge-application abilities of a professional nurse and should not be delegated. Nurse assistants may help with positioning.</p>
<ul>
<li>Instruct care provider in the proper positioning of a patient with chest tubes to facilitate drainage.</li>
<li>Explain to care provider the appropriate set-up of drainage equipment for the type of system to be used.</li>
<li>Instruct care provider to inform nurse of any changes in the vital signs, chest tube drainage or excessive bubbling (air loss) in water-seal chamber.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Chest drainage system (bottles or disposable system)</li>
<li>Suction source and set-up (wall canister or portable)</li>
<li>Non-sterile gloves</li>
<li>Sterile irrigation saline or sterile water (500 mL bottle)</li>
<li>Tape (5 cm width)</li>
<li>Sterile gauze sponges</li>
<li>Two artery forceps</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="steps">STEPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Assess patient for respiratory distress and chest pain, breath sounds over affected lung area and stable vital signs (see Chapter 27).</li>
<li>Observe for increased respiratory distress.</li>
<li>Observe:
a. Chest tube dressing.
b. Tubing for kinks, dependent loops or clots.
c. Chest drainage system, which should be upright and below level of tube insertion.</li>
<li>Provide two artery forceps for each chest tube, attached to top of patient's bed with adhesive tape. Chest tubes are clamped only under specific circumstances. Double-clamp close to the patient's chest only in the following circumstances:
a. To assess air leak.
b. To quickly empty or change collection bottle or chamber; performed by nurse who has received training in procedure.
c. To change disposable systems; have new system ready to be connected before clamping tube so that transfer can be rapid and drainage system re-established.
d. To change a broken water-seal bottle in the event that no sterile solution container is available.
e. To assess if patient is ready to have chest tube removed (which is done by medical order); the nurse must monitor patient for re-accumulation of pneumothorax.</li>
<li>Position patient:
a. Semi-Fowler's position to evacuate air (pneumothorax).
b. High-Fowler's position to drain fluid (haemothorax).</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="rationale">RATIONALE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rationale" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Signs and symptoms reflect improvement in respiratory distress and chest pain after insertion of chest tube.</p>
<p>Signs and symptoms of increased respiratory distress and/or chest pain, decrease in breath sounds over the affected and non-affected lungs, marked cyanosis, asymmetrical chest movements, presence of subcutaneous emphysema around tube insertion site or neck, hypotension and tachycardia. Notify medical staff immediately.</p>
<p>Ensures that tubing is patent.</p>
<p>Maintains a patent, freely draining system, preventing fluid accumulation in chest cavity.</p>
<p>System must be in this position to function properly and prevent air or water flowing back into the pleural cavity.</p>
<p>Artery forceps have a covering to prevent forceps from perforating chest tube.</p>
<p>Permits optimal drainage of air. Air rises to highest point in chest. Pneumothorax tubes are usually placed on anterior aspect at midclavicular line, second or third intercostal space.</p>
<p>Permits optimal drainage of fluid. Posterior tubes are placed on midaxillary line, eighth or ninth intercostal space.</p>
<p>FUNDAMENTALS OF NURSING: CLINICAL SKILLS WORKBOOK</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>6. Maintain tube connection between chest and drainage tubes intact and taped. Connections should be taped longitudinally not circumferentially.</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>a. Water-seal vent must be without occlusion.
b. Suction-control chamber vent must be without occlusion when suction is used.</p>
<ol start="7">
<li>
<p>Coil excess tubing on mattress next to patient. Secure with rubber band and safety pin or system's clamp.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Adjust tubing to hang in straight line from top of mattress to drainage chamber. If chest tube is draining fluid, indicate time (e.g. 0900) that drainage was begun on drainage bottle's adhesive tape or on write-on surface of disposable commercial system.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Passively drain any fluid in the tubing into the collection chamber. Strip or milk chest tube only if indicated:
a. Postoperative mediastinal chest tubes are manipulated if nursing assessment indicates obstruction of drainage secondary to clots or debris in tubing.
b. Postoperative assessment is done every 15 minutes for the first 2 hours. This assessment interval then changes based on patient's status. | Secures chest tube to drainage system and reduces risk of air leak causing breaks in airtight system. Inadvertent loosening of connections beneath the tape of circumferential taping may go unnoticed as tape covers the join completely.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>Permits displaced air to pass into atmosphere.</p>
<p>Provides safety factor of releasing excess negative pressure into atmosphere.</p>
<p>Prevents excess tubing from hanging over edge of mattress in dependent loop. Drainage could collect in loop and occlude drainage system.</p>
<p>Provides a baseline for continuous assessment of type and quality of drainage.</p>
<p>Stripping is controversial and should be performed only if hospital policy permits it and there is a medical prescription. Stripping creates a high degree of negative pressure and has potential to pull lung tissue or pleura into drainage holes of chest tube (Pierce, 2007).  |
|  Critical decision point: Review agency policy before milking or stripping chest tubes. In almost all instances this is contraindicated and not undertaken.  |   |
|  10. Perform hand hygiene.
11. Observe:
a. Chest tube dressing, tubing and chest tube drainage system, which should be upright and below level of tube insertion.
b. Water seal for fluctuations with patient's inspiration and expiration.
c. Bubbling (air loss) in water-seal bottle or chamber (see Table 40-9).</p>
<p>d. Type and amount of fluid drainage. Nurse should note colour and amount of drainage, patient's vital signs and skin colour.
(1) Less than 50â€“300 mL/h immediately postoperative in mediastinal chest tube; approximately 500 mL in first 24 hours; dark-red drainage is expected early in postoperative period, turning serous with time.
(2) Between 100 and 300 mL of fluid may drain in posterior chest tube during first 2 hours after insertion; rate will decrease after 2 hours; 500â€“1000 mL can be expected in first 24 hours; drainage will be grossly bloody during first several hours after surgery and then change to serous.
e. Bubbling in the suction-control chamber (when suction is being used) (see Table 40-9). | Reduces transmission of infection.</p>
<p>Ensures that tube is patent, and notes any drainage. Maintains tubing free of kinks and dependent loops. Note presence of clots or debris in tubing.</p>
<p>Fluid should rise in water seal with inspiration and fall with expiration, indicating that system is functioning properly.</p>
<p>When system is initially connected to patient, bubbles are expected in the underwater seal chamber from air that was present in system and in patient's intrapleural space. After a short period, bubbling will stop. Fluid will continue to fluctuate in water seal on inspiration and expiration until lung is re-expanded or system becomes occluded. It is important that the correct chamber is visualised to record the bubbling of air loss, i.e. underwater seal chamber and NOT the suction control chamber.</p>
<p>Sudden gush of drainage may be retained blood and not active bleeding. Increase in drainage can be result of patient position.</p>
<p>Re-expansion of lungs forces drainage into tube. Coughing can also cause large gushes of drainage.</p>
<p>Excessive amounts and/or continued presence of frank, bloody drainage after first several hours of surgery should be reported to the senior nurse or medical staff, along with patient's vital signs and respiratory status.</p>
<p>Suction-control chamber has constant, gentle bubbling. Tubing to suction source should be free of obstruction, and suction source should be turned on to appropriate setting.  |
|  RECORDING AND REPORTING | HOME CARE CONSIDERATIONS  |
|  â€¢ Record in nurses' notes patency of chest tubes, presence of drainage, presence of fluctuations, patient's vital signs, chest dressing status, type of suction and level of comfort. | â€¢ If patient goes home with chest tube (i.e. empyema), teach patient and family to care for chest tube and drainage bottle.  |</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="applying-a-nasal-cannula-or-oxygen-mask">Applying a nasal cannula or oxygen mask<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#applying-a-nasal-cannula-or-oxygen-mask" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="delegation-considerations">DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delegation-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<ul>
<li>Nasal cannula (see Figure 40-19) or oxygen mask</li>
<li>Oxygen tubing</li>
<li>Humidifier, if indicated</li>
<li>Sterile water for humidification, if indicated</li>

<li>Oxygen flowmeter</li>

<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>1. Inspect patient for signs and symptoms associated with hypoxia and presence of airway secretions.</td><td>Left untreated, hypoxia can produce cardiac arrhythmias and death. Presence of airway secretions decreases effectiveness of oxygen delivery.</td></tr><tr><td>Critical decision point: Patients with sudden changes in their vital signs, level of consciousness or behaviour may be experiencing profound hypoxia. Patients who demonstrate subtle changes over time may have worsening of a chronic or existing condition or a new medical condition.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>2. Explain to patient and family what the procedure entails and the purpose of oxygen therapy.</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<ol start="3">
<li>Perform hand hygiene.</li>
<li>Attach nasal cannula to oxygen tubing and attach to humidified oxygen source adjusted to prescribed flow rate.</li>
<li>Place tips of cannula into patientâ€™s nares (see illustration) and adjust elastic headband or plastic slide until cannula fits snugly and comfortably (see illustration).</li>
<li>Maintain sufficient slack on oxygen tubing and secure to patientâ€™s clothes.</li>
<li>Check cannula every 8 hours and keep humidification jar filled at all times.</li>
<li>Observe patientâ€™s nares and superior surface of both ears for skin breakdown.</li>
<li>Check oxygen flow rate and prescriptions every 8 hours (see illustration).</li>
<li>Wash hands.</li>
<li>Inspect patient for relief of symptoms associated with hypoxia. | Decreases patientâ€™s anxiety, which reduces oxygen consumption and increases patient cooperation.
Reduces transmission of microorganisms.
Prevents drying of nasal and oral mucous membranes and airway secretions.
Directs flow of oxygen into patientâ€™s upper respiratory tract. Patient is more likely to keep cannula in place if it fits comfortably.
Allows patient to turn head without dislodging cannula and reduces pressure on tips of nares.
Ensures patency of cannula and oxygen flow. Prevents inhalation of dehumidified oxygen.
Oxygen therapy can cause drying of nasal mucosa. Pressure on ears from cannula tubing or elastic can cause skin irritation.
Ensures delivery of prescribed oxygen flow rate and patency of cannula.
Reduces transmission of microorganisms.
Indicates that hypoxia is corrected or reduced.  |
|  Critical decision point: Note whether current oxygen therapy is meeting patientâ€™s oxygenation needs. Determine what factors have changed, resulting in new assessment findings.  |   |
|  RECORDING AND REPORTING | HOME CARE CONSIDERATIONS  |
|  â€¢ Document oxygen delivery device and litre flow in medical record.
â€¢ Document patient and family education.
â€¢ Report oxygen delivery device, litre flow and response to changes in therapy to oncoming shift. | â€¢ If patient is to have home oxygen therapy, teach patient and family how to use the oxygen equipment and properly apply the oxygen delivery device (see Skill 40-4).  |</li>
</ol>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="using-home-liquid-oxygen-equipment">Using home liquid oxygen equipment<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#using-home-liquid-oxygen-equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<li>Instruct care provider in unexpected outcomes associated with use of home oxygen and the need to inform the nurse if any occur.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Nasal cannula equipment (see Skill 40-3)</li>
<li>Primary and portable liquid oxygen source for mobility (see Figure 40-23)</li>
</ul>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>1. Assess:</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>a. Patient for need for home oxygen therapy.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>b. Patient's or family's ability to use oxygen equipment properly, or for appropriate use of oxygen equipment in home setting.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>c. Patient's and family's ability to observe for signs and symptoms of hypoxia: apprehension, anxiety, decreased ability to concentrate, decreased level of consciousness, increased fatigue, dizziness, behavioural changes, increased pulse, increased respiratory rate, pallor or cyanosis of the mucous membranes.</td><td>Candidates for home oxygen have an arterial partial pressure of oxygen (PaOâ‚‚) of â‰¤55 mmHg or an oxygen saturation of 88% on room air, or a PaOâ‚‚ of 55â€“59 mmHg or an oxygen saturation of 86â€“89% with evidence of right heart failure, cor pulmonale or polycythaemia.</td></tr><tr><td>Physical or cognitive impairments may require instructing family members or significant others on how to operate home oxygen equipment.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Hypoxia can occur at home despite use of oxygen therapy. It can be caused by worsening of patient's physical condition or another underlying condition, such as a change in the respiratory status.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>2. Explain procedure to patient and family.</td><td>Reinforces information given to patient and family; allows opportunity to ask questions.</td></tr><tr><td>3. Perform hand hygiene.</td><td>Reduces transmission of infection.</td></tr><tr><td>4. Demonstrate steps for preparation and completion of oxygen therapy.</td><td>Teaches psychomotor skill and enables patient to ask questions.</td></tr><tr><td>5. Prepare primary and portable oxygen.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>a. Place primary oxygen source in clutter-free environment.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>b. Check oxygen levels of both sources by reading gauge on top (see illustrations).</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>c. Refill portable source by placing on top of primary source and pressing down firmly. Check oxygen gauge to determine fullness of portable source (see illustration).</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>d. Select prescribed rate.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>e. Connect nasal cannula and oxygen tubing to oxygen source.</td><td>Primary oxygen source replaces compressed oxygen cylinders.</td></tr><tr><td>Ensures adequate amount of oxygen available for use and timely refills of primary source.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Provides secure connection and prevents leakage of oxygen into room. If not seated securely, the cold liquid oxygen will leak out, creating a snowlike precipitate.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Ensures delivery of prescribed amount of oxygen.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Connects oxygen source to delivery method.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>6. Have patient and family perform each step with guidance from the nurse.</td><td>Allows nurse to correct for errors in technique and discuss their implications.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Critical decision point: Discuss signs and symptoms of respiratory tract infection: fever; increased sputum production; change in colour, consistency or smell of sputum; difficulty clearing secretions; or shortness of breath.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="recording-and-reporting">RECORDING AND REPORTING<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#recording-and-reporting" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Record patient's and family's ability to safely use the home oxygen equipment.</li>
<li>If multiple care providers are in the home, report the type of equipment, patient's and family's understanding and any concerns to the other care providers.</li>
</ul>
<p>OXYGENATION 291</p>

<p>FUNDAMENTALS OF NURSING: CLINICAL SKILLS WORKBOOK</p>
<p>SKILL 40-5</p>
<p>Cardiopulmonary resuscitationâ€”basic life support</p>
<p>DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS
Cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) can be performed by trained staff.</p>
<ul>
<li>Review procedures for opening the airway if the patient has any risk of cervical neck trauma.</li>
<li>Caution care provider regarding differences between infants, children and adults.</li>
</ul>
<p>EQUIPMENT</p>
<ul>
<li>Ambu-bag, if available</li>
<li>CPR pocket mask or barrier device, if available</li>
<li>Chest compression board, if available and required. Hospital beds have a sufficiently firm base to perform compressions.</li>
<li>Gloves, if available</li>
<li>Resuscitation trolley, if available</li>
<li>Face shield, if available</li>
</ul>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>1. Danger</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Check for danger, e.g. potential electrical hazard.</td><td>Protects operator from potential injury.</td></tr><tr><td>2. Responsiveness</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Determine whether patient is unconscious by gently shaking patient and speaking loudly, giving simple commands such as 'Open your eyes, squeeze my hand'. If no response, grasp 2.5â€“5 cm of the trapezius muscle close to where the shoulder meets the neck. Squeeze and twist.</td><td>Confirms that patient is unconscious as opposed to intoxicated, sleeping or hearing-impaired.</td></tr><tr><td>3. Send for help</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Activate emergency medical services. Know telephone numbers for emergency services, both in the community and in the hospital.</td><td>The majority of adult victims are in ventricular fibrillation and need defibrillation and antiarrhythmic drugs as soon as possible.</td></tr><tr><td>4. Suction oropharynx or turn victim's head to one side, unless contraindicated.</td><td>Suction before opening airway minimises risk of aspiration of vomitus.</td></tr><tr><td>5. Open airway</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>a. If no head or neck trauma, use head tilt/chin lift method (see illustration).</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>b. Jaw-thrust manoeuvre (see illustration) can be used by healthcare professionals but is not taught to the general public. Grasp angles of victim's lower jaw and lift with both hands, displacing mandible forwards while tilting head backwards.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>c. If readily available, insert oral airway.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>d. Repeat suctioning procedure if necessary.</td><td>The tongue is the most common cause of airway obstruction in an unconscious patient. Airway obstruction from the tongue is relieved. If necessary, remove foreign body. When head and/or neck trauma is suspected, this manoeuvre opens the airway while maintaining proper head and neck alignment, thus reducing the risk of further damage to the neck.</td></tr><tr><td>6. Breathing</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Assess for breathing. Look and feel for movement of upper abdomen or chest. Listen for air leaving nose or mouth. If breathing absent, proceed straight to compressions.</td><td>Secretions may have previously moved further down the airway.</td></tr><tr><td>7. Cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Place victim on hard surface such as floor, ground or backboard. Victim must be flat. If necessary, logroll victim to flat, supine position using spine precautions. Initiate cardiopulmonary resuscitation in the ratio of 30 compressions followed by 2 breaths, commencing with compressions (as outlined below).</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>a. Assume correct and comfortable position.</td><td>External compression of heart is facilitated. Heart is compressed between sternum and spinal vertebrae, which must be on a hard and firm surface. Ventilation is provided.</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>Nurse may be administering CPR for extended period, particularly in community setting. Correct, comfortable position decreases skeletal muscle fatigue and promotes more effective compressions.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>OXYGENATION 293</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>A. One-person rescue</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Position to face victim, on knees, parallel to victim's sternum.</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>B. Two-person rescue
One person faces victim, kneeling parallel to victim's head. Second person moves to opposite side and faces victim, kneeling parallel to victim's sternum.</p>
<p>b. If available, put on gloves and face shield. | Allows rescuer to quickly move back and forth from victim's mouth to sternum.</p>
<p>Allows one rescuer to maintain breathing while other maintains circulation, without getting in each other's way.</p>
<p>Reduces transmission of microorganisms.  |
|  Critical decision point: It is important to avoid compressing below the lower limit of the sternum which may result in damage to the xiphoid process or internal organs and cause regurgitation of gastric contents.  |   |
|  c. The appropriate site for chest compressions is the lower half of the sternum regardless of infant, child or adult.</p>
<p>Adult
(1) Place hands on the lower half of the sternum. Keep hands parallel to chest and fingers above chest. Interlocking fingers is helpful. Keep fingers off chest wall. Extend arms and lock elbows. Maintain arms straight and shoulders directly over victim's sternum.</p>
<p>Child
(2) Place heel of one hand on the lower half of the sternum (see illustration). Maintain head tilt with other hand, if possible, to maintain patent airway.</p>
<p>Infant
(3) Place two fingers on the lower half of the sternum (see illustration). Maintain head tilt with other hand, if possible, to maintain patent airway.</p>
<p>d. Compress sternum to one third of the depth of the chest and then release pressure, maintaining contact with skin to ensure ongoing proper placement of hands. Do not rock, but transmit weight vertically down. One third of the depth of the chest is approximately:
(1) Adult: greater than 5 cm (see illustration).
(2) Child: approx. 5 cm.
(3) Infant: 4 cm.</p>
<p>e. Maintain proper rate of compression of 100/min regardless of age.</p>
<p>f. Palpate for carotid or femoral pulse with chest compressions. If pulse is not palpable, compressions are not deep enough or hand position is incorrect.</p>
<p>g. Mouth to mouth/mask is used for adults and older children.
Pinch the victim's nose with thumb and index fingers, and place the rescuer's mouth over the slightly open mouth of the victim or use CPR pocket mask. Maintain head tilt/chin lift while administering breaths so air enters lungs and not stomach. Each breath should last approximately 1 second and be of sufficient volume to raise the chest. Allow passive exhalation.</p>
<p>h. Mouth to nose is used for adult victims whose jaw remains clenched, or for infants and small children. Keep victim's head tilted with one hand on forehead. Use other hand to lift jaw and close mouth. Seal operator's lips around the victim's nose and blow. Allow passive exhalation. | Insufficient evidence exists for a specific site for chest compressions</p>
<p>Compression occurs only on sternum and is meant to squeeze the heart between the sternum and spine. Pressure necessary for external compression is created by nurse's upper arm muscle strength and upper body. When compression is released, the heart fills.</p>
<p>Proper number of compressions per minute should be delivered to ensure adequate cardiac output. Compression quality, particularly depth of compressions, deteriorates after a time.</p>
<p>Assessment of pulse validates that adequate stroke volume is achieved with each compression.</p>
<p>Provides adequate ventilation to excrete waste gas and supply adequate blood oxygen levels.  |</p>
<p>FUNDAMENTALS OF NURSING: CLINICAL SKILLS WORKBOOK</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>i. Ambu-bag; adult and child</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>For ambu-bag resuscitation use proper size face mask and apply it under chin, up and over victim's mouth and nose.</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>j. For all forms of ventilation, observe for rise and fall of chest wall with each respiration (see illustration). Listen for air escaping during exhalation, and feel for flow of air. If lungs do not inflate, reposition head and neck and check for visible airway obstruction such as vomitus.</p>
<ol start="8">
<li>Defibrillator
Attach an automatated external defibrillator (AED) as soon as one is available.</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Pads should be placed on bare skin of chest: one pad in anterior position, one pad in lateral position. Ensure good skin contact. This may require shaving chest hair. Adult pads are suitable for children over age 8 years. Paediatric pads should be used for children aged 1â€“8 years. Note that diagrams of appropriate placement are provided on pad packaging.</p>
<p>b. Switch AED on and follow the prompts.</p>
<p>c. Do not touch the victim during delivery of the shock.</p>
<p>d. Safety: avoid wet areas; remove oxygen from patient for delivery of shock. | Airtight seal is formed; as bag is compressed, oxygen enters patient.</p>
<p>Time to defibrillation is the primary factor in patient survival.</p>
<p>Appropriate pad placement ensures effective conduction and delivery of shock.  |
|  Australian Resuscitation Council (ARC) 2010 Guideline 4, Airway; Guideline 5, Breathing; Guideline 6, Compressions; Guideline 7. External automated defibrillation in basic life support; Guideline 8, Cardiopulmonary resuscitation. Melbourne, ARC. Online. Available at <a href="http://www.resus.org.au" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">www.resus.org.au</a> 30 May 2011.  |   |
|  RECORDING AND REPORTING | HOME CARE CONSIDERATIONS  |
|  â€¢ Immediately report arrest, indicating exact location of victim. In hospital setting, follow hospital policy. In community setting, call emergency services.
â€¢ Record in medical record and appropriate code sheet onset of arrest, medication and other treatments given, procedures performed and victim's response. | â€¢ Assess home environment to determine presence of a suitable backboard and patient's room to determine whether there is sufficient room to pull patient to the floor, if necessary, to perform CPR.
â€¢ A mouthpiece for CPR should be kept handy during all home health visits, and family should be advised to obtain mouthpieces when appropriate.
â€¢ If patient is at high risk of cardiopulmonary arrest, family or caregivers should be instructed and certified in CPR.
â€¢ Patient and family should keep emergency numbers taped to the phone. These numbers may include fire department, ambulance, hospital and doctor. Instruct patient and family on whom to call.  |</p>
