<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="pain-management">Pain management<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pain-management" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="overview">Overview<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#overview" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Pain is defined as an â€˜unpleasant sensory and emotional experience associated with actual or potential tissue damage or described in terms of such damageâ€™ (Jarvis, 2008, p 184). It is important that nurses remember that pain is always subjective: an understanding that â€˜painâ€™ is whatever the patient reports is necessary for the provision of appropriate pain management (Jarvis, 2008).</p>
<p>There are many pain assessment tools that nurses can use to measure the level or severity of pain that a patient is experiencing. The numeric rating scale (Jarvis, 2008) and the numerical pain intensity scale (Bryant &amp; Knights, 2011) are examples of tools that quantify the severity of the patientâ€™s pain and can inform an appropriate approach to pain management, such as the WHO pain ladder (Eisenberg &amp; Shifrin, 2011).</p>
<p>Pain management is a core focus of nursing care no matter what specialty is practised. The expectation of effective pain management is a basic human right; however, in both developed and developing countries pain is often poorly controlled (Brennan, Carr, &amp; Cousins, 2007; Kirk, 2011). Studies conducted in the community found that 15â€“25% of adults suffered from chronic pain; further studies found that up to 50% of patients experiencing cancer pain did not receive adequate pain relief, and a further 30% were not prescribed the appropriate pain relief medication (Brennan et al., 2007).</p>
<p>The key to effective pain management is a focused pain assessment. Just as it is necessary to regularly monitor patientsâ€™ vital signs, pain should be considered an important routine assessment; it is commonly referred to as the fifth vital sign in some healthcare facilities. The importance of pain assessment has led to the development of several mnemonics, such as the PQRSTU mnemonic which, when used correctly, can ascertain further in-depth subjective data about the nature and characteristics of the pain that a patient is currently experiencing and ensure continuity in clinical assessment among all nursing staff. A focused pain assessment is a vital component in pain management and the administration of appropriate pain relief medication.</p>
<p>The WHO pain ladder uses a three-tier approach to pain management and medication administration: step 1, mild pain: the use of non-opioid analgesia such as paracetamol or a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory such as ibuprofen; step 2, moderate pain: the use of a â€˜weakâ€™ opioid such as paracetamol with codeine or tramadol with or without non-opioid medications (Tassinari et al., 2011); and step 3, strong pain: the use of â€˜strongâ€™ opioids such as morphine or fentanyl with or without non-opioid medications (Caraceni, 2012; Eisenberg &amp; Shifrin, 2011). The use of pain management guidelines such as the WHO pain ladder provides consistency and effective pain management for patients who are experiencing pain.</p>
<p>The skill presented in this chapter addresses a focused pain assessment (41-1).</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260125-074c68d1.jpeg" alt="img-8.jpeg"></p>
<p>FUNDAMENTALS OF NURSING: CLINICAL SKILLS WORKBOOK</p>
<p>SKILL 41-1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="focused-pain-assessment">Focused pain assessment<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#focused-pain-assessment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="delegation-and-other-considerations">DELEGATION AND OTHER CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delegation-and-other-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Initial pain assessment is the basis for the development of the nursing care plan and therefore should not be delegated by the registered nurse.</p>
<p>Ongoing pain assessment may be delegated to an enrolled nurse who should report any abnormal findings.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Pain assessment tools (e.g. Numerical Rating Scale, Wong-Baker Faces Scale, FLACC tool for children &lt; 7 years)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="steps">STEPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="rationale">RATIONALE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rationale" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Critical decision point: The essential message about pain assessment is simple: 'Ask patients about their pain; accept and respect what they say; intervene to relieve their pain according to their pain management goals; and, once intervention has been implemented, ask them again about their pain to evaluate the intervention. It is a circle of assessment, intervention, and reassessment.' (Pasero and McCaffery, 2011:161).</p>
<ol>
<li>Routinely ask about the presence of pain or discomfort on admission and with all regularly scheduled nursing assessments.</li>
<li>Use a validated pain assessment tool such as the Initial Pain Assessment Tool (Pasero and McCaffery, 2011) or the Brief Pain Inventory (see Figure 41-7) to organise the pain interview. Ensure that the selection of the assessment tool is developmentally and clinically appropriate.</li>
<li>Conduct a pain history assessing each of the key characteristics of pain using the PQRSTU mnemonic.</li>
</ol>
<p>a. Provoking/Palliative factorsâ€”ask: What makes the pain better or worse?</p>
<p>b. Qualityâ€”ask the patient to describe what the pain feels like in their own words.</p>
<p>(1) If the patient has difficulty describing pain, ask about the appropriateness of possible descriptors (e.g. throbbing, shooting, sharp, cramping, aching, tender, pricking, burning).</p>
<p>(2) If necessary, ask: What could you do to me to make me feel the pain you have?</p>
<p>c. Region and radiationâ€”ask: Where is it? Does it radiate? Does it occur anywhere else?</p>
<p>(1) Ask the patient to mark the location on a pain drawing or have them point to the body area that is painful.</p>
<p>(2) If there is more than one site of pain, letters (A, B, C, etc) may be used to distinguish the various sites.</p>
<p>Regular assessment of pain leads to improved acute pain management (Macintyre and others, 2010). Treat pain intensity as the fifth vital sign, as it may also indicate clinical deterioration.</p>
<p>The pain measurement tool chosen should be appropriate to the individual patient: developmental, cognitive, emotional, language and cultural factors should be considered (Macintyre and others, 2010). Age and cognitive impairment may present significant barriers to effective pain assessment.</p>
<p>The gold standard for assessing the existence and intensity of pain is the patient's self-report. Self-reporting of pain should be used whenever possible (Macintyre and others, 2010).</p>
<p>Helpful to determine the cause of pain and inform the management plan. Known triggers can be avoided or additional analgesia given at those times. The patient may also know which medications and doses are helpful and may have found some non-drug methods helpful. If appropriate, these methods should be part of the care plan.</p>
<p>This information is helpful in diagnosing the underlying pain mechanism (e.g. nociceptive or neuropathic) and may have direct implications for the type of pain treatment chosen.</p>
<p>The location(s) and sensory distribution of pain are also helpful in determining the pain mechanism.</p>
<p>PAIN MANAGEMENT 299</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>d. <strong>Severity</strong>â€”have the client rate their pain intensity using a pain rating scale. Ask: How much pain do you have at rest? How much pain do you have with movement/coughing?</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>(1) Pain intensity can be scored for present pain, worst and least pain felt, and comfortâ€“function goals (pain ratings that will not interfere with necessary or desired functioning, such as ambulation or decreased anxiety).</p>
<p>(2) If the patient has more than one pain site, ask them to report the pain intensity for each site and record using the letter system above. | Pain rating scales are used to identify the intensity of pain over time for the purpose of evaluating the effectiveness of interventions to relieve pain.</p>
<p>Scoring should incorporate different components of pain, including the functional capacity of the patient. In the postoperative patient this should include static (rest) and dynamic (e.g. pain on sitting, coughing) pain (Macintyre and others, 2010).  |
|  <strong>Critical decision point: Always assess pain on movement and/or coughing as well as at rest.</strong>  |   |
|  e. <strong>Time of onset, duration and pattern</strong>â€”ask: When did the pain begin? How long does the pain last? Is the pain constant? If not, how often does it occur?</p>
<p>(1) To detect variations and rhythms, ask the patient: Is the pain better or worse at certain times, certain hours of the day or night or certain times of the month?</p>
<p>f. <strong>Clientâ€™s Understanding</strong>â€”ask about the clientâ€™s understanding of the cause of pain. What treatments have they tried to relieve it?</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>
<p>Assess the impact of pain.
a. Determine the impact on physical functioning and recovery. Assessment tools are available such as the Functional Activity Score (FAS).
b. Assess for important psychosocial factors related to pain (e.g. culture, previous pain events, beliefs, mood and ability to cope).
c. Assess for pain interference with daily activities and impact on quality of life.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Conduct a focused physical examination of the relevant body region or systems (e.g. neurological or musculoskeletal exam). | This information has diagnostic importance and may also alert to a new or worsening problem.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>These questions help screen for the presence of breakthrough pain.</p>
<p>Determines the success of other pain interventions.</p>
<p>Information about the impact of pain should inform the pain management plan and trigger referral to specialist advice and treatment if needed.</p>
<p>Assess for potential causes of pain using a structured approach. Uncontrolled or unexpected pain requires a reassessment of the diagnosis and consideration of alternative causes for the pain (e.g. new surgical/medical diagnosis, neuropathic pain) (Macintyre and others, 2010).  |
|  RECORDING AND REPORTING | HOME CARE CONSIDERATIONS  |
|  â€¢ Always accept and record what the patient says about their pain.
â€¢ Record assessment findings in patientâ€™s healthcare record following local hospital policy and protocols.
â€¢ Report any abnormal data following comprehensive assessment to the senior nurse, acute pain service or another appropriate medical officer. | â€¢ Has a discharge pain management plan been created?
â€¢ Has the client received information about the ongoing plan and follow-up arrangements?
â€¢ Do the family or significant others have concerns or need information to help with the plan?  |</p>

<p>CLINICAL SKILL 41-1: Focused pain assessment</p>
<p>DEMONSTRATES: The ability to accurately perform a focused pain assessment</p>
<p>DOMAIN/S (AUS): Professional Practice and Provision and Coordination of Care</p>
<p>DOMAIN/S (NZ): Professional responsibility; management of nursing care; interpersonal relationships</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="acute-care">Acute care<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#acute-care" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="overview">Overview<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#overview" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Perioperative nursing care includes nursing care given before (preoperative), during (intraoperative) and after (postoperative) surgery. It may take place in the hospital, in a surgical centre attached to a hospital, in a freestanding day-surgery centre or in a medical practitioner's surgery. Perioperative nursing is a fast-paced, changing and challenging field in which to work. It is based on the nurse's understanding of several important characteristics, including high-quality, multidisciplinary teamwork; effective and therapeutic communication and collaboration with the patient, the patient's family and the surgical team; effective and efficient patient assessment and intervention in all phases; advocacy for the patient and the patient's family; and understanding of cost containment. The nurse must practise good surgical asepsis, thoroughly document care and emphasise patient safety in all phases. Effective teaching and discharge planning are needed to prevent or minimise complications and ensure quality outcomes. The nursing process provides a basis for perioperative nursing, with the nurse individualising strategies throughout the perioperative period so that the patient has a smooth course from admission into the healthcare system to rehabilitation. Continuity of care is stressed in the perioperative model.</p>
<p>To safely manage the perioperative patient, the nurse must understand normal physiological processes and factors that promote or impede a return to functional health patterns following a surgical procedure. Many factors influence a patient's return to functional health, including effective deep-breathing exercises, lung expansion and incentive spirometry, repositioning and mobilisation, and prevention of deep vein thrombosis through leg exercises.</p>
<p>The psychomotor skills presented in this chapter relate to nursing care associated with caring for the perioperative surgical patient. The skill addressed is demonstrating postoperative exercises (44-1). Patient education is essential to facilitate the patient's understanding of, and therefore participation in, postoperative exercises. In addition, if the nurse is adequately prepared to teach and assist the patient with postoperative exercises, this will promote the patient's participation and thereby facilitate a reduction in postoperative complications, a return to functional health, earlier discharge from the healthcare facility and a return to pre-surgical lifestyle.</p>
<p>ACUTE CARE 303</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="skill-44-1">SKILL 44-1<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#skill-44-1" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="demonstrating-postoperative-exercises">Demonstrating postoperative exercises<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#demonstrating-postoperative-exercises" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="delegation-considerations">DELEGATION CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delegation-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This task requires the problem-solving and knowledge-application skills of a registered nurse. For this reason, delegation of this task to nurse assistants is inappropriate. The registered nurse can teach assistants to encourage patients to practise exercises regularly following instruction.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="equipment">EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Pillow or wrapped towel (optional)</li>
<li>Incentive spirometer</li>
<li>Positive expiratory pressure (PEP) device</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="steps">STEPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Assess patient's risk of postoperative respiratory complications. Review medical history to identify presence of chronic pulmonary conditions (e.g. emphysema, asthma), any condition that affects chest wall movement, history of smoking and presence of reduced haemoglobin.</li>
<li>Assess ability to cough and deep-breathe by having patient take deep breath and observing movement of shoulders and chest wall. Measure chest excursion during deep breath. Ask patient to cough after taking deep breath.</li>
<li>Assess risk for postoperative thrombus formation (see Figure 44-4). Observe for calf pain, redness, warmth, swelling or vein distension.</li>
<li>Explain postoperative exercises to patient, including their importance to recovery and physiological benefits.</li>
<li>Demonstrate exercises.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="a-diaphragmatic-breathing">A. Diaphragmatic breathing<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-diaphragmatic-breathing" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>(1) Help patient into comfortable sitting or standing position. If patient chooses to sit, help to side of bed or to upright position in chair.
(2) Stand or sit facing patient.
(3) Instruct patient to place palms of hands across from each other, down and along lower borders of anterior rib cage. Place tips of third fingers lightly together (see illustration). Demonstrate for patient.
(4) Have patient take slow, deep breaths, inhaling through nose. Tell patient to feel middle fingers separate during inhalation. Demonstrate.
(5) Explain that patient will feel normal downward movement of diaphragm during inspiration. Explain that abdominal organs descend and chest wall expands.
(6) Avoid using chest and shoulders while inhaling and instruct patient in same manner.
(7) Have patient hold slow, deep breath for count of 3 and slowly exhale through mouth. Tell patient middle fingertips will touch as chest wall contracts.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="rationale">RATIONALE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rationale" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>General anaesthesia predisposes patient to respiratory problems because lungs are not fully inflated during surgery; cough reflex is suppressed, so secretions collect within airway passages. After surgery, patient may have reduced lung volume and require greater efforts to cough and deep-breathe; inadequate lung expansion can lead to atelectasis and pneumonia. Patient is at greater risk of developing respiratory complications if other chronic lung conditions are present. Smoking damages ciliary clearance and increases mucus secretion. Reduced haemoglobin level can lead to inadequate oxygenation.</p>
<p>Reveals maximum potential for chest expansion and ability to cough forcefully; serves as baseline to measure ability to perform exercises after surgery.</p>
<p>General anaesthesia and immobilisation results in decreased muscular contraction in lower extremities, which promotes venous stasis.</p>
<p>Information allows patient to attend and can motivate learning. People tend to learn new skills when benefits can be gained.</p>
<p>Upright position facilitates diaphragmatic excursion.</p>
<p>Allows patient to observe breathing exercise.</p>
<p>Position of hands allows patient to feel movement of chest and abdomen as diaphragm descends and lungs expand.</p>
<p>Taking slow, deep breaths prevents panting or hyperventilation. Inhaling through nose warms, humidifies and filters air.</p>
<p>Explanation and demonstration focus on normal ventilatory movement of chest wall. Patient develops understanding of how diaphragmatic breathing feels.</p>
<p>Using auxiliary chest and shoulder muscles increases useless energy expenditure.</p>
<p>Allows for gradual expulsion of all air.</p>
<p>FUNDAMENTALS OF NURSING: CLINICAL SKILLS WORKBOOK</p>

Positive expiratory pressure therapy and â€˜huffâ€™ coughing</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(1) Wash hands.</td><td>Reduces transmission of microorganisms.</td></tr><tr><td>(2) Assemble appropriate PEP device, e.g. blow-bottle.</td><td>Promotes optimal lung expansion and expectoration of secretions.</td></tr><tr><td>(3) Instruct patient to assume semi-Fowlerâ€™s or high-Fowlerâ€™s position.</td><td>Ensures that all breathing is done through the mouth and that the device is used properly.</td></tr><tr><td>(4) Have patient place lips around tubing. Patient should take a full breath and then exhale 2â€“3 times longer than inhalation. Pattern should be repeated for 10â€“20 breaths.</td><td>Promotes lung expansion before coughing.</td></tr><tr><td>(5) Remove device from mouth and have patient take a slow, deep breath and hold for 3 seconds.</td><td>â€˜Huffâ€™ coughing, or forced expiratory technique, promotes bronchial hygiene by increased expectoration of secretions.</td></tr><tr><td>(6) Instruct patient to exhale in quick, short, forced exhalations.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td><strong>D. Controlled coughing</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(1) Explain importance of maintaining upright position.</td><td>Position facilitates diaphragm excursion and enhances thorax expansion.</td></tr><tr><td>(2) Demonstrate coughing. Take two slow, deep breaths, inhaling through nose and exhaling through mouth.</td><td>Deep breaths expand lungs fully so that air moves behind mucus and facilitates effects of coughing.</td></tr><tr><td>(3) Inhale deeply third time and hold breath to count of three. Cough fully for two or three consecutive coughs without inhaling between coughs. (Tell patient to push all air out of lungs.)</td><td>Consecutive coughs help remove mucus more effectively and completely than one forceful cough.</td></tr><tr><td>(4) Caution patient against just clearing throat instead of coughing.</td><td>Clearing throat does not remove mucus from deep in airways.</td></tr><tr><td>(5) If surgical incision will be abdominal or thoracic, teach patient to place one hand over incisional area and other hand on top of first. During breathing and coughing exercises, patient presses gently against incisional area to splint or support it. Pillow over incision is optional (see illustration).</td><td>Surgical incision cuts through muscles, tissues and nerve endings. Deep-breathing and coughing exercises place additional stress on suture line and cause discomfort. Splinting incision with hands provides firm support and reduces incisional pulling. (Some patients prefer to have pillow to place over incision.)</td></tr></tbody></table>

<table><thead><tr><th>STEPS</th><th>RATIONALE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>(6) Patient continues to practise coughing exercises, splinting imaginary incision. Instruct patient to cough 2-3 times every 2 hours while awake.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(7) Instruct patient to examine sputum for consistency, amount and colour changes.</td><td>Value of deep coughing with splinting is stressed to effectively expectorate secretions with minimal discomfort.</td></tr><tr><td>Sputum consistency, amount and colour changes may indicate presence of pulmonary complication, such as pneumonia.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>E. Turning</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(1) Instruct patient to assume supine position to right side of bed if permitted by surgery. Flexed right leg shifts weight for easier turning.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Pulling towards side rail reduces effort needed for turning.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Reduces risk of vascular and pulmonary complications.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>F. Leg exercises</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(1) Have patient assume supine position in bed. Demonstrate leg exercises by performing passive range-of-motion exercises and simultaneously explaining exercise.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(2) Rotate each ankle in complete circle. Instruct patient to draw imaginary circles with big toe. Repeat 5 times.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(3) Alternate dorsiflexion and plantar flexion of both feet. Direct patient to feel calf muscles contract and relax alternately (see illustration). Repeat 5 times.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(4) Have patient alternately raise each leg straight up from bed surface, keeping legs straight. Repeat 5 times.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(5) Have patient continue leg exercises by alternately flexing and extending knees. Repeat 5 times (see illustration).</td><td>Provides normal anatomical position of lower extremities.</td></tr><tr><td>Leg exercises maintain joint mobility and promote venous return to prevent thrombi.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Stretches and contracts gastrocnemius muscles.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Promotes contraction and relaxation of quadriceps muscles.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Contracts muscles of upper legs and maintains knee mobility.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>6. Have patient practise exercises at least every 2 hours while awake. Instruct patient to coordinate turning and leg exercises with diaphragmatic breathing, incentive spirometry and coughing exercises.</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>

<li>Observe patient's ability to perform all exercises independently.</li>
<li>Record exercises demonstrated and patient's ability to perform them independently. | Repetition of sequence reinforces learning. Establishes routine for exercises that develops habit for performance. Sequence of exercises should be leg exercises, turning, breathing, incentive spirometry and coughing.
Ensures that patient has learned correct technique.
Documents patient's education and provides data for instructional follow-up.  |</li>
</ol>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="demonstrating-postoperative-exercises">DEMONSTRATING POSTOPERATIVE EXERCISES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#demonstrating-postoperative-exercises" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<p>DEMONSTRATES: The ability to effectively demonstrate postoperative exercises</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="38612653">National Competencies for the Registered Nurseâ€”Australia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#38612653" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>ANMC
AUSTRALIAN NURSING &amp; MIDWIFERY COUNCIL</p>
<p>4th Edition
January 2006</p>
<p>NATIONAL COMPETENCY STANDARDS FOR THE REGISTERED NURSE</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="introduction">Introduction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#introduction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The Australian Nursing and Midwifery Council Incorporated (ANMC) is a peak national nursing and midwifery organisation established in 1992 with the purpose of developing a national approach to nursing and midwifery regulation. The ANMC works in conjunction with the state and territory nursing and midwifery regulatory authorities (NMRAs) to produce national standards which are an integral component of the regulatory framework to assist nurses and midwives to deliver safe and competent care.</p>
<p>The standards include the national competency standards for registered nurses which were first adopted by the ANMC in the early 1990s. These have been reviewed and revised regularly since then. Other standards developed by the ANMC for implementation by the NMRAs include the competency standards for enrolled nurses, midwives and nurse practitioners, codes of professional conduct and ethics, and a range of position statements and guidelines. The full list of standards, position papers and guidelines produced by the ANMC can be viewed on the website.</p>
<p>In 2004/2005 the ANMC undertook a review of the national competency standards for the registered nurse to ensure that they remain contemporary and congruent with the legislative requirements of the NMRAs. This review, which was undertaken by a team of expert nursing consultants, included extensive consultation with nurses around Australia. The resulting standards, whilst different in some areas from the previous competency standards, remain broad and principle based so that they are sufficiently dynamic for practicing nurses and the NMRAs to use as a benchmark to assess competence to practice in a range of settings.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="what-are-the-standards-used-for">What are the standards used for?<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#what-are-the-standards-used-for" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The national competency standards for the registered nurse are the core competency standards by which your performance is assessed to obtain and retain your license to practice as a registered nurse in Australia.</p>
<p>As a registered nurse, these core competency standards provide you with the framework for assessing your competence, and are used by your state/territory NMRA to assess competence as part of the annual renewal of license process, to assess nurses educated overseas seeking to work in Australia, and to assess nurses returning to work after breaks in service. They are also used to assess nurses involved in professional conduct matters. The NMRAs may also apply the competency standards in order to communicate to consumers the standards that they can expect from nurses.</p>
<p>Universities also use the standards when developing nursing curricula, and to assess student and new graduate performance.</p>
<p>These are YOUR standards â€” developed using the best possible evidence, and using information and feedback provided by nurses in a variety of settings. Included also are the principles of assessment which will assist you in understanding how these standards may be used to assess performance. We believe you will find them easy to understand, and user friendly.</p>
<p>ANMC would like to thank nurses throughout Australia for their willing input to the development of these standards.</p>
<p>FUNDAMENTALS OF NURSING: CLINICAL SKILLS WORKBOOK</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="description-of-the-registered-nurse-on-entry-to-practice">Description of the registered nurse on entry to practice<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#description-of-the-registered-nurse-on-entry-to-practice" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The registered nurse demonstrates competence in the provision of nursing care as specified by the registering authority's licence to practice, educational preparation, relevant legislation, standards and codes, and context of care. The registered nurse practices independently and interdependently assuming accountability and responsibility for their own actions and delegation of care to enrolled nurses and health care workers. Delegation takes into consideration the education and training of enrolled nurses and health care workers and the context of care.</p>
<p>The registered nurse provides evidence-based nursing care to people of all ages and cultural groups, including individuals, families and communities. The role of the registered nurse includes promotion and maintenance of health and prevention of illness for individual/s with physical or mental illness, disabilities and/or rehabilitation needs, as well as alleviation of pain and suffering at the end stage of life.</p>
<p>The registered nurse assesses, plans, implements and evaluates nursing care in collaboration with individual/s and the multidisciplinary health care team so as to achieve goals and health outcomes. The registered nurse recognises that ethnicity, culture, gender, spiritual values, sexuality, age, disability and economic and social factors have an impact on an individual's responses to, and beliefs about, health and illness, and plans and modifies nursing care appropriately. The registered nurse provides care in a range of settings that may include acute, community, residential and extended care settings, homes, educational institutions or other work settings and modifies practice according to the model/s of care delivery.</p>
<p>The registered nurse takes a leadership role in the coordination of nursing and health care within and across different care contexts to facilitate optimal health outcomes. This includes appropriate referral to, and consultation with, other relevant health professionals, service providers, and community and support services.</p>
<p>The registered nurse contributes to quality health care through lifelong learning and professional development of herself/himself and others, research data generation, clinical supervision and development of policy and clinical practice guidelines. The registered nurse develops their professional practice in accordance with the health needs of the population/society and changing patterns of disease and illness.</p>
<p>NATIONAL COMPETENCIES FOR THE REGISTERED NURSEâ€”AUSTRALIA 311</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="domains">Domains<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#domains" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The competencies which make up the ANMC National Competency Standards for the Registered Nurses are organised into domains.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="professional-practice">Professional Practice<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#professional-practice" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>This relates to the professional, legal and ethical responsibilities which require demonstration of a satisfactory knowledge base, accountability for practice, functioning in accordance with legislation affecting nursing and health care, and the protection of individual and group rights.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="critical-thinking-and-analysis">Critical Thinking and Analysis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#critical-thinking-and-analysis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>This relates to self â€“ appraisal, professional development, and the value of evidence and research for practice. Reflecting on practice, feelings and beliefs and the consequences of these for individuals/groups is an important professional benchmark.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="provision-and-coordination-of-care">Provision and Coordination of Care<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#provision-and-coordination-of-care" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>This domain relates to the coordination, organisation and provision of nursing care that includes the assessment of individuals /groups, planning, implementation and evaluation of care.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="collaborative-and-therapeutic-practice">Collaborative and Therapeutic Practice<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#collaborative-and-therapeutic-practice" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>This relates to establishing, sustaining and concluding professional relationships with individuals/groups. This also contains those competencies that relate to the nurse understanding their contribution to the interdisciplinary health care team.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="national-competency-standards-for-the-registered-nurse">National Competency Standards for the Registered Nurse<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#national-competency-standards-for-the-registered-nurse" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="professional-practice">Professional Practice<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#professional-practice" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Relates to the professional, legal and ethical responsibilities which require demonstration of a satisfactory knowledge base, accountability for practice, functioning in accordance with legislation affecting nursing and health care, and the protection of individual and group rights.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="1-practises-in-accordance-with-legislation-affecting-nursing-practice-and-health-care">1. Practises in accordance with legislation affecting nursing practice and health care<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-practises-in-accordance-with-legislation-affecting-nursing-practice-and-health-care" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h5 level="5" id="1-1-practises-in-accordance-with-legislation-affecting-nursing-practice-and-health-care">1.1 Practises in accordance with legislation affecting nursing practice and health care<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-1-practises-in-accordance-with-legislation-affecting-nursing-practice-and-health-care" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h5></div>
<ul>
<li>identifies legislation governing nursing practice</li>
<li>describes nursing practice within the requirements of common law</li>
<li>describes and adheres to legal requirements for medications</li>
<li>identifies legal implications of nursing interventions</li>
<li>actions demonstrate awareness of legal implications of nursing practice</li>
<li>identifies and explains effects of legislation on the care of individuals/groups</li>
<li>identifies and explains effects of legislation in the area of health</li>
<li>identifies unprofessional practice as it relates to confidentiality and privacy legislation</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h5 level="5" id="1-2-fulfils-the-duty-of-care">1.2 Fulfils the duty of care<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-2-fulfils-the-duty-of-care" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h5></div>
<ul>
<li>performs nursing interventions in accordance with recognised standards of practice</li>
<li>clarifies responsibility for aspects of care with other members of the health team</li>
<li>recognises the responsibility to prevent harm</li>
<li>performs nursing interventions following comprehensive and accurate assessments</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h5 level="5" id="1-3-recognises-and-responds-appropriately-to-unsafe-or-unprofessional-practice">1.3 Recognises and responds appropriately to unsafe or unprofessional practice<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-3-recognises-and-responds-appropriately-to-unsafe-or-unprofessional-practice" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h5></div>
<ul>
<li>identifies interventions which prevent care being compromised and/or law contravened</li>
<li>identifies appropriate action to be taken in specified circumstances</li>
<li>identifies and explains alternative strategies for intervention and their likely outcomes</li>
<li>identifies behaviour that is detrimental to achieving optimal care</li>
<li>follows up incidents of unsafe practice to prevent re-occurrence</li>
</ul>
<p>FUNDAMENTALS OF NURSING: CLINICAL SKILLS WORKBOOK</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="national-competency-standards-for-the-registered-nurse-continued">National Competency Standards for the Registered Nurse (continued)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#national-competency-standards-for-the-registered-nurse-continued" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="2-practises-within-a-professional-and-ethical-nursing-framework">2. Practises within a professional and ethical nursing framework<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-practises-within-a-professional-and-ethical-nursing-framework" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="2-1-practises-in-accordance-with-legislation-affecting-nursing-practice-and-health-care">2.1 Practises in accordance with legislation affecting nursing practice and health care<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-1-practises-in-accordance-with-legislation-affecting-nursing-practice-and-health-care" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<ul>
<li>accepts individuals/groups regardless of race, culture, religion, age, gender, sexual preference, physical or mental state</li>
<li>ensures that personal values and attitudes are not imposed on others</li>
<li>conducts assessments that are sensitive to the needs of individuals/groups</li>
<li>recognises and accepts the rights of others</li>
<li>maintains an effective process of care when confronted by differing values, beliefs and biases</li>
<li>seeks assistance to resolve situations involving moral conflict</li>
<li>identifies and attempts to overcome factors which may constrain ethical decisions in consultation with the health care team</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="2-2-integrates-organisational-policies-and-guidelines-with-professional-standards">2.2 Integrates organisational policies and guidelines with professional standards<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-2-integrates-organisational-policies-and-guidelines-with-professional-standards" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<ul>
<li>maintains current knowledge of and incorporates relevant professional standards into practice</li>
<li>maintains current knowledge of and incorporates organisational policies and guidelines into practice</li>
<li>reviews and provides feedback on the relevance of organisational policies and professional standards procedures to practice</li>
<li>demonstrates awareness and understanding of developments in nursing that have an impact on the individual's capacity to practice nursing</li>
<li>considers individual health and wellbeing in relation to being fit for practice</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="2-3-practise-in-a-way-that-acknowledges-the-dignity-culture-values-beliefs-and-rights-of-individuals-groups">2.3 Practise in a way that acknowledges the dignity, culture, values, beliefs and rights of individuals/groups<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-3-practise-in-a-way-that-acknowledges-the-dignity-culture-values-beliefs-and-rights-of-individuals-groups" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<ul>
<li>demonstrates respect for individual/group common and legal rights in relation to health care</li>
<li>identifies and adheres to strategies to promote and protect individual/group rights</li>
<li>considers individual/group preferences when providing care</li>
<li>clarifies individual/group requests to change and/or refuse care with relevant members of the health care team</li>
<li>advocates for individuals/groups when rights are overlooked and/or compromised</li>
<li>accepts individuals/groups to whom care is provided regardless of race, culture, religion, age, gender, sexual preference, physical or mental state</li>
<li>ensures that personal values and attitudes are not imposed on others</li>
<li>undertakes assessments which are sensitive to the needs of individuals/groups</li>
<li>recognises and accepts the rights of others</li>
<li>maintains an effective process of care when confronted by differing values, beliefs and biases</li>
<li>provides appropriate information within the nurse's scope of practice to individuals/groups</li>
<li>consults relevant members of the health care team when required</li>
<li>questions and/or clarifies orders and decisions that are unclear, not understood or questionable</li>
<li>questions and/or clarifies interventions that appear inappropriate with relevant members of the health care team</li>
</ul>
<p>NATIONAL COMPETENCIES FOR THE REGISTERED NURSEâ€”AUSTRALIA
313</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="national-competency-standards-for-the-registered-nurse-continued">National Competency Standards for the Registered Nurse (continued)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#national-competency-standards-for-the-registered-nurse-continued" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>2.4 Advocates for individuals/groups and their rights for nursing and health care within organisational and management structures</p>
<ul>
<li>identifies when resources are insufficient to meet care needs of individuals/groups</li>
<li>communicates skill mix requirements to meet care needs of individuals/groups to management</li>
<li>protects the rights of individuals and groups and facilitates informed decisions</li>
<li>identifies and explains policies/practices which infringe on the rights of individuals or groups</li>
<li>clarifies policies, procedures and guidelines when rights of individuals or groups are compromised</li>
<li>recommends changes to policies, procedures and guidelines when rights are compromised</li>
</ul>
<p>2.5 Understands and practises within own scope of practice</p>
<ul>
<li>seeks clarification when questions, directions and decisions are unclear or not understood</li>
<li>undertakes decisions about care that are within scope of competence without consulting senior staff</li>
<li>raises concerns about inappropriate delegation with the appropriate registered nurse</li>
<li>demonstrates accountability and responsibility for own actions within nursing practice</li>
<li>assesses consequences of various outcomes of decision making</li>
<li>consults relevant members of the health care team when required</li>
<li>questions and/or clarifies interventions which appear inappropriate with relevant members of the health care team</li>
</ul>
<p>2.6 Integrates nursing and health care knowledge, skills and attitudes to provide safe and effective nursing care</p>
<ul>
<li>maintains a current knowledge base</li>
<li>considers ethical responsibilities in all aspects of practice</li>
<li>ensures privacy and confidentiality when providing care</li>
<li>questions and/or clarifies interventions which appear inappropriate with relevant members of the health care team</li>
</ul>
<p>2.7 Recognises the differences in accountability and responsibility between registered nurses, enrolled nurses and unlicensed care workers</p>
<ul>
<li>understands requirements of statutory and professionally regulated practice</li>
<li>understands requirements for delegation and supervision of practice</li>
<li>raises concerns about inappropriate delegation with relevant organisational or regulatory personnel</li>
</ul>
<p>FUNDAMENTALS OF NURSING: CLINICAL SKILLS WORKBOOK</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="national-competency-standards-for-the-registered-nurse-continued">National Competency Standards for the Registered Nurse (continued)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#national-competency-standards-for-the-registered-nurse-continued" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="critical-thinking-and-analysis">Critical Thinking and Analysis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#critical-thinking-and-analysis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Relates to self-appraisal, professional development and the value of evidence and research for practice. Reflecting on practice, feelings and beliefs and the consequences of these for individuals/groups is an important professional benchmark.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="3-practises-within-an-evidence-based-framework">3. Practises within an evidence-based framework<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-practises-within-an-evidence-based-framework" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="3-1-identifies-the-relevance-of-research-to-improving-individual-group-health-outcomes">3.1 Identifies the relevance of research to improving individual/group health outcomes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-1-identifies-the-relevance-of-research-to-improving-individual-group-health-outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>identifies problems/issues in nursing practice which may be investigated through research</li>
<li>considers potential for improvement in reviewing the outcomes of nursing activities and individual/group care</li>
<li>discusses implications of research with colleagues</li>
<li>participates in research</li>
<li>demonstrates awareness of current research in own field of practice</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="3-2-uses-best-available-evidence-nursing-expertise-and-respect-for-the-values-and-beliefs-of-individuals-groups-in-the-provision-of-nursing-care">3.2 Uses best available evidence, nursing expertise and respect for the values and beliefs of individuals/groups in the provision of nursing care<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-2-uses-best-available-evidence-nursing-expertise-and-respect-for-the-values-and-beliefs-of-individuals-groups-in-the-provision-of-nursing-care" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>uses relevant literature and research findings to improve current practice</li>
<li>participates in review of policies, procedures and guidelines based on relevant research</li>
<li>identifies and disseminates relevant changes in practice or new information to colleagues</li>
<li>recognises that judgements and decisions are aspects of nursing care</li>
<li>recognises that nursing expertise varies with education, experience and context of practice</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="3-3-demonstrates-analytical-skills-in-accessing-and-evaluating-health-information-and-research-evidence">3.3 Demonstrates analytical skills in accessing and evaluating health information and research evidence<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-3-demonstrates-analytical-skills-in-accessing-and-evaluating-health-information-and-research-evidence" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>demonstrates understanding of the registered nurse role in contributing to nursing research</li>
<li>undertakes critical analysis of research findings in considering their application to practice</li>
<li>maintains accurate documentation of information which could be used in nursing research</li>
<li>clarifies when resources are not understood or their application is questionable</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="3-4-supports-and-contributes-to-nursing-and-health-care-research">3.4 Supports and contributes to nursing and health care research<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-4-supports-and-contributes-to-nursing-and-health-care-research" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>participates in research</li>
<li>identifies problems suitable for research</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="3-5-participates-in-quality-improvement-activities">3.5 Participates in quality improvement activities<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-5-participates-in-quality-improvement-activities" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>recognises that quality improvement involves ongoing consideration, use and review of practice in relation to practice outcomes, standards and guidelines and new developments</li>
<li>seeks feedback from a wide range of sources to improve the quality of nursing care</li>
<li>participates in case review activities</li>
<li>participates in clinical audits</li>
</ul>
<p>NATIONAL COMPETENCIES FOR THE REGISTERED NURSEâ€”AUSTRALIA 315</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="national-competency-standards-for-the-registered-nurse-continued">National Competency Standards for the Registered Nurse (continued)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#national-competency-standards-for-the-registered-nurse-continued" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="4-participates-in-ongoing-professional-development-of-self-and-others">4. Participates in ongoing professional development of self and others<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-participates-in-ongoing-professional-development-of-self-and-others" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="4-1-uses-best-available-evidence-standards-and-guidelines-to-evaluate-nursing-performance">4.1 Uses best available evidence, standards and guidelines to evaluate nursing performance<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-1-uses-best-available-evidence-standards-and-guidelines-to-evaluate-nursing-performance" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>undertakes regular self-evaluation of own nursing practice</li>
<li>seeks and considers feedback from colleagues about, and critically reflects on, own nursing practice</li>
<li>participates actively in performance review processes</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="4-2-participates-in-professional-development-to-enhance-nursing-practice">4.2 Participates in professional development to enhance nursing practice<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-2-participates-in-professional-development-to-enhance-nursing-practice" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>reflects on own practice to identify professional development needs</li>
<li>seeks additional knowledge and/or information when presented with unfamiliar situations</li>
<li>seeks support from colleagues in identifying learning needs</li>
<li>participates actively in ongoing professional development</li>
<li>maintains records of involvement in professional development which includes both formal and informal activities</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="4-3-contributes-to-the-professional-development-of-others">4.3 Contributes to the professional development of others<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-3-contributes-to-the-professional-development-of-others" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>demonstrates an increasing responsibility to share knowledge with colleagues</li>
<li>supports health care students to meet their learning objectives in cooperation with other members of the health care team</li>
<li>facilitates mutual sharing of knowledge and experience with colleagues relating to individual/ group/unit problems</li>
<li>contributes to orientation and ongoing education programs</li>
<li>acts as a role model to other members of the health care team</li>
<li>participates where possible in preceptorship, coaching and mentoring to assist and develop colleagues</li>
<li>participates where appropriate in teaching others including students of nursing and other health disciplines, and inexperienced nurses</li>
<li>contributes to formal and informal professional development</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="4-4-uses-appropriate-strategies-to-manage-own-responses-to-the-professional-work-environment">4.4 Uses appropriate strategies to manage own responses to the professional work environment<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-4-uses-appropriate-strategies-to-manage-own-responses-to-the-professional-work-environment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>identifies and uses support networks</li>
<li>shares experiences related to professional issues mutually with colleagues</li>
<li>uses reflective practice to identify personal needs and seek appropriate support</li>
</ul>
<p>FUNDAMENTALS OF NURSING: CLINICAL SKILLS WORKBOOK</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="national-competency-standards-for-the-registered-nurse-continued">National Competency Standards for the Registered Nurse (continued)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#national-competency-standards-for-the-registered-nurse-continued" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
